webTitle: 100 feared dead in Taiwan plane crash

fields.headline: 100 feared dead in Taiwan plane crash
fields.standfirst: Over 100 may have died as LA-bound jet aborts takeoff
fields.trailText: Over 100 may have died as LA-bound jet aborts takeoff
fields.body:
A Singapore Airlines 747 jetliner taking off for Los Angeles hit an object on the runway during a storm this evening and burst into flames. At least 47 people were killed, the airline said, and as many as 100 may have perished.

Singapore Airlines spokesman Cheng Jeng-hsien in Taipei said that in addition to those killed, 84 people were injured and 48 were unaccounted for. But in Los Angeles, airline spokesman James Boyd gave different figures, saying 49 people were killed and 69 passengers were injured.

Taiwan premier Chang Chun-hsiung told a news conference that 179 people were on board, including 20 crew.

Three survivors said they felt the plane slam into something on the runway while trying to take off at Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Despite heavy rain, video footage showed parts of the Boeing 747-400 series plane spewing tongues of flame and thick black smoke. Parts of the plane's blue fuselage appeared badly charred, with a gaping hole in the roof of the forward section.

British passenger Steven Courtney was sitting on a hospital bed, oxygen tubes in his nose as he was whisked away to operating room. "The left wing seemed to hit something and then it was just a big roller coast ride," he said. "Flames were everywhere."

"It felt like we bumped into something huge," said Doug Villerman, a Louisiana passenger."It looked like the front end just fell off. From there, it just started to fall apart. I ran to the escape hatch with the stewardess but we couldn't get it open. Two feet away from me, I saw flames.

"Everyone was just panicking," he said. "I tried to open the escape hatch on the top just a slit and saw a lot of smoke. The fumes were just incredible. But eventually we got it open. ... We were just all so scared it was going to blow up."

The aborted takeoff occurred at 11:18 p.m. Ambulances and rescue vehicles arrived a few minutes later. There were initial reports that the plane had struck a China Airlines plane on the runway, but a China Airlines official later said those reports were not accurate.

Local TV showed a frantic scene at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital near the airport, where emergency room workers lifted injured people from ambulances. Some appeared to be burned.

Dr. TL Huang said at least eleven of those admitted to the hospital were foreigners. He said he could not yet provide their nationalities.

Singapore Airlines, the South Asian city-state's flagship carrier, is one of the world's most profitable airlines. It has been flying for 28 years and had never had a crash.

In December 1997 a SilkAir Boeing 737 was cruising over Indonesia when the jet suddenly nosed down, diving at supersonic speeds until it smashed into a river, killing all 104 people aboard. Singapore Airlines is the parent company of SilkAir.

The storm pounding Taiwan, Typhoon Xangsane, had whirled closer to the island's southern coast today and heavy rains have already begun soaking the capital, Taipei. The typhoon has stirred up 90 mph winds and is expected to make landfall by tomorrow if it maintained its current course, the Central Weather Bureau said.

Earlier in the evening, the storm had prompted officials to set up disaster relief centres, cancel some flights and alert air and sea rescue services.

fields.headline: County sponsor jumps ship
fields.trailText: The EWCB now lacks sponsors for three of its most prestigious competitions after PPP Healthcare announced it was abandoning its support of the County Championship.
fields.body:
English cricket's sponsorship shortfall grew to a disturbing £6m yesterday as PPP Healthcare announced that it was abandoning its support of the County Championship.

The departure of PPP left the England and Wales Cricket Board lacking sponsors for three of its most prestigious competitions. John Read, the ECB's director of corporate affairs, expressed the hope yesterday that "several new sponsors will be in place by Christmas". It is to be hoped that the ECB does not wake up to find nothing more exciting than an Austin Powers Action Man and a poster of Stan Collymore.

English cricket is not short of promising signs: the national team is no longer a source for cheap laughs, there are fleeting signs of a revival in schools (things could hardly have got much bleaker), and a report funded by Sport England has confirmed that only football outdoes cricket (by a distance) for popularity.

Nevertheless, PPP's pull-out after two years completes a dire year in which Cornhill Insurance ended its 23-year Test sponsorship and NatWest exchanged the NatWest Trophy - the FA Cup of cricket - for the new triangular one-day international tournament.

A PPP statement said: "Our contract enabled us to review our participation after two years. For commercial reasons, we have decided to withdraw.

"Our decision has nothing to do with dissatisfaction with cricket, the state of the game in this country or the way it is organised by the ECB."

Alongside the £6m sponsorship hole is a further £3m revenue shortfall following a summer of early Test finishes and a triangular series against Zimbabwe and the West Indies which did not exactly light up the imagination.

That has alarmed the Professional Cricketers' Association, which fears that a slimming-down of county squads will not go hand in hand with the salary increases that they had anticipated.

Read countered: "It has been a difficult summer in terms of revenue, but the Test series win against the West Indies attracted phenomenal interest. Sponsors like nothing better than a successful England side and they can see we are striving to deliver. We want the right sponsors and we are involved in detailed discussions, but these commercial decisions take time."

The County Championship is relatively cheap, on offer for about £500,000 a year. The former NatWest Trophy should attract £1.5m, while sponsorship of the Test side is valued at more than £4m a year.

Next month the ECB will launch Howzat!, an educational resource pack, which shows how to involve cricket in the national curriculum. Read called this "the biggest single development initiative since the ECB's inception in 1997".

Howzat! is not at risk from cuts, as it is funded by the Channel 4 television deal. The government has pressed sports to spend 5-10% of their TV deals on grassroots development; cricket is committing 11%, which might explain why Kate Hoey, the sports minister, will attend the launch.

A Mori survey concluded that cricket was the only game over the past five years in which the numbers of those participating regularly had increased.

webTitle: Tears for souvenirs as England flop

fields.headline: Tears for souvenirs as England flop
fields.standfirst:
After flies and dew Hussain's men pass out under gas
Scoreboard
fields.trailText: What with the clouds of tear gas, the bottle throwing and the police lathi charges England might be forgiven a plea of mitigating circumstances for yesterday's heavy defeat which gave Pakistan a 2-1 win in this one-day series.
fields.body:
What with the clouds of tear gas, the bottle throwing and the police lathi charges England might be forgiven a plea of mitigating circumstances for yesterday's heavy defeat which gave Pakistan a 2-1 win in this one-day series.

After the fly invasion, heavy dews and iffy umpiring that had marred the two earlier matches the England captain Nasser Hussain has at least had his hope fulfilled that this tour should represent a "learning curve" for his players. The gradient has been a bit steep, that is all. Cricket is different in these parts.

In truth, however, England were beaten for valid cricketing reasons, betrayed by their hopeless inability to play quality spin on a responsive surface. This series was always going to end in tears, long before police uncorked the tear gas on a disgruntled crowd outside the stadium, the pungent fumes then wafting inside and twice bringing play to a halt.

Pakistan's comfortable victory, by six wickets with 6.3 overs to spare, was always likely once they had won the toss and chosen to bowl. Of the floodlit one-dayers played in this country, only two have been won by the side batting first.

The problems with dew and flies, though less pronounced than in Lahore on Friday, were still considerable for the side taking the field after the interval. For England, already markedly inferior in such conditions, the loss of the toss blew away their one realistic chance.

They should have batted better, though. They were bowled out for 158 and the shots played by Marcus Trescothick, Graeme Hick and Craig White were particularly awful. The worst sin of all was not using the full 50 overs; they lasted 42.5. Saqlain Mushtaq, for the sixth time in his one-day international career, took five wickets and did a lap of honour in his man-of-the-match car.

On a spongy, uneven pitch Pakistan's fast bowlers had already caused problems as Alec Stewart, still out of sorts, edged Abdur Razzaq to Moin Khan for 18. In the following over Hussain was the victim of a disgraceful leg-before-wicket decision by the umpire Meian Aslam after the ball from Wasim Akram pitched four or five inches outside leg stump.

However tempting it is to fear the worst, in the context of history, the biggest problem with umpires in Pakistan is plain incompetence. Later in the innings Andrew Flintoff, before he had scored, was conclusively caught behind but given not out.

At least Hussain's early departure gave Hick the chance to play a more major innings than his 56 in Karachi. He fluffed it. Against Saqlain's first delivery of the match he drove wildly and was bowled through a very wide gate.

In the same over Trescothick, who had once again batted well, hit Mushtaq Ahmed for three fours in as many balls, then spoilt it when he hit across the line and was bowled. That was 64 for four.

When Shahid Afridi came on for the 23rd over he had Flintoff caught at slip with his third delivery, a leg-spinner's classic dismissal. Then White slogged a full toss to deep backward square and it was 86 for six. It did not get any better.

Mark Ealham, dropped on eight, soon became Razzaq's 100th wicket in this cricket, and the innings ended in farce with Andrew Caddick and Graham Thorpe, who had been salvaging matters, caught at the same end of the pitch; Thorpe was run out.

Caddick took two wickets in two balls at the start of the Pakistan innings and, if Hick had taken the sharp slip chance offered by Salim Elahi with the score on 20, it might have got interesting.

In farcical fashion England also missed the chance to run out Inzamam-ul-Haq as he led Pakistan home with a bludgeoning unbeaten 60. If a stranded Inzy cannot be run out, there is little hope.

fields.headline: 'You don't get this at Chelmsford'
fields.trailText: As if defeat was not enough, England's cricketers had to suffer the indignity of being hit by tear gas and plastic bottles as they went down by six wickets.
fields.body:
England's cricketers were hit by tear gas and plastic bottles as they went down to Pakistan by six wickets in yesterday's one-day series decider, writes Paul Weaver .

Marcus Trescothick, one of the players most affected by the tear gas when it first appeared with England 33 for no wicket, said: "It was very difficult. My eyes were streaming and my throat was choking. I knew something was wrong because I saw everybody else hit the deck but, until somebody had explained what happened, I had no idea.

"I had to cover my eyes and my mouth. It was worrying because you wonder why they are doing it. You know something has gone wrong outside. It was another learning experience."

Police outside the ground twice used tear gas when large crowds, unable to get into the 15,000-seat stadium, refused to disperse. As well as tear gas the police repeatedly charged the crowd wielding lathis, or wooden sticks.

When England fielded, Andrew Flintoff was struck by empty plastic bottles and the captain Nasser Hussain was seen to remonstrate with the umpires.

Hussain said afterwards: "When the tear gas first hit the players it was bad. It got in their eyes and in their noses. These things happen in this part of the world. It's all part of the learning experience. There are a few things the match referee can look at in the context of future tours.

However, Hussain maintained that the hostile atmosphere was all part of touring the sub-continent. "We knew it would be difficult. This is how their cricket is played. It's full of chaos. It must make it great to watch because there's never a dull moment. But it can be difficult to play. You don't get those sort of things at Chelmsford.

"Freddie [Flintoff] came to me and said he had been hit by a couple of empty bottles. I said, 'Get on with it, you big tart.' Then, as he went for a catch he got hit again, so I told the umpires. These things happen in this part of the world, they get a bit bored when they see their side strolling it and throw a couple of bottles. It wasn't a big deal." Pakistan's captain Moin Khan said: "The tear gas was bad because you can't see it coming. But I've never experienced it before in Pakistan."

Hussain added: "It was very similar to the other day. We weren't good enough with the bat and were about 71 short. The wicket spun and they've got great spin bowlers.

"We were going at a decent rate and we just had to bat out the overs and get 200," he concluded. "That would have put us in the game. You can't get bowled out for less than your full overs. It's a basic rule."

webTitle: Colleges are failing NUS on governing body appointments

fields.headline: Students go by the board
fields.standfirst: Colleges are failing NUS on governing body appointments
fields.trailText: Colleges are failing NUS on governing body appointments
fields.body:
Almost one in 10 further education colleges are flouting government regulations by not having elected student governors on their governing boards, a survey by student leaders has revealed.

The National Union of Students is mounting a naming and shaming campaign against colleges still falling foul of government rules that came into force in August 1999 as part of efforts to clean up the reputation of college managers. The union is now calling for at least two student representatives to be appointed to boards in the future.

The results of the survey come to light ahead of a national NUS conference this week preparing student governors for the government reforms being ushered in for colleges next April.

The governing boards of colleges face a steep learning curve over the coming year. There are new funding arrangements under the National Learning and Skills Council and its 47 local councils, and a more intrusive inspection regime to be overseen by the Office for Standards in Education. There is also a new, broader A-level curriculum for sixth-formers introduced by the government this academic year.

Yet the survey has revealed that, as colleges gear up for the reforms, many are still failing to meet basic requirements for their governing boards to include elected students as members.

Preliminary findings from five regions of the national survey (covering East Anglia, East Midlands, London, North-east and North-west) show that 14 of the 152 colleges have no elected student governors.

"We want the Department for Education and Employment to use their powers to clamp down on the colleges, which year after year fail to comply to the mandatory requirements that students should sit on governing boards," said Mark Atkinson, NUS vice president further education union development.

Those named by the NUS include Hull, Middlesbrough, Darlington and South East Essex colleges. When asked, some colleges said they did have students on their governing boards. But the NUS says these are unelected and therefore illegitimate appointments.

Other colleges said that they were in the process of electing student governors, but were unsure of how they would do this or by when. One college told the NUS that an election would not be held until January, which the union believes is far too late in the academic year for the student to become an effective governor.

The move to tighten up the regulations for governing bodies came after a series of highly publicised financial scandals which hit the college sector. A number of government inspection reports revealed serious financial mismanagement in colleges around the country. In one case, a weak governing board was blamed for leaving unchecked the shady activities of a powerful and unscrupulous principal.

At the NUS student governor convention this week, Stephen Grix, Ofsted's chief inspector for 16-19 education, will introduce governors to the new inspection arrangements. Inspectors in future will visit colleges, rather than validating self-assessment by the colleges themselves.

Atkinson says that another problem inspectors are likely to encounter is that students are often excluded from discussions on governing boards.

The NUS student governor convention is being held on 3-5 November at the Conference and Training Centre, Yarnfield Park, Stone, Staffordshire.

Yet the survey has revealed that, as colleges gear up for the reforms, many are still failing to meet basic requirements for their governing boards to include elected students as members. Preliminary findings from five regions of the national survey (covering East Anglia, East Midlands, London, North-east and North-west) show that 14 of the 152 colleges have no elected student governors. "We want the Department for Education and Employment to use their powers to clamp down on the colleges, which year after year fail to comply to the mandatory requirements that students should sit on governing boards," said Mark Atkinson, NUS vice president further education union development. Those named by the NUS include Hull, Middlesbrough, Darlington and South East Essex colleges. When asked, some colleges said they did have students on their governing boards. But the NUS says these are unelected and therefore illegitimate appointments. Other colleges said that they were in the process of electing student governors, but were unsure of how they would do this or by when. One college told the NUS that an election would not be held until January, which the union believes is far too late in the academic year for the student to become an effective governor. The move to tighten up the regulations for governing bodies came after a series of highly publicised financial scandals which hit the college sector. A number of government inspection reports revealed serious financial mismanagement in colleges around the country. In one case, a weak governing board was blamed for leaving unchecked the shady activities of a powerful and unscrupulous principal. At the NUS student governor convention this week, Stephen Grix, Ofsted's chief inspector for 16-19 education, will introduce governors to the new inspection arrangements. Inspectors in future will visit colleges, rather than validating self-assessment by the colleges themselves. Atkinson says that another problem inspectors are likely to encounter is that students are often excluded from discussions on governing boards. The NUS student governor convention is being held on 3-5 November at the Conference and Training Centre, Yarnfield Park, Stone, Staffordshire.

fields.headline: Passenger plane crashes in Taiwan
fields.trailText: A Singapore Airlines jetliner bound for Los Angeles crashed today in Taipei, the capital of Taiwan. There were 179 people on board, and although an airline spokesman in LA initially said that there were no fatalities, the airline later said that more than 70 people were still unaccounted for. It said that more than 20 people had been taken to hospital.
fields.body:
A Singapore Airlines jetliner bound for Los Angeles crashed today in Taipei, the capital of Taiwan. There were 179 people on board, and although an airline spokesman in LA initially said that there were no fatalities, the airline later said that more than 70 people were still unaccounted for. It said that more than 20 people had been taken to hospital.

Strong winds seemed to have forced Flight SQ006 back down, where it collided with a China Airlines aircraft on the tarmac at Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, emergency officer Wu Bi-chang said.

But in a conflicting report, Taiwan's transport minister claimed no other aircraft were involved, Sky News reported.

The plane's blue fuselage appeared badly burned, with a gaping hole in the roof. John Diaz, a passenger on the flight, said flames "shot up right next to me as the plane tried to take off."

He told CNN: "When I got the airport conditions were so bad, and I asked them, 'Is the flight going to take off?' And they said, 'We do this all the time, it's fine."'

Speculation on the cause has focused on strong winds which seemed to have forced the plane down. A typhoon was expected to hit the island early tomorrow morning and heavy rains have already begun lashing Taipei.

The plane crashed around 11.18pm local time. Rescue workers were being dispatched to the scene at Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek international airport. Of the 179 people on board, 159 were passengers and 20 crew.

There are reports that the Boeing 747-400 plummeted to the ground during a storm phenomenon described as a "wind shear".

Eric Moddy, a former pilot, told Sky News: "Maybe the wind was not coming from a constant direction. Sometimes the currents change from being headwind to tail wind. The wind may have pushed it down back towards the ground."

The crash comes a year to the day after EgyptAir Flight 990 plunged into the Atlantic ocean while en route from New York to Cairo, killing 217 people.

fields.headline: A study in victory
fields.standfirst: After years of sanctions, it was Serbia's passionate student movement that finally sparked the downfall of Milosevic's feared and repressive regime, says  Helena Smith
fields.trailText: After years of sanctions, it was Serbia's passionate student movement that finally sparked the downfall of Milosevic's feared and repressive regime, says Helena Smith
fields.body:
The shambolic, ignominious fall of Slobodan Milosevic, for 13 years the most powerful figure in Yugoslavia, proves again that student power - the irreverence of youth - is the one enduring factor no leader should ever take for granted.

Milosevic appeared immovable until Generation X, Serbs as young as 16 who had only ever known war, decided to dislodge him, according to Balkan specialists.

The rottenness of the regime may have enabled it to collapse bloodlessly and in record time (three hours, witnesses say). But it was the birth and dedication of the student movement known as Otpor ("Resistance") which ultimately brought much-needed momentum to a process that Serbia's disillusioned democrats had otherwise given up on.

Amidst all the mirth and mystery still shrouding the precise chain of events that lead to Milosevic's calamitous defeat, there is one thing of which historians are in no doubt: the tyrant's ouster owes as much to the irrepressible optimism of Otpor as it does to the millions of dollars invested in the opposition by the west. Eventually, Serbia's youth - wide-eyed teenagers, university attendees and graduates - did what 10 years of economic sanctions, isolation and Nato bombs failed to do.

"In Serbia we have seen students yet again replace the workers," says Robert Rotberg, director of the Kennedy School's programme on intra-state conflict at Harvard University. "It happened in Hungary in 56, Iran in 79, China in 1989 and then Prague. Workers have more at stake. Students don't have jobs, families, children, and at the barricades they're not so easily coerced. They're fed on the rhetoric of change and they can galvanise people around them."

From the start Otpor was a non-violent movement. But it had an ingenuous, grassroots strategy that it followed from the outset; one that allowed the group to build the biggest possible anti-Milosevic coalition. Its ranks ultimately included members of Serbia's Orthodox church and other once-prominent nationalists.

By artfully blending street protests with plain silly happenings, the movement managed to channel anger into the countryside, where ordinary Serbs, manipulated by Milosevic's propaganda machine, had no idea how to vent their frustration.

"We made a few very simple calculations," explains Vuk Jeremic, Otpor's international representative who "spread the message" from his Tower Hill home in London.

"Our polls showed that 40% of the population was so disillusioned, after 13 years of war, poverty and the Nato bombing, it did not even want to vote. When we found out that at least 65% of that number was between 18 and 25 we realised we had found our target audience."

The hope, he said, was to get at least 70% of the population to vote "because you can steal 150,000 votes, but it's practically impossible to steal a million".

With the clenched-fist as their symbol, the activists had two slogans - Vremeje ("It's Time") and Gotov Je ("He's Finished"); three weapons - badges, stickers and posters; and one mission - to give people the courage to believe that every ballot would count in the battle to remove a regime that relied on fear. But campaigning was far from easy. "After the Nato bombing, telling Serbs to emulate western democracies was like putting a red rag to a bull," says Jeremic.

Recognising Otpor's burgeoning popularity, however, western organisations began injecting much-needed cash into the movement.

Last April, Harvard's Kokkalis program on south-eastern Europe at the Kennedy school invited Jeremic and other Serb opposition leaders to flesh out their policies at a now historic conference. "There was a lot of arguing, but there were US state department officals there who said, 'If you want to campaign, this is what you should do'." The advice was to prove invaluable.

Otpor was originally conceived to resist the draconian 1997 university law purging higher education establishments of opposition voices. From its birth, it operated as an amorphous group that eschewed leadership as much as it avoided politics (other than the cause of democracy) in a deliberate bid to both elude detection and keep squeaky clean.

More than anything, historians say, it was the movement's incorruptible, innocent image that helped transform it into a truly national force. By election day, Otpor had opened 140 branches across the pariah state, its clenched fist and optimistic tone infiltrating every village and hamlet.

"Otpor was much less institutionalised than any of the opposition parties," says Slobodan Homen, one of the movement's original founders. "But it was very organised and disciplined and could adapt much more easily to any situation. Being flexible enabled us to mobilise a huge number of people who were disappointed in the opposition and saw through the lies of the regime."

A lot of that initial support came from the families of Otpor members, now believed to exceed some 50,000. The sight of youngsters being beaten, or arbitrarily arrested, was more than many Serbs could take. As the repression grew so too did the resistance of exiled Serb students, who also joined the movement.

"We had some 2,500 arrests on record and whenever members were hauled into the police station it was mothers who went and begged for their release," says Jeremic. "Entire families soon joined the cause, often under the influence of their children."

Do Homen or Jeremic, whose parents fled to England with the rise of Milosevic in 1990, envisage becoming involved in the new Serbia's political scene? There are not a few who believe that Otpor activists could soon be forming the country's new political elite.

"I'm sure a lot of us will want to go into politics once we have finished studies that have been disrupted for so long," says Homen, 28. For the moment, however, Otpor is keen to just act as a watchdog "to see that reform is done". "We're not going to go away," says Jeremic. "We're going to watch from below."

As true revolutionaries who work from the bottom, Serbia's militant youth are clearly going to be the new conscience of their new country.

Can you help?

Precisely because Serbian students were the target of so much of the ancien regime's venom, Yugoslavia's new politicians are now prioritising educational reform. In deference to Otpor's revolutionary role, the Democrats have moved fast to purge the country's five state-run universities - institutions that often suffered at the behest of Slobodan Milosevic's powerful, pseudo-academic sociologist wife Mira Markovic. Tenured professors, deans and departmental heads, ousted by government-approved replacements when the regime passed laws stripping universities of their autonomy in 1998, are being reinstated.

Professor Maria Bogdanovic, the eminent philosopher, is back as chancellor of Belgrade University. Other faculty members who had joined her in setting up an alternative university - run for two years as an underground establishment - are returning. In several departments classes have begun. "One of our main aims is to get exiled students to return," says Harvard-based Ana Trbovic, who heads the organisation of Serbian students abroad.

Academic erosion began in 1992, when the international community slapped economic sanctions on Serbia. Most of the institutions, including Belgrade University, once seen as the best in Eastern Europe after Moscow, now lack basic equipment.

Otpor hopes that the new government will make up for the losses by re-channelling Milosevic's ludicrous expenditure on the police and military into education. "We're in this strange wait-and-see time with a lot of reforms being put on hold until [parliamentary] elections this December," says Jeremic. "We are appealing to academics everywhere to come and help."

If you want to help, contact Otpor founder Slobodan Homen at slobodanhomen@hotmail.com or call the human rights group Civic Alliance of Serbia: 003811 3341696

 Helena Smith is currently a Nieman fellow at Harvard University

fields.headline: Warne's Pura Cup agony
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Shane Warne doesn't play for Victoria very often these days. He may well be ruing his participation in the match against arch-rivals New South Wales in Melbourne after breaking his spinning finger and seeing his side lose heavily. Warne was fielding at first slip when he appeared to juggle a simple chance from Mark Waugh - the ball hit the end of his finger, breaking the first joint, and he required surgery to insert two metal plates. Australia's leading wicket-taker will now miss at least the first three Tests of the forthcoming series against West Indies. The entire first day was lost to rain, and after a delayed start on the second morning some creative captaincy was needed to ensure a result. New South Wales reached 250 in their first innings, with Waugh making 53 before being induced to balloon that catch to Warne off the bowling of Colin Miller, and Shane Lee also making 53. Victoria captain Paul Reiffel declared his side's first innings closed at 194-6 with Brad Hodge unbeaten on 85, and Steve Waugh reciprocated by declaring the New South Wales second innings at 210-6, after an entertaining late cameo from Don Nash, who made 46 off just 23 balls. Chasing 267 to win and missing the injured Warne, Victoria collapsed to 149 all out in the face of Brett Lee (5-42) and Stuart MacGill (3-50) who may well be expecting a call-up to the Australian squad.

New South Wales 250 and 210-6 dec
Victoria* 194-6 dec and 149
New South Wales won by 117 runs
New South Wales 6pts, Victoria 0pts

The one-day Mercantile Mutual Cup game between the same two sides at the Richmond Cricket Ground in Melbourne was a tense, low-scoring affair in which Victoria scraped home by two wickets. On a day when ball dominated bat, the star-studded New South Wales side managed only 129 after being put in, the only partnership of note being 49 from the Waugh brothers for the third wicket. Victoria then made life difficult for themselves by collapsing to 60-5 before a steadying partnership between youngsters Michael Klinger (19) and Ben Oliver (29). There looked to be another twist to the game as Brett Lee (3-41) launched a late onslaught, but experienced wicketkeeper Darren Berry (14*) managed to push Victoria over the line.

New South Wales 129 (42 overs)
Victoria* 130-8 (41.5 overs)
Victoria won by 2 wickets

South Australia managed to hold on for an unlikely draw against Western Australia in their first Pura Cup game of the season, at the Adelaide Oval. After winning the toss and electing to bat Western Australia amassed 480-8 declared, the highlights being a patient 122 from Damien Martyn and a characteristically explosive 102 from Adam Gilchrist off 99 balls, including 12 fours and two sixes. In reply South Australia managed 282, with a surprising contribution of 51 from fast bowler Jason Gillespie, batting at the unaccustomed position of No5. South Australia were asked to follow on and looked in some trouble before Jeff Vaughan, who had made a duck in the first innings, gritted his teeth and held on for six-and-a-half hours to make an unbeaten 131, his third first-class century, as the game ended in a draw.

Western Australia* 480-4 dec
South Australia 282 and 358-5
Match drawn
Western Australia 2pts, South Australia 0pts

Not even a dazzling career-best 233 from Ricky Ponting could set up a win for Tasmania against Queensland in an extraordinary match in Brisbane. After the Tasmania captain Jamie Cox had won the toss and elected to bat, Ponting put on a superb display. He struck 37 fours and four sixes, and shared in century partnerships with all-rounder Dan Marsh (61), the son of ex-Australian wicketkeeper Rodney Marsh, and Sean Young (22). Tasmania looked to be in the driving seat as they dismissed Queensland for 289 and then, with time running out, declared their second innings at 258-7. Ponting (61) and Marsh (58*) again proved their main contributors. Set a daunting 373 to win Queensland never looked in the hunt at 59-3, but a fourth-wicket partnership of 261 between Martin Love (161*) and the hard-hitting Andrew Symonds (133) set up an unlikely victory with just one over to spare.

Tasmania* 403 and 258-7 dec
Queensland 289 and 373-6
Queensland won by 4 wickets
Queensland 6pts, Tasmania 0pts

South Africa

Defending Supersport Series champions Gauteng (also known this season as the Highveld Strikers due to a sponsorship deal) defeated North West by 121 runs at Pootchefstroom, despite an excellent all-round performance from North West's West Indian star, Mark Lavine. Lavine destroyed Gauteng's top and middle order with 6-55 in their first innings, and then proceeded to follow it up with 85, including ten fours and three sixes, in North West's first innings. It was a lonely vigil though; Gauteng stepped up a gear in their second innings and made 322, with opening batsman Sven Koenig contributing 80. Koenig became the unlikely hero with the gloves in North West's second innings after regular keeper Nic Pothas had withdrawn with badly bruised fingers. He took three catches, including one to dismiss the dangerous Lavine, and seamer David Terbrugge picked up 5-39 to dismiss North West well short of their target.

Gauteng 224 and 322
North West 277 and 148
Gauteng won by 121 runs
Gauteng 16pts, North West 7pts

A well-crafted, chanceless 128 from captain Hylton Ackerman set up a win for Western Province in their game against Eastern Province at Port Elizabeth. Put in to bat, Western Province scored 362 before dismissing Eastern Province for 282, Dave Callaghan (129) scoring almost half the runs. Western Province then declared their second innings closed at 212-8, leaving Eastern Province to chase 293, but man of the match Claude Henderson, a left-arm spinner, took 5-40 as Eastern Province managed only 165.

Western Province 362 and 212-8 dec
Eastern Province* 282 and 165
Western Province won by 127 runs
Western Province 18pts, Eastern Province 7pts

Easterns started their campaign with a big win over Kwa-Zulu Natal at Benoni, despite a defiant 104 from Kwa-Zulu Natal No9 Golam Bodi. The diminutive Bodi, an Indian-born slow left arm bowler, scored his maiden first-class century (easily beating his previous best score of 33) in entertaining fashion, thrashing eleven fours and six sixes, but it was to no avail as Kwa-Zulu Natal went down by 108 runs. Kwa-Zulu Natal had won the toss and asked Easterns to bat, restricting them to 245 as medium-pacer John Kent took a career-best 6-77. Kwa-Zulu Natal found themselves equally restricted, struggling to 123 against the bowling of West Indian quickie Kenny Benjamin (3-23) and left-arm medium-pacer Gareth Flusk (3-31). They were helped by an excellent performance by wicketkeeper Dylan Jennings, who took six catches. When Easterns declared their second innings at 284-8 KZN were set 407 to win, but never looked in contention despite Bodi's last-minute knock. They were blown away by the pace bowling of Benjamin (4-79) and Andre Nel (5-64).

Easterns 245 and 284-8 dec
Kwa-Zulu Natal* 123 and 298
Easterns won by 108 runs
Easterns 16pts, Kwa-Zulu Natal 4pts

Some fine bowling from seamer Charl Langeveldt (5-19 and 1-49) and medium pacer Brad Player (3-11 and 5-26) ensured a win for Boland over Free State at Paarl. After asking the visitors to bat Boland blew them away for 102 in their first innings and restricted them to 249 in the second. Boland made 330 in their first innings, mainly thanks to Pieter Barnard (120) and James Henderson (76), and then openers Henderson and James Trott knocked off the 22 runs required in their second innings without loss.

Free State 102 and 249
Boland* 330 and 23-0
Boland won by 10 wickets
Boland 18pts, Free State 2pts

Pakistan

Lahore registered a ten-wicket win over Karachi Blues in their Quaid-e-Azam Trophy Grade I match at the LCA ground in Lahore, thanks to a sparkling 174 from wicketkeeper-batsman Kamran Akmal. He hit 28 fours and one six in his innings, sharing partnerships of 109 for the sixth wicket with Tariq Mahmood (46) and 129 for the seventh with Naeem Ashraf (28), as Lahore reached 428. Earlier they had dismissed Karachi Blues for 259 after asking them to bat; Afsar Nawaz was the mainstay of the Karachi innings with 114. When Karachi managed only 192 in their second innings Lahore were left with a target of 24, which openers Ali Hussain and Maqsood Rana polished off in 3.3 overs.

Karachi Blues 259 and 192
Lahore 428 and 26-0
Lahore won by 10 wickets

In a high-scoring match in Karachi, the home side drew with Bahawalpur after neither team seemed able to bowl the other out quickly enough for a positive result. Karachi racked up 485-8 declared in their first innings, with Mohammad Masroor (97), Hasan Raza (81), Asif Mujtaba (81) and one-time Pakistan wicketkeeper Atiq-uz-Zaman (62) all making major contributions. Bahawalpur replied with 367 (Shadab Kabir 84, Usman Tariq 62), and Karachi had reached 267-4 in their second innings (Shadab Kabir 116, Zeeshan Pervez 96) when time ran out.

Karachi 485-8 dec and 267-4
Bahawalpur 367
Match drawn

Elsewhere in the Quaid-e-Azam Trophy Grade I it was a case of ball dominating bat, with low-scoring games producing wins for Peshawar over Faisalabad, Sheikhupura over Gujrunwala, Rawalpindi over Sargodha, and Lahore Blues over Islamabad.

Peshawar 174 and 177 (Shahid Nazir 6-58)
Faisalabad* 73 (Nauman Habib 5-11) and 170
Peshawar won by 108 runs

Sheikhupura 146 (Qaisar Abbas 67, Sarfraz Ahmed 5-43) and 194 (Zahid Javed 59, Mubashir Nazir 6-56)
Gujrunwala* 198 (Naved-ul-Hasan 6-80) and 145-6 (Majid Saeed 94*)
Gujrunwala won by 4 wickets

Sargodha 106 and 219 (Misbah-ul-Haq 73)
Rawalpindi* 383-9 dec (Pervez Aziz 154, Naeen Akhtar 64)
Rawalpindi won by an innings and 58 runs

Lahore Blues 199 (Stephen John 5-82) and 357-9 dec (Imran Farhat 77, Mohammed Hussain 65, Stephen John 5-128)
Islamabad* 209 (Husnain Kazim 6-58) and 180 (Asif Ali 63)
Lahore Blues won by 167 runs

Catherine Hanley is an Australian who supports Somerset but lives and works in Sheffield. To read last week's Global Scorebox, on how the Red Stripe Bowl was won, click here.

He may well be ruing his participation in the match against arch-rivals New South Wales in Melbourne after breaking his spinning finger and seeing his side lose heavily. Warne was fielding at first slip when he appeared to juggle a simple chance from Mark Waugh - the ball hit the end of his finger, breaking the first joint, and he required surgery to insert two metal plates. Australia's leading wicket-taker will now miss at least the first three Tests of the forthcoming series against West Indies. The entire first day was lost to rain, and after a delayed start on the second morning some creative captaincy was needed to ensure a result. New South Wales reached 250 in their first innings, with Waugh making 53 before being induced to balloon that catch to Warne off the bowling of Colin Miller, and Shane Lee also making 53. Victoria captain Paul Reiffel declared his side's first innings closed at 194-6 with Brad Hodge unbeaten on 85, and Steve Waugh reciprocated by declaring the New South Wales second innings at 210-6, after an entertaining late cameo from Don Nash, who made 46 off just 23 balls. Chasing 267 to win and missing the injured Warne, Victoria collapsed to 149 all out in the face of Brett Lee (5-42) and Stuart MacGill (3-50) who may well be expecting a call-up to the Australian squad. New South Wales 250 and 210-6 dec Victoria* 194-6 dec and 149 New South Wales won by 117 runs New South Wales 6pts, Victoria 0pts The one-day Mercantile Mutual Cup game between the same two sides at the Richmond Cricket Ground in Melbourne was a tense, low-scoring affair in which Victoria scraped home by two wickets. On a day when ball dominated bat, the star-studded New South Wales side managed only 129 after being put in, the only partnership of note being 49 from the Waugh brothers for the third wicket. Victoria then made life difficult for themselves by collapsing to 60-5 before a steadying partnership between youngsters Michael Klinger (19) and Ben Oliver (29). There looked to be another twist to the game as Brett Lee (3-41) launched a late onslaught, but experienced wicketkeeper Darren Berry (14*) managed to push Victoria over the line. New South Wales 129 (42 overs) Victoria* 130-8 (41.5 overs) Victoria won by 2 wickets South Australia managed to hold on for an unlikely draw against Western Australia in their first Pura Cup game of the season, at the Adelaide Oval. After winning the toss and electing to bat Western Australia amassed 480-8 declared, the highlights being a patient 122 from Damien Martyn and a characteristically explosive 102 from Adam Gilchrist off 99 balls, including 12 fours and two sixes. In reply South Australia managed 282, with a surprising contribution of 51 from fast bowler Jason Gillespie, batting at the unaccustomed position of No5. South Australia were asked to follow on and looked in some trouble before Jeff Vaughan, who had made a duck in the first innings, gritted his teeth and held on for six-and-a-half hours to make an unbeaten 131, his third first-class century, as the game ended in a draw. Western Australia* 480-4 dec South Australia 282 and 358-5 Match drawn Western Australia 2pts, South Australia 0pts Not even a dazzling career-best 233 from Ricky Ponting could set up a win for Tasmania against Queensland in an extraordinary match in Brisbane. After the Tasmania captain Jamie Cox had won the toss and elected to bat, Ponting put on a superb display. He struck 37 fours and four sixes, and shared in century partnerships with all-rounder Dan Marsh (61), the son of ex-Australian wicketkeeper Rodney Marsh, and Sean Young (22). Tasmania looked to be in the driving seat as they dismissed Queensland for 289 and then, with time running out, declared their second innings at 258-7. Ponting (61) and Marsh (58*) again proved their main contributors. Set a daunting 373 to win Queensland never looked in the hunt at 59-3, but a fourth-wicket partnership of 261 between Martin Love (161*) and the hard-hitting Andrew Symonds (133) set up an unlikely victory with just one over to spare. Tasmania* 403 and 258-7 dec Queensland 289 and 373-6 Queensland won by 4 wickets Queensland 6pts, Tasmania 0pts South Africa Defending Supersport Series champions Gauteng (also known this season as the Highveld Strikers due to a sponsorship deal) defeated North West by 121 runs at Pootchefstroom, despite an excellent all-round performance from North West's West Indian star, Mark Lavine. Lavine destroyed Gauteng's top and middle order with 6-55 in their first innings, and then proceeded to follow it up with 85, including ten fours and three sixes, in North West's first innings. It was a lonely vigil though; Gauteng stepped up a gear in their second innings and made 322, with opening batsman Sven Koenig contributing 80. Koenig became the unlikely hero with the gloves in North West's second innings after regular keeper Nic Pothas had withdrawn with badly bruised fingers. He took three catches, including one to dismiss the dangerous Lavine, and seamer David Terbrugge picked up 5-39 to dismiss North West well short of their target. Gauteng 224 and 322 North West 277 and 148 Gauteng won by 121 runs Gauteng 16pts, North West 7pts A well-crafted, chanceless 128 from captain Hylton Ackerman set up a win for Western Province in their game against Eastern Province at Port Elizabeth. Put in to bat, Western Province scored 362 before dismissing Eastern Province for 282, Dave Callaghan (129) scoring almost half the runs. Western Province then declared their second innings closed at 212-8, leaving Eastern Province to chase 293, but man of the match Claude Henderson, a left-arm spinner, took 5-40 as Eastern Province managed only 165. Western Province 362 and 212-8 dec Eastern Province* 282 and 165 Western Province won by 127 runs Western Province 18pts, Eastern Province 7pts Easterns started their campaign with a big win over Kwa-Zulu Natal at Benoni, despite a defiant 104 from Kwa-Zulu Natal No9 Golam Bodi. The diminutive Bodi, an Indian-born slow left arm bowler, scored his maiden first-class century (easily beating his previous best score of 33) in entertaining fashion, thrashing eleven fours and six sixes, but it was to no avail as Kwa-Zulu Natal went down by 108 runs. Kwa-Zulu Natal had won the toss and asked Easterns to bat, restricting them to 245 as medium-pacer John Kent took a career-best 6-77. Kwa-Zulu Natal found themselves equally restricted, struggling to 123 against the bowling of West Indian quickie Kenny Benjamin (3-23) and left-arm medium-pacer Gareth Flusk (3-31). They were helped by an excellent performance by wicketkeeper Dylan Jennings, who took six catches. When Easterns declared their second innings at 284-8 KZN were set 407 to win, but never looked in contention despite Bodi's last-minute knock. They were blown away by the pace bowling of Benjamin (4-79) and Andre Nel (5-64). Easterns 245 and 284-8 dec Kwa-Zulu Natal* 123 and 298 Easterns won by 108 runs Easterns 16pts, Kwa-Zulu Natal 4pts Some fine bowling from seamer Charl Langeveldt (5-19 and 1-49) and medium pacer Brad Player (3-11 and 5-26) ensured a win for Boland over Free State at Paarl. After asking the visitors to bat Boland blew them away for 102 in their first innings and restricted them to 249 in the second. Boland made 330 in their first innings, mainly thanks to Pieter Barnard (120) and James Henderson (76), and then openers Henderson and James Trott knocked off the 22 runs required in their second innings without loss. Free State 102 and 249 Boland* 330 and 23-0 Boland won by 10 wickets Boland 18pts, Free State 2pts Pakistan Lahore registered a ten-wicket win over Karachi Blues in their Quaid-e-Azam Trophy Grade I match at the LCA ground in Lahore, thanks to a sparkling 174 from wicketkeeper-batsman Kamran Akmal. He hit 28 fours and one six in his innings, sharing partnerships of 109 for the sixth wicket with Tariq Mahmood (46) and 129 for the seventh with Naeem Ashraf (28), as Lahore reached 428. Earlier they had dismissed Karachi Blues for 259 after asking them to bat; Afsar Nawaz was the mainstay of the Karachi innings with 114. When Karachi managed only 192 in their second innings Lahore were left with a target of 24, which openers Ali Hussain and Maqsood Rana polished off in 3.3 overs. Karachi Blues 259 and 192 Lahore 428 and 26-0 Lahore won by 10 wickets In a high-scoring match in Karachi, the home side drew with Bahawalpur after neither team seemed able to bowl the other out quickly enough for a positive result. Karachi racked up 485-8 declared in their first innings, with Mohammad Masroor (97), Hasan Raza (81), Asif Mujtaba (81) and one-time Pakistan wicketkeeper Atiq-uz-Zaman (62) all making major contributions. Bahawalpur replied with 367 (Shadab Kabir 84, Usman Tariq 62), and Karachi had reached 267-4 in their second innings (Shadab Kabir 116, Zeeshan Pervez 96) when time ran out. Karachi 485-8 dec and 267-4 Bahawalpur 367 Match drawn Elsewhere in the Quaid-e-Azam Trophy Grade I it was a case of ball dominating bat, with low-scoring games producing wins for Peshawar over Faisalabad, Sheikhupura over Gujrunwala, Rawalpindi over Sargodha, and Lahore Blues over Islamabad. Peshawar 174 and 177 (Shahid Nazir 6-58) Faisalabad* 73 (Nauman Habib 5-11) and 170 Peshawar won by 108 runs Sheikhupura 146 (Qaisar Abbas 67, Sarfraz Ahmed 5-43) and 194 (Zahid Javed 59, Mubashir Nazir 6-56) Gujrunwala* 198 (Naved-ul-Hasan 6-80) and 145-6 (Majid Saeed 94*) Gujrunwala won by 4 wickets Sargodha 106 and 219 (Misbah-ul-Haq 73) Rawalpindi* 383-9 dec (Pervez Aziz 154, Naeen Akhtar 64) Rawalpindi won by an innings and 58 runs Lahore Blues 199 (Stephen John 5-82) and 357-9 dec (Imran Farhat 77, Mohammed Hussain 65, Stephen John 5-128) Islamabad* 209 (Husnain Kazim 6-58) and 180 (Asif Ali 63) Lahore Blues won by 167 runs Catherine Hanley is an Australian who supports Somerset but lives and works in Sheffield. fields.headline: The Way You See It (part 2)
fields.trailText: Earlier today, the reaction to Sven Goran Eriksson's appointment as England manager seemed muted and mixed. For every reader that wrote in embracing the news, there was some little Englander, brandishing his bulldog and muttering about the decline of our Fair Isle, expressing his "disappointment."
fields.body:
Earlier today, the reaction to Sven Goran Eriksson's appointment as England manager seemed muted and mixed. For every reader that wrote in embracing the news, there was some little Englander, brandishing his bulldog and muttering about the decline of our Fair Isle, expressing his "disappointment."

But now the idea of a foreign manager in charge of England has had time to settle in the stomach, most of you are happy. Ecstatic even. "Only last month, in perhaps unprecedented unison, we basked in the brilliant glow of national pride generated by the awesome achievements of arguably the greatest ever Olympian, Steven Redgrave. His coach is German," says an astute Gareth Price.

Meanwhile, Lucy Upson sums up the enlightened mood, pointing out that "we've had turnips - so why not a Swede?" And Monster Joel is also in a genial spirit, to a point. "At last someone to help us forget the last two idiots," he says. "And if you don't like having a foreign manager then go back and smash up some small Belgian town like you did this summer." Well

But those of you with an eye on the future worry that the press won't give Eriksson a fair chance. "I doubt very much whether any of the journalists who wrote the articles attacking the idea of a foreign coach know Eriksson very well - yet they feel equipped to condemn the man 8 months before he is due to start," says an infuriated Ben Dudley.

"Some critics have commented on his ability to change his mind on a whim - but who wouldn't change his mind about going to Blackburn? If that's the reaction now, God knows what it will be like when he actually starts the job. And in response to Lawrence "PISSED OFF" Jones, thank God the FA did have the "courage and balls" to appoint a foreign coach who clearly has more to offer than anyone English."

Elsewhere, James Carlin is certainly right when he says: "If Sven-Goran Erikson is more successful than previous recent England managers then his nationality will be irrelevant." And Jon Larby almost certainly has too much time on his hands, because he has found out that "the most lucid anagram of Sven Goran Eriksson's name is 'seven or so rankings'.

"According to the latest Fifa World Soccer Rankings, England are currently fifteenth. Applying this 'prediction' to the present situation (upwards) would put England eighth," he states bizarrely, before continuing: "Eighth place is currently held by England's nemesis Germany. Were the FA swayed? We need to be told." Well, if you say so Jon...

fields.headline: Platonic ideals
fields.standfirst: Lord Puttnam, the man behind the Platos, reflects   on their success one year on
fields.trailText: Lord Puttnam, the man behind the Platos, reflects on their success one year on.
fields.body:
Sunday night was absolutely remarkable, not only for the sheer calibre of the outstanding teachers who were presented with their "Platos" but also for the distance the Teaching Awards have come. Last year, as I sat through the ceremony at Alexandra Palace, I genuinely believed that nothing could cap the magic of the moment when those first teachers received their awards. But, since then, the Teaching Awards have gone from strength to strength. In our first year all those who supported the awards, including the unions, the political parties and the profession itself, took an enormous leap of faith. I only hope they now feel that it has been richly rewarded.

The aims of the awards are to put teaching high on the social agenda, and to give the public a chance to see the profession in its true light. Teachers spend so much of their time motivating and praising the achievements of their students that their own achievements are often overlooked. The Teaching Awards gave all of us the chance to say thank you.

The schools involved in last year's awards have obviously benefited from the substantial prize money. More importantly, the knock-on effects of the awards, both to the teachers and to their schools, have been tremendous. It is not surprising that many schools have reported a real boost in morale, as well as an incredible response from the local community. In addition to this, the awards have given many of the winners a personal boost in confidence through the acknowledgement of colleagues and parents. This has been invaluable. Confidence, in my view, is the key to success at every level. A confident nation relies on confident schools, which in turn are built on confident teachers, who help to create confident students. At its very best it is an entirely virtuous circle.

And the Teaching Awards themselves are not standing still. Now we are not only recognising and rewarding excellence, we are enjoying the fruits of an increasing sense of ownership by the teaching profession itself. Across the country many of the 1999 regional and national winners have joined our judging panels and steering committees. We have been listening to what teachers want from us, and we are attempting to facilitate their needs by setting up workshops for the exchange of good practice. Our associate sponsors - the Leadership Trust, BT and the Guardian - are all working with us to add value to the awards in the form of Leadership courses for the winners. BT are providing a state-of-the-art interactive website to enable the winners to network with each other.

We have learnt so much this past year. Early on many educationalists supported the awards in principle but believed that they could only pay lip-service to the efforts of teachers. Many of those sceptics have become our biggest supporters. Some of them have been working on our judging panels and have witnessed our winners' professionalism and dedication first hand. They, more than anyone, have come to believe that these teachers deserve recognition.

Through vast amounts of positive publicity, people now know that the Teaching Awards are a rich source of good practice. If the Teaching Awards are an attempt to improve the morale, status and perception of the teaching profession, this is also an absolutely central task of the General Teaching Council.

Many, if not most, of this government's initiatives seek to raise standards by identifying and spreading excellent practice - that which has been shown to work in the classroom. So it is essential that the General Teaching Council establishes itself as a respected, creative and constructive voice that will allow teachers to be far more instrumental in the "architecture" of change, and in decisions relating to the continuing professional development of every teacher. As a result of this involvement, teachers should develop ownership of the mechanisms through which they are expected to raise standards of achievement for this generation and beyond.

webTitle: The Lloyds TSB Lifetime Achievment Award - Teaching 2000

fields.headline: Young at heart
fields.standfirst: Catherine Samuel has taught under-fives for 39 years, but is still inspired by them. Jerome Monahan meets the winner of the Lifetime Achievement Award
fields.trailText: Catherine Samuel has taught under-fives for 39 years, but is still inspired by them. Jerome Monahan meets the winner of the Lifetime Achievement Award.
fields.body:
The week in which she was the centre of attention for a BBC film crew ended on a rather prosaic note for Catherine Samuel, the deputy head- teacher of Blaendulais Primary School near Neath. "I was getting a box down from high up in a storage room when a loose shelf fell on my toe," she explains. "It's not broken but I can't put on my shoe."

Injured toes apart, Samuel at 60 is as energetic and enthusiastic a teacher of early years as when she started 39 years ago  the vast proportion of that time at Blaendulais. In fact her connection to the school goes even further back, for between the ages of four and 10 she was a pupil.

Although she had a stint as a head, and clearly has had the chance to move into teacher training, Samuel decided to stay in the classroom and nurture the next generation of early years teachers at the same time. "Above all else, I am a practitioner," she says. "I spotted early on that heads were getting more isolated and so I stayed where I felt I was most effective."

Samuel's classroom has long been a centre of excellence and there is a constant stream of visitors. "Just last week I had four teachers in from the Swansea valley. Our present head is a firm believer in inviting others in to see our work: it keeps us on our toes."

Her nomination arose when a teacher spotted publicity for the Award and thought immediately of her. The idea was mooted at a governors' meeting and received unanimous support.

She takes me on a tour of her teaching area. It is made up of a series of sections in which children are offered the richest diet of experiences. "We have a computer area, and a puppet section - the children love playing with them. Then there is a construction corner, and an interchangeable area which can be transformed into a hospital, a post office or a fire station - depending on whichever visit we are due to make out in the community. In the 'listening station' the children hear stories of the past from some of the older ladies from the village. They also come in to help us make Welsh bread and take part in the old-fashioned wash day."

Catherine Samuel has a genius for creating school - community links, and always makes parents welcome. One said: "It is remarkable that Mrs Samuel has maintained such a high standard at the Nursery Unit over 30 years. We really appreciate the commitment she has given to our children. They could not have had a better start with their formal education."

For children in her class, the year is filled with out-of-school visits ranging from rescuing frog spawn from people's gardens to dropping in on the local dentist to allay some of their fears.

Some of the strongest links Samuel has forged have been with local farmers, poultry breeders and gamekeepers, who have supplied her 'growth area' with a wide range of eggs to incubate. "We have hatched goslings, quails and even pheasants. Our chicks have won awards at the Royal Welsh Show."

It is not only chicks that go on to achieve excellence by association with Samuel. "I have always valued the role in the classroom of the nursery nurse," she says. "It is such a waste that they have often been seen as dogsbodies. They have always worked alongside me and I have encouraged several to train to be teachers."

One former colleague, Ceinwen Williams, said: "She has proved to be my best teacher, most valued colleague and friend, my mentor and always my inspiration. In truth, she epitomises the best in early years practitioners."

Asked if there are any children that have particularly stood out for her, she answered that she is proud of them all. They have a high regard for her, too. Alissa Bevan, now aged nine, said, "Mrs Samuel is very fair; if there is an argument she listens patiently to both sides."

Samuel refuses to be drawn when asked what will be done with the £20,000 prize. "All I can say that what happens to the prize will be a whole school decision."

And what about her plans now her 60th birthday is approaching? Catherine Samuel is clear she is not entertaining thoughts of retirement. "I still enjoy it all."

The judge says:

We read nearly every day of the supposed shortcomings of the teaching profession, and yet almost every parent is loud in their acclaim of their own child's teacher. Ever since WWII, there has been a slide in the perceived status and commitment of teachers, who in my young days were seen as the leaders of their community.

The Teaching Awards are an attempt to rectify this misunderstanding and to honour the dedication, wisdom and hard work of so many of our teachers.

Teaching is even more of a calling than a profession. Our lifetime achievers are all people who have a clear and profound calling to help all their pupils to achieve the unbelievable, to go that extra mile. They give of themselves unselfishly and generously. With nominees of such a high calibre, we relied upon evidence from colleagues, parents and pupils, rather than academic statistics, to make the differentiation between the good and the remarkable.

I have been honoured to be given the task of chairing the excellent group of volunteer judges, and humbled by the example of the teachers who have been nominated for awards. They are all a beacon of light and hope for the futures of our young people.

Sir John Harvey Jones, Chair of judges

Phillip Staley West Midlands

Wellington Primary School, London

The Teaching Awards are an attempt to rectify this misunderstanding and to honour the dedication, wisdom and hard work of so many of our teachers. Teaching is even more of a calling than a profession. Our lifetime achievers are all people who have a clear and profound calling to help all their pupils to achieve the unbelievable, to go that extra mile. They give of themselves unselfishly and generously. With nominees of such a high calibre, we relied upon evidence from colleagues, parents and pupils, rather than academic statistics, to make the differentiation between the good and the remarkable. I have been honoured to be given the task of chairing the excellent group of volunteer judges, and humbled by the example of the teachers who have been nominated for awards. They are all a beacon of light and hope for the futures of our young people. webTitle: Winners of last year's Teaching Awards

fields.headline: Class of 1999
fields.standfirst: Last year's winners tell Simon Midgley how the award changed them - and their schools - for ever
fields.trailText: Last year's winners tell Simon Midgley how the award changed them - and their schools - for ever.
fields.body:
Keith Parry OBE, the 47-year-old director of Information and Communication Technology at Hyde Technology School in Cheshire was slightly discomforted by his award for the most creative use of ICT in a secondary school. "I felt almost embarrassed to be chosen when everybody else - my colleagues and the students - had really won the award for me," he said. "But from the school's point of view it has been marvellous. The students felt real pride."

Mr Parry was one of the 14 teachers whose schools, colleagues, pupils and parents basked in their reflected glory. One unforeseen consequence of winning was that around half the winners were awarded the OBE or CBE in the Birthday honours list for services to education.

Maureen Davies CBE, the 60-year-old winner of the lifetime achievement award, has spent 33 years of her 35-year-long career teaching at St Sebastian's Catholic Primary and Nursery School in inner- city Liverpool. Winning gave her a fantastic feeling: "It was not just for me. You could not get this on your own, you have to be part of a team." As far as the school was concerned: "It was wonderful. We celebrated the win with children, teaching students, staff, parents, governors and the church." Her prize money is equipping a new early years centre.

All the winners agree that the awards are a great boost to morale for themselves and their schools. The prize for excellence in special needs teaching went to Wendy Crockett, a 48-year-old special needs coordinator at Alderman Blaxill School in Colchester. "It gives you a lot of strength to carry on believing in yourself."

The national award for a secondary school teacher working with parents and the community was won by Bob Jennings OBE, 50, who was director of community development at Bristol's St George Community School. "There is a sense of pride across the whole school," he says. "It's as if your school has someone who makes the England football team. It was a celebration for everyone I worked with."

The award for excellence in special needs teaching in a primary school went to Elizabeth Seddon OBE, 46, at Elmtree First School in Chesham, Buckinghamshire. She said the award raised morale throughout the school. Most of the prize has been spent re-designing and equipping the school playground. The moment it was announced that Diana Sperry, 28-year-old ICT co-ordinator at Moat Farm Junior School in Oldbury, had won the award for the most creative use of ICT in a primary school, was "absolutely brilliant," she said. "But it all went so quickly. You want to catch the moment and savour it forever. It still brings tears to my eyes when I think about it."

How they spent their money

Hyde Technology School in Cheshire set aside £10,000 of its prize money, won by Keith Parry, to buy 200 second-hand, refurbished computers to lend to its pupils for home use. It has signed up with Tools for Schools, an organisation that refurbishes used computers donated by business and then sells them cheaply to schools. To date the school has taken delivery of 60 computers, 50 of which are now out on loan. The remaining £10,000 has been spent on a new digital camcorder to capture good quality video and a new digital camera. The £3,500 regional award money was used to buy video equipment to capture and edit video on the school's computer network.

Inverteign Junior School in Teignmouth spent some of its prize money on a minibus to ferry its children to sporting fixtures. Flo Witcombe, who was teaching sport when she won her award, said: "Obviously the money has been brilliant for the school. I was in charge of football and taking kids to matches was always a bit of a nightmare for us because a lot of our parents do not have cars. It was impossible to get to away matches. The minibus has been an absolute godsend. We also bought some stage lighting for the hall to make our productions a little bit more professional looking." A local artist has also painted a Matisse-like mural on an old mobile classroom in the school's playground.

Wingate Nursery School in County Durham is well equipped already, so the school spent the prize money, awarded to headteacher Paddy Beels for working with parents in the community, on training staff to develop children's creative thinking. Schools in Reggio Emilia in northern Italy have developed an innovative pre-school learning approach, now practised in Danish schools. This builds on children's interests. The entire teaching staff visited schools in Denmark and the head and deputy spent a study week in Reggio Emilia. The school has been refurbished in natural materials; and the garden developed to encourage outdoor activity.

fields.headline: What is a good teacher?
fields.standfirst: With a profession full of modest stars, identifying the individuals who stand out is always going to be extremely difficult, says Ted Wragg, one of the national judges. But it's worth it
fields.trailText: With a profession full of modest stars, identifying the individuals who stand out is always going to be extremely difficult, says Ted Wragg, one of the national judges. But it's worth it.
fields.body:
According to the adverts, nobody forgets a good teacher. The question facing the judges in the Teaching Awards each year is how to identify one. An even more pressing issue is how to pick the "best" teachers, first in each region, and then in the whole country.

Last year's winners made the sort of disarming speeches that you would expect from seasoned pros who understand what teaching is really about. They knew very well that they were members of a team, partly dependent on the quality of its members and on the children they taught, often stating that some of their colleagues were just as meritorious as them. This year's winners have also been impressive, and equally modest about what they do.

The demands on today's teachers are huge. In Victorian times pupils only attended school briefly, or not at all. Most were gone before their teen years. In former times those children entered work  now adults are kept on in school. To that can be added the many demands from government, parents, employers and society at large. Some of these are in the form of national targets for 11, 14, 16 or 18 year olds. Others are for personal qualities that school leavers need to have.

Look at any employer's recruiting literature and before long these requirements are spelled out clearly: willingness to learn, persistence, maturity, sociability, sensitivity, determination, punctuality, reliability, teamwork, imagination, initiative. Superhumans welcome; the rest please form an orderly queue.

So what are the criteria that indicate "good" teaching? Meeting short-term goals, like attaining high test scores? Long-term effect, such as stimulating a lifelong interest in learning? Producing decent citizens who also know their stuff in work and at home?

The short-term indicators are often criticised, since pencil and paper tests may only assess the easily measured. And how can you evaluate lifelong aspirations unless you hang around for a few decades? It is only when we look back in adult life that we can see which teachers really influenced us for the better.

In these circumstances, judges of the Teaching Awards look for a consensus of those in a position to judge. We talk to heads, parents, governors, pupils; and we watch teachers at work. Those who can put on a fine show when visited are not necessarily the ones to sustain it for a year, a decade, or a whole career. It needs people in regular contact to tell the marathon runners from the sprinters.

Research into teaching has often produced mixed results. In the 60s there was a vogue in the United States for trying to find universally "good" teachers who could be studied in detail, so the essence of their competence could be distilled and passed on to others with more modest talent.

The problem with this kind of research was neatly summed up by one 60s reviewer of several hundred such studies who stated: "Some teachers were preferred by administrators; some were liked by pupils; and some taught in classes where there were substantial pupil gains  and generally speaking these were not the same teachers".

Thirty years later another large-scale review of research concluded that classroom factors were more influential on children's learning than educational policies, and that classroom management was the most powerful factor. But this sort of finding merely highlights another problem: there are many different ways of managing a class.

The one area of research that has been astonishingly consistent is children's views of good teaching. Whether you look at primary or secondary pupils, studies from the 30s right through to research we did last year, their opinions hardly vary. Children like teachers who can keep order, explain Cleanly, show enthusiasm for their subject, treat them as individuals, and who have a good sense of humour. They hate teachers who are sarcastic, belittling, or unfair in their use of rewards and punishments.

The context is vital. At Exeter we did the largest study ever undertaken in this country of teachers alleged to be incompetent. A number were failures in one school, but a success in another.

We conducted a two-year study of what primary teachers did to improve children's literacy. Some who were highly regarded by their head teacher, and also secured high levels of improvement in pupils' reading, regularly displayed children's work. It was their way of showing that they valued what their classes did. Two other equally competent teachers, however, made virtually no use of display.

We gave reading tests to several hundred children at the beginning and end of the school year. One girl, Eva, scored the highest improvement of anyone in the sample, while a boy, Jack, had the greatest fall in his test scores over a year. So did Eva have a brilliant teacher, and Jack a lousy one? In fact, Eva and Jack were in the same class. Eva's mother spent hours writing elaborate stories with her. Sadly, Jack's parents split up and the poor lad daydreamed the year away. These strikingly different home factors seemed more potent than the teacher's influence.

Despite the difficulties involved in identifying "winners", I think the Teaching Awards are worthwhile. Impressive though these highly competent winners are, we cannot say they are unmistakably the best in the land, as they themselves have been quick to point out.

But they do illustrate a series of types: the dedicated person infinitely patient with children who find it hard to grasp what others absorb easily; the admired head who inspires colleagues; the computer buff passing on third-millennium wizardry and inventing new ways of teaching; the classroom assistant putting in far more than is required; the engaging nutter whose lessons are unforgettable.

When my secondary school music teacher, Norman Barnes, died recently, I realised what an enormous debt I owed to him. What he gave me and others was a lifelong love of music. If I had not worked in education I could gladly have been a professional musician.

Good teachers are the bearers of social genes, for they pass on to hundreds of pupils the knowledge, skills, beliefs and values that societies have accumulated over thousands of years. The winners of the Teaching Awards embody the qualities that the best practitioners bring to their work.

By the year 2006 about half the teaching profession will be over 50. We shall need to recruit 200,000 teachers over the next decade. Last year's winners have already shown that they are not only standard bearers, indicators of what is best, but also fine ambassadors for the profession.
