webTitle: The Teaching Awards 2000: How to nominate next year's winners

fields.headline: How to nominate next year's winners
fields.trailText: This has been an impressive second year for the Teaching Awards, with the commitment and dedication displayed by the winners a real indication of the successes being achieved out in the teaching world, both academically and personally. The awards were set up to both highlight excellence and encourage good practise by recognising and honouring outstanding teachers.
fields.body:
This has been an impressive second year for the Teaching Awards, with the commitment and dedication displayed by the winners a real indication of the successes being achieved out in the teaching world, both academically and personally. The awards were set up to both highlight excellence and encourage good practise by recognising and honouring outstanding teachers.

But what about next year? Whether you are a teacher, head teacher, parent or a pupil, and are reading this thinking "I know someone who should win an award" then the time to act is now. There are three key reasons for submitting a nomination: to celebrate as a community the great teachers within your school; to publicly share the ways in which their skills contribute to the school's success; and, thirdly, to benefit from the prestige of winning an award. And let's not forget the money. As the winners from last year prove, the substantial prizes awarded can facilitate significant improvements to the school.

The Teaching Awards are a chance for everybody in the school to get involved, as Beauchamp College in Leicestershire proved last year. Their maths teacher David Waugh won the award for Most Outstanding New Teacher in a Secondary School. He was nominated after the college had canvassed opinion from pupils and parents. The selection process should involve all those concerned: from teaching staff and governors to parents and students. Every pupil from 2000 award-winner Trenica King's class submitted their written reasons for nominating her in the Most Outstanding New Teacher in a Secondary School category. Pupil power indeed.

These awards are not an opportunity for head teachers to put their "favourite" staff member forward. They are a nationwide platform for staff to commend a colleague for their dedication. Crucially, the awards provide an opportunity for communities to show their appreciation of their teachers, as was the case for Eric Gates, headmaster at Chantry School in Gravesend, and winner of the 2000 award for Working with Parents and the Community in a Primary School.

The prestige from winning a "Plato", as the Teaching Awards have become known, reflects on the schools who allow these inspiring teachers thrive. The modesty from this year's winners only serves to illustrate how essential it is that caring and resourceful teachers receive the public recognition they deserve. Their success will inspire our future generations of teachers.

Who is eligible?

Nominations are open to teachers from all schools, whether state maintained or independent. All full-time, part-time and peripatetic teachers from every subject and activity area are eligible for nomination, including headteachers. All nominees, excepting those nominated in the classroom assistant category, must have qualified teaching status.

How to nominate

If your school would like to nominate a teacher for the Teaching Awards 2001 register your interest via the website at: www.teachingawards.com which also has up-to-the-minute news on the Teaching Awards.

Enquiries can be sent to info@teachingawards.com or telephone 020 7907 1500

fields.headline: 'She's the tops'
fields.standfirst: Denise Murray, classroom assistant, is highly trained, highly motivated, and is often in high spirits. Helen Carter meets a woman who can find the fun in anything
fields.trailText: Denise Murray, classroom assistant, is highly trained, highly motivated, and is often in high spirits. Helen Carter meets a woman who can find the fun in anything.
fields.body:
Denise Murray brings lots of spirited fun into the classroom at Beaumont Hill special school in Darlington; which is valued by colleagues and students alike. She is one of 25 classroom assistants at the school; her colleagues nominated her for Classroom Assistant of the Year. Murray says one of her proudest moments was when the school was awarded technology status. "It was such a big thing for the school and it was a brilliant day."

Murray has a NNEB qualification and has worked in special schools for 20 years, the last seven years spent at Beaumont Hill. She has gained the Specialist Teacher Assistant qualification, focused on literacy and numeracy, and is now a specialist maths SSA. She is also a trained counsellor and a staff member of the school's governing body.Working with children in a maths lesson, she is able to encourage children with a range of difficult disabilities. Murray speaks directly to every child and she uses references to a child's own experiences to keep them focused and make them feel special.

Dela Smith, head teacher of Beaumont Hill, describes Murray as one of life's givers. "Denise is a wonderful colleague," she says. "Her sense of fun and positive attitude has a huge effect on the school. This attitude is infectious and quite essential when the going gets tough - which it frequently does."Murray is renowned for her computer skills, which she uses to produce school newsletters, posters and certificates celebrating the children's achievements. "Because they don't make as much progress as those in mainstream schools, every success is a cause for celebration."

Matthew Smith, one of her students who is now in year 11, says: "I first knew Denise when I was 11 years old. She helped me with all my work and was very kind to me. When my mam died Denise came round and took me out for the day with her family." One parent told the award judges: "Denise provided transport for six disabled children so that my son could have his friends at his party. My eyes fill when I think of that." Alyson Everard, an advanced skills teacher at the school, says Murray always gives 101%. "Her commitment to the children is exceptional. She is always available to provide an ear for problems and, most importantly, to have fun." Everard says Murray continually worked long over the allotted hours and carried out extra duties. Everard says Murray is: "a truly lovely person who always manages to be cheerful. Her presence is like a breath of fresh air."

The £20,000 prize money will be used for an additional classroom for some of the most difficult children, some books for the school library and specialised seating for the most disabled children who have profound learning difficulties, as the chairs cost around £2,000 each. As ever Murray is focused on the children. She says she is very proud that some of the children have achieved key stage three and four in maths and science:"I always look forward to the records of achievement presentation in July," she says. "I like it when the parents cry because they are so proud and of course we all feel the same way as them. We are all so proud of what our children have achieved."

The judge says:

This is the first year the award for Classroom Assistant of the Year has been given nationally. Tim Brighouse recently made the point that schools of the future will have far fewer teachers but far more classroom assistants. I am certain he is right. Learners need to have both the confidence to learn and the skills to be successful learners, as an essential prerequisite to receiving essential skills, knowledge and understanding. Teaching assistants can ensure those prerequisites are met.

This year it has been my privilege to visit some inspiring teaching assistants. What they had in common, despite having a multitude of different roles, was a delight in going that extra mile in support of their teachers, students, families and communities. I saw and heard from those they supported what a difference it made to each of them. Some youngsters had been remotivated by these people's skills and their passionate commitment. These wonderful people all make a significant difference. They are not replicating the teacher's role but they certainly enhance it, and give individual children the means to enjoy learning.

Dame Tamsyn Imison

Eileen Burch East Midlands, Woodlands School, Nottingham

Beverley Chapman West Midlands, Finham Park School, Coventry

Carol Ford South West, The Cathedral School of St Mary, Plymouth

Janet Hawker West, St George Community School, Bristol

Caren Hopton Wales, Ysgol Gymraeg Ynyscedwyn, Swansea

fields.bodyText: Denise Murray brings lots of spirited fun into the classroom at Beaumont Hill special school in Darlington; which is valued by colleagues and students alike. She is one of 25 classroom assistants at the school; her colleagues nominated her for Classroom Assistant of the Year. Murray says one of her proudest moments was when the school was awarded technology status. "It was such a big thing for the school and it was a brilliant day." Murray has a NNEB qualification and has worked in special schools for 20 years, the last seven years spent at Beaumont Hill. She has gained the Specialist Teacher Assistant qualification, focused on literacy and numeracy, and is now a specialist maths SSA. She is also a trained counsellor and a staff member of the school's governing body.Working with children in a maths lesson, she is able to encourage children with a range of difficult disabilities. Murray speaks directly to every child and she uses references to a child's own experiences to keep them focused and make them feel special. Dela Smith, head teacher of Beaumont Hill, describes Murray as one of life's givers. "Denise is a wonderful colleague," she says. "Her sense of fun and positive attitude has a huge effect on the school. This attitude is infectious and quite essential when the going gets tough - which it frequently does."Murray is renowned for her computer skills, which she uses to produce school newsletters, posters and certificates celebrating the children's achievements. "Because they don't make as much progress as those in mainstream schools, every success is a cause for celebration." Matthew Smith, one of her students who is now in year 11, says: "I first knew Denise when I was 11 years old. She helped me with all my work and was very kind to me. When my mam died Denise came round and took me out for the day with her family." One parent told the award judges: "Denise provided transport for six disabled children so that my son could have his friends at his party. My eyes fill when I think of that." Alyson Everard, an advanced skills teacher at the school, says Murray always gives 101%. "Her commitment to the children is exceptional. She is always available to provide an ear for problems and, most importantly, to have fun." Everard says Murray continually worked long over the allotted hours and carried out extra duties. Everard says Murray is: "a truly lovely person who always manages to be cheerful. Her presence is like a breath of fresh air." The £20,000 prize money will be used for an additional classroom for some of the most difficult children, some books for the school library and specialised seating for the most disabled children who have profound learning difficulties, as the chairs cost around £2,000 each. As ever Murray is focused on the children. She says she is very proud that some of the children have achieved key stage three and four in maths and science:"I always look forward to the records of achievement presentation in July," she says. "I like it when the parents cry because they are so proud and of course we all feel the same way as them. We are all so proud of what our children have achieved." The judge says: This is the first year the award for Classroom Assistant of the Year has been given nationally. Tim Brighouse recently made the point that schools of the future will have far fewer teachers but far more classroom assistants. I am certain he is right. Learners need to have both the confidence to learn and the skills to be successful learners, as an essential prerequisite to receiving essential skills, knowledge and understanding. Teaching assistants can ensure those prerequisites are met. This year it has been my privilege to visit some inspiring teaching assistants. What they had in common, despite having a multitude of different roles, was a delight in going that extra mile in support of their teachers, students, families and communities. I saw and heard from those they supported what a difference it made to each of them. Some youngsters had been remotivated by these people's skills and their passionate commitment. These wonderful people all make a significant difference. They are not replicating the teacher's role but they certainly enhance it, and give individual children the means to enjoy learning. fields.headline: Attenshun, class!
fields.standfirst: David Baugh has had an unusual career- from Gurkha Rifles to ICT buff at his primary school. Perhaps that is why, when it comes to scarce resources, he is such a fighter. By Phil Revell
fields.trailText: David Baugh has had an unusual career- from Gurkha Rifles to ICT buff at his primary school. Perhaps that is why, when it comes to scarce resources, he is such a fighter. By Phil Revell.
fields.body:
For most teachers the route into teaching involves a closed circuit from school to college and back to school again. David Baugh is a good example of the advantages of breaking that cycle. Baugh's parents were aid workers, and his own education took place in schools scattered across the world - from Uganda to Botswana to Barbados.

Once back in England he took a degree then joined the Army. He joined the Gurkha Rifles, which involved more travel, to places like Hong Kong, Brunei and Nepal. The Gurkhas see more than their fair share of activity so Baugh was probably ready for a quieter life when he came out of the army. He joined an independent school as their bursar, which was great for management and financial experience, but after 6 years he was "heartily fed up" and decided to take the OU postgraduate route into teaching: "The best decision I ever made."

Teaching practice and experience was at Ysgol Frongoch in North Wales, where he stayed for the next five years. When he arrived the school had a few BBC micros and one PC. He was determined to bring Frongoch's systems up to scratch. "He had no difficulty in persuading me that this was the way to go," says headteacher Jeremy Griffiths. The difficulties were going to be practical and financial.

NGfL funding wasn't sufficient to build the kind of network Baugh had in mind. So, over a period of months, he begged, borrowed and scrounged second-hand machines from all over the UK. Some were PCs, some were Macs. The school saved several thousand pounds when Baugh led a team of parents to install a network in one day. He also persuaded the local computer centre to open its doors to Frongoch's pupils on an after-school basis: soon copied by other local primaries.

The school's 20-plus machines are scattered through the classrooms, a deliberate decision which reflects Baugh's view that ICT is not a peripheral subject, but a means to unlock the potential to learn in all subjects. "My philosophy is that it shouldn't be an add on," he says. "It should be central to the teaching."

The children use ICT in a multitude of ways, from simple word processing through to creating multimedia resources to illustrate the work they are doing. The current project is an EU initiative where schools across Europe produce multimedia web pages to describe themselves and their home towns. They are understandably enthusiastic about the opportunities they have been given and the skills they've developed.

"I like IT work in Mr Baugh's class, especially when we use Claris Works to make newspapers," said Holly Bovington, while James Whitehead simply said: "Class 7 IT work is superb." Frongoch's children have won awards for their work, including the TES Newsday competition, while Baugh has been poached by Denbighshire to run their ICT training across the county. "His management of the school infrastructure involves work far beyond the call of duty, with holidays and weekends sacrificed for the benefit of the school," said chair of governors Mona Evans. "I sometimes wonder what this would all have cost if the governing body had had to contract the work outside."

Despite the recognition evidenced by the local authority and others, Baugh was still taken by surprise by the award: "I'm humbled by the whole process." He hasn't given a great deal of thought to how the prize money will be spent. "I'd like to make it possible for the children to use laptops and connect to the network using wireless technology, so that they could be free to work wherever they happened to be."

Winning the national award is bound to make a difference, but Baugh seems genuinely reluctant to contemplate the possibilities the award will open up. "I'm not sure about the future. I think that I've got the job made in heaven at the moment - working across schools, working with children and expanding good practice."

webTitle: Working with Parents and the Community - Primary

fields.headline: Putting in the effort
fields.standfirst: Primary winner Eric Gates had to gain parents' trust before he could start to build a successful school, finds Susannah Conway
fields.trailText: Primary winner Eric Gates had to gain parents' trust before he could start to build a successful school, finds Susannah Conway.
fields.body:
Clean and brightly decorated, with shiny new windows and colourful murals on every wall, Chantry Primary School in Gravesend, Kent is a school filled with happy, inquisitive children. But it wasn't always this way. When headteacher Eric Gates, winner of this year's award for Working with Parents and the Community in a primary school, arrived, the school, situated in a deprived area of the town, had been placed in special measures by Ofsted. The father of three knew what had to be done: "I walked round the corridors and understood that I needed to do something special for these children," he says. "Nobody had put any effort into the school for a long time and while today people say there's a lovely feeling about the place, we've worked very hard to achieve that."

KS 1 teacher Jane Karabardak, who seconded the chair of governors' nomination, joined the school two terms before Gates. "The morale of the staff couldn't have been lower when we failed the Ofsted, and the area in general was very depressed. But Eric was very open and honest with the staff and they have backed him all the way."

One of the first things Gates did was call all the parents into school. "I said to them 'I am here for your children and want to do something for them.' And the parents actually applauded me and came up and shook my hand. They'd been very angry and that anger had been coming in with the children." From day one Gates made a point of being available in the playground at the beginning and end of the school day to help build a rapport with the parents. "It was important they knew me and understood I was on their side," he says. He also sent out weekly newsletters to keep them informed of the school's progress.

"Things happened straight away when Eric arrived," says Carol Farrant, a classroom assistant who also has two children at the school. "The parents trusted him because they could see he was a man of his word." Gates initiated the creation of two gardens in derelict quadrangles of land in the school: the multicultural garden has vegetables and plants representing the diverse cultures at Chantry; and the science garden, with its canals linked by a waterwheel and lock gates, offers practical educational learning.

Parents came in to work on the gardens; and Gates sourced financial support from local, national and international businesses for his projects. How did he do it? "I made a lot of noise. Someone clearly needed to be on the school's side."

His tireless commitment to the school, filling the classrooms with proper resources - from computers and books to decent pencils and paint - took the school out of special measures, building the self-esteem of both pupils and staff, who are now delivering real academic success. When asked how winning the prize made him feel, Gates, who started teaching in 1964, smiles: "I'm very fortunate to have the right attitude from the staff. It's not an easy school, but you have to have special staff to work with the type of children we have here."

The school has a diverse selection of nationalities, with many children drawn from local refugee families. Specialised staff are on hand to help children who have English as their second language, and morning assemblies regularly embrace different religions.

The children are all bursting to share their opinion of Mr Gates. "He helped my school," says 11-year-old Ryan Bremner, "because it was going to get knocked down but he came here and made it better." Shahzaad Khalid, 10, knows the measure of a good teacher: "When you were naughty our last headteacher just told you off, but Mr Gates gives you warning letters." The school will use the £20,000 prize money to create a new ICT suite; the whole community is eager to come in and use the computers. Three years ago they were ashamed of it, now the locals view Chantry as a valuable and essential resource.

Sadly for the pupils and parents of Chantry Primary School, Gates will be retiring at Christmas, but he can enjoy his retirement in the knowledge that not only has he turned the fortunes of the school around, but he has changed the lives of the most important people there: the children.

fields.headline: Climbing walls
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan meets Jenny O'Connor, winner of the award for Most Outstanding New Teacher in the  primary school category
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan meets Jenny O'Connor, winner of the award for Most Outstanding New Teacher in the primary school category
fields.body:
Jenny O'Connor has had a meteoric career. In just 18 months she has gone from a part- time cover teacher to a key player in her local education authority's quality management team, responsible for disseminating good classroom planning and practice to 48 Sandwell primary schools.

In her time at Yew Tree Primary in Walsall, for which she won her award, O'Connor assumed responsibility for special needs and ICT, ran numerous clubs, and organised several memorable outings including a week-long trip for 50 pupils to an outdoor activity centre in Snowdonia.

"It was just chance that brought me to the school," she admits. "A friend was down for a week's cover but asked me to step in for her. I was given a year 4 class and they were climbing the walls - I was just the latest in a succession of cover teachers. At 3.15pm, I thought, 'I've earned my money today and I'm never coming back'. But the following week, I was asked if I could return and for some reason I accepted. I found myself back with the same class. It all grew from there. When a full-time post came up I thought, 'I love this - I'm staying', and I did."

When O'Connor joined Yew Tree Primary it was in trouble. The head was on long-term sick leave, morale was low, and the intensive programme of HMI and local authority visits following a failed Ofsted inspection was beginning.

The school was also serving a tough inner-city estate - four in 10 of the children received free school meals and there were 60 children with special educational needs.

According to the school's acting headteacher, Howard Martin: "A special measures school needs special people. In O'Connor, the school had not only a special person but an extraordinary and exciting teacher. Her warmth, sense of humour, compassion and enthusiasm made a major contribution to the school's progress."

One of the biggest challenges was winning the parents over. "It became clear that I would have to earn their acceptance," she says. "But I didn't pursue it on purpose - it flowed from the work I was doing as the special educational needs coordinator. A sign I had cracked it came during a long parents' evening when people brought me bottles of beer."

One parent commenting on Jenny's work with her son said: "Because of her, I've got a normal little boy." Another told the Teaching Award judges: "She's got something that doesn't come along very often."

O'Connor is firmly committed to developing children's capacity for independent learning. Nominating her for the award, Howard Martin singled out the impact her capacity for "communicating with challenging children" has had in bringing about "a sense of pride and self-belief" in themselves. "The children were very unmotivated when I arrived," says O'Connor.

"If they couldn't do something immediately, that was it. Later on, it was good to see how much more prepared they had become to make mistakes and persevere."

Ofsted had criticised the lack of IT at Yew Tree and O'Connor offered to take it on. She made two successful bids for funding and began to create a dedicated computer suite - which can now be completed thanks to her prize money. "It's great that it will be up and running so much sooner than we thought."

Some of O'Connor's best experiences came with the trip to Snowdonia. "The kids were ace. I'll always remember them refusing to come out of a river, up to their knees in freezing cold water, their teeth chattering so much they couldn't speak. Overhearing two tough Year 6s talking about how relaxing they found the view and the sound of the water was very moving."

Fortunes at Yew Tree have improved. "The school rocketed out of special measures," she says. And typically, it was O'Connor who organised the staff celebration.

It is clear that O'Connor misses Yew Tree but, according to Liz Dix, project manager of the Sandwell quality partnership team and co-sponsor of her Award nomination: "It is lovely that so many more people can benefit from seeing her good practice - her teaching is spellbinding."

fields.headline: Spreading the net far and wide
fields.standfirst: Angela Gaunt is improving ICT standards in her own school, but finds time to help local primary schools too, finds Phil Revell
fields.trailText: Angela Gaunt is improving ICT standards in her own school, but finds time to help local primary schools too, finds Phil Revell.
fields.body:
Angie Gaunt is one that nearly got away. In the 70s in Leeds she wasn't considered A-level material and found herself doing a secretarial course. Course lecturers soon realised that she wasn't destined for the typing pool. "My college lecturer got me a place at teacher training college."

Gaunt's first job was in London, under ILEA control, where she taught business studies. Gaunt was first promoted to head of department and then to advisory teacher at the London computer centre. On the authority's demise, Angie moved north. She found herself at William Beaumont Community School in Warrington, as business studies teacher, ICT coordinator and head of year. Facilities were poor when she arrived - some teachers were still using BBC micros - but her results were soon among the best in Cheshire. In 1997 a new headteacher, John O'Callaghan, arrived from a City Technology College.

Determined to invest in ICT he asked Gaunt for her vision for the school and its pupils. "She convinced me that we should create a facility for the next century that would not only serve the needs of the school, but also the local primary schools and the community," he recalled. Three years later the school has five purpose-built ICT rooms with over 150 machines, networked with internet access. She uses her non-contact time to teach year 5 and 6 children. "Her enthusiasm and knowledge of ICT is tremendous," says Paul Fleming, headteacher of St Anne's Primary school. "She has the ability to get the best out of children and to put nervous colleagues at ease."

Her dedication has given her students confidence in ICT. Her year 11 group of 15-year-old students were working with Power Point, using sound, music and video to build a presentation on a local leisure centre. "If you don't understand something she'll sit down with you until you are 100% sure," says student Matthew Wilson. Sarah Clarke argues that Gaunt's success in her lessons comes from creating the right atmosphere. "In our lessons she's very relaxed," she said. "If she wants you to do something you'll do it because you respect her so much." With the award money the school will be buying an interactive whiteboard, but "I'd like to be able to allow parents and children to dial in to the system from home," Gaunt says.

In her spare time Gaunt works out at the local fitness centre: "The gym provides me with time and energy," she says. She's married and evenings are reserved for her nine-year-old daughter. "At least until she goes to bed, then it's back onto the internet." She's aware that winning the national award will open up opportunities, but she's not sure where her future lies. "There are still things I want to do here," she says. Whatever turns up she will resist pressures to leave the classroom. "I'm very much a teacher and I want to continue doing that."

The judge says:

It's crucial to our children that we develop their capacity to use ICT for work as well as for leisure. We must transform our schools and do it fast. We need teachers who will not just move themselves, but who will move the system. That's what we looked for in our ICT Teachers of the Year. They had to have gained enormous knowledge about the technology, and expertise in using it.

They had to recognise its potential throughout the school and have the character to fire up colleagues to want to have a piece of the action. They needed the obsessiveness of the visionary, but the patience that allows nervous colleagues to gain confidence exploring new territory. But, most of all, to win the award they had to excite children, motivate them, stretch them, give them the confidence to be bold and push themselves. They needed to have that wonderful control of a class where pupils fly rather than fear moving.

David Mallen

fields.headline: Judgement  day
fields.standfirst: The Judges
fields.trailText: The Judges
fields.body:
Selecting the finalists, let alone the winners, from this year's plethora of impressive nominees can't have been an easy task for the judges. But someone had to do it, and those that did are undoubtedly the best qualified for the job. The members of the judging panels - both regional and national - were drawn from across the educational spectrum, including teaching unions and parent-governor associations.

These awards were not implemented to bring "outsiders" in to schools to judge a profession they know nothing about. The Teaching Awards focus on peer appraisal: the celebration of those who practise excellence in education by those qualified to recognise it. In every region an awards panel made up of 30 representatives from the local education community was appointed. The chairs of these regional panels also served on the national awards panel, among them many practising teachers. Sir Robert Salisbury (Chair of the East Midlands panel) is the headteacher of Garibaldi School in Forest Town, Mansfield; Frances Raval (North of England), with 30 years of teaching experience, is now deputy headteacher at Bruntcliffe High School in Leeds; and Dame Tamsyn Imison (South East), is the headteacher of Hampstead School in London.

Many of the national judges have retired from long and notable careers in education, including Ian Kane BA Cert. Ed FRSA (North West) who retired in August 1999 from the post of Dean of the School of Education at Manchester Metropolitan University; and Bob Finch (East), whose career included seven years as a science teacher and 20 years as ICI's Education Adviser. Chris Tipple (North East and Cumbria), who recently retired from his post as Director of Northumberland Education Authority, began his life-long career in education as a geography teacher.

Other judges borrowed from further education included Professor Fabian Monds CBE (Northern Ireland) who is Provost of Magee College and Pro Vice Chancellor for Planning in the University of Ulster; Professor Roy James (Wales) who has 40 years experience in education, including 11 years as a maths teacher; Professor Jeff Thompson who has been Head of Education at Bath University since 1979; and Professor Ted Wragg (South West) who has been Professor of Education at Exeter University since 1978.

Other national judges include Ranjit Sondhi (West Midlands) who was recently appointed as a Governor of the BBC, and is presently serving on the Lord Chancellor's Advisory Committee on Legal Education and Conduct; and Professor David Mallen CBE (South) who is currently an adviser to the DfEE, and whose previous posts have included CEO in East Sussex from 1990-99 and Education Officer for ILEA.

fields.headline: In with a bang
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Smithers meets the secondary winner in the Most Outstanding New Teacher category,  Trenica King
fields.trailText: Rebecca Smithers meets the secondary winner in the Most Outstanding New Teacher category, Trenica King
fields.body:
After only two years in the classroom, Trenica King has inspired and influenced not only her pupils and fellow teachers, but also non-teaching staff and parents.

King is in her first job as a health and social care teacher at a sprawling secondary in an Essex "new town". The winner of the award for the most outstanding new teacher of the year in a secondary school has succeeded against the odds in winning the trust of teenagers living in a socially deprived area which has the highest crime rate and the highest proportion of single parents in the county.

At Chalvedon school in Pitsea near Basildon, her head teacher Alan Roach explains that King has faced tougher challenges than many young teachers at the start of their careers by deliberately choosing a school in an Education Action Zone.

The school has seen the proportion of youngsters gaining A-C grades at GCSE increase from just 4% 12 years ago to 34% now.

"She has won over difficult pupils and made them recognise the importance of education," he says. "She always goes that extra mile by going beyond the call of duty to support students whenever they are taking part in something". In return, the pupils who accompanied her to the regional awards ceremony in Norwich rewarded her with a deafening roar of approval as she went onto the stage.

Roach claims King's vision of what could be achieved by children regardless of their social background was clear even when she came for interview. "It was evident even from her school record of achievement that she had something very special to offer. We consider ourselves very lucky to have her".

Lynn Pounder, the school's chair of governors, adds: "From the very start Trenica impressed her mentors and senior staff, gaining the respect of all her colleagues and winning the trust and admiration of her pupils. She uses her talents to support and develop the whole team".

While still in her first year as a health and social care teacher King was given extra responsbilities and was later promoted to head of department. She has made the GNVQ course highly popular. Some of the sixth formers who praised her teaching abilities said it was "amazing that she is able to make units like 'the structure of the NHS' interesting", describing her as "a combination of brilliant teacher and friend".

King is form tutor for 30 15-year-olds. Her charges confide in her, and parents report that they find her a rare and special teacher, who communicates with all age groups.

Every single member of her form, 9P, provided a letter of support for her nomination. "I think Miss King is the best form tutor because she is caring, helpful, honest and most of all exciting," said Chloe Emmons. Ross Whittaker added: " She praises you when you need praising and helps you when you need helping". As an extra bonus, King takes her tutor group out on weekend outdoor activities, where they benefit from her sporting and sailing prowess.

King does not believe that winning the national award will make a difference to her personally, but it will help to put the school on the map. The school intends to use the £20,000 prize money to create the first hi-tech "staffroom of the future" in the country. "The award won't change me, but it's absolutely fantastic for the school," she concluded.

 The judge says:

Being inside a classroom observing these gifted new teachers was a privilege. We were recording and celebrating qualities which had already been recognised by the governors, headteachers and colleagues who had nominated them. Their good teaching practice arose from personality, education and training - and their school. They were special people who all worked in challenging but supportive schools which allowed their potential to be released.

They were all extraordinarily mature, confident and highly organised individuals who obviously enjoyed their jobs and liked their pupils. We found absolutely no resentment from colleagues, quite the opposite. We came away from each visit full of optimism about these new entrants to the profession. Bob Finch

Michelle Jones E Mids, Vale of Catmose College, Oakham
James Kelly North, Ripon College, Ripon
Raza Khan N West, Elms Bank Comm. High, Mancs

Del Planter West, Downend School, Bristol

webTitle: Working with Parents and the Community - Secondary

fields.headline: The world outside their windows
fields.standfirst: The energy of the winners in this category can't be contained within four walls. Below, Phil Revell meets secondary winner Lyn Reynolds
fields.trailText: The energy of the winners in this category can't be contained within four walls. Below, Phil Revell meets secondary winner Lyn Reynolds.
fields.body:
After a few minutes in Lyn Reynolds' company there's one question which begs an answer. Where does she find the time? This is a woman whose day often starts with the Breakfast Club at Birmingham's Byng Kendrick Central School (BKC), before moving on to a round of meetings in the city's education action zone, before returning to BKC to see how the after-school clubs are getting on, before teaching her history A-level group, before

"All I do is the job that thousands of other teachers are doing every day," she says. Reynolds has worked her patch in Birmingham for nearly 20 years, all of which has been spent at BKC, which serves a sprawl of estates on the city's outer ring. Headteacher Karl Turner describes her as one of the "most outstanding teachers" he has ever worked with, and action zone director John Bailey's testimonial to her work was scattered with words like "zeal", "passion", "amazing" and "astounding".

She's an historian who still gets good results, and whose work was commended by Ofsted, but her real talent appears to be what BKC's previous headteacher Ben Collins described as "a unique capacity to get people involved". Three years ago Reynolds became a tutor at the fledgling University of the First Age, which was pioneering out-of-hours approaches to exclusion and underachievementReynolds set up an out-of-hours centre at BKC and was pivotal in getting parents involved. "It was extremely difficult to get this off the ground," said Maggie Farrar, UFA national project director. "But Lyn never gave up, she just kept inviting parents in, running Saturday family events, and talking to them at every opportunity."

After the success of the out-of-hours initiative at BKC, Reynolds wrote a lottery bid for £200,000 of funding for summer school activities across the action zone's 14 schools. It was successful and she was seconded to work with the Education Action Zone to coordinate the project. "The challenge now," she says, "is to extend vacation schools to other holidays, because the children love them so much."

Reynolds has the ability to rope anyone in to one of the projects she runs: the once-a-month Saturday morning journalism club will shortly be receiving a visit from a Guardian feature writer. At BKC she established a supportive study scheme which allowed students to get extra help with their GCSE coursework and revision, this ran alongside residential revision weekends, with teachers along for support.

"I didn't believe I'd win it," she says of the national award. Some of the prize money will be spent on hiring a room in a pub, but not for a celebration party. "We are going to run our parent training from there. It will be interesting to see if that brings more people in." But that's hardly likely to clear the whole £20,000. So what else? "We could really use a minibus for the out of hours stuff," she says. "Ferrying disaffected lads to motor mechanics courses."

And the future? "At the moment this is challenging and new, but I wouldn't be very happy with it unless I was teaching the kids as well. The thing about out-of-hours teaching is that it's addictive, it gives you energy and it doesn't drain you."

BKC sixth former Charlene McIntosh has known Reynolds for all her school career and can testify to that unflagging energy. "Society is too willing to blame teachers for not working hard enough," she says. "It's nice to have a teacher like Mrs Reynolds to prove them all wrong."

The judge says:

As chair of the National Association of Governors and Managers, I am particularly interested in this category. Many of the schools have catchment areas which include deprived communities and children who have major educational and behavioural difficulties. Invariably candidates in this category see the involvement of parents as the route to the involvement of the children. The ways in which this is done, the flair, imagination and, above all, sensitivity deployed can be quite breathtaking.

Some teachers focus on bringing the world of work into the school; others on utilising the school facilities as a true community centre, with local clubs and societies running a range of out- of-school activities. At one school the nominee had started a "summer school" for the long holiday. One girl had (reluctantly) enrolled and found, to her great surprise, that the programme of events was quite good fun. It was only after three weeks she realised that she was learning. People who can teach children without them even knowing have a rare gift.

Professor John Adams

Regional winners:

Anna Brookes South, Patcham High, Brighton

John Brooks S East, Chestnut Grove School, London

Lynda Fox North East, Grangefield, Stockton on Tees

Geoffrey Guttridge East, North Walsham High, Norfolk

Karen Hanks N West, Longdendale High, Hyde

Richard Hoban North, Benton Park School, Leeds

Bob Mitchell East Midlands, Beauchamp College, Oadby

David Perrett South West, Estover Community College, Plymouth

Lyn Reynolds W Mids, Byng Kenrick Central, Birmingham

Andrew Williams Wales, Willows High School, Cardiff

webTitle: The Leadership Trust Award for School Leadership - Primary

fields.headline: Power to the people
fields.standfirst:
Headteacher Mags Long, winner of the primary school leadership award, has created 
an outstanding school by involving everyone in its development, says Geoff Gibbs
fields.trailText: Headteacher Mags Long, winner of the primary school leadership award, has created an outstanding school by involving everyone in its development, says Geoff Gibbs.
fields.body:
Mags Long bursts into the staff room. "Welcome to the madhouse," she laughs, radiating an infectious combination of enthusiasm and energy that remains with her throughout our tour of St Rumon's, the west country infant school of which she has been headteacher for the past 13 years. Long, who entered teaching 30 years ago because she "wanted to make a difference", has received the national award for Contribution to School Leadership in a Primary School.

As we drop in to watch a maths lesson in progress, hands stretch eagerly upwards to catch her attention as she joins in the exercise of estimating the height of what was once an austere Victorian classroom. Like other classrooms in the school, the room is now themed with bright colours, helping to create the stimulating learning and teaching environment that so impressed the judges.

St Rumon's is a Church of England infants school with 150 pupils aged from four to seven. Four years ago government inspectors lauded it as "outstanding" and a second inspection this year has produced a glowing report.

The site is cramped but under Long's energetic leadership it has developed into an exciting, well-equipped school. Outdoor passageways have been covered over to provide additional learning and library spaces, while a stretch of river bank owned by the school has been transformed into a supervised environmental study area. "It will enable us to action every improvement and enhancement to the building we have ever dreamt of," she says.

"We plan to enclose another two outside areas of the school to give us areas where the children can work and conduct experiments under cover." The school also intends to buy more outdoor play equipment and extend a specially designed wooden climbing frame in the school playground.

She has never stopped studying: despite a punishing schedule that includes being south west coordinator of the School Centred Initial Teacher Training project (SCITT) she is about to complete a masters degree on the theme of "parental involvement and partnership in children's learning."

Parents play a key role in the life of St Rumon's, involved in everything from classroom help to organising the "virtual buses" that walk an increasing number of pupils to school each day. But it is the way Mags Long inspires and encourages the school community as a whole that caught the judges' attention. They noted how staff felt empowered to seek training and career development, and how support staff also felt their views and suggestions were valued and encouraged.

Long says her philosophy is to make every single person involved in St Rumon's feel valued; to feel that their opinions matter. "We want the children to be confident, competent learners. But we also want them to be happy."

Members of Orange class, keen to share their views as they left their maths lesson, have no doubt that she has succeeded. "I like it when she takes my class," said six-year-old Thea Dickinson. "She is funny because sometimes when we are writing she gives us little tricks for spelling words." Matthew McClung, seven, whose mother is vice chair of governors at St Rumon's, agreed. "She is really nice because she lets us have treats and sometimes we go out for trips. She lets us have three playtimes, too."

According to Mrs McClung, the parent responsible for organising the walking bus scheme, it is the head teacher's enthusiasm for the school that stands out. "She inspires everybody, the teachers, the children, the parents, the governors. Parents help every day of the week and it's down to her enthusiasm. It rubs off on everybody. She has got this way of finding the best in every child."

fields.headline: First impressions
fields.standfirst:
The school buildings may be a bit ramshackle, but it's what's on the inside that counts. 
Phil Revell meets headteacher Anthony Cooper, who has breathed new life into his school
fields.trailText: The school buildings may be a bit ramshackle, but it's what's on the inside that counts. Phil Revell meets headteacher Anthony Cooper, who has breathed new life into his school.
fields.body:
Tony Cooper is a solid, quietly spoken man with big, well-worn hands and sparkling eyes. His school is less immediately impressive, with shambling buildings which the Teaching Awards judges described as the least attractive accommodation they had visited.

So much for first impressions. This year 63% of Aldercar's Year 11 gained 5 or more higher grades at GCSE. Many schools in leafy suburbs would be quite satisfied with that figure, but Aldecar, sandwiched between Derby and Nottingham, is a depressed ex-mining community where over a quarter of that year group entered school with reading ages up to 4 years below their chronological age.

In 1994 an Ofsted inspection raised serious concerns about the school, but the past 5 years have seen a 231% increase in higher grades at GCSE, an increase the judges described as "quite staggering". The school has held the Basic Skills Agency's quality mark for the past two years. Children learn Japanese and, if an application to become a language college is successful, the school hopes to offer Mandarin. Yet in the mid-90s the school's reputation was dire.

"The school was very comfortable with where it was," says Cooper. "Yet the results were mediocre. Every year group were being done a disservice. The quote that I got - and still get - is: 'well, what do you expect from children from that area'."

Cooper expected better. He was a deputy at the school in the 90s, which he found "frustrating at times, because you wanted to move things forward." When the headship became available colleagues expected him to apply for "better schools elsewhere", but there was never any real question of where he wanted to be. "Anybody can pick the cherries. Go to a school with 90% higher grades, and let things ride. But that's not me."

With a new management team, Cooper set about seizing the school and its community by the scruff of the neck. An early decision involved bringing support workers into the heart of the school and involving them directly in learning. "One of the things that used to exist in the school was the attitude 'We're teachers - you're not'," he says, "so we've worked on that." Blending together a team of lunchtime supervisors, librarians and ancillaries Cooper formed a literacy "hit squad" which, on average, raises pupils' reading ages by 20-24 months in just a term of school time. Many of the team are parents. Other initiatives to bring the community into the school include allocating accommodation for the local playgroup, and allowing parents to study alongside pupils in a range of subjects.

"When I first came to this school, people were saying 'You don't want to go there, it's rubbish'," says year 10 pupil Adam Grice. "Now some of them want to come here, but they can't get in." The children are fiercely proud of their school, particularly as some came to Aldercar after unhappy experiences elsewhere. They understand that the school's encouraging atmosphere is down to their headteacher: "He's easy to talk to," said Laura Wadsley. "If you have any problems you can go to him and he'll sort it out for you. In my old school I didn't get on with any of the teachers."

Cooper doesn't see himself as a superhead and he certainly doesn't envisage parachuting into other schools to solve their problems. "I've yet to be convinced that because someone has done a wonderful job in one school, they can be lifted and dropped into a challenging school and suddenly expect it to rise out of the ashes," he says. "It's taken us five years to get this far and we're not there yet."

The prize money will be used to support the language college bid. Competing claims on the funding include new sports developments, a community performing arts centre, and the never-ending fight to maintain sub-standard buildings. Moving on isn't an option that has occurred to him. Apart from unfinished agendas, he has his family to consider. His children attend the school and he would like that to continue. "Ten to 15 years ago this school used to follow in the wake of others," he says. "I'm never going to let that happen again. If something good is available for the kids of this area then we must grab it."

Led by Tony Cooper, the people at Aldercar seem to have done everything that could have been asked of them. Perhaps someone should have a look at the environment they're expected to work in.

The judge says:

Despite all the talk about superheads running several schools at once, almost all schools have a single head- teacher, usually assisted by one or more deputies. Whenever a school is scrutinised, whether by inspectors, researchers, or the travelling army of schools improvers, its leadership is an important factor in any success and failure. The award winners had inspired teachers, pupils, parents, governors, support staff and their communities, showing that this impossible-looking job can still be done well. Their speeches always stress teamwork: all are respectful about their colleagues and their pupils. Winners of leadership awards do not boast.

Professor Ted Wragg

webTitle: Excellence in Special Needs Teaching  - Primary

fields.headline: Yes, you can
fields.standfirst: In Mary Campbell's primary special needs class there is no such word as 'can't'. Paul McGill meets her
fields.trailText: In Mary Campbell's primary special needs class there is no such word as 'can't'. Paul McGill meets her.
fields.body:
Mary Campbell could have taken early retirement when she was confined to a wheelchair after an operation two years ago. "But all I ever wanted to do was teach. I knew that at the age of 11 when I was inspired by a great teacher."

With the encouragement of her principal, Bobby Rooney, she returned to work at St Gerard's Educational Resource Centre in West Belfast. The centre takes pupils aged 4-16 with moderate learning difficulties, and does outreach work for special needs pupils in other schools. When she returned to St Gerard's, where she teaches Year 7 pupils, she got a projector because she could no longer write on the blackboard. "I was so pleased at how easily I was able to cope," she said, but this is not a story of coping. It is the tale of an exceptional teacher with remarkable determination.

Bobby Rooney, now retired, who nominated Campbell for the award, believes she is simply a brilliant teacher. "Her enthusiasm, preparation, professionalism and organisational flair is immediately evident and her approach is permeated with a great sense of humour and a dynamic zest for living life to the full."

Overflowing, rather than full: apart from teaching, Campbell is vice-principal; she helps to induct beginning teachers; and sits on the Belfast Education and Library Board. Tony McGlone, the new head, endorses the praise. "She is an exceptionally gifted teacher in her skills and abilities in the classroom; and she is extremely dedicated. The class is child centred, but she pushes them to the limit of their potential and sometimes beyond." Campbell herself exudes enthusiasm for teaching and for children. She has great respect and love for the pupils but recognises that learning is the main aim.

"The teacher sets the standard for children and they rise to meet it. I have never met a child who does not rise to your expectations. We are not allowed to say 'I can't' in my classroom; we say 'I have to find another way'."

She creates books for the children if textbooks are not suitable. This year she has already made about a dozen books, such as 'Life in early Times'. The pupils in turn will do anything to please her and win one of the stickers saying "I'm one of Mrs Campbell's superstars". Several parents wrote to support Campbell's nomination, all impressed by the progress their children make with her. "I think she is just tremendous," said Pat McAllister. "She has a wonderful personality and great sensitivity and puts in an extraordinary effort. Her hallmark is respect for the children but she also has the skills to go along with it to do an outstanding job." "I am delighted and absolutely honoured to have won," Campbell says. "But you can't single out one teacher because it is all about teamwork." And where could the money best be spent? Replacing the obsolete Archimedes machines in the primary department; and literary and numeracy resources.

Mary Campbell appreciate what the award represents: "To reach the point that you are recognised by your peers for your contribution to children is extremely gratifying."

webTitle: Excellence in Special Needs Teaching - Secondary

fields.headline: Above and beyond
fields.standfirst: For secondary Special Needs winner Jane Dowell, teaching RE and music is not a theoretical exercise - it is a spiritual quest. Angelique Chrisafis reports
fields.trailText: For secondary Special Needs winner Jane Dowell, teaching RE and music is not a theoretical exercise - it is a spiritual quest. Angelique Chrisafis reports
fields.body:
Jane Dowell, 58, winner of the Award for Excellence in Special Needs Teaching in a Secondary School, has taught at Piper Hill School in Manchester for 11 years. She is currently coordinator of religious education, music and equal oportunities.

"I believe every child should have the opportunity to develop themselves as fully as they can," she says. Her headteacher, Jenny Andrews, says Dowell's nomination was a unanimous decision by staff and parents. "In Jane's long career, she has never lost one iota of her energy."

One of Dowell's key achievements at Piper Hill has been to develop the RE curriculum and apply it to special education needs. This is particularly invaluable as Piper Hill is a multi-faith school. Dowell also coordinates music in the school and, as a non musician, she has developed a music curriculum alongside perapatetic teachers, which enables staff without musical training to teach music. She has also adapted a further education curriculum to meet the needs of supported and experiential learners. Students are taken out on excursions to a variety of workplaces, where they can try on uniforms and handle equipment.

Students have vivid memories of their excursions with her. Deborah McKindie, 16, remembers a choir trip to London; Lee Cannon, 17, remembers shopping excursions, writing lists and counting out money; and Nikhil Kumar, 17, particularly remembers when the class adopted a rhino at the zoo.

"With a high level of support in special education, we can increase a student's awareness of the world," Dowell says. "Learning should be fun and interesting at an appropriate level for each student." Dowell's good work happens out of school, too: her family have offered respite breaks to one student, Claire Beswick, now 17, since she was six. Catherine Beswick, Claire's mother, said: "Ten years ago, Claire had feeding and developmental problems. Now Claire is in Jane's form again and talks enthusiastically about her school work."

Dowell also works as an equal opportunities coordinator for the school, which four years ago amalgamated with another, changing its catchment area and cultural make up. Jane Ashton, Head of Further Education, commented: "Jane has helped develop the staff's knowledge of the cultures and faiths within the school population."

Jenny Andrews says: "Jane approaches her planning and target-setting with an intellectual rigour. But most importantly, her work is not just a theoretical exercise. It is a kind of spiritual quest that makes it real for the children and staff." Dowell says the award is a reflection on the work of all the staff and that the prize money will enable them to invest in the development of the lower school grounds - "something that will really benefit the younger students' learning experience."

The judge says:

Judging excellence is always a challenge. Judging for this particular category was even more so. In all our visits, we were struck by the use of innovative techniques to deal with sensory impairment, autism or dyslexia, while fostering a deeper sense of personal dignity.

All of them exhibited an indefatigable energy coupled with flair and imagination.For some despairing parents, these teachers had given them back their children. The best were effective managers, great communicators and natural leaders - inspired, irrepressible, ubiquitous and gifted. It is a great privilege to witness extraordinary teachers at work, meeting the needs of unusually challenging pupils with such personal devotion and professional intensity.

Ranjit Sondhi

The best were effective managers, great communicators and natural leaders - inspired, irrepressible, ubiquitous and gifted. It is a great privilege to witness extraordinary teachers at work, meeting the needs of unusually challenging pupils with such personal devotion and professional intensity. webTitle: The Guardian Award for Teacher  of the Year - Primary

fields.headline: Here's something I prepared earlier...
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan meets Alison Hatch, primary school teacher of the year, who could have had a career on Blue Peter, given her talent with chicken wire
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan meets Alison Hatch, primary school teacher of the year, who could have had a career on Blue Peter, given her talent with chicken wire.
fields.body:
Alison Hatch is a great fan of chicken wire and Modroc, the stuff used to make plaster casts. They have played a part in her winning this year's Guardian Award for Primary Teacher of the Year. With them Hatch performs the feats of after-school artistry that transform her 4th Year classroom at Northdown School, Margate from a dragon's lair to an Egyptian pyramid by way of a WWII air raid shelter. One of her colleagues has described visiting her as being akin to "walking into a storybook".

"This term we are studying the Romans - hence the columns," she explains. On another wall is a gigantic pair of 3D lips. "That's made from corrugated card and it's linked to a unit we're studying about language. I'm also linking it to some work on a healthy diet and fillings." This capacity to squeeze the maximum from every resource seems to be Alison's style. She admits to sleeping with a paper and pen at her bedside - "in case I get a good idea in the night."

It seems remarkable that Alison Hatch has any time for sleep. She is the team leader for Years 3 and 4, she is the PE coordinator, in charge of ICT, she runs dance and gymnastic clubs after school, and has recently taken on the role of teacher governor.

Hatch has been a teacher for 11 years; this is her third school. Northdown serves what has been described as one of the most socially disadvantaged communities in Kent. Many of the parents are living in B&B and refuge accommodation. "Just when you have got the class settled, there are newcomers. And as many of them come as refugees, their English is often non-existent. Hence, the interest in language and lips!"

Hatch aims to create a place of order and calm in the children's lives. Her headteacher, Jacqueline Cox, who nominated her, said: "Through her high expectations and warm personality she instils a sense of pride and delight."

Hatch's enthusiasm rubs off on the parents too. One parent who supported her nomination for the Guardian Award said: "Miss Hatch was the only teacher who actually got on the bouncy castle with her class at a fund-raising event last year. There was much laughter all round. Her fondness for the children was so apparent."

Hatch is overjoyed at the attention the school is receiving as a result of her success. But this is not the first time she has put Northdown on the map. Her efforts have been central to the success of the school's football, rounders and netball teams. "I heard that we had won the Thanet five-a-side football trophy the first time when I was in hospital and my scream of joy scared everyone on the ward."

Hatch has a severe form of Lupus - which causes her immune system to turn on her own organs and joints. All the more remarkable then, that the children praise her for her consistent good humour.

Alison sees her award as a vote of confidence for the whole school and pays tribute to the teamwork that makes Northdown such a happy place. The £20,000 prize will be spent on networking. "We hope to set up a web link to cameras in the pond and some nesting boxes in our environment garden," she explains. "The children will be able to keep an eye on the caddis fly and check out what the snails are doing."

webTitle: Let's teach the  world to sing

fields.headline: Let's teach the  world to sing
fields.standfirst: The chamber choir and school band make regular international appearances, but the head of music, Cathy Roberts, is the real star. Angelique Chrisafis reports
fields.trailText: The chamber choir and school band make regular international appearances, but the head of music, Cathy Roberts, is the real star. Angelique Chrisafis reports.
fields.body:
Cathy Roberts has been head of music at St Aidan's Church of England Secondary school in Harrogate for six years. "My philosophy is equal opportunities in music for every child," says Roberts. "They each have a creative streak, whatever their coordination and whatever their physical ability. My job is to make them believe in themselves." Her enthusiasm for her work has not gone unrecognised - her nomination for the Guardian Award for Teacher of the Year was proposed by the parents.

"We have a Down's Syndrome pupil who is learning flute and piano because she loves music," says Roberts. "I believe music is a marvellous leveller, which develops so many skills - coordination, performance, discipline and listening - which can be brought to other subjects." Roberts, 34, has a background in both primary and secondary schools, and taught primary teachers how to teach music. At St Aidans, she heads a team of three full-time music staff, one part-time teacher and 17 instrumental teachers. Headteacher Dennis Richards said: "In this age of focus on numeracy, literacy and science, it is so refreshing and invigorating to have a musician like Cathy involving each pupil in a subject which might have been sidelined, or deemed less important."

Around 400 pupils take instrumental lessons, and Roberts directs three ensembles, including the school concert band of 120 which has played in Canada, the US and Sweden. She also heads the Chamber Choir of 52 which has toured Holland, Belgium and Germany, and reached the semi-finals of Sainsbury's Choir of the Year."She has a superhuman commitment," says Richards. "In 30 years, I have never met a teacher who comes anywhere remotely near her in terms of devoting their own time to students."

Her dedication is particularly evident when one learns that once a term the chamber choir sings live for Radio Four's daily service. This requires them to leave school at 5:30am, rehearse from 8am, go live at 9:45 and get back on the bus for school at 10am. "Cathy works brilliantly under pressure and has enabled a bunch of not naturally outstanding youngsters to sing to a very high standard indeed,"says Philip Billson, the producer for BBC Religion. "She achieves this both through her own excellent musicianship, but also her inspiring leadership."

Roberts' passion for her job means she is at school most nights until 8pm. "If I've gone the extra mile for music it's in the hours," she admits. "But I don't often think about it, because as soon as I arrive at a cathedral on a Sunday morning and see how excited the children are to perform, it's all worth it."

Roberts's teaching methods are inclusive, and every pupil at the school will take part in a concert performance. This term, Roberts is teaching year 7 rhythm and singing through the cantata - 230 pupils will then sing at the Royal Hall in Harrogate. "It is really important that each child experiences a live performance," she says. "Every pupil must know what it is like to be on stage and see the audience clapping them. Every child should be given a voice." She is currently teaching rap to year 9, culminating in a performance by 13 and 14 year olds using only their voices and classroom props.

When asked about her award, Roberts says: "I am here to represent the school, so I have won for them. Without the support of other staff, I wouldn't be here." The prize money will go towards music technology teaching at the school, which has just started an A-level in the subject. "Recording and mixing equipment and microphones are important not only for our pupils, but for the local special school and blind students."

The last word should go to a parent. Pauline Hanover, whose 13-year-old son attends St Aidan's, feels she owes a debt of gratitude to Roberts: "The musical soul of our son has been encouraged, nurtured and strengthened by Mrs Roberts. Music is undoubtedly her life, and now, through her inspiration, it is our son's."

Surely that is what every teacher strives to achieve.

The judge says:

Judging the secondary teacher of the year national award this year, I was very conscious of how proud each school was of their finalist. They saw the award as recognition of both their excellent teacher and their school. We spoke to ex-pupils, present pupils, other staff, parents and the community. We were continually impressed, both by the outstanding teaching and by the ex pupils, parents and others who took time to tell us about the impact of a particular teacher on their lives.

Each visit was a school's celebration of the best there is in teaching. If only we could bottle this pride and enthusiasm and give it to those who decry our teachers. While we have teachers like these, the future is bright.

Frances Raval

webTitle: TV islanders get hooked on footie

fields.headline: TV islanders get hooked on footie
fields.trailText: Youngsters on a remote South Atlantic island have became hooked on football during an experiment to find out whether TV makes children violent.
fields.body:
Youngsters living on a remote South Atlantic island have became hooked on football during an experiment to find out whether television makes children violent.

Locals on St Helena had satellite TV broadcast to them 24 hours a day for five years.

Sixty hours of the Supersport channel were screened on the island every week as well as round-the-clock coverage from the Discovery channel, KTV, Movie Magic and the BBC.

Experts studied more than 30 hours of video footage of children aged between three and eight recorded in the playgrounds of two of the island's schools.

They discovered that instead of showing aggressive, anti-social behaviour learned from TV, the island's 1,000 children became addicted to soccer.

The youngsters' behaviour actually improved as they began to take part in team games in a bid to copy their new heroes, including Aston Villa star David Ginola and Manchester United's David Beckham.

In fact, the children on the former colony - whose 5,644 inhabitants live a 1,000 miles from the African mainland - were found to be among the best-behaved.

Now experts from Cheltenham & Gloucester College of Higher Education, Gloucestershire, have argued that the breakdown of the family network, and not television, is to blame for violent, unruly behaviour.

They have claimed although the youngsters may have picked up examples of bad behaviour from watching TV, they have been prevented from practising them because of the close-knit, watchful community on St Helena.

Professor Tony Charlton, leading the research, said: "One of the claims levelled against television is that viewing encourages children to imitate violent behaviour. This has not happened on St Helena so far.

"Blaming TV succeeds only in diverting attention away from the real causes. One cause could be that traditional support networks are less prominent now than a generation ago. Families, neighbourhoods and communities have tended to lose their unity and influence."

He put the new-found passion for football down to children's desire to copy idols.

Prof Charlton said: "They want to try and emulate players like Beckham. Part and parcel of watching TV is identifying with someone.

But he said that the results do not contradict claims that children learn aggressive behaviour from their TV viewing.

"They suggest aggressive behaviour learned from TV may remain unpractised. That depends on the extent to which young viewers' behaviour is monitored regularly in the home, school and community."

Researchers are now hoping to get funding to continue to monitor the effect of TV and investigate what aspects of island life help keep children on the straight and narrow.

webTitle: Bertelsmann gets into bed with Napster

fields.headline: Bertelsmann gets into bed with Napster
fields.trailText: German media giant Bertelsmann is linking up with Napster, the rogue internet music site which it is facing in the courts, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
German media giant Bertelsmann is linking up with Napster, the rogue internet music site which it is facing in the courts.

BMG, Bertelsmann's music industry subsidiary, will withdraw its lawsuit against the company if the collaboration proves successful.

Bertelsmann is to develop a new secure file-sharing music service with Napster, which achieved instant notoriety with record executives when it launched a site that enabled fans to download and share music free of charge.

Radiohead have been the most high-profile victims of the service, which record companies claim threatens the payment of royalties and the future of the industry.

But Bertelsmann has decided to lend money to Napster to develop a more secure service.

The service will provide payments to copyright holders, including recording artists, songwriters, record companies and music publishers.

Thomas Middelhoff, chairman of Bertelsmann, said rival record and publishing companies should follow his company in embracing music on the net.

He said: "Napster has pointed the way for a new direction for music distribution, and we believe it will form the basis of important and exciting new business models for the future of the record industry."

fields.headline: True North snaps up MBS
fields.trailText: True North Communications has acquired the largest privately held UK media agency, MBS and Expert Media, for an undisclosed amount, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
True North Communications has acquired the largest privately held UK media agency, MBS and Expert Media, for an undisclosed amount.

The move is intended to beef up the agency's media presence in the UK.

MBS, which has billings of around £150m, will be combined with the in-house media buying capabilities of True North's UK agency Banks Hoggins O'Shea/FCB. Banks Hoggins, however, will retain its in-house media planning capabilities.

Glenn Burton, the chairman of MBS and its parent company Genus Media, will remain chairman of Genus Media, which will retain its identity under True North's ownership.

David Bell, chairman and chief executive of True North, said: "This agreement is consistent with our commitment to growing our media brand and further expanding FCB in Europe.

"MBS is a media services brand of the highest quality and their addition strengthens our global media capabilities. We have been approached many times before, but True North shared our same company values, which was very important."

fields.headline: Eriksson: the reaction
fields.trailText:
Peter Taylor

Leicester manager, in charge for England's friendly against Italy on November 15
fields.body:
Peter Taylor

Leicester manager, in charge for England's friendly against Italy on November 15

"I am very much looking forward to working alongside someone of his stature and ability. He has an excellent record as a coach and I'm sure I can learn a great deal for him."

Kate Hoey MP

Sports Minister

"The FA have clearly identified Sven-Goran Eriksson as the best coach available for the English national team. I am glad the uncertainty is over and I welcome the involvement of a team of young English coaches to work with him with an eye to the future. I wish them all well."

John Barnwell

Chairman, League Managers Association

"Are the FA saying there is nobody in this county who can do this job? Have they tried hard enough to find someone in this country? We don't think so.

"As an association we are disappointed we have not been consulted, as we were promised and has been reported in some newspapers, by the FA over who they should pick as their new coach or manager.

"There is quite a ground swell of opinion that has been disappointed in the way in which the FA have just pushed aside all the managers over this.

"We as an association will obviously bite on the bullet and give him as much co-operation as we can."

Terry Butcher

Former England captain, speaking to Sky Sports

"From my experience, if there was a foreign coach in charge for England and I was a player coming into that set up, I would be very interested to hear what he had to say.

"I imagine his opinions would be very different to those of typical English coaches. I think someone of that experience can only do English players good.

"I would expect to see blossoming under his ideas and tactics."

"I imagine his opinions would be very different to those of typical English coaches. I think someone of that experience can only do English players good. "I would expect to see blossoming under his ideas and tactics."

fields.headline: BBC online ads 'could mean end of licence fee'
fields.trailText: Tory culture spokesman Peter Ainsworth said that any move to carry ads on BBC Online could sound the death-knell for the licence fee. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Tory culture spokesman Peter Ainsworth said that any move to carry ads on BBC Online would hit at the heart of its public service remit and could sound the death-knell for the licence fee.

"There will be significant consequences for the licence fee. No one should be under any illusions," said Mr Ainsworth. "It will be hard for the BBC to justify its hefty licence fee if it starts taking ads on its public service website.

"It's yet another example of the BBC being an unchained beast marauding around the ecology of broadcasting."

Mr Ainsworth said his sources at the BBC suggested the issue of advertising on BBC Online had come out of conversations about moving some of the lifestyle-oriented content on BBC Online over to its commercial site, beeb.com.

This would put the gardening and food websites into the commercial domain and enable the BBC to start making money from the content.

He said he would welcome such a move, adding: "It would be better to move material over to where advertising already appears and give a better definition to BBC Online."
