fields.headline: Ritalin - wonder drug or 'monster' creator?
fields.standfirst: A government drug watchdog responded today to fears over the use of the drug Ritalin, used to calm hyperactive children. For some, it's a wonder drug whilst others have claimed it has turned children into "monsters" or "zombies". Mark Oliver examines today's move, which will define who should be prescribed the drug.
fields.trailText: A government drug watchdog responded today to fears over the use of the drug Ritalin, used to calm hyperactive children. For some, it's a wonder drug whilst others have claimed it has turned children into "monsters" or "zombies". Mark Oliver examines today's move, which will define who should be prescribed the drug.
fields.body:
What is Ritalin used to treat?
Attention deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD), which causes severe impulsive, restless and inattentive behaviour and can make children aggressive and disturbed. Young sufferers often fail at school and are even suspended or expelled because of their uncontrollable actions. Around 3% of the population, mainly children, have ADHD or attention deficit disorder (ADD). The incidence of cases has increased threefold between 1991 and 1995, with the trend still rising.


What is Ritalin?
Ritalin is a stimulant, chemically similar to cocaine or amphetamines like speed but, surprisingly, works by actually calming sufferers down. It is a class B drug and its chemical name is methylphenidate hydrochloride.


How widely is Ritalin used?
Last year, 157,000 prescriptions were written for Ritalin, mainly for children. It has been around for 50 years but its use rose dramatically during the nineties with prescriptions doubling every year until 1999. Prescriptions have levelled off but are still rising overall.


Does Ritalin work?
Some parents say their children's lives have been transformed for the better by the drug. However, others claim that Ritalin has turned their youngsters into "monsters" or "zombies", claiming it is used like "a chemical cosh" to make hyperactive children docile, leaving them staring into space and dreamy. Parents in the US are taking legal action against Ritalin manufacturers, Novartis Pharmaceuticals, alleging that the company failed to warn about its possible impact on children's cardiovascular and nervous systems. Here, there have also been allegations of over-prescription of Ritalin, with huge increases in the number of children diagnosed with ADHD and put on psychoactive drugs. Campaigners are concerned that the UK is going the way of the US, where four million children are taking Ritalin. There are claims that some UK doctors are now dishing the pills out "like smarties". The US author, Elizabeth Wurtzel, who wrote Prozac Nation, told earlier this year how she became addicted to Ritalin, chopping up and snorting up to 40 tablets a day.

What are the government doing?
The NHS's "best practice" watchdog is to issue guidelines advising caution on its use for very young children. There are concerns that the use of the medication can mask emotional or other causes of troubled behaviour. Psychiatrists have warned that toddler tantrums, for example, may be confused with more serious disorders. The National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice) was setting out advice today on who should be prescribed the drug. Nice is expected to recommend that Ritalin should not be given to under-fives. Although older children may continue to receive it, there will be clearer definitions of the conditions for which it can be beneficial as part of a specialist treatment programme. The move is a bid to end the "postcode lottery" where patients in some parts of the country have access to the drug and others are denied it. The body is also expected to give a clearer definition of exactly who can benefit from it. Ministers, manufacturers and patients have had a few weeks to challenge the findings before today. The guidelines will cover England and Wales.

Will everyone welcome this development?
No. Gill Mead, of ADHD Support for Families, said parents of younger children would be "disappointed" if they were refused medication. She said: "Most parents start coming to us when their children first enter social situations - nursery school. The touch-paper is ignited, the minute you put them into situations that trigger anxiety. "Some parents are very anti-medication. I can recall a sad case of two head teachers with a son diagnosed with ADHD. They said, 'We don't need medication and we don't need to pump our son full of drugs' - they came back to me and said they wished they had tried drug treatment because he is now up for grievous bodily harm." Ms Mead firmly believes that Ritalin works, "not only for the child but for the parents, who are given enough of a breathing space from troubled behaviour to assist the family to maintain the love for that child".

Caroline Hensby, a mother-of-three from Thanet, Kent, has a teenage son with ADHD and last year she was diagnosed with ADD at the age of 37. She believes Ritalin has helped both her and her son Richard. She said: "There have been a lot of scare stories about Ritalin but it has helped thousands and thousands of children and adults. I used to lose my temper and just explode. "Now I can recognise a situation where that might happen, focus and stop myself from exploding. There are but these are also controversial. In the US, the family of a man who shot dead his baby daughter and tried to kill himself is suing a British drug company which produced the ADHD drug Adderall. Ryan Ehlis, 26, from North Dakota, in the US, was acquitted of the murder of his five-week-old daughter Tyra. A spokeswoman for Shire Pharmaceuticals said: "The safety profile for Adderall is extremely good. Novartis say its drug is a mild stimulant with no association to violent behaviour. "But some children, and probably some adults, with ADHD suffer from other conditions which may make their management more complex," it said in a statement.

fields.bodyText: What is Ritalin used to treat? fields.headline: BBC online ads plan sparks rivals' fury
fields.standfirst:
Small but welcome say advertisers
BBC Online: what you need to know
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The BBC was today plunged into a storm after director general Greg Dyke declared he was considering putting adverts on its online service, writes Amy Vickers.
Small but welcome say advertisers
BBC Online: what you need to know
fields.body:
The BBC was today plunged into a storm after director general Greg Dyke declared he was considering putting adverts on its online service.

The move was branded "a total scandal" by commercial rivals who claim it is an abuse of the corporation's public service status.

Emap Online managing director Roger Green said: "It is a complete disgrace to use licence payers money to compete with commercial publishers. If Greg needed the shortfall. He should spend less on irrelevant online publishing activities such as the gardening website."

The BBC's rivals believe it is outrageous that the service, which costs £23m of licence payers money, should now be allowed compete for advertising revenue.

One online sales executive said: "This is too horrific to contemplate. A move like this will even kill off Freeserve. It will sweep up whatever little advertising is in the marketplace."

Advertising on the BBC's online service has been mooted before but the move has always been thwarted by opponents who say it is an abuse of the BBC's public service status.

But advertising bosses today welcomed the move. They have long lobbied for the corporation to be opened up to commercials and they see this as a first step towards getting ad breaks on BBC1 and BBC2.

Bob Wooton, director of media and advertising affairs at the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, said: "This is not surprising, it's a question that has been asked with increasingly regularity.

"We advocate a mixed economy funding of the BBC and this is a small step in the way we are seeking. The money at stake is buttons."

BBC Online is widely considered one of the best services in the UK and is one of the top 10 internet sites in the country.

Last year's government-ordered report on the BBC by economist Gavyn Davies recommended that BBC Online should look at taking advertising on international services.But it stopped short of recommending full-blown ad sales across all BBC Onlione's activities.

In an interview in today's Financial Times, Mr Dyke made it clear that he is exploring the possibility of adverts on the domestic services.

Mr Dyke said that BBC News and BBC Education sites would remain free and without adverts.

But he admitted that BBC strategists were looking at finding a way of persuading the public and politicians that advertising was a way of boosting the BBC's revenue on other sites such as those dedicated to hit shows like EastEnders or The Human Body which attract a huge number of users.

He said they were looking at "what are the commercial opportunities and what are the public service obligations".

On the question of advertising on BBC Online, Mr Dyke said: "There are commercial opportunities, but how big they are and how much they are worth - that is what we are looking at."

Emap's Roger Green said he would be happy to compete with the BBC as long as it was on a equal footing. He said it would be acceptable if the BBC was banned from using the licence fee to fund the online service.

A spokesman for the BBC insisted the corporation was only "bouncing around" the idea of Online adverts.

He said: "The BBC has been charged with maximising revenues . We've been given tough targets of internal savings and generating commercial revenues of some £1bn over the next seven years, as part of its licence fee settlement. You'd expect the BBC to explore all options to bring more public service programmes to viewers and listeners - some may come to fruition, some may not."

webTitle: Give us BBC cash says Sky

fields.headline: Give us BBC cash says Sky
fields.trailText: 12pm BSkyB today unveiled a campaign to thwart the BBC's plans to launch new TV channels including new children's networks, writes Jason Deans reports.
fields.body:
BSkyB today unveiled a new campaign to thwart the BBC's plans to launch TV channels including new children's networks.

BSkyB wants new rules that will give it a slice of licence payers' money for its own channels.

Sky's director of public affairs, Ray Gallagher, said the money the BBC was planning to spend on its new services - BBC3, BBC4 and two children's networks - should be ploughed into a new public service "fund" available to all.

The fund would be ringfenced from the BBC but the corporation and other organisations could pitch for it, he said at today's Royal Television Society autumn symposium.

Mr Gallagher argued that the BBC's recently revised licence fee settlement, which will deliver hundreds of millions of pounds in extra funding up to 2006, should be split into two pools, for core BBC services and new digital offerings.

The latter money should form the new public service fund, which could be used to finance new arts or children's services.

Mr Gallagher added that the BBC had been awarded the extra money for new services by the government, without setting out specifically what those services would be.

Mr Gallagher said: "Much of what passes for debate about public service broadcasting is not about what's best for the public, but what's best for public service broadcasters. Market failure must be the fundamental test of what public resources should be allocated to public service broadcasting."

Granada TV bosses also had their begging bowls out today.

Granada Media chief executive Steve Morrison agreed with the idea of a public service fund for new digital services that any TV company could bid for. But he said this fund should come from new money, and should not be taken from the existing BBC licence fee.

Mark Thompson, BBC director of television, countered, saying the suggestions were simply non-starters. He said the issue of the BBC's funding until 2006 had already been dealt with by the Davies Committee.

"In our view the licence fee settlement and the broad picture the Davies Committee drew about the BBC's role in public service broadcasting until 2006 was the right one," he added.

But Mr Thompson said that the BBC was open to discussing partnerships as a way of delivering new digital public services.

Channel 4 chief executive Michael Jackson also questioned the idea of a public service fund. He said: "It does have a very seductive logic. My worry is that it's a way of dissipating something which is very powerful."

fields.headline: Marketeers make too much of the net, survey warns
fields.trailText: 1pm: The Chartered Institute of Marketing has warned that marketeers may be storing up trouble by investing too heavily in the internet. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Chartered Institute of Marketing has warned that marketeers may be storing up trouble by investing too heavily in the internet at the expense of more traditional communications.

The warning came as the CIM published its latest Marketing Trends Survey, revealing that marketeers are planning huge increases in internet spending. But growth in other marketing areas, including PR and sales promotion, will drop as a result.

The CIM's director of marketing, Ray Perry, said: "The internet is the biggest issue facing marketeers, and the profession is showing the determination to deal with it effectively.

"But by continuing to invest heavily in their online capabilities, marketeers may be failing to resource their other activities adequately.

"Companies must understand that marketeers need additional financial resources to tackle the internet - simply diverting money away from other activities is not a constructive activity."

The survey, which is published quarterly, revealed that marketeers are feeling more confident than at any time since July 1995.

As a result, the number of people employed in marketing is set to rise with 23% of firms saying they planned to take on more people and only 10% planning to cut their staffing levels.

fields.headline: Halloween
fields.standfirst: The pumpkin industry gets its annual cash injection today and budding Ghostbusters get to try out their skills. Here's our lowdown on that night when the occult does its bit for the national economy, Halloween
fields.trailText: The pumpkin industry gets its annual cash injection today and budding Ghostbusters get to try out their skills. Here's our lowdown on that night when the occult does its bit for the national economy, Halloween.
fields.body:
1. Halloween - more correctly Hallow E'en, is an ancient festival rooted in Celtic lore, though some claim a Greek connection.

2. In its modern form, it is a tribute to America's unhealthy obsession with the paranormal, and a homage to the greatest god of our time: money.

3. Those who have harmless fun at Halloween are mostly nominal or practising Christians. However, some Christians hate it, in a mildly dotty or thoroughly demented sort of way.

4. The urban myths surrounding Halloween were well summarised by Jeffrey Victor in his marvellously titled work Satanic Panic.

5. This fundamentalist gobbledygook is distressing to witches and atheists. Druids are not best pleased either.

6. Halloween is now essentially a US festival, reimported to the British Isles. Americans invented the pumpkin lantern, for example, and the "trick or treat" custom, known in northern England as "mischief night".

7. In Scotland, the tradition of kids dressing up is known as "guising". Until recently, the custom was for children to go from door to door, offering to sing or recite a poem in return for a small offering of sweets or nuts or whatever. Money did not change hands, and there was no alternative to a "trick".

8. Now, in our enterprise economy, it's all about cash.

9. The traditional lantern in Britain and Ireland is made not from a pumpkin, but a turnip. But pumpkins, it must be said, are nicer to eat.

10. Lamp-carrying is based on the particularly naff legend of Jack-O'-Lantern.

webTitle: Izzard and Bogdanovich bank on Chaplin for career boost

fields.headline: Izzard and Bogdanovich bank on Chaplin for career boost
fields.trailText: After a string of flops each, comedian Eddie Izzard and director Peter Bogdanovich are hoping for career resurrection with their new Chaplin film
fields.body:
He failed to set the screen alight in the Brighton-set gangster flick Circus, and his presence didn't save Mystery Men and The Avengers from flopdom, but Eddie Izzard must be doing something right.

The comedian is to take the lead role in a new Lions Gate films production about Charlie Chaplin, called The Cat's Meow, with Peter Bogdanovich directing.

This will be Bogdanovich's first cinema project since 1993's The Thing Called Love, the last film completed by the late River Phoenix. The director had been one of Hollywood's most successful players in the 70s, with films such as The Last Picture Show and Paper Moon bringing widespread acclaim. But his personal life became mired in scandal, his golden touch failed him, and he was declared bankrupt in the 80s.

The 20s-set story will centre on a lavish birthday party on media tycoon William Randolph Hearst's yacht, where Chaplin met Hearst's young mistress Marion Davies (to be played by up-and-coming actress Kirsten Dunst), who later became the actor's lover. Filming on the £25m production is due to begin next month, in Germany and Greece.

The lead role is a huge step forward for Izzard's film career. An associate told PA news: "Eddie isn't leaving the world of comedy altogether but he loves working in the movie business. He sees this as his biggest part yet. He is completely over the moon."

The Chaplin project is the second film about the immortal comic in a decade, after Richard Attenborough's weighty Chaplin in 1992. On that occasion the central role was taken by Robert Downey Jr, who scooped an Oscar nomination before sliding into a vortex of drug addiction, rehab and jail. Izzard, no doubt, will be hoping to avoid a similar fate.

 More info on Izzard fan site Cake or Death.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: Has Sven Goran Eriksson's appointment as England's first ever foreign coach resulted in angry letters in red biro to the Way You See It? Come on man, this is the Guardian! That said, not everybody is happy with the prospect of a Swede managing the national team.
fields.body:
Has Sven Goran Eriksson's appointment as England's first ever foreign coach resulted in angry letters in red biro to the Way You See It? Come on man, this is the Guardian! That said, not everybody is happy with the prospect of a Swede managing the national team.

"All I can say is I feel incredibly disappointed and let down that short - sighted old farts lack the courage and balls to reinstate Terry Venables," writes Lawrence 'PISSED OFF' Jones. "This will be remembered as black Tuesday for England fans. The FA twats who probably never kicked a ball in their lives clearly need sacking. Thanks for nothing."

"Nothing personal against Eriksson, but we are not a third rate country with third rate players," he continues, in a slightly less 'PISSED OFF' fashion, before returning his fire onto the FA. "We have both the players and coach, so what's the problem?" he asks. "Football is all about the fans - but once again the F(*cking) .A(rrogant) bastards insult and ignore us again. Thanks for nothing."

But Lawrence is not the only one who is angry. "We've sold out to all we once knew as english," cries Zee Bacchus. "And I do not apologise for spelling "english" without a capital "E" - that is how it should be spelt in future, if a Swede coaches england."

Meanwhile a much more coherent argument comes from Simon Morehen. "Didn't David Davies himself say that the FA are looking for a coach with integrity?" he points out. "How does he square this with Sven Goran Eriksson reneging on his agreement to coach Blackburn?"

The clear majority of our readers, however, seem to support Eriksson's appointment. "As much as it hurts to admit to being a second class footballing nation a foreign coach could well be the answer," reckons Richard Lowes.

"His non-domestic impartiality and experience in handling the biggest egos in world football could stand Eriksson in good stead. And seeing some players for perhaps the first time will perhaps be a bonus towards his first squad selection. Not having been immersed in the Phillips/Cole/Heskey debate - among others - will enable him to bring a fresh perspective.

"As long as the FA does not stop here and continue with this new approach the (distant) future could be rosy for us," he adds.

And Matthew Willis agrees, although he wants to know why the choice of a foreign manager has become inevitable. "Personally, I don't find it an insult to my pride, as so many narrow minded xenophobes have stupidly suggested that England are about to have a foreign coach," he says. "But the point I'm interested in, which doesn't seem to have been discussed greatly, is why there is such a shortage of English candidates? Or, put another way, why are English footballers so bloody stupid?"

"The answer to this would seem to me to be the culture of English football, which has traditionally removed anyone capable of kicking a ball from the normal system of education. It doesn't seem to be the same with foreign footballers - looking at all of the fluent English speaking players in the Premiership, the majority are foreign.

"If English football is to be self-reliant ever again, the system needs to start putting more emphasis on education and basic literacy."

"We have both the players and coach, so what's the problem?" he asks. "Football is all about the fans - but once again the F(*cking) .A(rrogant) bastards insult and ignore us again. Thanks for nothing." But Lawrence is not the only one who is angry. "We've sold out to all we once knew as english," cries Zee Bacchus. "And I do not apologise for spelling "english" without a capital "E" - that is how it should be spelt in future, if a Swede coaches england." Meanwhile a much more coherent argument comes from Simon Morehen. "Didn't David Davies himself say that the FA are looking for a coach with integrity?" he points out. "How does he square this with Sven Goran Eriksson reneging on his agreement to coach Blackburn?" The clear majority of our readers, however, seem to support Eriksson's appointment. "As much as it hurts to admit to being a second class footballing nation a foreign coach could well be the answer," reckons Richard Lowes. "His non-domestic impartiality and experience in handling the biggest egos in world football could stand Eriksson in good stead. And seeing some players for perhaps the first time will perhaps be a bonus towards his first squad selection. Not having been immersed in the Phillips/Cole/Heskey debate - among others - will enable him to bring a fresh perspective. "As long as the FA does not stop here and continue with this new approach the (distant) future could be rosy for us," he adds. And Matthew Willis agrees, although he wants to know why the choice of a foreign manager has become inevitable. "Personally, I don't find it an insult to my pride, as so many narrow minded xenophobes have stupidly suggested that England are about to have a foreign coach," he says. "But the point I'm interested in, which doesn't seem to have been discussed greatly, is why there is such a shortage of English candidates? Or, put another way, why are English footballers so bloody stupid?" "The answer to this would seem to me to be the culture of English football, which has traditionally removed anyone capable of kicking a ball from the normal system of education. It doesn't seem to be the same with foreign footballers - looking at all of the fluent English speaking players in the Premiership, the majority are foreign. "If English football is to be self-reliant ever again, the system needs to start putting more emphasis on education and basic literacy."

fields.headline: Debt  clouds Deutsche Telecom profits rise
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Deutsche Telekom, the debt-laden owner of the One2One mobile phone network, is counting the cost of an aggressive chase for customers. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
German Telecoms giant Deutsche Telekom, the debt-laden owner of the One2One mobile phone network, is counting the cost of an aggressive chase for customers.

The company increased profits by an astonishing 500% with third quarter profits of E8.4bn (£4.74bn), against E1.3bn (£750m) for the same period last year. Revenues were E29.3bn (£17bn), up from E25.6bn (£14.8bn).

However, the figures were boosted by a mammoth £6.2bn windfall from the sale of Deutsche's stake in the Global One corporate communications network and the flotation of its T-Online internet arm.

The results were weighed down by the cost of building the company's customer base at its T-Mobile cellphone subsidiary.

Analysts said Deutsche has been forced to bolster its mobile phone arm due to pressure on its fixed line business from Mannesmann, which was snapped up by Vodafone of the UK this year.

Deutsche has splashed out £9.2bn on mobile phone licences in the UK, the Netherlands and Germany this year, raising concerns that European telecoms companies are building up too much debt in an attempt to dominate the mobile phone market.

The company is now in the black to the tune of £36bn, causing Deutsche's credit ratings to be slashed earlier this month.

British Telecom is already committed to shaving £10bn off its £28bn debt burden by the end of next year, with the flotation of its wireless division the most likely option.

Deutsche's shares tumbled 3.5% to 2396p in Frankfurt this morning, down from their March high of 6091p. Analysts say the company's trump card is its position as the leading telecoms player in Germany, which remains the Eurozone's strongest economy.

fields.headline: Kingfisher snaps up Streets Online stake
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Kingfisher is buying an 85% stake in Streets Online, a leading UK online entertainment retailer, for £15.7m, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Retail giant Kingfisher is buying an 85% stake in Streets Online, a leading UK online entertainment retailer, for £15.7m.

The move is aimed at strengthening Kingfisher's MVC entertainment retail business, which operates 87 stores throughout the UK.

The remaining 15% stake is owned by BSkyB, which invested in the company earlier this year. Streets Online is the preferred books and music retailer on Sky.com.

Freeserve, which sold its 15% stake in Streets Online to Kingfisher as part of the deal, also announced that it was extending its existing commercial arrangement with Kingfisher.

Kingfisher will now distribute Freeserve's CDs in its MVC stores in return for Freeserve giving Kingfisher's retail brands significant ad space across its network. Kingfisher's health and beauty retailer, Superdrug.com, continues to work with Freeserve on the development of a health channel.

Freeserve said its long-term commercial arrangements with Streets Online could only be enhanced by the online retailer's new ownership structure, which is expected to be completed in mid-December.

Streets Online will become part of the new General Merchandise company, which will receive a substantial share of the online market following the deal. Freeserve will receive £2.6m in cash for its 15% stake.

Stephen Cole, managing director of Streets Online, said: "Bricks and clicks working together has always been important for us. Kingfisher is very entertainment-led, and the deal gives us access to new users."

The Streets Online brand and management team will remain in place.

Kingfisher's general merchandise retail brands comprise Woolworths, Superdrug and MVC. Streets Online began life in 1996 and operates Audiostreet (music), DVDstreet (DVD), Gamesstreet (games) and Alphabetstreet (books). It has now cancelled plans for a flotation.

webTitle: Rocket launch heralds international space cooperation

fields.headline: Rocket launch heralds international space cooperation
fields.standfirst: Graphic: the space station
fields.trailText: A Russian rocket carrying the first residents of the international space station blasted off today from Kazakhstan on a mission that Nasa hopes will lead to the permanent occupancy of space.
fields.body:
A Russian rocket carrying the first residents of the international space station blasted off today from Kazakhstan on a mission that Nasa hopes will lead to the permanent occupancy of space.

Nasa astronaut Bill Shepherd, the space station's first commander, became only the second American to be launched aboard a Russian rocket.

He was strapped into the snug Soyuz capsule along with cosmonauts Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev. "Let's go do it," Shepherd shouted before boarding the rocket.

Nasa sent about 100 employees to the Russian space program's Baikonur cosmodrome in central Asia to witness the launch.

The 17-story Soyuz rocket soared into a desert fog from the same launch pad where the space age began 43 years ago this month with the very first space rocket.

"It's history again repeating itself - in a different way," said Joe Rochenberg, head of Nasa's human space flight program. The space station was zooming over the Sahara when Mr Shepherd and his crew took off on their delayed journey. They will reach their new home on Thursday and settle in for a four-month stay.

The rocket was visible for only three seconds because of the thick fog. Its brightly burning engines could be seen several seconds later as the rocket gained speed and altitude.

Nine minutes later, Shepherd and his crew were safely in orbit, prompting tears and applause from the crowd of more than 500.

Nasa Administrator Daniel Goldin and top Russian space officials celebrated with Scotch whiskey.

"It's a wonderful day, not for America, not for Russia, but for the people who live on this planet," Mr Goldin said.

"There are so many people who felt maybe we couldn't do it. But it's happening, period. It's here. We're going to be in space forever with people who are circling this globe and then we're going on to Mars, back to the moon, and with bases on asteroids."

Sixteen countries are participating in the $60bn-plus [£41bn+] project, widely considered to be the largest technological enterprise ever undertaken on a global scale.

It is America's first space station since the 1970s Skylab and, unlike that early orbiting outpost, holds the promise of people living continuously in space.

It's also the culmination of the space station proposed by the former US president, Ronald Reagan, in 1984.

However, the space station, parts of which have been in orbit for two years, is far from perfect. Shepherd said: "It needs to be the model for how human beings work in space, to enable going back to the moon and other expeditions farther than Earth."

Shepherd and his crew have been training for Nasa's so-called Expedition One mission for nearly five years.

The three men will turn on all the life-support systems once they arrive at the 240-mile [384-kilometre] high outpost and start tackling all the maintenance and repair work.

Nasa hopes to finish building the space station in 2006 and to operate it as a first-class laboratory until at least 2016 and hopefully long beyond.

Mr Krikalev and Mr Gidzenko, both veterans of Russia's Mir space station, have considerably more space experience than Shepherd even though they're a decade younger.

Among the Russians, there has been some bad feeling at the nationality of the commander but Nasa were adamant, however, that it should be an American and that that astronaut be Shepherd.

Shepherd, an astronaut since 1984, flew on three space shuttle flights before moving into space station management in 1993, the same year Russia joined the international space station project; his longest, and most recent, space mission lasted 10 days back in 1992.

Space shuttle Discovery is supposed to drop off a replacement crew and bring the first crew back at the end of February next year.

fields.headline: Hindujas submit Express bid
fields.trailText: 1.30pm update: The Hinduja brothers have made a formal bid for Express Newspapers valued at an estimated £120m plus. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The Hinduja brothers made a formal bid for Express Newspapers at 6pm today, valued at an estimated £120m and designed to blow the Daily Mail's bid out of the water.

A source close to the Hinduja group confirmed an "aggressive" bid had been mounted following yesterday's dramatic offer to rescue the ailing titles by the newspaper's arch-rival the Daily Mail.

"We are not disclosing our price, but the understanding is that the Daily Mail bid is around £120m and our offer has been set accordingly.

"Our bid is very aggressive," said the source.

The company believes it can offer a serious alternative to the Mail which today claimed it would protect the editorial independence of the paper with a separate board.

It is understood the Hinduja's bid has been made with a management team recruited from national titles already waiting in the wings.

A source close to the company said the brothers had been approached by a team of highly experienced personnel put together by as-yet-unnamed national newspaper executives.

"They are not from a single publication, but everyone will recognise the names," said the source.

The source added: "The Hindujas are prepared to enter into a negotiating process with United, and feel sure that the company's shareholders would prefer a bid that is not tied up in regulatory demands."

The bidding war for the Express was sparked in September when the Barclay brothers, owners of the Scotsman, submitted a bid for the papers. That bid, believed to be in the region of £75m, was withdrawn last week.

Other potential bidders, including Daily Telegraph owner Conrad Black and former Mirror chief executive David Montgomery, have yet to play their hands.

If accepted, DMGT's bid will immediately be referred to the Department of Trade & Industry's competition commission, as the combined circulation of the groups' newspapers would exceed 500,000.

The London-based Hinduja brothers, who run oil, banking and cable TV companies in Europe and India, will not be subjected to regulatory scrutiny as they do not own any UK newspapers.

Meanwhile, industry sources today claimed that Express Newspapers may barely break even when revenue from the West Ferry print operation, a joint venture with the Daily Telegraph, is stripped out of its revenue figures.

DTI regulations allow a newspaper to bypass the regulatory minefield if it can prove that its acquisition target is in dire financial straits. The Daily Telegraph has an arrangement with its business partner that allows it to buy the other 50% of the West Ferry plant should the Express be bought.

Conrad Black is expected to make a bid for the Express titles through his Hollinger company. He was unavailable for comment this afternoon.

webTitle: BBC ad revenue small but welcome, say advertisers

fields.headline: BBC ad revenue small but welcome, say advertisers
fields.standfirst:
Fury at BBC online ad plan
BBC Online: what you need to know
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Jim Marshall of the IPA Institute of Practitioners in Advertising has described the BBC's decision to consider online ads as like being 'a little bit pregnant'. by Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Jim Marshall, chairman of media policy at the IPA Institute of Practitioners in Advertising has described the BBC's decision to consider online advertising as like being 'a little bit pregnant'.

He said the possibility of online advertising would make "bugger all difference to anyone - it's not an economy breaker".

Mr Marshall said that while TV advertising pulled in approximately £2bn in revenue per annum and sponsorship about £100m per annum, "to describe the impact of online advertising as a drop in the ocean would be flattering it".

The real issues, he said, should be in deciding the role of the BBC and to whom it was accountable. "At the moment its down to the governors, which is like the police investigating the police."

Bob Wooton, director of media and advertising affairs at the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, said he would also welcome ads on BBC online services.

He said: "The fact of the matter is that the online media industry is still tiny. Advertisers will welcome ads online but we're not all giving ourselves a hernia over it.

"The holy grail is TV and radio advertising - we want access to those audiences. We are the only country in the modern world where 40 per cent of TV audiences go straight into a black hole where advertisers cannot reach them.

"This is a very important change. The BBC won't be able to say 'we don't do that'. Now's it's a case of 'we hardly ever do that'"

fields.headline: BBC Online - what you need to know
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk's print-out-and-keep guide to BBC Online.
Fury at BBC online ads plan
Small but welcome say advertisers
fields.trailText: 12pm: MediaGuardian.co.uk's print-out-and-keep guide to BBC Online.
fields.body:
Q. What does it do?
A. BBC Online has over half a million pages of content covering just about everything you could ever want to know about, from music and sport to education and the arts. It is a rich package of news and information that doubles as a lifestyle site offering advice, entertainment listings and gossip. It also contains highly maintained interactive sites dedicated to the BBC's most popular programmes, including EastEnders and Changing Rooms.

Q. How long has it been around?
A. BBC Online launched in November 1997 as a collection of programme-related sites. In November 1999 it was relaunched in a new format under 20 different categories to make it easier for users to find their way around the site.

Q. How much money has the BBC invested so far?
A. About £90m of licence-payers money. BBC Online was launched with an initial investment of £30m and the corporation has since spent about £30m a year on the service. This represents about 1% of the total licence fee income - the equivalent of several years-worth of EastEnders.

Q. How much is it planning to spend?
A. The BBC is tight-lipped on this one, but given that it is continuing to expand it is reasonable to assume that investment will continue at the current levels at least. Last year's annual report shows it spent £32m on the site.

Q. How well is it doing?
A. Very well indeed. BBC Online is the most popular site in Britain and the most-visited non-portal website outside the US. In the UK it receives approximately 200m page impressions every month and latest figures give it a 25% reach in the UK, which means a quarter of the internet-using population of the UK visits the site.

Q. How many staff does it employ?
A. BBC Online employs 450 dedicated staff across the country, from designers to journalists to technical staff.

fields.headline: What the columnists say
fields.standfirst: A quick round-up of the papers finds that not everyone is happy with the impending appointment of Sven Goran Eriksson
fields.trailText:
"Bobby Robson was persecuted for his white hair; Glen Hoddle for his beliefs, Terry Venables for his business dealings, and Graham Taylor for just about everything. Welcome to the world's toughest job, Svennis,"
Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet
fields.body:
"Bobby Robson was persecuted for his white hair; Glen Hoddle for his beliefs, Terry Venables for his business dealings, and Graham Taylor for just about everything. Welcome to the world's toughest job, Svennis,"
Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet

"And so the nation which gave the game of football to the world has been forced to put a foreign coach in charge of its national team for the first time in its history. What a climb-down. What an admission of decline. What a humiliation. What a terrible, pathetic, self-inflicted indictment. What an awful mess."
John Sadler, The Sun

"It takes a brave man to cross the channel and step into the ruins of English football. But the truth is that England have entered the 21st century. From the route one football which failed under Graham TaylorEngland now have a man steeped in the modern, continental game."
John Dillon, The Mirror

"Eriksson has a track record of success nobody can argue with. He boasts championship successes in three countries - Sweden, Portugal and Italy - the ability to handle big-name players with attendant reputations and respect from even the most demanding of audiences. Alas, he has one other trait - his ability to change his mind on a whim."
Martin Lipton, Daily Mail

"Those who follow England, and those who report on the national team's every blip and blunder, have to accept that the best coaches are overwhelmingly foreign. If we can't beat them, sign one up to help us. English football needs to enter the modern world, to join the Continental drift."
Henry Winter, The Telegraph

"A championship winning coach in three countries, polyglot and citizen of Europe, Sven Goran Eriksson is the very model of a modern football major-general. In Italy he has had his critics - who in Italian football has not? - but most were silenced last May when he delivered the Serie A title to Lazio after a 26-year wait."
Steve Tongue, The Independent

Martin Lipton, Daily Mail "Those who follow England, and those who report on the national team's every blip and blunder, have to accept that the best coaches are overwhelmingly foreign. If we can't beat them, sign one up to help us. English football needs to enter the modern world, to join the Continental drift." Henry Winter, The Telegraph "A championship winning coach in three countries, polyglot and citizen of Europe, Sven Goran Eriksson is the very model of a modern football major-general. In Italy he has had his critics - who in Italian football has not? - but most were silenced last May when he delivered the Serie A title to Lazio after a 26-year wait." Steve Tongue, The Independent  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk.

webTitle: Flynn diary goes under the hammer

fields.headline: Flynn diary goes under the hammer
fields.trailText: Errol Flynn's previously unpublished diary is to be auctioned along with other Flynn memorabilia in Los Angeles next month
fields.body:
Errol Flynn's previously unpublished diary is to be auctioned along with other Flynn memorabilia in Los Angeles next month.

Written in pencil in 1937, when the 32-year-old actor made a mysterious visit to the front line of the Spanish Civil War, the diary has been put on sale by his daughter Dierdre.

The leather-bound diary, expected to fetch more than $6,000 (about £4,200), illustrates Flynn's reputation for an adventurous life. "Flynn comes off with apparent courage, style, humour, a lot like his screen persona, but somehow even more interesting, and compelling," writes auction house Christie's in the accompanying catalogue.

In one excerpt, the actor describes riding first class on a bullet-riddled train. "Everyone is armed - some with large knives plus revolvers, but all with revolvers. The train is stopped. A plane has been heard - we are crowded with young loyalists all armed and with oddest assortment of uniforms."

Flynn, who died of a heart attack in 1959, has always been the subject of controversy. He was reviled as a Nazi sympathiser and undercover agent in Charles Higham's 1980 biography Errol Flynn: The Untold Story, a book which also reported that Flynn was bisexual.

Yet his diary suggests an altogether different allegiance: revealing that the actor addressed a group of communists in Spain and was saluted by them. Furthermore, Flynn's last film project was a semi-documentary tribute to Fidel Castro which he also wrote, narrated and co-produced.

Deirdre Flynn is also offering nine autographed letters and one heavily inscribed photo of her father at the November 15 Christie's Film, Pop and Posters auction in Los Angeles.

webTitle: Watchdog seeks stricter controls on animal feed

fields.headline: Watchdog seeks stricter controls on animal feed
fields.trailText: The government's food watchdog has today called for a ban on meat and bone meal in animal feed as part of a series of measures to prevent a repeat of the BSE crisis.
fields.body:
The government's food watchdog has today called for a ban on meat and bone meal in animal feed as part of a series of measures to prevent a repeat of the BSE crisis.

It would mean extending the current ban on feeding recycled remains to cattle, sheep and goats to all other animals, including poultry and fish.

Blood, poultry offal meat, feather meal and tallow are still legally permitted by-products which can be used to feed farm animals.

A report from the food standards agency (FSA) says that "intra-species recycling" - a euphemism for cannibalism - could theoretically amplify a new spongiform encephalopathy disease such as BSE.

It also advises ministers to reject calls from farmers to allow meat and bone meal to be fed to poultry. The report suggests that recycling animal blood, gelatine and tallow in animal feed be stopped.

The recommendations are contained in a draft review of the current BSE controls.

"The evidence is that the current UK controls, which are based on the precautionary approach, are working. But, because of so much uncertainty, the review suggests that current controls be retained and in some areas tightened," said FSA chairman Sir John Krebs.

Supermarket firm Co-op called for a Europe-wide ban on the feeding of animal waste to farm animals claiming that consumers find the practice "abhorrent".

"This type of feeding practice is tantamount to cannibalism and must be stamped out if governments want to eliminate potential safety risks and restore consumer confidence in meat," said a spokeswoman.

At the height of the BSE crisis, the last government banned the feeding of mammalian meat and bone meal to cattle but stopped short of outlawing all animal by-products.

webTitle: A selection of the best books for children about food

fields.headline: Feeding frenzy
fields.trailText: A small girl of my acquaintance insists on eating cornflakes without milk, flake by flake. It's a complicated thing, eating, but there are some wonderful books on the subject that might - just possibly - help
fields.body:
A small girl of my acquaintance insists on eating cornflakes without milk, flake by flake. It's a complicated thing, eating, but there are some wonderful books on the subject that might - just possibly - help.

Eat Your Peas, by Kes Gray and Nick Sharratt (Bodley Head, £9.99)
This will strike a chord in any desperate parent's heart. Daisy just won't eat her peas, even when Mum (check out Mum's necklace) offers her 92 chocolate factories, the moon, the stars, the sun - and a new fluffy pencil case. How to resolve the problem? There's a splendidly non-didactic ending and a strong bid by Daisy for a touch of common sense. It's also great fun as a counting book - double value for the money!

How to be a Practically Perfect Pig, by Nick Ward (Scholastic, £4.99)

This was a massive hit with every one of my testers. There's a neat touch of reverse psychology here: the two-, three- and four-year-olds suddenly turned amazingly virtuous when confronted with the anarchic goings on in the pig household, and claimed that they never gobbled down their food. (Time will tell if the effect is permanent.) The illustrations are stuffed with the tiny details that small readers love, and there's plenty to amuse adults too.

The Last Chocolate Biscuit, by Jamie Rix (Walker, £4.99)
It's rare to find a fresh new take on the vexed question of table manners, but Rix has managed it with this gloriously daft romp of a story along with an hilarious set of pictures by the irrepressible Arthur Robins. It's marvellous to read out loud, and it's also quite possible for a non-reader to study the pictures and make a pretty fair guess at everything that's going on, as Maurice does exactly as he is told and offers the last chocolate biscuit to everyone - even Maurice Monster in outer space. Fortunately space monsters have to mind their manners too, and Maurice gets home again ... to find a final twist in the tale. Hugely entertaining all round.

Wow! It's great being a duck, by Joan Rankin (Red Fox, £4.99)
This deals with the problem of being a dinner rather than eating one. Lillee is the smallest of all the ducks, and - typical of a youngest sibling - wants to be different. Off to the forest she goes, and at every excursion she is encouraged to eat a little more and grow a little fatter by Mr Furry-legs-Long-tail-Sharp-snout-Pink-tongue, until ... until what? Read it and find out. Like the illustrations, the words are both delicate and subtle ... there's a real Beatrix Potter quality to this story. "She glared at his furry legs. She studied his LONG TAIL. She observed his sharp snout." It's also beautifully designed ... a lovely, lovely book.

Growing Good, by Bernard Ashley (Bloomsbury, £4.99)
If you want to know where food comes from, try this. Illustrated in luminous glowing colours by Anne Wilson, it's a real celebration of a book - a factory is knocked down, and the wasteland is taken over by the neighbours to grow all kinds of fruit and veg and flowers, despite Mr Tott's hopes for a car park. The words alone sound good enough to eat: "Onion and okra and sorrel and spinach. Potatoes, pumpkin and poppies."

Goldilocks and the Three Bears, by Tony Mitton (Walker, £3.99)
The children's favourite has never looked as jolly as this. Mitton's catchy rhyming text rattles the story along, while Liz Million's bright and breezy illustrations bounce off the page. There are flip-flap pages for extra fun, and a dog and a duck to keep Goldilocks company. Even the tiniest of my testers adored every page and shouted "Again!" every time I finished the story ... and then ate every mouthful of her breakfast.

fields.headline: Stewart and Lara implicated
fields.trailText:
Sunday October 1
At the request of the players involved, the PCB puts back its deadline for appeals against fines meted out in the Qayyum Report to October 20th.
fields.body:
Sunday October 1
At the request of the players involved, the PCB puts back its deadline for appeals against fines meted out in the Qayyum Report to October 20th.

Monday October 2
The King Commission inquiry, due to reconvene today, is postponed for approximately a week to allow state prosecutor Shamila Batohi to sift through evidence acquired during her recent trip to India.

Salim Malik meets the chairman of the PCB, Lt. Gen. Tauqir Zia, in a bid to reverse the life ban given him in the Qayyum Report.

Tuesday October 3
In his annual report, New Zealand Cricket chairman Sir John Anderson confirms that a Corruption Commission is to be set up. "It saddens me and all cricket supporters that this blight of corruption has been discovered in our game. The positive in this issue is the vigour with which cricket administrations world-wide are pursuing the truth."

Wednesday October 4
Shamila Batohi announces that the King Commission will not now resume until November. "As a result of our deliberations in India it has necessitated us taking steps to acquire certain documentation from India." The Commission was originally scheduled to resume on October 2.

Thursday October 5
News from India suggests that the publication of the interim report on match-fixing by the Central Bureau of Investigation, which has already been delayed, will again be held up. The report, it is alleged, has been given the green light by the CBI's legal department and will contain the names of four Indian stars.

Friday October 6
Former South African president Nelson Mandela is reported to have had "stern words" with Cronje when they met. Cronje invited the international hero to his home and Mandela is said to have told him he should have confessed all when the allegations surfaced in April, but he now must turn "tragedy into triumph".

Saturday October 7
South Africa's new captain Shaun Pollock says his team have signed an honesty pledge in an attempt to remove the stain of scandal from cricket in his country.

Mihir Bose in the Daily Telegraph reports on how the long-awaited resumption of South Africa's King Commission has been indefinitely postponed and may not resume until December, if at all. Bose says a highly-placed source has told him that the Commission has been unable to secure copies of the tapes from Delhi police.

Monday October 9
PCB chairman Lt Gen Tauqir Zia announces his country is to investigate allegations of betting, gambling and match-fixing in last year's World Cup in England. Claims of biased umpiring by Javed Akhtar during South Africa's tour of England in 1998 will also form part of the inquiry. Zia claims there has been no external pressure to investigate, saying: "The PCB has requested this new probe for its own satisfaction and to clear the players once and for all."

Wednesday October 11
Cronje is banned for life by the UCBSA after he admitted to the King Commission that he had accepted money from bookmakers and had offered cash to team-mates to under-perform.

Australia captain Steve Waugh says Cronje must accept the ban: "I think people are getting sick of it all but the good thing is the administration is doing something about it by giving punishment. He admitted he did a lot of things wrong and he has to take the punishment."

Thursday October 12
ICC president Malcolm Gray welcomes Pakistan's move to look at the 1999 World Cup, but former captain Imran Khan slams the decision. He says: "Without evidence it makes no sense to me and it will be an attempt to tinker with the players ahead of an important home series with England. I don't subscribe to the point of view that Pakistan played any fixed matches."

Sunday October 15
The Independent's Derek Pringle says Wasim Akram may face a ban of between two years and life if the ICC Code of Conduct Commission decide the Qayyum Report didn't go far enough.

It is reported that the four Indians against whom the CBI is alleged to have collected "circumstantial evidence" are unlikely to face prosecution under the country's Prevention of Corruption Act as they are not public servants who come under its jurisdiction.

News circulates that the report is likely to find Kapil Dev not guilty of the allegations levelled by Manoj Prabhakar, that Kapil had offered him a bribe to under-perform in a one-day international against Pakistan in Colombo in 1994.

The timing of the chairman of the ECB, Lord MacLaurin, is questioned when he calls for a ban on players named in the Qayyum Report, including Wasim Akram, during the three-Test series against England. MacLaurin is reported to have said: "It's ridiculous. If someone is under suspicion he should be removed from the game until the case is heard and his innocence is proven. If an England player were involved that is what would happen." Critics of MacLaurin say his comments will inspire the Pakistanis against England.

Since the Qayyum report in May, the chairman of the ICC's Code of Conduct Commission, Lord Griffiths, has been considering evidence to see if further action should be taken against the "guilty" Pakistan players, Wasim Akram, Mushtaq Ahmed, Inzamam-ul-Haq, Saeed Anwar and Waqar Younis. According to an English newspaper report today, Griffiths has concluded that more severe punishment is needed.

South African players reportedly question the timing of the announcement of Cronje's life ban just before the ICC tournament.

Monday October 16
Lawyers for Cronje say they may sue the UCBSA over his life-ban. His legal representative, Leslie Sackstein, says the decision is unlawful but he declines to say why, claiming it is privileged information.

Former Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Condon, who heads the newly-established ICC anti-corruption unit, says it will not interfere with the match-fixing and bribery inquiries set up by the ICC's affiliated nations. The unit will receive $4 million over the next year.

Wasim Akram describes Cronje as "a brave man". The former Lancashire captain says: "At least he admitted he did something wrong." Akram says Cronje has a point when he says he was treated unfairly compared to Shane Warne and Mark Waugh.

Indian sports minister SS Dhindra says his country's interim report on the match-fixing will be tabled in parliament in November.

Tuesday October 17
Wasim Akram speaks out over Lord MacLaurin's comments and says his call for bans on some Pakistan players are an attempt to distract them from the series against England. Lt Gen Tauqir Zia also joins in, saying MacLaurin's comments are "unnecessary and negative tactics".

The UCBSA ignores the deadline set by Cronje's lawyers to repeal their ban on him. Cronje demands he be allowed to work as a cricket columnist and broadcaster.

Thursday October 19
The ICC met in Kenya during the ICC tournament and announce today that they are encouraged that the PCB "intends to pursue a policy of no tolerance to corruption". They say that Lord Griffiths has been asked, however, as a matter of some urgency, to secure further confidential information from Pakistan before producing his final report.

The ICC confirms they are content with the penalties imposed on South Africa's Henry Williams and Herschelle Gibbs, who have been banned until the start of 2001.

All international players, umpires, referees, team officials, administrators, employees and curators/groundsmen will be required to complete confidential questionnaires before November 30. Among the five questions, one asks whether individuals have "ever taken part in or been approached to take part in any arrangement with any other person involved in the playing or administration of the game of cricket which might involve corruption in any form".

The other questions involve rigged matches, infringements of the ICC's code of conduct, weather information for financial gain and playing badly to contrive a result.

There is a report that the King Commission will resume in November after all.

Friday October 20
India captain Sourav Ganguly is unimpressed by the ICC's documents on fair play which players and officials will be soon required to sign. He is reported to have said: "I don't see how that will help. Ultimately it is the players who have to be honest. You can fill in 10 such forms and still tank a match."

Sunday October 22
The Sunday Telegraph's Scyld Berry reports that two West Indian cricketers have been named in the long-awaited report on match-fixing by India's CBI. Four Indian cricketers - Mohammed Azharrudin, Ajay Jadeja, Ajay Sharma and Manoj Prabhaker - were named on Saturday October 21 by the Indian Express in a summary of the leaked report. The Sunday Telegraph reveals that in a chapter on foreign players in the report, two senior West Indies players and three Australians are named - but no England players. The involvement of the two West Indians, says Berry, relates to a qualifying match during the World Cup in 1996, when the Caribbean side surprisingly lost by 73 runs to Kenya. He concludes by saying that the evidence is mounting that about half of Test-playing countries have been tainted by match-fixing.

Monday October 23
According to Reuters, India's federal investigators announce they will present their interim report into allegations of match-fixing to the government during the week ahead.

The Australian Cricket Board says it will ignore what it describes as "unsubstantiated reports" accusing unnamed Australian players of being included in the Indian CBI's report on cricket's betting scandal until more substantial evidence emerges.

Tuesday October 24
The West Indies Board is reported to have asked to see the report by India's CBI before commenting on allegations that two of its players have been involved in the scandal. The claim relates to the shock 1996 World Cup match where the West Indies lost to Kenya by 73 runs.

Wednesday October 25
Former Pakistani umpire Javed Akhtar says he will sue Ali Bacher of the United Cricket Board of South Africa to the tune of R100M (about £1,210,000) for bringing his name into disrepute. Bacher is reported to have accused Akhtar of giving eight questionable lbws during the crucial Headingley Test between England and South Africa in 1998. Bacher said Akhtar was paid to influence the result of that 5th and final Test that England won by 23 runs and that he colluded with a bookmaker whose name starts with R. Bacher first accused Akhtar when he was interviewed by the Australian newspaper in April, although he later retracted the statement saying he had been misquoted. However, he again levelled charges against Akhtar in front of the King Commission in June.

Thursday October 26
Richie Richardson denies that he is one of the two West Indians reported to be named in the CBI report. The former West Indies captain told Starcom Network Sports: "I never had approaches and I wasn't aware of the sort of things that were going on. I could not conceive that somebody could be playing for their country and want to sell a match." Richardson said during his career he had received calls from individuals asking about the weather and the toss, but he hadn't thought anything of this. He said: "Match-fixing is a serious thing and whoever is involved should be dealt with severely. I can't say exactly how, but I just think they should be dealt with severely. It's the worst thing anybody can do - to sell out their country."

The manager of the Kenyan cricket team who beat the West Indies in 1996, Harilal Shah, says allegations that the match was rigged are "total nonsense". Shah, now vice-chairman of the Kenyan Cricket Association, said to the Kenyan national newspaper, the Daily Nation: "I was present during the match and [what] I saw in the faces of the West Indies team was total shock and disbelief."

Friday October 27
Wasim Akram tells the Guardian's Paul Weaver how angry he is with England and Wales Cricket Board chairman Lord MacLaurin. Akram said: "I lived in England and have been helping England whenever I could for the past 12 years, working with youngsters and trying to do my best while I play. So when the boss of English cricket says [I should be banned for the series against England] of course I'm going to be disappointed." He also claims the allegations of match-fixing have given him diabetes.

Sunday October 29
India's CBI report will be handed to the Union Sports Minister on Monday October 30 according to agency sources in Delhi. Reports indicate at least five Indian players will be named in the 150-page report, plus some foreigners, based on the testimony of bookmakers.

Monday October 30
The Guardian reports that the public hearings into alleged match-fixing by Cronje have been postponed until next year, according to Judge Edwin King, who leads the inquiry.

The CBI's interim report on betting and match-fixing was finally handed to the Union Sports Minister SS Dhindsa in New Delhi today. Dhindsa said that he will seek a legal opinion on what possible action can be taken against those found "guilty" in the report.

India's Star Television said Mohammed Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja, Nayan Mongia, Manoj Prabhakar, Ajay Sharma, Mark Waugh and Salim Malik were also named in the CBI report. Brian Lara has denied any involvement.

Tuesday October 31

Manoj Prabhakar has hit back at reports that he has been found "guilty" in his country's CBI interim report on match-fixing. Prabhakar, who made allegations against former team-mate and coach Kapil Dev, said: "I don't know on what basis my name is being bandied about. If serving the nation is a crime, I plead guilty. As far as I am concerned, now the ball is neither in the CBI's court nor in the Government's court but it is in the people's court. It is for the people of the country to decide whether I am guilty or not."

West Indies Cricket Board chief Pat Rousseau is reported to have said he would not "fuel the rumour mill" by commenting on an Indian government report that allegedly accuses Brian Lara and others of involvement in a match-fixing scandal. According to Associated Press, Rousseau told The Observer newspaper in the Caribbean: "So far all we can hear is sources saying this and that without a shred of evidence."

English cricket is stunned when Alec Stewart is dragged into the scandal. It is reported that Indian sports minister SS Dhindsa is claiming that the names of Stewart and Brian Lara are in the CBI's report due to be released on Wednesday November 1, but he did not reveal the context in which their names appeared. It is unclear whether Stewart and Lara are accused of any wrongdoing.

Stewart and ECB officials in Pakistan declined to comment on the reports. Dhindsa said on Star News TV: "Lara is there, and Stewart, the English player."

Watch this space

It is reported that the four Indians against whom the CBI is alleged to have collected "circumstantial evidence" are unlikely to face prosecution under the country's Prevention of Corruption Act as they are not public servants who come under its jurisdiction. News circulates that the report is likely to find Kapil Dev not guilty of the allegations levelled by Manoj Prabhakar, that Kapil had offered him a bribe to under-perform in a one-day international against Pakistan in Colombo in 1994. The timing of the chairman of the ECB, Lord MacLaurin, is questioned when he calls for a ban on players named in the Qayyum Report, including Wasim Akram, during the three-Test series against England. MacLaurin is reported to have said: "It's ridiculous. If someone is under suspicion he should be removed from the game until the case is heard and his innocence is proven. If an England player were involved that is what would happen." Critics of MacLaurin say his comments will inspire the Pakistanis against England. Since the Qayyum report in May, the chairman of the ICC's Code of Conduct Commission, Lord Griffiths, has been considering evidence to see if further action should be taken against the "guilty" Pakistan players, Wasim Akram, Mushtaq Ahmed, Inzamam-ul-Haq, Saeed Anwar and Waqar Younis. According to an English newspaper report today, Griffiths has concluded that more severe punishment is needed. South African players reportedly question the timing of the announcement of Cronje's life ban just before the ICC tournament. Monday October 16 Lawyers for Cronje say they may sue the UCBSA over his life-ban. His legal representative, Leslie Sackstein, says the decision is unlawful but he declines to say why, claiming it is privileged information. Former Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Condon, who heads the newly-established ICC anti-corruption unit, says it will not interfere with the match-fixing and bribery inquiries set up by the ICC's affiliated nations. The unit will receive $4 million over the next year. Wasim Akram describes Cronje as "a brave man". The former Lancashire captain says: "At least he admitted he did something wrong." Akram says Cronje has a point when he says he was treated unfairly compared to Shane Warne and Mark Waugh. Indian sports minister SS Dhindra says his country's interim report on the match-fixing will be tabled in parliament in November. Tuesday October 17 Wasim Akram speaks out over Lord MacLaurin's comments and says his call for bans on some Pakistan players are an attempt to distract them from the series against England. Lt Gen Tauqir Zia also joins in, saying MacLaurin's comments are "unnecessary and negative tactics". The UCBSA ignores the deadline set by Cronje's lawyers to repeal their ban on him. Cronje demands he be allowed to work as a cricket columnist and broadcaster. Thursday October 19 The ICC met in Kenya during the ICC tournament and announce today that they are encouraged that the PCB "intends to pursue a policy of no tolerance to corruption". They say that Lord Griffiths has been asked, however, as a matter of some urgency, to secure further confidential information from Pakistan before producing his final report. The ICC confirms they are content with the penalties imposed on South Africa's Henry Williams and Herschelle Gibbs, who have been banned until the start of 2001. All international players, umpires, referees, team officials, administrators, employees and curators/groundsmen will be required to complete confidential questionnaires before November 30. Among the five questions, one asks whether individuals have "ever taken part in or been approached to take part in any arrangement with any other person involved in the playing or administration of the game of cricket which might involve corruption in any form". The other questions involve rigged matches, infringements of the ICC's code of conduct, weather information for financial gain and playing badly to contrive a result. There is a report that the King Commission will resume in November after all. Friday October 20 India captain Sourav Ganguly is unimpressed by the ICC's documents on fair play which players and officials will be soon required to sign. He is reported to have said: "I don't see how that will help. Ultimately it is the players who have to be honest. You can fill in 10 such forms and still tank a match."
