Four Indian cricketers - Mohammed Azharrudin, Ajay Jadeja, Ajay Sharma and Manoj Prabhaker - were named on Saturday October 21 by the Indian Express in a summary of the leaked report. The Sunday Telegraph reveals that in a chapter on foreign players in the report, two senior West Indies players and three Australians are named - but no England players. The involvement of the two West Indians, says Berry, relates to a qualifying match during the World Cup in 1996, when the Caribbean side surprisingly lost by 73 runs to Kenya. He concludes by saying that the evidence is mounting that about half of Test-playing countries have been tainted by match-fixing. Monday October 23 According to Reuters, India's federal investigators announce they will present their interim report into allegations of match-fixing to the government during the week ahead. The Australian Cricket Board says it will ignore what it describes as "unsubstantiated reports" accusing unnamed Australian players of being included in the Indian CBI's report on cricket's betting scandal until more substantial evidence emerges. Tuesday October 24 The West Indies Board is reported to have asked to see the report by India's CBI before commenting on allegations that two of its players have been involved in the scandal. The claim relates to the shock 1996 World Cup match where the West Indies lost to Kenya by 73 runs. Wednesday October 25 Former Pakistani umpire Javed Akhtar says he will sue Ali Bacher of the United Cricket Board of South Africa to the tune of R100M (about £1,210,000) for bringing his name into disrepute. Bacher is reported to have accused Akhtar of giving eight questionable lbws during the crucial Headingley Test between England and South Africa in 1998. Bacher said Akhtar was paid to influence the result of that 5th and final Test that England won by 23 runs and that he colluded with a bookmaker whose name starts with R. Bacher first accused Akhtar when he was interviewed by the Australian newspaper in April, although he later retracted the statement saying he had been misquoted. However, he again levelled charges against Akhtar in front of the King Commission in June. Thursday October 26 Richie Richardson denies that he is one of the two West Indians reported to be named in the CBI report. The former West Indies captain told Starcom Network Sports: "I never had approaches and I wasn't aware of the sort of things that were going on. I could not conceive that somebody could be playing for their country and want to sell a match." Richardson said during his career he had received calls from individuals asking about the weather and the toss, but he hadn't thought anything of this. He said: "Match-fixing is a serious thing and whoever is involved should be dealt with severely. I can't say exactly how, but I just think they should be dealt with severely. It's the worst thing anybody can do - to sell out their country." The manager of the Kenyan cricket team who beat the West Indies in 1996, Harilal Shah, says allegations that the match was rigged are "total nonsense". Shah, now vice-chairman of the Kenyan Cricket Association, said to the Kenyan national newspaper, the Daily Nation: "I was present during the match and [what] I saw in the faces of the West Indies team was total shock and disbelief." Friday October 27 Wasim Akram tells the Guardian's Paul Weaver how angry he is with England and Wales Cricket Board chairman Lord MacLaurin. Akram said: "I lived in England and have been helping England whenever I could for the past 12 years, working with youngsters and trying to do my best while I play. So when the boss of English cricket says [I should be banned for the series against England] of course I'm going to be disappointed." He also claims the allegations of match-fixing have given him diabetes. Sunday October 29 India's CBI report will be handed to the Union Sports Minister on Monday October 30 according to agency sources in Delhi. Reports indicate at least five Indian players will be named in the 150-page report, plus some foreigners, based on the testimony of bookmakers. Monday October 30 The Guardian reports that the public hearings into alleged match-fixing by Cronje have been postponed until next year, according to Judge Edwin King, who leads the inquiry. The CBI's interim report on betting and match-fixing was finally handed to the Union Sports Minister SS Dhindsa in New Delhi today. Dhindsa said that he will seek a legal opinion on what possible action can be taken against those found "guilty" in the report. India's Star Television said Mohammed Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja, Nayan Mongia, Manoj Prabhakar, Ajay Sharma, Mark Waugh and Salim Malik were also named in the CBI report. Brian Lara has denied any involvement. Tuesday October 31 Manoj Prabhakar has hit back at reports that he has been found "guilty" in his country's CBI interim report on match-fixing. Prabhakar, who made allegations against former team-mate and coach Kapil Dev, said: "I don't know on what basis my name is being bandied about. If serving the nation is a crime, I plead guilty. As far as I am concerned, now the ball is neither in the CBI's court nor in the Government's court but it is in the people's court. It is for the people of the country to decide whether I am guilty or not." West Indies Cricket Board chief Pat Rousseau is reported to have said he would not "fuel the rumour mill" by commenting on an Indian government report that allegedly accuses Brian Lara and others of involvement in a match-fixing scandal. According to Associated Press, Rousseau told The Observer newspaper in the Caribbean: "So far all we can hear is sources saying this and that without a shred of evidence." English cricket is stunned when Alec Stewart is dragged into the scandal. It is reported that Indian sports minister SS Dhindsa is claiming that the names of Stewart and Brian Lara are in the CBI's report due to be released on Wednesday November 1, but he did not reveal the context in which their names appeared. It is unclear whether Stewart and Lara are accused of any wrongdoing. Stewart and ECB officials in Pakistan declined to comment on the reports. Dhindsa said on Star News TV: "Lara is there, and Stewart, the English player." Watch this space

webTitle: Interview: Dennis Cooper, writer of Period

fields.headline: 'I used to be crazy'
fields.standfirst: Rape, mutilation, murder - no wonder Dennis Cooper has received death threats for his novels. But, he tells  Nick Hasted, they have kept him sane
fields.trailText: Rape, mutilation, murder - no wonder Dennis Cooper has received death threats for his novels. But, he tells Nick Hasted, they have kept him sane.
fields.body:
"I'll say this once," says a narrator purporting to be Dennis Cooper, in Cooper's novel Guide. "I'm extremely fucked up." List the subject matter of Cooper's critically adored five-novel cycle, completed this week with Period, and few would disagree. In the 47-year-old Californian's two decades of fiction, you'll find the most obsessively explored sexual pathology since Sade, an uninhibited fascination with the opening of male bodies in the search for some inner perfection, whether through sex or imagined butchery. Murder, mutilation, even paedophile rape are, to the casual observer, passed over with a cool eye.

No wonder, you think, he has received death threats (from Queer Nation). No surprise that American Psycho author Bret Easton Ellis calls him, "the last literary outlaw in mainstream American fiction". What, though, was William Burroughs thinking when he canonised Cooper as "a born writer"?

Take another look. And beneath the Californian cool and grisly physicality you may find an artist more to your taste. From the first pages of his debut novel, 1989's Closer, a desire for love infects the carnage. The humour and tenderness in 1994's Try - the cycle's structural and emotional heart, about an 18-year-old boy's search for affection amid ongoing abuse - are undeniable. Pop culture mastery and structural daring are also part of the picture; in Period, prose is pared back almost to notes, and only a lost zombie boy, George - the beloved, damaged hero of Closer - still shows emotion.

Cooper comes as no surprise in the flesh, simply because it is useless to imagine who could write such things. Handsome, with glinting yet evasive eyes, he's tense and nervous at first, stuttering answers, but soon settles into lucid honesty. We start talking about Period, and George, the boy who has floated from one end of his fiction to the other. Any idea that the work is that of a sick sadist is quickly snuffed. George was a real boy, his deepest love from his schooldays. Just before starting Period, he discovered that George had died: a shotgun suicide.

"I wanted to make a book that disappeared, that committed suicide," Cooper says. "I wanted it to be a grave for George. It was written out of real grief for this friend. It was about the fact that I actually wrote all these books for him, and then found out by accident he had killed himself, that he'd been dead before I started the first book. That's why Period is so full of guilt, because I'd taken this real boy, the most important person to me, and put him through the mill in my books, until he was abstract.

"And it's full of failure. Because the fact he had killed himself seemed to have something to do with the books. I always thought of them as being for him, but they hadn't done anything for him. I wrote the books partly to resolve my interest in sex and violence - and I did, I got rid of them, they're a joke by the end. But the stuff with George wasn't resolved at all."

Even the books without George, it turns out, have the same unexpected sentiment. "Each book has someone in it who is really close to me," Cooper says. "The reason I picked George originally, and then the others, is that I know if they're the main character, I will never hurt them. No matter how bad things get, the books will always be about caring for them."

Peripheral characters aren't so fortunate. From Cooper's first short stories in the early 1980s (collected in 1992's aptly titled Wrong), beautiful young boys are blankly cut up, raped and ripped, a reason for Queer Nation's ire, and others' repulsion. These are the personally gentle Cooper's own fantasies, obsessively repeated until, with Period, they seem used up. What did he learn, putting such viciousness on the page?

"Clarity. The books have some confused attitudes towards some really terrible things, and so did I. I'm more reasonable for writing them. I used to use a lot of drugs, I used to be crazy, and I'm not any more. I'm not as sexual. I could never just be with someone because I was so interested in the body and what was inside it. It was psychosis to write about it. But when I wrote it, I did believe it."

Frisk (1991) is Cooper's definitive account of his fantasy life; it includes a long letter describing the imagined destruction of blameless boys sure to shake most readers. Written after Cooper had spent two debauched years in the novel's Amsterdam setting, and directly after an unspecified "incident where I realised OK, this is not good", repulsion was not the aim.

"No, I wanted the book to seduce you. He writes that letter wanting company, and I wrote the book to say, 'Am I the only one?' I got all kinds of responses. I got a death threat. I'm going to live down that book the rest of my life. But on the other hand, a lot of people really did understand it. It made me feel better."

Were Cooper's fiction just a safety valve for his own fetishes, it would be hard to recommend. But his resolve to write out a fantasy life that began, aged 12, when he read about three boys being raped and mutilated near his home and felt a shiver of eroticised fear and fascination - to write it even though his real-life impulses are desperately protective of the young - asks deeper questions, and offers, perhaps, deeper relief. Cooper's dissection of his sexuality, and the unexpressed twists it puts in his head, will strike a chord with more people than may care to admit it.

It all sounds "sick", he knows. He has a ready-made excuse if he wants it - an alcoholic mother who terrorised him as a child with repeated threats of suicide, a father who beat him. But he won't shift the blame. "I cut my family off emotionally when I was 16, and barely stayed at home," he says. "So however horrible that stuff was, I don't feel it's the answer."

Cooper rejected the hippies around him as a teenager too, instead finding his ideals later, in anarchism, punk and the perfectionist writing theory of his idol, Rimbaud, the source of his structural rigour.

"He had absolute purity of intention," he declares. "Otherwise I don't see the point. I would never be satisfied just writing a novel that sells and gets good reviews. It has to be more than that. I'm not sure my books are really good, but I think they are unique."

Constant pressure to write a more conventional, "big" novel, to cash in his critical acclaim, as well as Period's exhaustion of himself as a fictional source, will next see him basing a book on an American high-school shooting and the teenage murderer's taped confession: "one of the most moving things I've heard in my life. It's another way to write intensely about incommunicable emotions. I totally related to this."

Cooper will no doubt face more accusations that he's bad, a nihilist. "I never was that," he sighs. "It's just because of the subject matter, and because I don't judge it. It's such lazy thinking. If anything, I err on the side of the romantic."

 Period is published on Thursday by Serpent's Tail, priced £17.99.

fields.headline: Una speranza sotto gli ulivi
fields.standfirst: Libera has been formed by a big group of organisations who aim to fight the mafia. Mariacarla Pavoni gets some local opinions
fields.trailText: Libera has been formed by a big group of organisations who aim to fight the mafia. Mariacarla Pavoni gets some local opinions
fields.body:
Decine di capi di stato si riuniranno in dicembre a Palermo per un summit sulla lotta alla criminalità e alle mafie nel mondo. Parteciperà all'incontro, su richiesta dell'ONU, anche un'associazione italiana che è diventata simbolo di lotta alle mafie: Libera. Questa associazione raccoglie 741 gruppi che operano nei campi più disparati, con ispirazione religiosa o laica, ma hanno un obiettivo comune: educare alla legalità e alla cittadinanza attiva. Libera conduce la lotta dal basso, col lavoro quotidiano di prevenzione, cultura, impegno civile. Il suo fondatore, don Luigi Ciotti, ne è l'anima e lo stimolo. Fra le molte campagne di Libera, la raccolta di un milione di firme che hanno sostenuto l'approvazione della legge del 1996 che consente l'uso dei beni confiscati alla mafia per fini sociali. Questi beni vengono trasformati in scuole, uffici, parchi pubblici, centri sociali, cooperative agricole . . . Vogliamo raccontare una di queste esperienze di riconquista del territorio attraverso le parole di don Salvatore Lo Bue, che ne è uno degli artefici, e le opinioni di alcuni giovani. Capiremo cosa lega una bottiglia di olio alla lotta alla criminalità!

Come nasce l'esperienza della Casa dei Giovani? Don Salvatore Lo Bue - La Casa dei Giovani nasce nel 1983 a Bagheria, vicino a Palermo, luogo famoso per le sue sontuose ville barocche e per la fama di molti suoi figli, come il pittore Renato Guttuso, ad esempio. Ma anche luogo famigerato, roccaforte della grossa mafia che ne ha condizionato pesantemente lo sviluppo. Proprio in una delle ville di Bagheria abbiamo fondato una comunità terapeutica per le tossico dipendenze. Non volevamo solo salvare giovani vite, ma combattere i portatori di morte espressi dalle grandi organizzazioni mafiose internazionali. Dopo la legge del 1996, abbiamo ottenuto dallo Stato un terreno in provincia di Trapani confiscato a Bernardo Provenzano, la primula rossa della mafia, che pare si nasconda proprio a Bagheria. Era un uliveto abbandonato al degrado, che abbiamo reso produttivo. Ci lavorano i ragazzi che escono dalla comunità terapeutica. Da vittime e inconsci collaboratori della mafia, poiché spesso a loro volta spacciatori, i ragazzi diventano protagonisti di un impegno civile e politico che li riscatta. Non è cosa facile: subiamo intimidazioni, come il taglio alla base di piante di ulivo o l'incendio di un trattore, ma è una grossa vittoria. Produciamo olio di oliva di altissima qualità. Lo abbiamo chiamato Libera, come l'associazione fondata da don Ciotti di cui facciamo parte. Sull'etichetta abbiamo scritto: "Dalle terre confiscate alla Mafia . . ." Cosa pensi di questa esperienza? Sabrina, animatrice scolastica - Sono siciliana, lavoro a Torino ma torno in Sicilia spesso. Quando ho saputo di questa esperienza, il cuore mi si è aperto. Ridare ciò che è stato tolto e dare occasione di lavoro a dei ragazzi è bellissimo. Gabriele, studente aTorino - Credo sia positivo trasformare terre mafiose in terre di legalità e ho molta ammirazione per quello che fa Libera. Eleonora, studentessa a Palermo - Impegnare ragazzi con difficoltà in una cosa concreta, come produrre olio, è un'idea forte. Sentirsi utili è importante.

Hai mai percepito la presenza della mafia? Sabrina - Quando vado in Sicilia sento che l'aria che si respira è pesante. Chi sta bene tende a negare la presenza della mafia, i più poveri invece la vedono come qualcosa di inevitabile, pensano che non ci sia niente da fare. Gabriele - Direttamente no, ma ho discusso di multinazionali e commercio globale durante una settimana di studio con altri studenti e ho capito come, anche se non lo sentiamo direttamente, malavita e illegalità si insinuano nella vita di tutti. Eleonora - L'anno scorso, quando facevamo interviste per strada per il giornale scolastico, percepivamo l'omertà. Facevamo domande sul pizzo, l'usura, la droga e la gente spesso diceva "non so", "non voglio rispondere".

Cosa pensi possa fare la scuola per educare alla legalità? Sabrina - Bisogna parlare di queste cose il più possibile. Il silenzio è colpevole. I giovani devono sentire che non è giusto rassegnarsi. E bisogna essere presenti, in modo che nessuno si senta solo. Gabriele - Per molti anni ho vissuto la scuola solo come un obbligo. Poi ho cominciato a frequentare le attività di aggregazione nel pomeriggio e ho capito quanto si può crescere socialmente mettendosi in rapporto con gli altri. Queste sono le occasioni che la scuola deve dare: far parlare, discutere, confrontarsi. Eleonora - Ho frequentato una scuola media che mi ha insegnato moltissimo. La cultura mafiosa si combatte conoscendo la legge, imparando ad avere fiducia nelle istituzioni. E anche imparando che l'unione è importante. Insieme ce la possiamo fare.

Glossario/Glossary

l'animatrice scolastica - teaching assistant

l'aria é pesante - there's an oppressive atmosphere

l'artefice - leader

mafioso - (adj) of the mafia

mi si é aperto il cuore - (coll) I was overjoyed

non c'é niente da fare - there's little we can do

l'omertá - guilty silence due to complicity with or fear of criminals

pare che - it seems

il pizzo - (slang) protection money

stare bene - (coll) well-off

subire intimidazioni - to be threatened

la tossico dipendenza - drug addiction

Vogliamo raccontare una di queste esperienze di riconquista del territorio attraverso le parole di don Salvatore Lo Bue, che ne è uno degli artefici, e le opinioni di alcuni giovani. Capiremo cosa lega una bottiglia di olio alla lotta alla criminalità! Come nasce l'esperienza della Casa dei Giovani? Don Salvatore Lo Bue - La Casa dei Giovani nasce nel 1983 a Bagheria, vicino a Palermo, luogo famoso per le sue sontuose ville barocche e per la fama di molti suoi figli, come il pittore Renato Guttuso, ad esempio. Ma anche luogo famigerato, roccaforte della grossa mafia che ne ha condizionato pesantemente lo sviluppo. Proprio in una delle ville di Bagheria abbiamo fondato una comunità terapeutica per le tossico dipendenze. Non volevamo solo salvare giovani vite, ma combattere i portatori di morte espressi dalle grandi organizzazioni mafiose internazionali. Dopo la legge del 1996, abbiamo ottenuto dallo Stato un terreno in provincia di Trapani confiscato a Bernardo Provenzano, la primula rossa della mafia, che pare si nasconda proprio a Bagheria. Era un uliveto abbandonato al degrado, che abbiamo reso produttivo. Ci lavorano i ragazzi che escono dalla comunità terapeutica. Da vittime e inconsci collaboratori della mafia, poiché spesso a loro volta spacciatori, i ragazzi diventano protagonisti di un impegno civile e politico che li riscatta. Non è cosa facile: subiamo intimidazioni, come il taglio alla base di piante di ulivo o l'incendio di un trattore, ma è una grossa vittoria. Produciamo olio di oliva di altissima qualità. Lo abbiamo chiamato Libera, come l'associazione fondata da don Ciotti di cui facciamo parte. Sull'etichetta abbiamo scritto: "Dalle terre confiscate alla Mafia . . ." Cosa pensi di questa esperienza? Sabrina, animatrice scolastica - Sono siciliana, lavoro a Torino ma torno in Sicilia spesso. Quando ho saputo di questa esperienza, il cuore mi si è aperto. Ridare ciò che è stato tolto e dare occasione di lavoro a dei ragazzi è bellissimo. Gabriele, studente aTorino - Credo sia positivo trasformare terre mafiose in terre di legalità e ho molta ammirazione per quello che fa Libera. Eleonora, studentessa a Palermo - Impegnare ragazzi con difficoltà in una cosa concreta, come produrre olio, è un'idea forte. Sentirsi utili è importante. Hai mai percepito la presenza della mafia? Sabrina - Quando vado in Sicilia sento che l'aria che si respira è pesante. Chi sta bene tende a negare la presenza della mafia, i più poveri invece la vedono come qualcosa di inevitabile, pensano che non ci sia niente da fare. Gabriele - Direttamente no, ma ho discusso di multinazionali e commercio globale durante una settimana di studio con altri studenti e ho capito come, anche se non lo sentiamo direttamente, malavita e illegalità si insinuano nella vita di tutti. Eleonora - L'anno scorso, quando facevamo interviste per strada per il giornale scolastico, percepivamo l'omertà. Facevamo domande sul pizzo, l'usura, la droga e la gente spesso diceva "non so", "non voglio rispondere". Cosa pensi possa fare la scuola per educare alla legalità? Sabrina - Bisogna parlare di queste cose il più possibile. Il silenzio è colpevole. I giovani devono sentire che non è giusto rassegnarsi. E bisogna essere presenti, in modo che nessuno si senta solo. Gabriele - Per molti anni ho vissuto la scuola solo come un obbligo. Poi ho cominciato a frequentare le attività di aggregazione nel pomeriggio e ho capito quanto si può crescere socialmente mettendosi in rapporto con gli altri. Queste sono le occasioni che la scuola deve dare: far parlare, discutere, confrontarsi. Eleonora - Ho frequentato una scuola media che mi ha insegnato moltissimo. La cultura mafiosa si combatte conoscendo la legge, imparando ad avere fiducia nelle istituzioni. E anche imparando che l'unione è importante. Insieme ce la possiamo fare. fields.headline: Love on the run
fields.standfirst: Real Lives:  They are tall, muscly and bouncing with energy: it's hardly surprising that personal trainers are attracting the likes of Vanessa Feltz and Madonna.  Jess Cartner-Morley explores the allure of the 'fitness gurus'
fields.trailText: Real Lives: They are tall, muscly and bouncing with energy: it's hardly surprising that personal trainers are attracting the likes of Vanessa Feltz and Madonna. Jess Cartner-Morley explores the allure of the 'fitness gurus'.
fields.body:
No woman has ever been more defined by her weight than Vanessa Feltz. Even Bridget Jones had cigarettes and chardonnay to worry about as well. As the happily married matriarch of daytime television, Feltz's ample cleavage and dimpled cheeks were the essence of tea-and-sugar sympathy; in the year since her marriage broke up and her career took a dive, she has fought back in Daily Mail-approved fashion, drowning her sorrows in Slimfast and losing five stone.

So it is almost eerily appropriate that Feltz's new man should be Dennis Duhaney, the personal trainer who helped her lose weight. And even more fitting that their first paparazzi-snapped kiss should be Lycra-clad in a swimming pool, at the Marrakesh Sheraton. (Perhaps they are treading water? Very good for the thighs, after all.)

Of course, Feltz is years behind Madonna, who hired, had a daughter by, and dismissed Carlos Leon before most of us even knew what a personal trainer was. Over the past five years, personal trainers have become, for a certain type of woman, as de rigueur a lifestyle accessory as karma bracelets and wheat-free diets. Madonna now has a private yoga teacher, the über -chic version of the personal trainer. Victoria Mather, travel editor of Tatler magazine and author of The Party Blonde book of social stereotypes, describes them as "a matching accessory to the modern woman's life". Stories of legging-clad lust abound. There is the powerful female media player whose personal training sessions allegedly consist of a 6am run, a 15-minute intimate workout on the sitting room floor, then straight into a gruelling weights session.

Matt Roberts Personal Training, which has branches in Knightsbridge, Mayfair, One Aldwych hotel and Mauritius, is one of the most exclusive companies around. Unsurprisingly, John Roberts, brother of Matt and a director of the company, is keen to disabuse the public of the image of personal trainers as glorified strollers. "It's just not an issue for us. When clients come to us, they are coming to an expert who is going to help them achieve their goals. Of course, it's important for the client to enjoy the process, but the keys to this are professionalism and trust. Any friendship that a trainer and a client have would mean nothing if there were no results."

As for the pictures of Feltz's swimming pool clinch: "If a trainer is on holiday with a client to help her make sure she is training every day, that's professional," says Roberts. "But if the relationship goes beyond that it's going to be unhelpful."

None the less, it doesn't take an in-depth knowledge of psychology to spot the latent erotic potential of the trainer-client relationship. "It's not complicated," says Vicki Woods, a 52-year-old journalist who hired personal trainer Lee Hogan two years ago when she felt she needed to lose weight. "The thought wouldn't have occurred to me in a million years - we are both happily married and he's much younger than I - but I can definitely see how it happens. Trainers get more up close and personal than almost anyone else, after all. Plus they tend to be 6ft 3in, lightly, but rather brilliantly muscled, bouncing with energy and heterosexual. And they give you all this attention. You find yourself showing off about how you've been eating rice cakes because you want this god-like creature to praise you."

God-like indeed: while a trainer in a gym is a fitness instructor, personal trainers are usually referred to as "fitness gurus". What Mathers calls "the undivided attention, and from someone who's seen you at your very worst" is all the more addictive as the trainer typically has a host of female clients. "He would tell me about his other clients - not their names, he was very discreet, but he'd talk about how one client had done really well, had lost 6lbs this week," says Woods. "So although I didn't know who they were, I knew I was being compared to five or six other women in my area."

And even if you do keep the relationship strictly professional, others can get the wrong impression. "When you come lurching out of a copse, purple in the face and lapped with sweat, out of breath and leaning on this long, lean, lithe person in a gleaming singlet, and you bump into your neighbour who's out walking the dog in a Barbour, the look on their face is hilarious," says Woods.

For many clients, losing weight is closely tied with the process of gaining or regaining sexual attractiveness, which lends the relationship with the trainer a symbolic sexual or romantic significance - whether requited or not. Feltz's new slimline image is a classic example of the breakover phenomenon - a post break-up makeover, designed to show the world and your ex that you have Bounced Bravely Back.

Mathers feels that client-trainer relationships "show exactly the same lack of imagination as a man marrying his secretary. It shows you can't be bothered to go out and do it properly". After all, standing in sports bra and leggings having your body fat percentage measured isn't exactly the romantic how-we-met story with which one imagines oneself boring the grandchildren.

"It was absolutely the most humiliating experience," says Mathers. "We trained in my drawing room and as well as feeling fat, I'd push back a chair to make room and discover that no one had vacuumed under it in living memory. He was actually a terribly nice man but I started to resent him deeply. It was all just so embarrassing. I go to the gym now, which is much more private than having a personal trainer."

"The relationship with a client is important," says personal trainer Gerry Jackson. "As you develop a friendship you understand more about personal problems, the things that mean someone gives 100% one week and not the next. But clients only get too attached if you allow that to happen. If the chemistry gets too strong, it's down to the trainer to think, I'm doing a job here and I can't afford to get involved. It might be fine for a few months, but somewhere down the line it's going to create problems."

fields.headline: Augenzeuge
fields.standfirst: Harald Peterson from Berlin saw 'Mel C's Radio Show' in Columbiahalle
fields.trailText: Harald Peterson from Berlin saw 'Mel C's Radio Show' in Columbiahalle
fields.body:
Melanie C mag ich. Sie ist ein bischen wie Robbie Williams, wenn sie auf der Bühne steht. Sie schüttelt ihr Haar und spielt Luftgitarre. Die hat soviel Energie, das ist Wahnsinn. Manchmal springt sie auf und ab und hält dabei ihren Busen fest. Dann krabbelt sie wieder auf allen Vieren über den Boden. Das beste an ihr finde ich, dass sie nicht versucht, sich über ihre Fans zu stellen. Sie will genauso sein wie wir. Und sie glaubt an eine bessere Welt und will sie herbeisingen. Ihr Lied über die Obdachlosigkeit ging mir richtig unter die Haut. Ihre Show besteht nur aus Musik und Licht. Sie wechselt nicht ihr Kostüm und macht auch keinen anderen Firlefanz, wie Videos oder Tanzeinlagen. Am Besten hat mir ihr Lied, "Suddenly Monday" gefallen. Das hätten auch die Beatles schreiben können. Ich gehe zwar auf viele Konzerte in Berlin, aber bei Melanie C war das etwas ganz anderes. Die war schon als Spicegirl oben, aber ich finde, was sie jetzt macht ist tausendmal besser. Damals waren die Spice Girls wie ein Eisbecher: für jede Geschmacksrichtung war was dabei. Ihren Trainingsanzug hat Melanie C zum Glück jetzt in den Orkus geschickt. Was die jetzt anhat, sieht echt klasse aus. Die ganze Show war voll fetzig. Aber es gab natürlich auch eher ruhige Stücke. Leider hat der Auftritt nur wenig mehr als eine Stunde gedauert, mit nur einer Zugabe. Dann war Melanie C. verschwunden. Doch die Fans klatschten immer noch.

Glossar/Glossary:

Die Luftgitarre spielen - to simulate playing a guitar

auf allen Vieren krabbein - to crawl around on all fours

etwas geht unter die Haut - something gets under one's skin

Keinen Firlefanz machen - to amke no big act

etwas in den Orkus schicken - to get rid of something

 Harald Peterson was speaking to Olivia Schoeller.

fields.headline: Chelsea sign £7.8m Gronkjaer
fields.trailText: Chelsea today completed the signing of Danish international Jesper Gronkjaer from Ajax for £7.8m.
fields.body:
Chelsea today completed the signing of Danish international Jesper Gronkjaer from Ajax for £7.8m.

But the 24-year-old midfielder is currently injured with a slight thigh strain and will not arrive at Stamford Bridge until January 1.

Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson said: "Because of Euro 2000 Jesper only had one week of holiday this summer. The present minor injury needs rest."

Gronkjaer, who was born in Greenland and has won 14 Danish caps, joined Ajax in July 1998 after three seasons at Aalborg.

His arrival ends a 12-month chase for Chelsea, who were twice rejected by Ajax during the summer.

Gronkjaer said: "I never had any doubts about joining Chelsea. They are a big club.

"The Premiership was always my first option. I could have gone to Italy or Spain but I always said if I left Ajax I wanted to play in England.

"This is a great move for me. I was very impressed when I visited Chelsea. I spoke with Claudio Ranieri for two hours and I liked what he had told me.

"I am looking forward to working with him and playing with some of Europe's top players."

fields.headline: Drug scheme cuts users' spending
fields.trailText: Offenders referred to a government scheme cut the amount of money they spent on drugs by more than 90% and committed far less crime while they were being treated, research revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Offenders referred to a government scheme cut the amount of money they spent on drugs by more than 90% and committed far less crime while they were being treated, research revealed yesterday.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, said new drug treatment and testing orders (DTTOs) had helped abusers tobreak the vicious cycle which addiction often brought.

But the National Association of Probation Officers warned that the research, based on three pilot sites, was misleading. "For every person accepted on the scheme, another was rejected for being too high risk," a spokesman, Harry Fletcher, said. "The orders are not going to solve the country's drug problems."

Orders were introduced in Croydon, south London, Liverpool and Gloucestershire in October 1998, giving courts an extra option for dealing with drug abusing offenders. Two hundred and ten people were monitored over 18 months. They were put on treatment programmes and their drug use was evaluated with regular urine tests.

According to a report published by the Home Office yesterday, the average amount that offenders spent on drugs fell from £400 to £25 within six weeks. The average number of crimes committed dropped from 137 in the month before arrest to 34 within the first few weeks of the order.

With £60m pledged by the Home Office, orders are being rolled out across the country and should be available everywhere by the end of 2002.

Mr Straw said: "DTTOs help to break the vicious cycle of drug abuse and crime."

Mr Fletcher said probation officers had told him the schemes had not worked as well as the evaluation suggested. "The pilot sites only looked at a small number of people and the offenders were selected quite carefully. We are not against the orders, but we want people to realise DTTOs have their limitations."

fields.headline: BBC policy chief joins ITC
fields.trailText: 4pm: Dominic Morris, the BBC's controller of policy development, is leaving to join the ITC.
fields.body:
Another former member of Lord Birt's kitchen cabinet has quit the BBC.

Dominic Morris, the corporation's controller of policy development, is joining Patricia Hodgson at the Independent Television Commission as director of policy.

Mr Morris, a former Downing Street adviser, will be crucial to the ITC's campaign for survival in the face of a hostile communications white paper.

Ms Hodgson, a former head of policy and planning at the BBC, left the corporation this summer to take over as the commission's chief executive.

webTitle: Verizon shares drop after disappointing results

fields.headline: Verizon shares drop after disappointing results
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Telephone operator Verizon Communications is the latest US tech stock to fall in value after posting indifferent results, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telephone operator Verizon Communications yesterday became the latest US tech stock to let down the market.

Verizon, which was formed by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE and is the largest local telephone company in the US, said its third-quarter profits were flat at $2bn (£1.3bn), matching the total for the same period last year.

The silver lining was provided by revenues, which rose 7% from $15.4bn (£10.6bn) to $16.5bn (£11.3bn).

The indifferent results did little to settle nerves on another day of jittery trading on the technology-heavy Nasdaq index, which fell 3% by midday.

The US stock market is reeling from a string of poor figures and profits warnings posted by suffering TMT players, including Sprint, Nortel and Yahoo!.

Meanwhile, online bookseller Amazon.com saw its shares tumble 8% as analysts once again questioned the financial welfare of the company, despite the group's announcement last week of upbeat third-quarter figures.

Ravi Suria, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, said Amazon's credit was weak and crumbling, adding that he remained concerned about the company's cashflow.

The comment is a blow for tech stocks, as brokers were hoping that Amazon's optimistic results would see a volatile market turn the corner.

fields.headline: WPP lays off 100 Y&R staff
fields.trailText: 8.45am: WPP has made 100 staff from Young & Rubicam redundant, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
WPP has laid off 100 staff from Young & Rubicam, less than one month after it acquired the advertising network.

Approximately 80 of the redundancies were in the legal, finance, purchasing, information systems and human resources departments. Fifteen employees were laid off on the Y&R agency side.

While the cull was expected, the size of the cuts and the layoffs at Y&R Advertising have shocked staff.

In 1989, shortly after WPP acquired Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in a highly publicised hostile takeover, the new parent axed around 50 employees. The cuts also took place in the administrative departments and were said to involve jobs that overlapped with those at WPP.

More cuts are anticipated within other Y&R divisions before the end of the year.

Other Y&R companies that may be affected include media specialist the Media Edge; multicultural agencies Bravo Group and Kang & Lee; direct shops Impiric and KnowledgeBase Marketing; public relations groups Burson-Marsteller, Robinson Lerer & Montgomery and Cohn & Wolfe; brand identity specialist Landor & Associates; London design shop the Partners; healthcare agency Sudler & Hennessey; and British technology agency Banner Corp.

webTitle: Channel 5 launches Home and Away fanzine show

fields.headline: Channel 5 launches Home and Away fanzine show
fields.trailText: 8.45am Channel 5 is launching a weekly fanzine show from the set of Australian soap Home and Away, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 is launching a weekly fanzine show from the set of Australian soap Home and Away, in an attempt to maintain the show's profile in the UK before the broadcaster begins transmitting it daily next summer.

Home and Away - Back to the Bay will run for 15 minutes every Friday at 5.15pm from November 24. It will feature behind the scenes gossip, cast interviews and on-set visits.

Channel 5 snatched the rights to Home and Away from ITV in February. But ITV's contract runs until the end of June next year and the broadcaster pulled the show in the summer rather than let Channel 5 begin broadcasting it early.

Dawn Airey, Channel 5 chief executive and director of programmes, said: "Since ITV prevented us from showing Home and Away in June, we have had thousands of complaints. So we wanted to give fans a chance to catch up on their favourite soap."

fields.headline: Newcastle Brown goes upmarket
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Haway! Bosses at Newcastle Brown Ale are shedding their working man's image and going for a new-look drinker, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Haway! Bosses at Newcastle Brown Ale are shedding their working man's image and going for a new-look drinker.

The traditional drink of labourers, students and bikers is to go under the microscope after brewer Scottish Courage hired a firm of consultants to work on the brand.

Circus won the task of revamping the classic beer brand in a competitive pitch earlier this year. The company will work on the brand strategy as well as help to develop a website and a communications campaign dedicated to the beer.

Paul Twivy, a partner at Circus, said: "Newcastle Brown is in a category of its own and inspires a lot of affection in its drinkers. It deserves to be liberated from the cage its reputation currently places it in, ie as an old-fashioned, Geordie working man's staple or a beer for students and bikers.

"It is actually that rare thing, a beer of real character, and our aim is to bring that character alive."

Stuart Catchpole, brands director for Scottish Courage, said he was confident the beer's fortunes could be turned around.

"We were impressed by Circus's holistic approach to the brand's issues and the quality of their creative work," he added.

This is the second time Scottish Courage has tried to take Newcastle Brown upmarket.

In 1996 the brewer launched an advertising campaign using the line, "World famous British beer" in a bid to tone down the brand's laddish image and reintroduce it as a premium beer.

fields.headline: BT rapped over internet ads
fields.trailText: 8am: British Telecom has been found guilty by TV watchdogs of misleading viewers about its internet calls packages, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
British Telecom has been found guilty by TV watchdogs of misleading viewers about the availability of its internet calls packages.

The Independent Television Commission has ordered BT to withdraw its TV advertising campaign after the telecoms giant implied that a special offer was available nationwide.

Following complaints from viewers and the Bromley Trading Standards department, ITC investigators found that in some regions three in four viewers couldn't receive the service.

The ad, created by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, was used to promote BT's 'Surf Time' package and stated that it offered, "unlimited internet calls every evening and weekend for just £5.99 a month."

On-screen text added, "Access via participating ISP also required. Subject to availability. Line rental and minimum contract applies."

A total of 29 viewers complained that the ad implied that the service was available to all customers when in some TV regions it had been as low as 24 per cent.

BT admitted the service was rolling out on an exchange-by-exchange basis but said at the time of launch 41% of exchanges had been upgraded to cater for demand.

It also believed that the inclusion of superimposed text saying "subject to availability" would alert viewers to the lack of availability of the service.

But the ITC disagreed. It said the text was the equivalent of small print, adding that BT "had not adequately alerts viewers" to the limitations.

This is the second rap over the knuckles for BT. Last month the Advertising Standards Authority took issue with the company's Surf Time print advertising again over claims about cost and availability. The ASA insisted on amendments.

The ITC also upheld a complaint against an ad by Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper for the Peugeot 206 Gti.

The ad featured a magician performing a series of magic tricks to passers-by while saying, "This is not a trick" as he is shown climbing into the car and accelerating out of the camera shot. The voiceover announces, "Now you see it, now you don't".

Viewers complained that the ad reinforced the belief that speeding was socially acceptable.

webTitle: Husband and wife team to edit Time

fields.headline: Time Magazine hires husband and wife team to edit Euro edition
fields.trailText: 8am: Time Magazine has taken the unusual step of hiring a husband-and-wife team to edit its European edition, Time Atlantic, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Time Magazine has taken the unusual step of hiring a husband-and-wife team to edit its European edition, Time Atlantic.

Ann and Donald Morrison arrive in London this week to take up their new positions as co-editors of Time Atlantic. They replace Christopher Redman, who has been promoted to editor-at-large and will continue to write for the magazine.

Mr and Mrs Morrison are the first co-editors at Time since co-founders Henry R Luce and Briton Hadden jointly edited the magazine in the early 1920s.

They will supervise Time Atlantic's 30-strong editorial staff based in London as well as 11 regional news offices in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

The couple has spent the past six years in Hong Kong, where Mrs Morrison was editor of the Asian news magazine Asiaweek and Mr Morrison was editor of Time Asia.

webTitle: Leader: Government should intervene in Express bid

fields.headline: Mail merge
fields.standfirst:
The government cannot stand aside

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Newspapers, said Chris Smith recently, are not like products on the supermarket shelf. And that is why his colleague, the trade secretary, has a vital role to play in press mergers and takeovers. If, by some oversight, the office of fair trading failed to refer the bid by the Daily Mail for its rival the Daily Express to the competition commission, Stephen Byers would have to call it in.
fields.body:
Newspapers, said Chris Smith recently, are not like products on the supermarket shelf. And that is why his colleague, the trade secretary, has a vital role to play in press mergers and takeovers. If, by some oversight, the office of fair trading failed to refer the bid by the Daily Mail for its rival the Daily Express to the competition commission, Stephen Byers would have to call it in. He can forget fashionable theories about government having no role in adjudicating competition: there is a mound of public interest in who owns the press and so shapes the agenda, influences voting and gives public opinion a voice.

This small earthquake in the mid-market, where the legatees of Beaverbrook and Northcliffe still battle it out, will shake the government. For it exposes the Blairites' hope that they could love Rupert Murdoch and Associated Newspapers to death, wean them from the habits of a lifetime, rather than treat these over-mighty subjects (foreigners in the cases of Mr Murdoch and Conrad Black) as an obstacle to good governance. Media policy-making, such as it has been, has been a course of avoidance. And where did it get the government? The idea that the Daily Mail must be palliated for fear of retribution is risible - for months it has been getting its retaliation in first.

That is not to pretend it is easy for a government to have a "policy" for the press, since it has to embrace the role of journalists in embarrassing the powers that be by reporting uncomfortable truths. Had Labour been less executive-minded, less illiberal over freedom of information, its capacity to reshape the press would be much greater.

But technology and commerce dictate that it must have a policy. Now, on the eve of the publication of the government's plans for future communications regulation, hard decisions must be taken about cross-ownership and the proportion of audience/circulation that constitutes abuse.

webTitle: Saatchi's to make film for UK fashion designer

fields.headline: Saatchi's to make film for UK fashion designer
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Fashion designer Matthew Williamson, who counts Liz Hurley and Madonna, has teamed up with Saatchi & Saatchi. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
British fashion designer Matthew Williamson, who counts Liz Hurley, Madonna and Julia Roberts among his fans, has teamed up with Saatchi & Saatchi to boost his selling power.

The 28-year-old Manchester-born designer has worked with the agency to create a 10-minute film highlighting his work from the recent London Fashion Week.

The film, which marks the first time Mr Williamson has collaborated with an ad agency, includes behind-the-scenes footage from his shows and interviews with the designer. It will be used as a promotional tool in-store and sent out to potential buyers.

Joseph Velosa, managing director at Matthew Williamson in London, said "Saatchi & Saatchi has created something much better than we could normally afford. It's great for both parties."

Showing his first collection in 1997, Mr Williamson has become known for his intricate embroideries, beading, cutaway T-shirts and body-revealing dresses. He now stretches to 50 outfits a show.

The film was produced by Inca Productions

fields.headline: Gates to buy $1bn Sky stake
fields.trailText: Microsoft is in talks to buy a stake in the satellite television business to be spun out of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Microsoft is in talks to buy a stake in the satellite television business to be spun out of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation in a deal that could cost the software group $1bn.

The investment in Sky Global Networks would represent the first time that Bill Gates, Microsoft's co-founder, and Rupert Murdoch, the head of News Corp, have worked closely together in a business venture.

Through its investments in cable television during the past two years, Microsoft had looked likely to compete against News Corp's satellite-based business. However, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday that Mr Gates' Seattle-based group was seriously considering a 3.5% stake in Sky Global Networks in an attempt to dominate the set-top box technology used for interactive TV.

A News Corp spokesman in New York declined to comment on the talks yesterday, as did a Microsoft spokeswoman in Seattle.

Analysts welcomed signs of a deal yesterday. Shares in both Microsoft and News Corp climbed after reports of the de tailed discussions first emerged. The timing of the leaked talks is particularly important for News Corp as it prepares to spin off its satellite arm.

Mr Murdoch has indicated that he expects the business - which will consist of News Corp's stake in BSkyB, its Star TV arm in Asia and operations in Latin America and Europe - to be valued at between $38bn and $40bn. The group has been forced to delay the planned initial public offering amid the crisis in confidence for technology shares.

Its plans were dealt a further blow earlier this month when Vivendi, the French group, announced its decision to sell its 22% stake in BSkyB in return for regulatory approval of its takeover of Seagram.

The forced sale is likely to act as a drag on the stockmarket value of Sky Global Networks.

One Wall Street analyst said of the Microsoft talks: "The key thing this would do is lock in a valuation [for Sky]."

News Corp has held talks with several media and technology companies about a possible partnership in Sky Global Networks. Web portal Yahoo! and Nokia, the mobile phone group, have been mentioned as the most likely partners along with Microsoft. Talks with Nokia and Yahoo! appear to have cooled during the past month or so. Mr Murdoch has made it clear during this time that he would like to do a deal with either DirecTV, the satellite business owned by Hughes Electronics, or Echostar, another US satellite business.

Microsoft already has a partnership with DirecTV, America's largest satellite broadcaster, through a new service, Ultimate TV, due to be launched later this year.

Mr Murdoch has a deal with American cable TV tycoon John Malone for his Liberty Media Group to take a 4.76% stake in Sky Global Networks.

Separately, Microsoft executives yesterday sought to play down the impact of the hacking episode that prompted urgent calls to the FBI last week.

A report in the Wall Street Journal quoted one executive saying that the company had been able to monitor the trespasser soon after the "break-in".

The newspaper's report raised eyebrows among security experts who doubted that such a control would have prompted the company's decision to shut down all remote access for Microsoft's employees around the world.

Microsoft already has a partnership with DirecTV, America's largest satellite broadcaster, through a new service, Ultimate TV, due to be launched later this year. Mr Murdoch has a deal with American cable TV tycoon John Malone for his Liberty Media Group to take a 4.76% stake in Sky Global Networks. Separately, Microsoft executives yesterday sought to play down the impact of the hacking episode that prompted urgent calls to the FBI last week. A report in the Wall Street Journal quoted one executive saying that the company had been able to monitor the trespasser soon after the "break-in". The newspaper's report raised eyebrows among security experts who doubted that such a control would have prompted the company's decision to shut down all remote access for Microsoft's employees around the world.

webTitle: Daily Mail bids for Express Newspapers

fields.headline: Daily Mail makes £100m play for Express Newspapers
fields.trailText: Daily Mail & General Trust yesterday submitted its bid for Express Newspapers. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Daily Mail & General Trust yesterday submitted its bid for Express Newspapers with an offer thought to value the business well in excess of £100m.

A second offer, from the wealthy Hinduja brothers, has been delayed, according to their advisers, and is likely to be made today.

If DMGT's bid is successful it would bring the Daily Mail and long standing rival the Daily Express under one roof.

DMGT has drawn up elaborate plans which is says will ensure the continued editorial independence of the left-leaning Daily Express, hoping these provisions will persuade competition authorities to clear the deal.

The bid will automatically be referred to the competition commission and is likely be scrutinised for about three months.

Although the two newspapers compete in the mid-market, the merged group would have a national share of around 26%, still lower than News International, which owns the Times and the Sun.

DMGT executives also hope to persuade regulators of the company's ability to strengthen the titles through significantly increased investment. The Daily and Sunday Express have continued to decline under Lord Hollick's stewardship at United News & Media and suffered severe cost cutting.

About four years ago he merged the editorial teams of the two newspapers to create a seven-day operation.

The other national title in Express Newspapers, the Daily Star, has also seen staff numbers cut.

Hollinger, which owns the Daily Telegraph, is also understood to be interested in the Express titles, as is David Montgomery, former chief executive of the Mirror Group.

Lord Hollick is said to have been seeking offers of around £130m and earlier this month rejected a £75m bid from the Barclay brothers' Press Holdings. Merrill Lynch, broker to United New,s recently put a valuation on the division of between £74m and £105m.

The anticipated disposal of the newspapers was appreciated by investors who marked the United share price up 17p to 849p.

Spokesmen for DMGT and United News declined to comment.

webTitle: Analysis: Proposed takeover of Express Newspapers

fields.headline: Paper tigers
fields.standfirst: The proposed takeover of Express Newspapers will attract close scrutiny. But whatever happens, the outcome is unlikely to set a precedent
fields.trailText: The proposed takeover of Express Newspapers will attract close scrutiny. But whatever happens, the outcome is unlikely to set a precedent. By David Teather
fields.body:
Trade secretary Stephen Byers says he wants to take politics out of company mergers and takeovers. He would in future accept the findings of the office of fair trading and the competition commission and no longer intervene except in "exceptional circumstances".

But suggestions that he will adopt a hands-off approach to the takeover of the Daily Express are wide of the mark. Daily Mail & General Trust yesterday lodged a bid in excess of £100m for Express Newspapers.

Decisions on the takeover of newspapers or their parent companies are subject to rules different from those found in other industries - their role in opinion forming makes them unique. The Fair Trading Act of 1973 put newspapers into a special category - the 25% threshold on market share which triggers investigations by the OFT in other industries does not apply to the press. Proposed legislation will leave the government's more interventionist role in newspapers untouched.

Under the rules governing newspaper ownership, a referral to the competition commission is automatically made if the total circulation of the titles being acquired plus those owned by the buyer are together more than 500,000. Any acquisition of an individual newspaper with average sales of 50,000 by another media group must also be referred.

In other words any sizeable merger or takeover will automatically come under the scrutiny of the competition commission for a "public interest" test before being passed to Mr Byers for a final decision. The views of anyone from rivals to advertisers will be taken into account when making a decision but issues such as pluralism of opinion are not an exact science and are open to broadly differing interpretations. Accurate presentation of news and freedom of expression are the key criteria set out by the commission.

It has been some time since a national newspaper merger took place and it is unclear whether the fact that the Mail and Express occupy the same mid-market space would be a deal-breaking issue. The Mail group argues that it can maintain plurality of voice within a single group. It may be encouraged by the recent takeover of the Belfast Telegraph by Tony O'Reilly's Dublin-based Independent News & Media. When that deal was first announced it caused uproar among the unionist community who feared the newspaper falling into the hands of a company with its headquarters in the Irish Republic.

Mr O'Reilly, however, managed to assuage those fears by promising a separate independent board for the Belfast Telegraph and keeping the present moderate unionist editorial line.

The Mail group is preparing a series of similar safeguards to maintain the leftwing stance of the Daily Express, at least until after the next general election. Mail insiders argue that to maintain a different editorial line makes economic sense instead of building a Daily Mail mark II. The Mail group will also hope to win favour with the promise of substantial investment in Express Newspapers.

Rupert Murdoch's acquisition of the Times and the Sunday Times in 1980 employed an "urgency" caveat in the rules which can allow the secretary of state to make a decision without reference to the competition commission. The rule can be invoked if the titles are "not economic", that is not making money. It was argued at the time that the Times and the Sunday Times were both making a loss, although diary extracts from the late Lord Wyatt of Weeford later suggested that Lady Thatcher had colluded with Mr Murdoch and that the Sunday Times was in fact in profit. Mr Murdoch made use of the rule again in 1987 when he bought Today.

Because of the media's role in influencing the electorate, it is easy to believe that decisions taken on mergers or takeovers are rarely based on empirical evidence alone. According to the rules the financial state of the parent company does not come into play, merely the health of the newspapers. In that case, an argument could be constructed around recent figures released by City advisers to Express Newspapers' parent company United News & Media which suggested they were hardly breaking even. However, United's boss, Lord Hollick, would have to threaten the titles with closure.

News International has since managed to build a market share of more than 30%. Put together the titles owned by the Mail and Express Newspapers would account for between 25% and 30%, depending on how the total market is defined. (The chart uses a more restrictive definition based on full rate sales.) There is no set limit on how much of the national market any single newspaper baron can control.

Even if the government's own self-interest is high on the agenda, the decision may hinge on how seriously ministers believe the reinvention of the Express should be taken. Its turn to the left has only been in effect for the past two-and-a-half years - not long in the history of Beaverbrook's creation. Although it has made much of its transformation and the attraction of a new, younger readership, a large part of its circulation is as likely to vote Tory as ever.

If the takeover sets a precedent in the industry it is likely to be short-lived. The rules governing newspaper ownership could be turned upside down in the communications bill (due for publication later this year) which will re-examine everything from cross-media ownership to the role of BBC governors.

David Teather is the Guardian's media business correspondent

webTitle: High pound prompts Honda production change

fields.headline: High pound prompts Honda production change
fields.trailText: One of Britain's biggest carmakers, Honda, today announced big changes to production plans at its UK plant, providing fresh evidence that the high value of the pound and uncertainty over the euro is damaging British manufacturing.
fields.body:
One of Britain's biggest carmakers, Honda, today announced big changes to production plans at its UK plant, providing fresh evidence that the high value of the pound and uncertainty over the euro is damaging British manufacturing.

A previously announced plan to build a new "super Mini" at the factory in Swindon has been postponed, the company said in a statement from Tokyo. The carmaker also announced that a 4x4 Honda - the CR-V - which has just started production at Swindon - will be exported to north America.

The company cited the continued high value of the pound as one of the main reasons for Honda altering its production plans so that Swindon reaches full manufacturing capacity quicker than previously announced. "Honda's commitment to the UK remains rock solid," said a company spokesman. "We have worked our way around the euro/high pound problem by adapting manufacturing facilities."

Employment levels will not be affected by the announcement, with Honda continuing to increase its workforce at Swindon from the present 3,000 to 4,000 by 2002.

The company launched a major recruitment drive last month to hire 500 production workers to support planned expansion at Swindon.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said he was disappointed that the new "super Mini" will not be built at Swindon but added he was relieved that no jobs were being lost.

"This shows that unless we join the euro we will become uncompetitive and find it more difficult to export into Europe," he said. "Most companies will not be able to switch markets like Honda and job losses will undoubtedly follow."

fields.headline: Hauliers plan five-day 'Jarrow convoy'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Protesters campaigning for cuts in fuel tax last night announced a new Jarrow crusade - a convoy of trucks which will set off from the north east of England on a five-day journey to a rally planned for Hyde Park on November 14.
fields.body:
Protesters campaigning for cuts in fuel tax last night announced a new Jarrow crusade - a convoy of trucks which will set off from the north east of England on a five-day journey to a rally planned for Hyde Park on November 14.

"I would like to make an invitation to every person in the country to go on a little jaunt down to London on November 10," said Andrew Spence, a member of the committee of the People's Fuel Lobby at a meeting of hauliers and farmers in Chelford, Cheshire, last night. "I don't know if anyone has heard of the Jarrow crusade (when unemployed men marched to London in 1936). Well, it's starting again, only bigger. We want as many vehicles on the road as possible."

Mr Spence said the convoy would assemble in Jarrow on November 10 and move on first to Newcastle and York, then to Leeds and Manchester, then Stoke, Wolverhampton and Birmingham before passing through Northampton and Milford Keynes to arrive in London on November 14.

"We want every member of the public to come along and support us, whether they are there for 10 minutes or four days," he said. This is a historic crusade against an illegal tax."

More than 100 people attended the meeting designed to rally support for the Hyde Park demonstration. November 13 will see the expiry of the 60-day period in which protestors, who halted the distribution of fuel supplies in September, demanded that ministers should cut fuel tax.

David Handley, the lobby's chairman, promised the rally would be "a demonstration like no one has ever seen before. It's going to be a peaceful protest," he said. "But don't think we are going to sit on the grass and twiddle our thumbs. We are going to be there to send a message, but this is the last time we are coming to talk."

webTitle: Opec says extra oil is on the way

fields.headline: Opec says extra oil is on the way
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Oil exporters promised yesterday to release more crude onto world markets to bring down prices from their 10-year highs.
fields.body:
Oil exporters promised yesterday to release more crude onto world markets to bring down prices from their 10-year highs.

Opec, the alliance of oil producing countries, agreed earlier this year to increase production by 500,000 barrels if world prices stayed above $28 a barrel for 20 working days.

That threshold was reached on Friday and yesterday Saudi sources said extra oil at would be pumped from midnight.

But markets are sceptical that the 11-member cartel can deliver the extra oil. Benchmark Brent crude prices in London rose 33 cents to $31.28 a barrel after the news.

"It's a paper gesture," said Leo Drollas, chief economist for the Centre for Global Energy Studies in London. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Qatar were producing 270,000 barrels a day above present quotas while most other members were hard pressed to meet their existing quotas.

Western finance ministers are worried rising energy prices could cut into growth and raise inflation.

But Britain might escape more lightly than most, according to Bank of England's new chief economist, because inflation has been under the government's 2.5% target for more than a year.

"We have room to take a bit of an acceleration in inflation without any serious difficulty," Professor Charlie Bean told MPs on the Treasury select committee yesterday.

"It would only be if oil prices went above $40 a barrel and stayed there for any serious length of time that I'd start getting worried about the implications for growth and inflation," he said.

webTitle: Essential fuel users urged to stock up

fields.headline: Essential fuel users urged to stock up
fields.standfirst:
Tories accuse Straw of risking renewed panic buying as ministers confirm 1,000 soliders are ready to drive oil tankers
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Tories accuse Straw of risking renewed panic buying as ministers confirm 1,000 soliders are ready to drive oil tankers.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday urged industry and essential fuel users lto stock up on petrol in case militant campaigners for cheaper fuel taxes try to renew their strangehold on supplies in two weeks' time.

Mr Straw's remark that the looming crisis "places the responsibility on industry and organisations like the health service to get in stocks" prompted complaints from senior Tories that he is bound to provoke panic buying among ordinary motorists.

In a series of radio and TV interviews to promote the government's hard line the home secretary, who chairs the cabinet's civil emergencies committee, also confirmed that soldiers are being rapidly trained - up to 1,000 ministers later admitted - to drive oil tankers.

Bernard Jenkin, the Tory transport spokesman, wrote to Mr Straw, accusing him of provoking "panic buying amongst the population as a whole" because ministers had been"humiliated" by the September protest.

As both sides in the dispute flexed their muscles two weeks before the expiry of the protesters' 60 day deadline for tax concessions, Tory MPs at Westminster also denounced ministerial "sabre rattling" and demanded to know who would be in charge if troops are de ployed to "bust any sort of strike".

In the Commons yesterday, the defence minister, John Spellar, confirmed weekend press reports that 1,000 soldiers will have been "prudently and contingently" trained to drive oil tankers by the November 13 deadline, to avoid repetition of the rapid collapse of stocks in September.

Encouraged by unions which recall the efficiency with which Margaret Thatcher defeated public sector strikes in the 1980s ministers are taking a belligerent line against the motley alliance of farmers, truckers and their allies, determined to show they too can maintain public order and essential supplies in the face of a determined campaign.

"It is absolutely right to make contingency plans in the event that there is a request from the civil authorities for the military forces to train a number of personnel to be able to undertake such tasks in order to maintain the supply of essential services to the nation," Mr Spellar told MPs.

Opposition MPs demanded to know the legal basis of soldiers' involvement and whether they would all be volunteers for what truckers warn will be a dangerous exercise even without the possibility of intimidation.

Oil tankers are hard to drive and carry an explosive cargo, they point out.

With the fuel protesters leaders complaining that they have not been allowed to make their case directly to Tony Blair or Chancellor Brown, the financial secretary to the Treasury, Stephen Timms, was forced by the bad weather to postpone a private meeting with freight industry representatives yesterday.

"This was to have been part of a consultation process. It would have been us talking and them listening. We have had a series of meetings and the government are definitely in listening mode," Geoff Dossetter, a truckers' spokesman, said.

Nine days ahead of Mr Brown's annual pre-budget report, which will signal many of the tax and spending changes in the March budget - including petrol and vehicle taxes-- Mr Timms is seeing a number of representative bodies.

Both sides are engaged in a war of nerves ahead of the threatened showdown while keen not to lose public opinion which sided with the protesters in September.

Ministers believe that, now that the previously unreported intimidation of oil tanker drivers has emerged, ordinary voters will not be so sympathetic.

webTitle: Comment: We've got to fix those cars

fields.headline: We've got to fix those cars
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The devastating floods in the south and in the East Midlands two years ago, without precedent in living memory, were just one sign. Now there are tornados in West Sussex. There are plenty of other signs. And they all throw the recent fuel crisis into sharp relief.
fields.body:
The devastating floods in the south and in the East Midlands two years ago, without precedent in living memory, were just one sign. Now there are tornados in West Sussex. There are plenty of other signs. And they all throw the recent fuel crisis into sharp relief.

In the last two years we have seen massive flooding and mud slides in Venezuela and Mozambique, devastating hurricanes in the Caribbean and Orissa in India, and inextinguishable forest fires in Greece and the western states of the US. Floods in the Yangtse river basin in 1998 caused 4,000 deaths and economic losses of $30bn.

It would be foolish to pretend that every time extreme weather conditions occur, it is due to global warming. But the increasing frequency and intensity of extreme climate phenomena, particularly the concentration of unprecedented climatic events within the last two years, suggest that although global warming is certainly not the sole cause, it is very likely to be a major contributory factor.

Climate change is not some trendy intellectual scenario for the distant future. It is with us now. It is remarkable that, during the recent fuel crisis, hardly anyone mentioned the environment.

Of course nobody would suggest that Opec's arbitrary ratcheting up of the price of oil is the right way to make an environmental policy for transport. But there is an environmental case to be made. Vehicles are, worldwide, the single fastest rising cause of carbon dioxide emissions, the main driver of climate change.

The real lesson from the fuel crisis is that we should greatly speed up our shift from fossil fuels to renewable sources of energy. We should cut out our over-dependence on oil by accelerating our research and development of alternative fuels.

That is why we have the tax system to roll out cleaner fuels and are promoting fuel efficient cars. Through the EU, we have persuaded manufacturers to improve fuel efficiency by 25%. Vehicle Excise Duty is now linked to vehicle emissions for the first time. Currently there are around 20,000 cars which can run on gas and over 500 liquid propane gas refuelling sites. Through our Powershift programme we have just made available an additional £9m for converting vehicles to cleaner fuels.

Toyota and Honda are selling hybrid cars which are twice as efficient as conventional models. The Honda Insight does 80 miles per gallon, which would save £400 a year on petrol bills for the average motorist. Production costs are expected to fall over time to petrol and diesel levels. The production technology is novel, and the first large-scale plants are only just being constructed in the US. But if these plants are successful, similar plants in the UK could be constructed by 2004.

Solar photovoltaics and wind energy capacity are growing fast - at perhaps 30% a year - but it will still be several years before they provide a significant contribution.

Here in the UK we too face threats - the prospect of exotic diseases becoming commonplace, of floods in some years, droughts in others, of low-lying areas being swallowed by the sea.
