fields.headline: Government tackles debt
fields.standfirst: Taskforce to call for responsible lending.
fields.trailText: A government taskforce is to be set up to tackle Britain's soaring debt problem and is expected to call for a tightening up of the rules governing how banks and other lenders market products such as credit cards and loans, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
A government taskforce is to be set up to tackle Britain's soaring debt problem and is expected to call for a tightening up of the rules governing how banks and other lenders market products such as credit cards and loans, it was announced yesterday.

Following a "debt summit" to discuss the issue, consumer affairs minister Kim Howells said the taskforce, which would include consumer groups and industry representatives, would start its deliberations next month and intended to come up with a set of recommendations by early spring.

The group will look at ways of achieving more a responsible attitude to lending and borrowing in the wake of a recent report from the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, which found that personal debts - including credit cards and store cards, overdrafts and hire purchase repayments - had increased 16% on last year.

Mr Howells said the average British adult had debts of £17,000, including mortgages. Overall outstanding consumer debt, including home loans, now stands at £610bn, while unsecured loans have risen to £115bn. The minister announced the formation of the taskforce following a summit meeting held in London attended by the British Bankers' Association, Council of Mortgage Lenders, the National Consumer Council and others.

He said he wanted to see greater transparency on contracts - "what the percentage rates are, how long the loan will last and what it will mean to the borrower in terms of their personal finances". Too often, the most important information was buried in the small print.

There was also concern about the methods companies use to lure people into taking out their products - NACAB said it had come across cases where companies were offering free products in order to tempt people into signing up.

It later emerged that one company highlighted at the meeting was credit card firm Capital One, which has been sending unsolicited letters to people offering them the chance to sign up for a platinum card with a credit limit of up to £25,000.

fields.headline: A village under the weather
fields.standfirst:
After the rain: Residents suffer fourth flood in 10 months.

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: As British Summer Time ended with a night of gales, blizzards and flooding which killed at least five people, residents of North Tawton evacuated their homes.
fields.body:
While most of Britain was safe in bed yesterday, listening to rain battering the rooftops, Christine King was knee-deep in water in her front room.

She had spent the night shifting her possessions to the safety of her Devon home's upper floor. But as the clock struck 4am, she felt the muddy red waters of the River Taw gush over her wellington boots and admitted defeat. The weather had won.

"It's all a bit of a haze," she said wearily. "I haven't slept since yesterday morning.

"We've had three other floods here in the last 10 months, so we were expecting it.

"But even the fire engine couldn't pump it out. "

As British Summer Time ended with a night of gales, blizzards and flooding which killed at least five people, her neighbours in North Tawton evacuated their homes.

Howling winds brought down fences and branches as families took refuge in the town hall, while a hailstorm hindered clean-up attempts later in the day. Around 60mm of rain had fallen across north and mid Devon in just 24 hours, and 20 of the county's rivers were on flood alert as the environment agency warned that more rain was on its way.

Across the country storms closed roads, tore up trees and left householders without power.

The Met Office said that the clash of warm air from across the Atlantic and freezing winds from Iceland was to blame for the appalling conditions.

The 90mph winds and heavy rains brought back memories of the great storm of 1987 - even if forecasters had given a warning this time.

In 1987, forecaster Michael Fish came out with the now famous words: "A woman rang to say she'd heard a hurricane was on the way. Well, If you're watching, there isn't."

The 1987 hurricane left 19 people dead, compared to six in the storms that struck early yesterday.

Estimates of damage in 1987 were more than £100m against £200m this time.

Commuters struggled to get to work as train operators cancelled services, and fallen trees and heavy flooding made roads impassable.

Tens of thousands of households were left without heat or light as trees brought down power lines, affecting up to 50,000 in East Anglia.

A burst water main left 13,000 properties in Exeter without supplies.

In North Tawton they wearily began to clear up the mess after the fourth - and worst - flood in 10 months.

Even the gloom of a festive flood last Christmas Day could not compare to the daunting sight of these waters, which rose two feet in just half an hour.

The little Dartmoor village, six miles from Okehampton, has picture-postcard charm. But yesterday it was at the mercy of the savage natural forces celebrated by poet Ted Hughes, who lived here for much of his life and is buried in the graveyard of St Peter's church.

The late Poet Laureate would have relished the storms that tore across the country.

In Wind - written in the village - he celebrated the "grimace" of winter skylines, "the woods crashing through darkness, the booming hills," and gusts "stampeding the fields".

But yesterday few of those in North Tawton and beyond shared his enthusiasm.

Instead they began the slow process of repairing the damage and preparing for a long, cold, stormy winter.

fields.headline: Cost of the clean-up could reach £1bn
fields.standfirst:
Claims Insurers say disaster is third worst on record.

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The final bill for the storms and floods that have lashed southern England is expected to reach £500m, making it the third worst British disaster on record, in insurance terms, and threatening a steep increase in premiums next year.
fields.body:
The final bill for the storms and floods that have lashed southern England is expected to reach £500m, making it the third worst British disaster on record, in insurance terms, and threatening a steep increase in premiums next year.

But with more than a quarter of homes not having adequate contents insurance and because few insurers pay out for damaged fences, the true cost of the clean-up may approach £1bn.

Shares in insurance companies dived when the stockmarket opened yesterday, with £250m wiped off the value of Royal & SunAlliance, Britain's biggest household insurer.

Calls to claims departments reached four times their normal levels yesterday morning, but insurers said the damage reported was much less severe than that caused by the hurricane of 1987 or gales of 1990.

Eagle Star said: "We had 700 claims by 11am, but it's not a catastrophe on the scale of 1987 or 1990. The trees that were going to be uprooted and the chimney stacks that were going to fall disappeared then, so the damage now is not so severe."

Sunday night's gales hit some towns where insurance experts had only just started assessing claims following recent tornadoes. Direct Line - which had taken 2,000 claims calls by midday - said: "In some areas, such as Bognor Regis, we already had teams in place. We are currently giving telephone authorisation for urgent repairs of up to £1,000."

The full scale of losses will not be known for several weeks, according to Jeffrey Salmon, managing director of Salmon Assessors, but he estimates that the bill is unlikely to be lower than £350m. Then he warned that losses would be clawed back in higher premiums next year.

"Premiums went up steeply after 1987 and 1990, and I estimate that they will go up an other 50-60% next year. In some ways the insurers enjoy these big events, because it gets everybody to come to them and allows them to put up premiums. Every time there is a major disaster, the following year the insurers report record profit figures," said Mr Salmon, who acts on behalf of individuals whose claims have been denied by insurance companies.

However, the Association of British Insurers denied that big premium increases are in the pipeline. "A big storm in itself will not be sufficient to force premiums up," said a spokesman.

The average buildings insurance premium in Britain is £160, with contents insurance adding a further £88, says the ABI. A 60% increase would add around £150 to the bill.

Premiums have remained fairly steady over the past three years, partly because wetter weather has reduced subsidence claims, which cost insurers more than storm damage. A Royal & Sun Alliance spokesman said: "It's been swings and roundabouts for us - what we've lost on storm damage we've made up on fewer subsidence claims."

Biggest payouts

2 Oct 1987 Hurricane (south) £1,050m

3 Oct 2000 Gales/flooding (south) £500m*

4 Dec 1995 Snow/ice (Scotland, north) £320m

5 Jan 1987 Snow/ice (south) £277m

6 Dec 1997 Flooding (national) £270m

7 Jan 1982 Arctic weather (national) £250m

8 Feb 1991 Snow/flooding (national) £185m

= Jan 1993 Storms/flooding (national) £185m

10 Jan 1984 Snow/ice (north) £145m

*Industry estimate

Source: Association of British Insurers

webTitle: Estrada risks replay of the domino effect

fields.headline: Estrada risks replay of the domino effect
fields.standfirst: The Philippine president is leading South-east Asia's currencies into a downward spiral
fields.trailText: The Philippine president is leading South-east Asia's currencies into a downward spiral, report John Aglionby in Jakarta and Charlotte Denny.
fields.byline: John Aglionby in Jakarta and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Anyone watching South-east Asia's tumbling markets could be forgiven for believing they are experiencing a case of déjà vu. Only this time it is the Philippine peso that is leading the currency plunge rather than the Thai baht.

As the Philippines economy continued its relentless downward spiral yesterday, the man at the centre of the storm, president Joseph Estrada, refused to resign. Fighting for his political life, he offered to relinquish the country's top economic job to his deputy and chief critic, vice president Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

"I will not resign," Estrada said in a televised address to the nation, in response to charges that he took £7.5m in payoffs from illegal gambling. "I will answer all the charges point by point at the proper time. Let the impeachment process take its due course."

Last night it was unclear whether Ms Arroyo, who resigned from the cabinet earlier this month, would accept the olive branch and take the chair of the economic co-ordinating council.

The president's address to the nation is unlikely to reassure investors, who remember that the last crisis also began with a currency collapse. When the Thai government stopped defending the baht's peg against the dollar in July 1997, it triggered a domino effect of collapsing currencies throughout the region.

Shock waves

The after shocks from the Asian crisis rumbled through world financial markets for most of the following year. The collapse of the Long Term Capital Management hedge fund, which nearly brought the world financial system to a halt in October 1998, had its origins in events in Asia. By 1999 the worse hit economies had made strong recoveries and the IMF proclaimed the end of the crisis. While growth has recovered, markets and currencies throughout the region have taken another bath this year.

This time, regional development analysts are trying to convince anyone who will listen that the turmoil is nothing to worry about. The Asian Development Bank, for instance, in its October Asia Recovery Report, put a remarkably bullish spin on a region where equity market capitalisation in local currency levels has fallen by an average of over 30% since the start of the year.

"The magnitude of net capital outflows is nowhere near as large as it was in 1997 and 1998," it says. "The symptoms are the same, but the causes are quite different," said Yoshihiro Iwasaki, the head of ADB's regional economic monitoring unit.

In the last crisis, a massive inflow of foreign investment put the weak financial systems of the region under strain. This time, investors have been more wary so there is less foreign money to withdraw. Most countries in the region have abandoned pegging their currencies, forcing companies to hedge against the risk of fluctuations in the exchange rate.

The trigger for investor nerves this time has been politics rather than economics. The peso has fallen from less than 44 to the US dollar to 51.3 at yesterday's close, thanks to Mr Estrada's involvement in the gambling scandal. Mr Estrada likes to boast that the Philippines is doing better than its neighbours and has recovered much of its losses since 1997. The reality is that its economy did not have so far to fall and is now barely afloat.

Indonesia is not far behind. Its currency, the rupiah, was at 8,500 to the dollar 10 weeks ago. Yesterday it fell from 9,035 to 9,410 before firming slightly to 9,325. The central bank advocates intervention but the president, Abdurrahman Wahid, disagrees. Mr Wahid is embroiled in several financial scandals himself, including giving heavily-indebted cronies billions of pounds in debt bailouts. There is growing anti-western sentiment in Indonesia. Many investors have pulled out.

Tight controls

Malaysia rejected international assistance in 1997 and imposed capital controls instead. The last of these controls were lifted yesterday and a slew of foreign money left for safer climes immediately. No one is predicting what the next few weeks will hold.

Thailand is proving to be the nation with its finger in the dyke. While there is nervousness in Bangkok over December's general election and a clear slowdown in economic reform, the baht appears to be holding its own. Dealers say the crucial level is 44 baht to the US dollar. Experts believe that a drop in that level could create problems in Thailand and elsewhere. It closed yesterday at 43.65 with dealer sentiment becoming increasingly negative.

Gerard Lyons, head of treasury research at Standard Chartered, says the causes of unease this time are specific to individual countries, and are therefore less likely to lead to a re-run of the last crisis. But he notes that the lesson to be learnt from 1997, is that contagion quickly spreads. "You can easily be too complacent."

The last of these controls were lifted yesterday and a slew of foreign money left for safer climes immediately. No one is predicting what the next few weeks will hold. Thailand is proving to be the nation with its finger in the dyke. While there is nervousness in Bangkok over December's general election and a clear slowdown in economic reform, the baht appears to be holding its own. Dealers say the crucial level is 44 baht to the US dollar. Experts believe that a drop in that level could create problems in Thailand and elsewhere. It closed yesterday at 43.65 with dealer sentiment becoming increasingly negative. Gerard Lyons, head of treasury research at Standard Chartered, says the causes of unease this time are specific to individual countries, and are therefore less likely to lead to a re-run of the last crisis. But he notes that the lesson to be learnt from 1997, is that contagion quickly spreads. "You can easily be too complacent."

fields.headline: Gossip buoys Kingfisher
fields.trailText: Kingfisher, the retail conglomerate behind Woolworths and B&Q, was in the spotlight yesterday on talk that it might be about to unload its stake in Liberty Surf, one of France's largest internet service providers.
fields.body:
Kingfisher, the retail conglomerate behind Woolworths and B&Q, was in the spotlight yesterday on talk that it might be about to unload its stake in Liberty Surf, one of France's largest internet service providers.

Its shares ended the session 13p better at 391.75p, on whispers that Kingfisher chief executive Sir Geoff Mulchay wants out of the venture, which is expected to cost the company something in the region of £40m this year.

Apparently Sir Geoff has been on the road in the past week visiting City brokers and institutions in an effort to persuade them of the merits of the proposed split of Kingfisher into two businesses. The sale of its 35% stake in Liberty Surf is said to be one of a number of measures designed to reassure investors who are nervous about the demerger.

Since Kingfisher announced the plan to spin off Woolworths and Superdrug in a separate company from B&Q and Comet, its shares have fallen over 85p.

It seems Sir Geoff is unhappy about the losses at Liberty Surf and is looking for what one dealer said was a "corporate way out". The disposal of the Liberty Surf stake, even at a knock-down price, would be welcomed by shareholders not least because the losses currently depress pretax profits by about 6%-7%.

At the presentations Kingfisher is also said to have indicated that it is examining the best way to maximise value from its £1.6bn property portfolio. Under discussion the gossips claim is a plan to sell and then lease back the property and use the proceeds to pay down Kingfisher's debt burden, which is expected to hit £1.5bn. Kingfisher refused to comment.

For a storm ravaged day in October (the last one helped trigger the 1987 crash) leading shares remarkably finished higher. Adding to Friday's 64.2 point gain, the FTSE 100 ended the day 21.9 ahead at 6,388.4, with firm telecoms and drugs stocks providing the upward impetus.

But market professionals were not getting carried away noting that the total number of shares traded was just over 1bn as many dealers, owing to the weather, stayed at home.

British Airways, up 25.25p to 290.25p, topped the blue-chip performance chart with dealers citing strong results from one-time merger partner KLM and a weakening oil price as the reasons behind the move.

The oil price was also helping chemicals group ICI, which surged 19p to 423p, after admitting that it was talking to Belgium-based Ineos about disposals. Reportedly Ineos will buy ICI's remaining industrial chemical operations.

Industrial electronics supplier Electrocomponents was also in demand rising 24.5p to 672.5p after UBS Warburg restarted coverage with a "buy" rating and a 800p price target.

Elsewhere, the City's current bid favourite BG was having a bad day. Shares in the oil and gas exploration company fell 20.75p to 278.25p after a number of brokers said the stock, which rose 39p last week on talk of a bid, is now overvalued. Al Stanton at Deutsche Bank, who yesterday lowered his stance on BG spoke for many when he said: "Investors should invest in BG on its industrial merits and be wary of any price volatility based on takeover prospects."

Things were also bad in the technology sector. Yesterday's problems started when a US analysts lowered his price target for Cisco, the network equipment maker, citing concerns about capital expenditure. Bookham Technology, which makes components used in high-speed telecom networks, was the worst hit slipping 147p to £21.44, while Marconi lost 28p to 849p. The Techmark index closed 57.72 points lower at 3,353.83.

Sema eased 59p to 857p after UBS Warburg lowered its earnings forecasts and cut its price target to £11 from £12.50 after a meeting with Anglo-French IT services outfit.

Lower down in the technology group African Lakes added 5p to 40.5p on the appointment of former Mirror Group boss, David Montgomery, as chairman.

fields.headline: Bush turns fire on California
fields.standfirst:
Race for the White House

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The race for the White House headed to the west coast yesterday as George W Bush and Al Gore fought an unexpectedly fierce battle for California, previously thought to be firmly in the Gore camp.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington and Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
The race for the White House headed to the west coast yesterday as George W Bush and Al Gore fought an unexpectedly fierce battle for California, previously thought to be firmly in the Gore camp.

California's 54 electoral college votes are the richest single prize in next week's presidential election. So when last week's polls showed Mr Gore's lead slipping, both candidates rescheduled their plans for the final week.

Mr Bush was the first to hit California, arriving yesterday for rallies in Los Angeles and in the agricultural heartland city of Fresno, where he was joined by his former Republican rival Senator John McCain.

Mr Gore was not far behind, heading west last night for a campaign swing through Oregon and California today after spending yesterday in the battleground states of Michigan and Wisconsin.

Underlining the importance the two sides attach to the country's most populous state, President Clinton will also spend two days on the stump in California later this week, focusing his appeal on ethnic minority voters, and rallying Democrats who might be tempted to vote for the Green candidate, Ralph Nader.

When the presidential race began in earnest in September California did expect to be courted so seriously, especially in the final week of the campaign. So confident of victory was Mr Gore that he had not visited the state since speaking at the Democratic convention in Los Angeles in August.

Mr Bush had made brief visits, but there were few indications that the Republicans had a realistic chance of winning until last week, when a Los Angeles Times poll showed Mr Gore's lead under threat for the first time.

The poll, putting Mr Gore on 48%, Mr Bush on 41%, and Mr Nader on 5%, showed the race too close for Democratic comfort and spurred a new £1m advertising assault from the Republicans.

A more recent poll, carried out for the San Francisco Examiner and published yesterday, has better news for Mr Gore. It finds him on 49% to Mr Bush's 39%, with Mr Nader on 5%.

With Mr Nader also due back in the state this week, the campaign will not lack for Californian glamour. Mr Gore is scheduled to appear at a rally in Los Angeles with the actress Whoopi Goldberg.

Mr Bush and Mr Gore are also both taking the opportunity, while in Los Angeles, of appearing once again on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. The chance to take part in a high-ratings show that will demonstrate their "human" side is considered too good to be missed.

Mr Nader will be attending a final mass rally in Long Beach on Friday night, but his hold on his supporters in California may be facing a squeeze as the Bush-Gore contest heads towards a photo finish.

Greg MacArthur, who has been financing a $320,000 ad campaign for Mr Nader on behalf of Citizens for Strategic Voting, pulled his ads from the Los Angeles Times, San Francisco Examiner and San Francisco Chronicle newspapers last week as fears arose that a Nader vote night lose Mr Gore the state.

Mr Bush will be vying with Mr Clinton in making a special pitch to the large Latino vote in California.

Spanish language ads for the Republicans have been shown widely in the state and Mr Bush addressed Latino community leaders in the city of Anaheim by satellite on Sunday.

 Two weeks after her husband died in an air crash, the widow of the Missouri governor and Democratic senatorial candidate Mel Carnahan announced yesterday that she would take up his seat if he is posthumously elected on November 7.

The late governor's name remained on the ballot after a small plane crashed killing him, his son and an aide.
Julian Borger, Washington

webTitle: India starts to count its losses

fields.headline: India starts to count its losses
fields.standfirst: Exodus:  West lures doctors and IT workers
fields.trailText: There is nothing new about migration from the Indian subcontinent. It was, after all, Indian architects who built the great temples at Angkor Wat in Cambodia in the 12th century.
fields.body:
There is nothing new about migration from the Indian subcontinent. It was, after all, Indian architects who built the great temples at Angkor Wat in Cambodia in the 12th century.

It is only now, after more recent migrations of Indian doctors to Britain and skilled IT workers to Silicon Valley in the United States, that the world's biggest democracy is beginning to count the cost.

About 18m Indians live abroad, in more than 100 countries. They range from a solitary Roman Catholic priest from Goa on the Cape Verde islands to 1.5m Indians in the US. Many were trained in India, and it is India which is at last starting to comprehend its loss.

The same problem besets other countries in the developing world. Recent research shows that only half the foreign doctoral and post-doctoral students who study in Europe and America return to their own countries within two years of finishing their studies.

The mixed feelings of people in countries such as India towards their successful expatriates find their most bittersweet focus in Europe. Under pressure to ease intensifying skills shortages, European governments are looking increasingly to India as a potential source of workers.

About 1.3m people of Indian origin live in Britain, where they form the biggest single ethnic group in the NHS. France and Germany have about 40,000 each.

So what are the costs to India of helping Europe to cope with its labour shortages?

Some, like Bob Bradnock, professor of geography at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London, see the brain drain as a "positive" force. "People develop skills abroad. There is a two-way flow," he said. But there is no doubt that poorer countries still suffer a net loss.

There are plenty of Indian doctors in the NHS, but too few in rural India. India needs 2.2m IT professionals of its own over the next eight years - a figure it is unlikely to reach because of the continuing exodus of bright graduates from its elite institutes of technology to jobs abroad. Engineers, physicists, pilots, nurses and teachers have also gone overseas in large numbers, creating their own shortages.

In a global marketplace all countries suffer from the migration of skilled workers, according to LM Singhvi, former Indian high commissioner in London. But those in the developed world are better able to cope with the loss.

"There is no doubt it has a negative impact. You are losing skilled manpower in which you have put a considerable investment," he said.

Dr Singhvi, an eminent jurist and Indian MP, has recently been appointed to a new cabinet committee to forge better links between India and its diaspora.

He wants Britain and other countries to compensate India for the initial cost of educating skilled workers who then go abroad, in the form of investment in Indian colleges and universities.

"Equity demands that something should be done. The British are well known for their sense of fair play. As things stand India gets a bad bargain," he said.

But others suggest that the only reason Indians have been successful abroad is because they left in the first place.

LK Sharma, the Times of India's veteran London correspondent, points to the example of Har Gobind Khorana, who won the Noble prize for medicine after leaving Indian research facilities for the US. He later decided to become a US citizen.

"The ethos of their new countries has something to do with their achievement," Mr Sharma said.

'Life is good. Italians are good people'

Razzak Abdu, 33, from Bangladesh, works in a grocery shop in Rome

"I left my home 11 years ago to find a job because in Bangladesh it was impossible, there were so many people. I left my family behind but it was the only way.

"I came to Italy and was lucky. There were far fewer foreigners than there are now. I got papers and was allowed to work legally. For the first few years I stayed with a friend in Rome, before finding my own place.

"He helped me to find a job in a grocery shop and I've been here ever since. I sort out deliveries, stock the shelves, clean, run messages. Usually I work around 12 hours a day, six days a week. It's long, but I like it.

"It was a few years before I spoke good Italian. My wife and two children joined me three years ago. I can make just one visit home a year, and I miss my parents.

"Life is good here. Italians are good people, they have treated me decently, though I have many friends who can't find apartments because they're foreigners. Some day I'd like to open my own shop."

'The worst thing is being talked down to'

Norma Vitor, 37, took a job as a cleaner after moving from Peru to Spain

"If I had known how hard it was going to be I wouldn't have come. I shouldn't complain - I had enough money and contacts. I've known some who slept out in the streets.

"I'd taken a payoff from the company I worked for in Peru as a secretary. The economy and the politics were bad. I'd seen films about Spain; we spoke the same language. I thought that people would be more welcoming.

"First I flew to Lisbon [in Portugal] and then took the train. I was terrified the police would ask for my papers - I knew they were sending people back.

"I soon found work cleaning. It's a step down but I don't mind. The worst thing is being talked down to. Spanish people can be very harsh. At home they're softer, they have more time.

"Things have worked out. I have my residency permit. I'm even thinking of buying a flat. But the sense of distance is very hard. Without the other Peruvians I wouldn't have survived."

fields.headline: Syngenta float valued at £4.4bn
fields.standfirst: Triple listing kicks off next month
fields.trailText: Syngenta, the company formed from the demerged agri-business interests of Novartis and AstraZeneca, is expected to be valued at £4.4bn when it makes its stock market debut next month.
fields.body:
Syngenta, the company formed from the demerged agri-business interests of Novartis and AstraZeneca, is expected to be valued at £4.4bn when it makes its stock market debut next month.

A total of 4.5m shares, priced between SFr85 (£32) and SFr105, will be available in a global offering on November 13 which will see the new venture floated in London, New York, on SWX in Switzerland and the OMX in Sweden.

But the plan may still face delays as the US federal trade commission is yet to approve the move, which follows the merger of Novartis and AstraZeneca.

The two companies decided to spin-off their crop protection and seeds operations into Syngenta, in order to concentrate on health care.

Syngenta also announced yesterday it was selling its corn herbicides business to Dow Chemical for an undisclosed sum.

Michael Pragnell, the company's chief executive, refused to disclose further details of the sale which was required by the European Commission as part of its competition review for creating Syngenta. "The major divestment is acetochlor, which is corn herbicides," he said at a news conference in Zurich, adding that further, smaller sales might result from talks currently in progress with potential buyers.

Analysts were generally disappointed with the news, saying the valuation was considerably lower than Syngenta had originally expected.

The reasons behind the relatively low figure, they suggested, included disenchantment with the specialty chemicals industry and the fact the farm sector was yet to bounce back to prominence.

Another City analyst commented Syngenta would find its markets tough over the next year but easing towards 2002.

"There's a feeling it's been tough but is unlikely to get any worse," he said. "Next year is likely to be different with some sort of recovery taking place."

The flotation plans will see a syndicate led by Credit Suisse First Boston and UBS Warburg will sell up to 4.5m Syngenta shares in the offering. Bookbuilding starts today and is scheduled to run until November 9.

fields.headline: US group takes biscuit empire
fields.trailText: Wagon Wheels, the Wild West-themed biscuit consumed by generations of children, will switch to American ownership following the £130m sale of Burton's Biscuits by Associated British Foods.
fields.body:
Wagon Wheels, the Wild West-themed biscuit consumed by generations of children, will switch to American ownership following the £130m sale of Burton's Biscuits by Associated British Foods.

The Burton's business, which also produces Jammie Dodgers and Jaffa Cakes, is to be brought together with Horizon Biscuits under its new owner, Hicks, Muse, Tate and Furst, a private equity group.

The sale is the latest part of restructuring of ABF, which also controls British Sugar and the retail chain Primark in its £4.3bn turnover international business.

New chief executive Peter Jackson is committed to hiving off non-core interests to focus on businesses perceived to have faster growth potential.

The Burton's sale was announced simultaneously with the disposal of ABF's margarine and bakery fats business, Rowallan Creameries, to Anglia Oil, a subsidiary of Aahus Olie of Denmark.

Adrian Sharp , chief executive of Burton's, has been asked by Hicks, Muse to take a similar post in the new business which will produce Wagon Wheels alongside Maryland Cookies and Cadbury Fingers.

He made little effort to hide his frustration over the way in which the sale of Burton's had been organised. In a statement to staff he said: "Since Mr Weston's retirement due to ill health there has been a different and uncertain attitude from the new chief executive, Peter Jackson, to those companies which lack the scale of, say, British Sugar."

Pay and other conditions of employment would be unaffected but "there will inevitably be changes in many of our work practices and in rationalisation of products".

Burton's employs 2,500 staff at three factories in Blackpool, Edinburgh and Llantarnam, Wales. Last year the company sold £172m worth of biscuits.

The sector has become ripe for consolidation. This year United Biscuits was sold for £1.26bn and Jacob's Club biscuits put up for sale by French owner Danone.

For ABF the latest disposals will help create a warchest of nearly £1bn. Mr Jackson will be under pressure to explain how he plans to spend the money when annual financial results are released on November 8.

Further acquisitions rather than share buybacks are anticipated following moves over the past 12 months into areas such as the ingredient markets through American companies such as Abitec.

Big wheels Wagon Wheels were enjoyed as much by the KGB as by British children. When the Soviet Union collapsed, a massive store of the biscuits was found at secret service headquarters.

webTitle: Germany says welcome, but for how long?

fields.headline: Germany says welcome, but for how long?
fields.standfirst: In the second and final part of our series we look at a 'green card' scheme aimed at bringing in much-needed hi-tech workers from the developing world. But are the Germans ready for a new influx of guest workers?
fields.trailText: In the second and final part of our series we look at a 'green card' scheme aimed at bringing in much-needed hi-tech workers from the developing world. But are the Germans ready for a new influx of guest workers?
fields.body:
Destinies can be shaped in unlikely ways. The chain of events that led 24-year-old Vivek Bhardowaj to a converted factory in east Berlin is more ironic than most. As he was studying for his finals at the Punjab Technical University earlier this year, a politician 4,000 miles away in the Rhineland was looking for a way to boost his regional election campaign. Jürgen Rüttgers of the Christian Democrat Union attacked the centre-left German government's plan to import up to 20,000 computer experts from the developing world. Germany, he said, needed better education, not more immigrants. Someone with an ear for a rhyme summed up his approach as Kinder statt Inder (Children not Indians).

A Berlin start-up, Datango, which was opening a jobs page on its website, seized on the controversy with its own jokey slogan: Sind Sie Inder ? (Are you an Indian?). A T-shirt with the slogan and the web address of Datango's jobs page appeared at an IT exhibition and up in the pages of the Times of India. Datango received 130 applications, one from Mr Bhardowaj.

The arrival in Germany of Mr Bhardowaj and thousands like him has sparked an explosive debate that touches on labour needs, educational failure and race.

Tighter controls
The Christian Democrats are debating whether to follow Mr Rüttgers' lead and make an anti-immigration stance the focus of their 2002 general election campaign. Yesterday two conservative parliamentary leaders vowed to follow his example and press ahead with plans to seek tighter immigration controls, despite warnings that they are playing with fire.

Fredrich Merz and Michael Glos said there was widespread concern about uncontrolled immigration.

"It's not an issue that is being artificially whipped up for an election campaign," said Mr Glos, parliamentary floor leader of the Bavarian Christian Social Union. "It's a topic that the public is concerned about and it has to be resolved. Declaring it taboo is the same as saying, 'The public is too dumb for this.'"

The launch of the scheme that attracted Mr Bhardowaj to Germany has made the choice more difficult than it would have been a few months ago: it has inverted the terms of a debate in which the right have traditionally enjoyed a natural advantage.

"In the past we always discussed immigration in terms of how we could avoid bringing people into Germany," Thomas Mickeleit, spokesman for IBM Deutschland, said. "Now, we're talking about the opposite."

His own company's support for the scheme highlights another important novelty: that in this debate the right cannot count on support from its natural allies in business. Indeed, the government's plan grew out of a dinner for IT company bosses in February given by the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

It lets computer experts live and work in Germany for up to five years provided they have either a university degree or the offer of a job paying more than DM100,000 (about £30,000) a year. The press dubbed it the "green card" scheme.

Hans Mader, the official in charge, said that in its first 10 weeks of operation, 2,261 people had been placed: to some a disappointing result. But, Mr Mickeleit, said, scheme and the debate should not be confused. "The number of Germans applying for courses in engineering sciences and IT has doubled since it began. It has become obvious to the public that there is a gap in their economy."

But behind the green card plan looms the question of whether Germany, like other European states, needs to import not thousands but millions of workers. Could Germany cope without an outburst of xenophobic resentment?

Mr Bhardowaj's first impression of Berlin was overwhelmingly positive. But he has been in Germany only a short time.

Jarnail and Ramona Singh have different experiences to recount. They, too, live in Berlin, having fled from the eastern town of Meerane, where they ran a restaurant.

On September 30, after a dispute with their neighbours, their premises were stormed by a howling drunken mob.

Racism and racist violence are scarcely unique to Germany, but there are several reasons why Germany is likely to find the transition to a multi-ethnic society more difficult than other western European countries.

For a start, it now includes the formerly communist east - a region in which, until just 10 years ago, the imposition of socialism was held to have obviated the need for a thorough reckoning with the racist past.

While the level of racial violence in the west is comparable with that elsewhere in western Europe, in eastern Germany it is four times the level of that in Britain, according to conservative official estimates.

In Germany there is an exceptionally close link in the public mind between nationality and ethnicity. Only this year have those born in Germany gained the automatic right to become Germans if their parents were born elsewhere. To most other Germans the 7m who belong to ethnic minorities are Ausländer (foreigners).

For decades the main parties insisted that Germany was "not a country of immigration". The foreigners who arrived as cheap labour were not immigrants but Gastarbeiter (guest workers). And, like guests, they were expected to leave when no longer welcome.

Several consequences flowed from this fundamental self-delusion. One was that when immigration rose again in the 80s it was dealt with not by a modern immigration act but by bending the asylum laws.

Just like apartheid
As Mr Schröder and the captains of hi-tech industries sat down to their dinner, Christopher Nsoh was drafting an open letter to highlight the grievances of asylum seekers.

"We cannot work. We cannot study. And we cannot travel," Mr Nsoh, a lawyer from Cameroon who lives in a hostel in the eastern town of Rathenow, explained. "If we want to go more than 60 miles outside the boundaries of our Landkreis [borough] then we need permission from the immigration officer. It is just like South Africa before the fall of apartheid."

To add to their problems, asylum seekers are favourite targets for neo-Nazi skinheads. "I've tried going out at night three times in Rathenow and I've been assaulted each time," Mr Nsoh said. "[It is] racism on the streets, racism in the institutions and racism in the law."

The green card initiative has undoubtedly helped to change perceptions. It has made the point that immigrants are a boon, not a burden. At the same time it is helping to sustain the old myth that one day, if circumstances change, the foreigners may all go home and leave Germany to the Germans. The green cardholders, with their five-year work permits, are ultimately modern hi-tech guest workers.

webTitle: Sketch: Simon Hoggart on Commons procedures

fields.headline: Archaic Commons procedures block lines of inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: It was the day of the great travel chaos and the Commons benches were as bare as last month's bread shelves in the supermarkets. If more than a sprinkling of electors had turned up they would have quickly emptied what was left into their trolleys. "Look,   dear, they've got an Anne McIntosh (Con, Vale of York) left. We'd better get her while we can."
fields.body:
It was the day of the great travel chaos and the Commons benches were as bare as last month's bread shelves in the supermarkets. If more than a sprinkling of electors had turned up they would have quickly emptied what was left into their trolleys. "Look, dear, they've got an Anne McIntosh (Con, Vale of York) left. We'd better get her while we can."

"Should I pick up that Paul Flynn and Ben Bradshaw while we're at it? Where would we keep them?"

"I think there's some room left in the freezer..."

So few MPs had managed to make it to Westminster that only 14 were present to ask the first 28 questions on defence.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, apologised for the absence of the under secretary of state. This was caused by the late arrival of the incoming minister, Lewis Moonie. So Mr Hoon, and another of his understrappers, John Spellar, had to race through all the questions in a rare example of panic answering. Sometimes they did this in a fairly disorganised way, which I blame on the bulky sheaves of briefing notes provided by civil servants: the wrong kind of lines on the leaves, as we say in the rail chaos business.

Throughout it all the new Speaker made announcements, alerting us to cancelled questions and delayed ministers. In this he resembled the station Tannoys so many of us have spent hours listening to in the past week or so, being designed to help but quite incomprehensible. The main problem of course is Commons procedure, which is as good at blocking a train of thought or a line of inquiry as any fallen tree.

There's only one important topic for defence ministers now, which is the fact that all our nuclear submarines are out of action. But yesterday's questions were tabled two weeks ago, before the news emerged.

Couldn't the order paper be adapted to allow MPs to raise the subject? Heavens, no! In Parliament, nothing is allowed to change. The permanent way means literally the permanent way; if it wasn't done like that in 1723, it can't be done now.

So instead the Tories were obsessed by plans to use soldiers to drive petrol round the country if there's another fuel blockade next month. Apparently this is part of a sinister Labour plot to keep the country moving and the wheels of industry turning even if a bunch of unelected, secretive conspirators would like to stop them.

John Wilkinson was particularly upset by the news. He asked if this was the best use of our military personnel, displaying a new and tender regard for operations such as Sierra Leone, which until a week ago were seen as outrageous examples of Robin Cook's ludicrous so-called ethical foreign policy which was stretching our forces to breaking point and making us an international laughing stock.

"Is this not sabre rattling that is likely to inflame industrial relations rather than calm them down?" Mr Wilkinson demanded.

Could this be the same John Wilkinson, I mused, who was an enthusiastic supporter of Margaret Thatcher, who left the streets of Britain to be thronged by muggers, housebreakers and footpads when she sent off tens of thousands of police to calm down industrial relations with the miners? Why, according to Who's Who, the very same!

Mr Spellar was full of fake amazement that the Tories should seem to support those who would "blockade, barricade and conduct a potentially illegal action".

There is a simple solution. MPs should be trained to stock the petrol stations. We would all be grateful; the prestige of the legislature would be restored, and on yesterday's showing, parliament would get on perfectly well without them.

fields.headline: Gun dealer paid £1.4m for false conviction
fields.trailText: An arms dealer whose conviction for selling machine guns to Iraq was quashed after evidence emerged that senior Foreign Office and customs officials had interfered in his trial has been awarded more than £1m in compensation.
fields.body:
An arms dealer whose conviction for selling machine guns to Iraq was quashed after evidence emerged that senior Foreign Office and customs officials had interfered in his trial has been awarded more than £1m in compensation.

Alexander Schlesinger, sales consultant to Atlantic Commercial, based in Rotherham, South Yorkshire, has been awarded £1.375m plus costs under the Home Office compensation scheme for miscarriages of justice.

The sum was agreed by Jack Straw, the home secretary, on the advice of an independent assessor who took into account the seniority of diplomats and customs officers whose conduct was described by Sir Richard Scott, chairman of the arms-to-Iraq inquiry, as disgraceful.

The claim is the latest in a series made by individuals and companies whose wrongful convictions for selling weapons to Iraq have already cost taxpayers more than £4m. The final total is likely to be far higher.

Mr Schlesinger was fined £3,000 in 1985 for his part in the sale of 200 Sterling submachine guns to Iraq via Jordan. With Reginald Dunk, director of Atlantic Commercial, he pleaded guilty after diplomats at the Jordanian and Iraqi embassies in London reneged on their promises to appear as witnesses for the defence. The diplomats had said the guns were a gift from Iraq to Jordan.

Documents released to the Scott inquiry revealed that, at the behest of customs, senior British diplomats agreed to have "friendly words" with the Iraqi and Jordanian ambassadors. One document said: "I confess to innocent reluctance to connive at impeding the course of justice!"

In 1994 Lord Taylor, then lord chief justice, said what he called the "machinations" in the case "to prevent witnesses for the defence being available, coupled with the non-disclosure of what had been done, constituted such an interference with the justice process as to amount to an abuse of it".

Last year Mr Dunk, who has since died, was awarded £2.15m in compensation for miscarriage of justice, loss of business - his company collapsed - and personal distress.

Mr Schlesinger and Mr Dunk also received £125,000 in an unprecedented settlement arising from the conduct of two senior diplomats, Cartsen Pigott and Patrick Nixon, in the arms case.

The dealers accused them of "abuse of public office". It was the first compensation where damages were recovered from a government department criticised in the Scott report. The FO maintained the payment was "without any admission of liability".

Mr Schlesinger, 58, said last night: "I am relieved that after 17 years of fighting to clear my name and to obtain compensation, this is finally all over." If it had not been for Sir Richard Scott and the late Lord Taylor, "the wrongful conviction would not have been quashed", he said.

"My business and personal life has been destroyed and I have been denied the opportunity of a fair trial and the chance to clear my name."

His lawyer, Lawrence Kormornick, said: " This was a serious case about human rights, the rule of law and government accountability." He regretted that neither customs nor the FO had apologised.

Mr Kormornick is now seeking compensation for Paul Henderson and Peter Allen, former directors of Matrix Churchill machine tools company, whose arms-to-Iraq trial collapsed after evidence emerged that the then Conservative government had turned a blind eye to the sale of arms-related equipment to Saddam Hussein in the 1980s.

Mr Kormornick is also claiming compensation for Ali Daghir, director of Euromac, who was convicted in 1991 for supplying "nuclear capacitors" - equipment used to store and release energy - to Iraq. His conviction was quashed after the appeal court ruled that the trial judge had misdirected the jury.

Paul Grecian, director of Ordtec, a military engineering company, is seeking compensation after his conviction for trying to sell equipment to Iraq was quashed. The appeal court found that crucial documents were not passed to the defence.

The total bill for miscarriages of justice arising out of arms-to-Iraq scandals could amount to £30m, including legal and court costs, Mr Kormornick said yesterday.

fields.headline: Crime risk of anti-begging policy
fields.trailText: Stopping giving money to beggars - as the government is encouraging the public to do in the run-up to Christmas - will lead to an increase in crime, academics warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Stopping giving money to beggars - as the government is encouraging the public to do in the run-up to Christmas - will lead to an increase in crime, academics warned yesterday.

The government claim that there is no proven link between clamping down on begging and crime were attacked as "nonsensical".

The government's rough sleepers unit plans an advertising campaign urging the public to donate money to charities, help out in soup kitchens or give food and clothes instead of giving money to beggars.

A group of academics including Ruth Lister of Loughborough University have written to Tony Blair and Louise Casey, the director of the rough sleepers unit, expressing alarm over a "potentially harmful campaign".

The letter said: "Withholding income from people who beg will not help those with drug and alcohol problems to overcome them.

"They will simply be forced to find other ways to feed their addictions, including, in at least some cases, crime and prostitution.

"The proposals that charities rather then people in poverty themselves should be the recipients of public donations ... is worryingly reminiscent of 19th century philanthropy."

Supporting charities and giving money to beggars are being presented by the government as "mutually exclusive alternatives", but this is not the case, the academics said. "We need to meet peo ple's long-term needs, but donations of money and time to charities will not help someone begging to survive until tomorrow."

In a statement Ms Casey reiterated the government's line that: "There is no proof that stopping giving money to people on the street will lead to an increase in other crime. Studies have shown that people who beg are already committing other crime."

Suzanne Fitzpatrick, lecturer in housing and social policy at the University of Glasgow, one of the signatories, said: "Here is incontrovertible proof that people use begging as an alternative to crime."

Hartley Dean, professor of social policy at, Luton University, said: "There is persuasive evidence that some at least of those who beg would resort to criminal activities. You don't have to be Einstein to work this one out."

The latest government campaign builds on the work of the rough sleepers unit which aims to reduce the number of people sleeping on the streets to 620 by 2002. The current figure is said to be 1,200.

Charities report that Ms Casey has threatened to withdraw funding from groups which refuse to back the anti-begging drive.

One feature of the campaign is the setting up of an "alternative giving fund" with collection points in shops and pubs where the public will be invited to donate rather than give directly to beggars.

The academics, however, say diverted giving schemes have been shown to be ineffective in their impact on several English towns where they have been tried out.

fields.headline: A&L sees bigger internet spend as survival strategy
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Alliance & Leicester is expected to announce today plans to quadruple its investment in the internet as it tries to convince the City it has a coherent strategy for independence.
fields.body:
Alliance & Leicester is expected to announce today plans to quadruple its investment in the internet as it tries to convince the City it has a coherent strategy for independence.

The move is believed to be part of a strategic review which has seen the bank also consider dropping the second part of its name.

The decision to increase internet spending to £60m is expected to be one of the main conclusions of the review, begun after the surprise resignation of former chief executive Peter White last year and two subsequent attempts to merge with larger rivals.

At the time of Mr White's acrimonious departure the chairman, John Windeler, made no secret of the need for the bank to enhance its technological capabilities. A&L has committed £15m to develop an internet bank which is yet to be launched, but is understood to have concluded that at least another £45m is needed to put the rest of its operation online.

The internet bank is expected to emerge under the Alliance tag rather than A&L. Alliance has been the name for the bank's attempt to step up its presence in the small business banking market and for the current account introduced last week. This has heightened speculation the shorter name will replace A&L in the future.

It is thought the bank has concluded that it does not need to take the axe to its 310 branches.

City analysts say the conclusion of the review is critical for the long term future of Mr Windeler and Peter McNamara, recruited as managing director from Lloyds TSB. Sceptics say the bank is too small to survive independently and believe it has acknowledged this fact through the two failed merger attempts.

While A&L refuses to confirm that it tried to merge with Woolwich, now part of Barclays, it is widely believed that the failure of those talks led to the discussions with Bank of Ireland that ended very publicly and acrimoniously.

The relationship of A&L's Girobank operation with the Post Office is under threat from attempts by the government to set up a PO-based universal bank.

webTitle: Elton John sues over tour costs

fields.headline: Elton John sues over tour costs
fields.trailText: Lawyers for Sir Elton John yesterday sought to block the release of "embarrassing" evidence of his flamboyant lifestyle as he started a legal battle to recover an alleged £20m loss of earnings from his business partner and accountancy firm.
fields.body:
Lawyers for Sir Elton John yesterday sought to block the release of "embarrassing" evidence of his flamboyant lifestyle as he started a legal battle to recover an alleged £20m loss of earnings from his business partner and accountancy firm.

Gordon Pollock QC, for Sir Elton, told the high court in London there was concern that the singer's spending habits could be deployed to cause "a media frenzy" and put pressure on him.

Sir Elton, 53, claims that for more than 10 years he was charged for expenses on his overseas tours that his managing company, John Reid Enterprises Ltd, should have borne.

The court heard that the alleged discrepancy in his income came to light only in 1998, when he parted company with his long-time manager and friend, John Reid.

Mr Pollock said the problem started when the accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers were finalising accounts of his 1987 North American tour. The firm had taken on the singer's business only a year before the alleged blunder.

He said that under a new contract signed in 1986 and dating back to 1984, JREL had increased its commission to 20% of Sir Elton's gross earnings (previously it had been net earnings) on the condition that the managing company took on additional costs. But the team of three accountants failed to implement the change in contract, leaving Sir Elton paying hefty booking fees, travel expenses and accountancy charges while on tour.

He has issued a writ against two named defendants, claiming PricewaterhouseCoopers were negligent in not contacting him or his solicitors when initial concerns were noted. Mr Pollock said these concerns were not followed up despite being raised in the original assessment of Sir Elton's accounts.

He is also suing his long-term business partner, Andrew Haydon - who managed his subsidiary company, Happenspace Ltd, which oversaw much of his tour business - for breach of contract.

A settlement between Sir Elton and Mr Reid of $5m (£3.5m) in compensation was agreed on their parting.

Mr Pollock told the court that over 18 years Mr Reid received around £73.5m by way of commission.

Sir Elton "hires people to do these mundane administrative tasks, and he trusted them implicitly," Mr Pollock said. "Mr Haydon effectively ran and was the driving force behind JREL. He received on top of his generous salary a bonus of 5% of the company's commission from Elton John's earnings.

"But the main issue of this case concerns certain costs when Sir Elton goes on tour, costs _ which should have fallen to JREL."

Mr Pollock told the court that PricewaterhouseCoopers would state that the contract would simply have been rectified if discussed earlier. The firm would also claim that the $5m settlement between Sir Elton and Mr Reid settled any compensation for all parties.

Mr Haydon is expected to claim that it was "standard industry practice" for the artist to pay the costs which Sir Elton claims he wrongly incurred. The hearing continues.

webTitle: Local youth group learns to cut burglaries

fields.headline: Wrong numbers
fields.trailText: In Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, 12 members of a local youth group have hit the headlines by helping to cut burglaries.
fields.body:
In Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, 12 members of a local youth group have hit the headlines by helping to cut burglaries. They spent a weekend making elderly people's bungalows more secure by fitting more than 300 special ceiling alarms in their bedrooms. The tactic has already worked, putting off thieves who liked to strike in the early evening when people were watching soap operas on television.

This success fits in with recent national crime figures, which show a 21% cut in burglaries, partly because more people are putting security devices in their homes.

What are these new crime figures?

They are part of the eighth British Crime Survey (BCS). This is published every two years. It is important because it reflects the views of 19,000 people aged over 16, who are quizzed about the crimes they have experienced and not just the crimes they have reported. It's thought to give a far more accurate picture of what is going on across the country than the six-monthly "recorded crime" statistics based on figures from the UK's 43 police force areas.

The survey and the police figures do not precisely overlap. There are crimes such as fraud or drug use that do not feature in the survey. But where they do cover the same offences, the statistics show that nearly six in 10 crimes do not get reported.

Why do people not tell the police if a crime is committed against them?

Many people think what has happened to them is too unimportant to mention, or that the police will not be able to do anything. Much more serious are the violent crimes that remain hidden - 65 in every 100 cases. One reason for this may be that many assaults result from violence in the home, which people can prefer to keep private. By far the most frequently reported crimes are those involving cars or burglaries. The obvious reason for this is that a police crime number is needed before people can make an insurance claim.

Does the survey suggest crime is on the increase or not?

There was good news in this year's report - overall the crime figures were 10% down on the 1998 survey. The biggest reductions were in burglaries and thefts from vehicles. The government claims its policies are working. This drop has also appeared in the "reported crimes" statistics in each of the last six years. But crime in Britain is still high - far above the level in the early 1980s. For example, burglaries may be down but there are still 1.3m of them a year, putting us top of the international burglary league.

Who is behind many of these crimes?

Young people. The peak time for men to be convicted or cautioned for criminal activity is when they are 18. One in 10 young men of this age end up with a police record. Girls are over four times less likely to get involved in crime and they hit their criminal peak younger, at 15. Overall, teenage offenders commit over 7m offences a year and cost the taxpayer £1bn. The government hopes the Crime and Disorder Act (1998) will tackle these problems by targeting young criminals.

Who are the main victims of these crimes?

Young men between 16 and 24 suffer five times the average number of violent assaults. Robberies also affect young people more, accounting for nearly 12% of the 14% rise in this kind of crime - mobile phones are a particular target. Another worry is that while crime is falling generally, across the country some communities have to live in hotspots where criminal activity is dug in and growing. For example, Nottingham police are routinely patrolling with guns because of shooting incidents on certain housing estates. The other cause for concern is the growth of assaults by strangers, often in pubs and clubs. Often, as with so much crime, alcohol is the root cause.

Is a falling crime level making people feel more secure?

For all sorts of reasons, people still feel crime is getting worse. Anxiety about crime is almost as serious a problem as crime itself.

webTitle: QXL opens bidding with live Wembley auction

fields.headline: QXL opens bidding with live Wembley auction
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: A sale of Wembley stadium memorabilia was simultaneously broadcast on television and the net last night as QXL.com launched its live auctioneering programmes.
fields.body:
A sale of Wembley stadium memorabilia was simultaneously broadcast on television and the net last night as QXL.com launched its live auctioneering programmes.

The company has rebranded its subsidiary, Ibidlive, as QXL.tv after increasing its stake to 62% last week; it plans to run hundreds of online auctions every year.

Jim Rose, chief executive officer of OXL, said the move followed a year of working with Ibidlive and examining the opportunities for interactive auctioneering.

"QXL.tv is a platform from which we can showcase our regularly featured, live, online auctions," he said in a statement to the stock market.

Analysts describe the Ibidlive subsidiary, which provides the interactive online auctioneering software, as a "very interesting business" but still in its infancy.

"The Ibidlive name is a slightly more recognised brand in the US, although it's in its early days," said Phil Clark of Goldman Sachs. "QXL has a strong brand in Europe, so from that perspective the rebranding makes sense."

Football fans were yesterday able to bid for a piece of history as everything from flags to the famed steps went under the hammer, screened over the web and on BSkyB's Sky Sports 1 channel.

It is hoped the high-profile launch will further boost the popularity of online auctions, already very popular in America, within the UK.

QXL's rebranding comes in a turbulent year for the company, which has suffered a 96% fall in its shares from the highs of 800p to only 31p earlier this month.

Analysts have blamed a fickle marketplace and the sell-off of hi-tech stocks, which appears to have hit QXL more than most dot.coms, for the rapid decline in its fortunes.

"There's been a general negative sentiment across the whole internet sector," said one. "The fact QXL will need cash to fund it into profitability is not new, it's just been more of a focus since the change in sentiment."

But as the London markets closed last night there was still no respite for QXL's management, with the shares slipping 0.5p to 28p - perilously close to its 22p year-low.

The company is due to report its third quarter figures at the end of next month.

fields.headline: Internet know-how: safety
fields.trailText: A guide to child-safety sites on the web
fields.body:
Sparklers are cheap and can be held in the hand, so it's surprising to learn that they cause more injuries than air-bombs, bangers, rockets and roman candles put together. Children adore them - which is what makes them so dangerous, particularly in back-garden bonfire night displays.

The adults in charge of a fireworks display will appreciate the danger of fireworks (even after a few drinks) but children may not. A sparkler doesn't seem very hot but three sparklers together generate as much heat as a blowtorch, and they can inflict very serious burns. The UK Firework Safety site at www.fireworksafety.co.uk run by the British Pyrotechnists Association and the government, has advice for people holding back-garden parties as well as teachers supervising a display. An even better resource is the DTI's 2000 campaign at www.dti.gov.uk/fireworksafetyforschools which includes lesson plans for key stages 1-3 and the official guidance on organising a safe display.

Once bonfire night is over, a couple of other sites might prove useful if you're preparing a lesson about the dangers of fire. The Home Office's Frances the Firefly, the tale of a foolish female glow-worm who was persuaded to make her tail glow brighter by a devious cockroach with a box of matches (shades of Eve and the serpent) is at www.homeoffice.gov.uk/fepd/frances1.htm KS1 children may enjoy having the story read to them during the literacy hour and drawing posters afterwards.

The British Fire Service, meanwhile, has a Kids' Corner at www.fire.org.uk/kids/home.htm with quizzes about smoke detectors and fire extinguishers. The US counterpart, Sparky the Fire Dog, shows off his fire trucks and safety advice at www.sparky.org

The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents site at www.rospa.org.uk may seem dour by comparison, but it covers safety in the home particularly thoroughly. Safety at Home at www.consumer.gov.uk/consumer_web/safety.htm explores many risks, including the dangers of DIY and electric blankets.

When should you teach a child to cross the road alone? The guide at www.roads.detr.gov.uk/roadsafety/crsc/publications.htm advises parents when to teach different road-safety skills. This page also links to the Green Cross Code.

Big cities present special dangers. The Met advises young people on taxis, using buses and the tube and street safety at www.met.police.uk/

webTitle: If you ask me...about smoking in school

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My daughter has been caught smoking at breaktime in the school toilets. We have been very clear with her at home that we will not tolerate her smoking, and it comes as a bit of a blow to find that she can so easily do so at school. What should the school be doing about this?
fields.trailText: My daughter has been caught smoking at breaktime in the school toilets. We have been very clear with her at home that we will not tolerate her smoking, and it comes as a bit of a blow to find that she can so easily do so at school. What should the school be doing about this?
fields.body:
Amanda Sandford, research manager, ASH

Most schools have a policy on smoking but they vary in scope and degree of enforcement. You should check the school policy and speak to the head or whoever is responsible for enforcing it. Many schools also provide smoking education, but its impact is likely to be reduced if smoking is tolerated within the school premises.

Meanwhile, try to find out what prompted your daughter to start smoking. Research suggests that stressing the health dangers to young people rarely convinces them of the need to quit. Instead, expressing your disapproval and serious concern is more important. Even where parents themselves smoke, this can be effective, especially if you show how much you regret starting.

You may also like to find out where your daughter got the cigarettes. Although it's not illegal for your child to buy them under 16, it is illegal for shopkeepers etc to sell them to underage buyers. Why not tackle this aspect of the problem first, either alone or with other parents in a similar situation. Cutting off the means of supply could dissuade the "casual" smoker from continuing.

Many young people who do view themselves as "casual" smokers do not know just how addictive nicotine is. Explain to your daughter that she should not underestimate how big a part cigarettes will play in her life if she persists.

Health Education Authority spokesperson

Anti-smoking activities in schools should be part of a community-wide programme of action. Simply educating young people about the risks of smoking is not enough. Young people are exposed to considerable pressures to smoke at a time when their future health often has a low priority. They must be equipped to resist these pressures. Schools may wish to tackle smoking in various ways, but they will all need a firm commitment to action from teachers, governors and parents.

Where one does not already exist, schools should set up a working party and appoint a senior member of staff as smoking policy co-ordinator to work towards establishing a smoke-free school. To assess the extent of the problem, smoking should be monitored regularly, involving anonymous classroom questionnaires and comparisons with national and regional figures. The results should then be communicated to staff, students, parents and governors for discussion.

School rules should prohibit smoking by pupils during school hours; prohibit smoking by staff on or near school premises or during school activities; provide for appropriate measures, including support and sanctions, given the addictive and self-destructive nature of smoking; prohibit smoking during school meetings, including governors' meetings and parent-teacher meetings; and clearly explain the rationale behind the policy.

A written policy records the school's approach to smoking and what action it is taking. Developing a policy should involve setting down the elements of the school anti-smoking campaign, and developing the draft through discussion with students (a specially constituted group or school council), staff, governors and parents.

As well as incorporating smoking-related topics in class teaching, schools should aim to link up with the wider community, eg get involved in national schemes such as No Smoking Day; work more closely with local shopkeepers to reduce sales of cigarettes to pupils. Local health promotion units can often provide useful resources.

Specific anti-smoking campaigns are essential in a comprehensive smoking policy. They keep the issue fresh and enable you to vary the point of attack. Different approaches can be considered - discussion groups; posters, signs and poster competitions; presentations; practical demonstrations such as carbon monoxide (smoking breath tests) on pupils; training sessions for resisting pressures to smoke; and a smokers' clinic.

Helplines

The following offer confidential, freephone services for anyone who wants to stop smoking:

Quitline: tel: 0800 00 22 00; 1pm-9pm every day; also in Bengali, Gujerati, Hindi, Punjabi, Urdu, Turkish and Kurdish on various days

Smokeline (Scotland): tel: 0800 84 84 84; 12pm-12am every day

Smokers' Quitline (N Ireland): tel: 02890 66328; 9am-5pm weekdays

Smokers' Helpline (Wales): tel: 0345 697 500; 9am-5pm weekdays

Next week's problem: My son has missed a lot of school through illness. He's returned to school for the occasional day, but finds it exhausting and difficult having been absent so often. How do I arrange for home tuition so he doesn't fall behind, but also ensure he keeps contact with school?

fields.headline: Open plan, open mind?
fields.standfirst: Tony Pitcher  and  David Howe  of South East Essex College answer back
fields.trailText: Tony Pitcher and David Howe of South East Essex College answer back to last week's Rostrum
fields.body:
Oh dear, Jean Simmonds! (Rostrum, October 24) - so many omissions in your article, so much jumping to conclusions without any fact-checking, so many assumptions quite unsubstantiated by any of the text in the piece by Peter Kingston on South East Essex College (Are you being Served? October 10). As Simmonds said, it was an article on the "open-plan, learning-centre" style of internal college architecture that we have developed. "Students, energised by the mere proximity of other students and assisted by 'learning advisers', work from student-centred materials and the college intranet. The simple removal of walls improves behaviour and boosts performance." Absolutely! OK so far.

Jean Simmonds claims there are deliberate evasions and omissions. Peter Kingston spent some time in the college talking to staff and students describing what he saw - not simply reading about us and jumping to conclusions based on pre-conceived, outmoded ideas.

Jean Simmonds asserts, not having seen it, there is "a shoddy reality, having more to do with economic imperatives than educational benefits".

Surprising as it may seem to educational reactionaries, the driving imperative is the educational benefit of our complex, interlocking sets of strategies for managing student learning for successful achievement. A reputation for student satisfaction and success is what brings students in to enrol, the younger ones fully supported by their parents in choosing this college. From that derives our general institutional success, which enables us to provide learning environments to smart, professional workplace standards, equipped with a range of educational resources to match modern learning requirements.

One strand of these strategies is to work in many large learning centres. These can accommodate many groups, can be staffed with several teachers and additional learning support staff and can be provided with an extensive range of specialised resources. Peter Kingston captured this concept through the "department store" analogy.

Within large specialist centres, many staff can be deployed to give support to individual students, qualified learning advisers help students to use the hardware and software resources and centre co-ordinators deal with much of the administration. The intranet structures student learning (potentially 24 hours a day), provides asynchronous in-course communications, assignments, deadlines, wider reading and research links and learning materials to a college standard where previously these might have been dictated, copied from the board or put into handouts of variable quality.

On top of all this, the teacher is still there, getting on with essential professional tasks; supervising the progress of learners, encouraging, motivating, assessing, providing feedback and ensuring the up-to-date curriculum delivers students' learning objectives.

We employ a normal number of teaching staff with a standard average schedule with learners of 21 hours per week; all 350, full-time and part-time, are employed in permanent salaried positions. In addition, we employ 46 academic and learning support staff, 29 learning advisers, 28 centre co-ordinators and 15 staff maintaining network systems. All the above staff are qualified. Most of them have subject-specific degrees.

The support we give to students through tutorials and a range of other activities is only possible because of our learning approach - in two successive inspections, we were awarded grade 1 (outstanding). Last year an independent national benchmarking service concluded that the staff/student ratio and student contact hours were considerably higher than average, yet student qualifications outcomes per hour of teaching were the highest they had ever found.

We use staff effectively, in multidisciplinary teams and they work with resources (also grade 1 in both inspections) that visitors from numerous colleges and universities have told us they envy.

Finally back to the learners. They work in a busy, stimulating, social environment precisely as envisaged by Tim Brighouse (TES, October 20): "... the number of relationships created by teachers, support learning staff, peer tutors and mentors increase the likelihood of the learner feeling so 'special and unique' that they suspend disbelief and make great learning strides."
