webTitle: Are university entrance policies undermining  Curriculum 2000

fields.headline: Mismatch point
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley asks if university entrance policies are undermining the whole basis of Curriculum 2000
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley asks if university entrance policies are undermining the whole basis of Curriculum 2000
fields.body:
Sixth-form and further-education colleges may be wholeheartedly embracing Curriculum 2000, but not all universities are rushing to endorse the reformed qualifications for young people of 16 to 19.

In academic circles there is a growing suspicion that the older "selecting" universities are dragging their feet and preferring instead to rely on the traditional three or four A-level entry package. Many fear that this could critically undermine the government's attempt to broaden sixth-form level study.

The new Curriculum 2000 changes introduced this term include five key elements: enabling students to study up to five subjects to AS-level before specialising in three or more A2 levels in the second-year sixth; the introduction of vocational A-levels; key skills qualifications in communication, application of number and information technology; and student involvement in enrichment programmes, such as the Duke of Edinburgh's award, sport and citizenship.

Bernie Borland, principal of St Francis Xavier Sixth Form College in Clapham, south London, which has 1,100 students studying for more than 30 A-level, AS and advanced vocational courses, argues that the more selective universities, often the redbricks, have been quite muted in their response to Curriculum 2000.

"They have not wished to say anything that goes against the government's intentions," he says. "But they still, I believe, will want three or four good A2 grades related to the area in which the student is going to pursue his or her degree."

This view is endorsed by Margaret Ingram, deputy principal of Hills Road Sixth Form College in Cambridge, which has 800 students in its lower sixth following a four or five AS-level course with key skills and enrichment activities. She said that there were signs that some universities were being very slow in signalling their support for Curriculum 2000.

"They are playing safe by saying really they will want three good A-levels," she said. "If AS-levels are going to be valued then sooner or later the universities are going to have to take note of them.

"There is also a question mark over whether the universities are going to require key skills as part of the A-level package. I think some of them will and some of them will not, but it would be quite helpful to schools and colleges if they were to say: 'Yes, we would like everybody to have a key skills qualification'."

Predictably, perhaps, the newer universities, which traditionally have greater problems recruiting students, are higher education's most enthusiastic supporters of Curriculum 2000. But this is not in itself cause for celebration as it merely opens the way for the reintroduction by the back door of the two-tier higher education system that incorporation was designed to abolish.

Sally McEnhill, principal of Merton College in west London, which has 650 students doing AS, A-levels and advanced vocational courses, praised the former polytechnics and the newer universities for their involvement in the widening participation agenda by giving Ucas points for key skills and more subjects representing a broader curriculum. But she could see little prospect of improvement while Oxbridge and the red bricks were still insisting on the traditional three A-levels.

"Until the universities really say it is worth having these additional qualifications, we are going to have difficulty in convincing young people that it is worth their while putting that extra effort into the wider curriculum," she said, echoing the feelings expressed by principals across the further education sector.

"Some may well start with four or five AS-levels, but how many will keep them up? The sort of students we have will do better through the broader curriculum with the opportunity to review their progress after one year, than they would do on the traditional two-year A-level programme, where a lot of them would drop out. The universities that they go to are the ones that are courting Curriculum 2000 - places such as Greenwich, Guildhall or even Kingston."

Michael Marchant, principal of The College of Richard Collyer in Horsham, said that some university tutors had told him that they did not wish to discriminate against small sixth forms that might not be able to run a wide range of AS courses or offer key skills.

The problem with that approach, Marchant added, was that if the government did not get the universities to make a stronger commitment to Curriculum 2000 the initiative would be unsuccessful.

"Curriculum 2000 is all about breadth," he said "I know universities are into depth but people in this century are going to have two or three careers so they need transferable skills. A-levels in Greek and Latin might be great for a classics degree but they won't necessarily give you the skills to enable you to go into a third career in 10 or 20 years time."

Even with these misgivings, most colleges are very enthusiastic about the move to a broader curriculum supported by key skills qualifications and enrichment activities.

Ken Kerr, director of curriculum at Bury College in Greater Manchester, which has 1,000 students doing A-levels and advanced GNVQs, said Curriculum 2000 was the first real opportunity for students to combine academic study with vocational study.

"In the past some of those who embarked on straight A-levels were, perhaps, encouraged to do so as much by parental aspirations as their own," he said. "The new structure of the single vocational A-level allows students to combine the academic with the general vocational in a way which will hopefully prepare them both for employment and for higher education in a much more positive way."

Dr John Guy, principal of the Sixth Form College, Farnborough, which has 850 students in the first-year sixth doing four or five AS-levels, pointed out that the new curriculum had led to startling leaps in the number of students opting to take additional courses in subjects where the government was keen to see growth.

The numbers of students, for example, taking French, German and Spanish AS-levels in his college had more than doubled in size. Those taking music at AS-level had risen from 20-25 to 57 students this year. Computing and IT student numbers had nearly doubled and those taking philosophy at A-level had risen from 17 to 47.

"I think the breadth of experience that they are getting is much better now," he added. "Curriculum 2000 has been about expectations. Sir RonDearing was right - a broader fix on education was needed and now there is an impetus to provide it."

True. But only in some sectors, and Curriculum 2000's long term success depends on it being embraced by all concerned. Just how committed the older universities are to a broader-based education system only time will tell. For now there is, most definitely, a spanner in the works.

webTitle: YCTV is refreshing the youngsters school couldn't reach

fields.headline: Telly addicts
fields.standfirst: YCTV is refreshing the youngsters school couldn't reach
fields.trailText: YCTV is refreshing the youngsters school couldn't reach
fields.body:
If you had to put money on where you'd expect to find one of Prince Charles's former girlfriends, you'd opt for the gossip columns over a shabby west London industrial building any day of the week. But Sabrina Guinness has seldom conformed to stereotype.

Eight years ago at the time of the LA riots, Guinness was working in Hollywood watching her film script ideas sit on the shelf, when she became interested in a City Kids initiative that put rival gang members together in a safe space and allowed them to act. She intuitively felt that, good as the idea was, it was something of a cul-de-sac because there was little chance of the kids making a career out of acting. So, on her return home, she adapted the idea to focus on film and television production, where experience counts for a great deal, and Youth Culture TV was formed in 1995.

Today children from all over the country attend programmes covering all aspects of TV production, and each week produce a half-hour programme that goes out on the local NTL cable channel. "It is important for the kids to know they have to produce this material," says Guinness, "as it gives them a taste of the discipline the industry requires." Which isn't to say there aren't a few hissy fits, walkouts and no-shows, but that's just another point of overlap between teenage and TV life.

YCTV is clearly doing something right as its first terrestrial commission, Pass the Mic, presented by one of Sabrina's brightest and best, 19-year-old Luke Hyams, is currently showing on the BBC. It is a moment that both Guinness and Hyams are savouring. At 14, Hyams was to all intents and purposes on the educational scrapheap. "I was getting into a lot of trouble", he says, "and I was excluded from Queens' Park school." To its credit, the Brent education authority allowed Hyams to continue his education at YCTV, where he picked up most of the tricks of the TV trade and transformed himself from a grumpy, monosyllabic teenager into an all-singing, all-dancing hustler with his own production company and a second commission under his belt.

It was precisely to help young people such as Hyams that YCTV was created. "I didn't have a particularly happy time at school myself," says Guinness, "and I felt it was pointless trying to get some children to fit into the conventional system. At YCTV we educate them through a medium they have grown up with and which they understand; we develop literacy through scriptwriting, numeracy through compiling budgets and IT skills through familiarisation with the editing equipment. However, there is none of the resistance to learning you find in schools because the kids can see that what they are doing has a practical purpose. We've even encouraged some children to go back to college."

Guinness may like to play down the fact she has an address book to die for, but there is little doubt that her connections have proved useful. Peter Mandelson, Tony Blair, Bill Clinton and Mick Jagger all agreed to be interviewed by Hyams for Pass the Mic, Harrison Ford has taken a carpentry workshop and her list of project supporters includes Dan Ackroyd, David Bowie, Bob Geldof, Anjelica Huston and Ruby Wax. Even so, finding the £400,000 to keep the YCTV show on the road each year proves an uphill struggle.

But Guinness is adamant it will continue and is looking for more commissions to extend the YCTV network. And nice as it is to get the high-profile plaudits, it is often the smaller achievements that give the most pleasure. "We ran a competition to see who would get to interview Harrison Ford and it was won by a boy called Lee," says Guinness. "Even Harrison admitted he did a brilliant job and Lee took the video home to show his mum. She had never before said "well done" to him for anything, but she now carries the tape in her handbag at all times. It has transformed their relationship and Lee has become far more confident as a result." So who says too much telly is bad for you?

Which isn't to say there aren't a few hissy fits, walkouts and no-shows, but that's just another point of overlap between teenage and TV life. YCTV is clearly doing something right as its first terrestrial commission, Pass the Mic, presented by one of Sabrina's brightest and best, 19-year-old Luke Hyams, is currently showing on the BBC. It is a moment that both Guinness and Hyams are savouring. At 14, Hyams was to all intents and purposes on the educational scrapheap. "I was getting into a lot of trouble", he says, "and I was excluded from Queens' Park school." To its credit, the Brent education authority allowed Hyams to continue his education at YCTV, where he picked up most of the tricks of the TV trade and transformed himself from a grumpy, monosyllabic teenager into an all-singing, all-dancing hustler with his own production company and a second commission under his belt. It was precisely to help young people such as Hyams that YCTV was created. "I didn't have a particularly happy time at school myself," says Guinness, "and I felt it was pointless trying to get some children to fit into the conventional system. At YCTV we educate them through a medium they have grown up with and which they understand; we develop literacy through scriptwriting, numeracy through compiling budgets and IT skills through familiarisation with the editing equipment. However, there is none of the resistance to learning you find in schools because the kids can see that what they are doing has a practical purpose. We've even encouraged some children to go back to college." Guinness may like to play down the fact she has an address book to die for, but there is little doubt that her connections have proved useful. Peter Mandelson, Tony Blair, Bill Clinton and Mick Jagger all agreed to be interviewed by Hyams for Pass the Mic, Harrison Ford has taken a carpentry workshop and her list of project supporters includes Dan Ackroyd, David Bowie, Bob Geldof, Anjelica Huston and Ruby Wax. Even so, finding the £400,000 to keep the YCTV show on the road each year proves an uphill struggle. But Guinness is adamant it will continue and is looking for more commissions to extend the YCTV network. And nice as it is to get the high-profile plaudits, it is often the smaller achievements that give the most pleasure. "We ran a competition to see who would get to interview Harrison Ford and it was won by a boy called Lee," says Guinness. "Even Harrison admitted he did a brilliant job and Lee took the video home to show his mum. She had never before said "well done" to him for anything, but she now carries the tape in her handbag at all times. It has transformed their relationship and Lee has become far more confident as a result." So who says too much telly is bad for you?

fields.headline: Great shot!
fields.standfirst: Technical skill was the winner in our photo competition, but runners-up were strong too.  Peter Kingston reports
fields.trailText: Technical skill was the winner in our photo competition, but runners-up were strong too. Peter Kingston reports
fields.body:
It was a broad, but simple, theme that we set all you budding photographers who fancied a crack at our competition.

We asked you to send us a picture which could bear the title: Student Life - The Reality.

And judging from some of the entries, reality for one or two of you is a very foreign land indeed. Which was fantastic because, to paraphrase Eamonn McCabe, The Guardian's picture editor and one of the judges, competitions are about taking risks.

But they are also about technical skills, according to his distinguished fellow judge, Paul Wombell, director of The Photographers' Gallery in London, where the 12 winning pictures are now on display.

"As well as a good idea, you have to be able to express it photographically using the language of the medium, and that would mean both using the camera well and making the print well in the dark room."

The picture judged overall winner is by Vanessa Beard, who is 28 and studying for a BTec national certificate in photography at City of Westminster College.

"It perfectly captures a moment of tension in a training restaurant," according to Chris Hughes, third judge and chief executive of the Further Education Development Agency, co-organisers of the competition.

In Wombell's opinion, the winner stands out from the field, partly because of its display of technical skill.

"This is somebody thinking about the technology. There's an awareness of the use of flash and how that can be used to represent movement," he says.

"It is also very well constructed in terms of the image and how the ele ments are put together", Wombell says.

The judges were also struck by Ruth Saunby's study of a mature student trying to juggle books and parenthood. In Wombell's view, her shot taken from above of a man on his sofa hemmed in by essay-writing paraphernalia clinched a place for Saunby, from South Nottingham College, as "a good runner-up".

McCabe was impressed by a whimsical series of shots by Hannah Marsh, also at South Nottingham. Her studies show students posing as if for police mugshots, but with the name of their subject rather than a crime number.

One of two chief runners-up, Mark Hunt, 34, is also from City of Westminster College - four of the 12 winners come from this stable. He too chose a mature student as his subject, this time a woman. "A very strong set of pictures," is Wombell's verdict.

The entries as a whole, he thinks, show lack of technical skill: "If there's a competition next year, hopefully that would be something participants would give some thought to."

But McCabe adds: "I felt the standard was much better than in most competitions from student photographers."

Vanessa Beard, 28, City of Westminster College, BTec National Certificate in Photography; Andrew Blackburn, 22, Doncaster Art College, National Diploma Photography and Video; Christel Sundeback, 28, City of Westminster College, BTec National Diploma in Photography; Mark Hunt, 34, City of Westminster College, BTec National Diploma in Photography; Ruth Saunby, 24, South Nottingham College, BTec National Diploma in Photography; Katie Reader, 17, South Downs College, A-Level Photography (Art); Maria Kenward, 17, Taunton's College, Southampton, Media Studies, English, Photography;Victoria Hill, 34, City of Westminster College, BTec National Diploma in Photography; Jason Hendley, 30, Solihull Art School, HND Photography; Hannah Marsh, 24, South Nottingham College, BTec National Diploma in Photography; Alison Aram, 19, South Nottingham College, BTec Photography; Andrew Lynch, 32, Doncaster Art College, National Diploma Photography and Video.

webTitle: Universities' attempts to stop students behaving badly

fields.headline: A real headache
fields.standfirst: Anita Chaudhuri reports on universities' attempts to stop students behaving badly
fields.trailText: Anita Chaudhuri reports on universities' attempts to stop students behaving badly
fields.body:
For most students, searching for a post-club night-bus to whisk them back to a far-flung hall of residence is a rite of passage, usually accompanied by an unsuitable companion, a can of cider and perhaps a substance of more dubious provenance. So one can only pity undergraduates at Southampton University, guinea pigs in the campus ClubZone initiative, a subsidised night bus which ferries students back to their suburban campus at weekends. It sounds like a great idea - until one learns that there are uniformed stewards on board employed by the university to keep an eye out for any signs of anti-social behaviour.

Like many universities across the UK, Southampton is becoming increasingly alive to the benefits of staying on the right side of members of the local community. Drunken students carousing in the streets are not just disruptive, they reflect badly on the good name of their alma mater. Last week Leeds University announced the appointment of its first community liaison officer to mediate between students in private accommodation and the residents of Headingley, the area which is most densely populated by students.

Yet students are not children. Surely what they do, off-campus at least, is their own business? "Well, strictly speaking, we are not in loco parentis; students are adults," says Peter Reader of Southampton University. "In practice we happen to think that looking out for their welfare is providing a valuable service. It also benefits the local community at large."

To this end, at Southampton, students in private flats who misbehave at the weekend are liable to get a pep-talk from the university's accommodation officer on Monday morning. All students are regularly sent leaflets about noise pollution, health and safety, and even reminders of when to put their rubbish out. Surely rubbish is going a little too far?

"Not at all. Student litter is a really big problem for residents associations," says Reader.

So to what extent can we expect a university to be responsible for the behaviour of its students? This month the parents of Scott Krueger, a first year student at Massachussetts Institute of Technology, Boston, who drank himself to death at a fraternity initiation, won a settlement of $6m.

Could the same situation arise in the UK?

"One hopes not, but things are moving in that direction," says David Ball, director of student services at the University of Hertfordshire. He believes that universities are caught in a dilemma between protecting the privacy of students and respecting the wishes of other interested parties, be they disgruntled residents or worried parents.

"Parents often ring us and say they're convinced that their offspring is developing a drug or alcohol problem. There's really very little we can do in that instance, except asking a tutor to keep an eye on them. Students are adults and, lest we forget, they are protected by the Data Protection Act. We aren't allowed to pass on information we hold in our files on students to anyone - not even their own parents."

But parents seem to have increased expectations over how far a university's duty of care should extend. "Families and sponsoring organisations are making much bigger financial commitments to a student than previously, and that means they want to protect their investment, so they're more likely to ring us with worries, and they're more likely to want legal redress if students fail their exams."

Alcohol abuse is one area which colleges appear keen to address. Earlier this month, a joint venture was launched by the University of Oxford and Oxford Brookes which aimed to educate freshers about safe drinking habits. Postcards and posters were distributed in local pubs, a sharp anti-dote to the usual feverish "drink as much as you can" propaganda of freshers weeks gone by. The move has been prompted in part by the fact that a number of Oxford students have died from excessive drinking in recent years; two years ago Mark Young, an Oxford Brookes student, was run over and killed after a night out.

"Educating students about acceptable behaviour is part of our policy of being socially responsible to the community we serve," explains David Attwood, community liaison officer at Oxford Brookes. His department was the first such university initiative to be set up when it opened in 1993.

"We serve as a point of contact between students and residents," he explains. "That means on Monday morning my phone is often ringing off the hook. But things have improved drastically since we set up. Residents are much more likely to put up with a couple of parties a term than they used to be. With increased communication, everyone benefits."

webTitle: Redundancies threaten first all-out academic strike for years

fields.headline: Oh, Mr Porter
fields.standfirst: Redundancies threaten first all-out academic strike for years, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Redundancies threaten first all-out academic strike for years, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Budget cut-backs and department closures across the academic sector are threatening thousands of university jobs. Anger over low pay and the spectre of redundancies looks set to trigger the first strike of academic workers in many years, with porters, secretaries and security staff joining professors and lecturers taking to the streets in protest against the cuts.

Ironically, it would be those in the least prestigious jobs - porters, cleaners, caterers and security staff - who would have the biggest impact, say union leaders, who are organising a ballot from next week to trigger the first day of action on December 5.

Shortfalls in security cover could lead to closure of campuses, predicted Chris Kaufman, national secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, which has 10,000 members working in higher education. He said their expectations had been raised by the Bett report into university pay and conditions, which found manual workers had fallen behind and should have earnings raised to £11,000 over three years.

Christine Lewis, national officer at Unison, the union representing technicians and administrative staff, said morale was very low. It has sent a letter to every employer with a list of demands emanating from the Bett report. Unless institutions responded to the demands, a ballot for national industrial action would follow. "The mood of dissatisfaction is intense," said Lewis. "With workers on pay as low as £4.06 an hour, it's hardly surprising."

Staff at King's College London, wearing Halloween masks, will hold a protest this evening outside the college's Strand campus against management plans to cut 300 jobs to address a funding deficit of £10.2m.

Unison also reports growing tensions at University College London, which is facing a £4m budget deficit, and threatened cuts at Northumbria, Hertfordshire and London Guildhall universities. Management at Greenwich University intends to close a whole site due to reduced funding.

The lecturers' union Natfhe, meanwhile, says that the University of Northumberland in Newcastle faces a 7% cut in staffing likely to result in the loss of 70 lecturers and 70 non-teaching staff. At Sheffield Hallam, 423 part-time lecturers have been issued with redundancy notices. Redundancies are also being introduced at the Thames Valley University business school, Coventry University's engineering department and across the board at Hertfordshire and London Guildhall universities. Bolton, Southampton, and Ripon and York institutes also face cuts.

The Association of University Teachers says 443 jobs among the old universities have been lost or have come under threat during the last six months. Imperial College plans to cull 120 positions at its medical faculty, while rationalisation is on the cards at King's College and Queen Mary College medical schools. Other "problem institutions" are Warwick, Loughborough and Edinburgh universities. Job losses are thought to be inevitable following the merger of Birmingham and Aston universities.

An informal consultation among Natfhe members suggests two thirds favour strike action. "The mood is generally one of 'enough is enough'," said Tom Wilson at Natfhe. "We're also deeply angry at the employers' refusal to even discuss issues like workloads, conditions, low pay and the Bett reforms."

The Universities and Colleges Employers' Association asked the unions to reconsider, saying their action would damage progress on implementing the Bett recommendations on pay.

Financial instabilities at universities have been triggered by various factors, such as over-spending in previous years, rationalisation of medical schools, and under-recruitment of students on teacher training courses.

More recent government incentives designed to boost recruitment on postgraduate teacher training (PGCE) courses appear to be driving applications down for bachelor of education degrees and forcing many courses to fold.

webTitle: Britain's research scientists and the truth about BSE

fields.headline: Silent witness
fields.standfirst: Though not attacked by the BSE report, Britain's research scientists must ask themselves if they allowed the truth to be suppressed
fields.trailText: Though not attacked by the BSE report, Britain's research scientists must ask themselves if they allowed the truth to be suppressed
fields.byline: John Crace, with additional reporting by Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Despite the naming and shaming of nearly 30 senior civil servants and eight former Tory ministers in last week's report by Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers over their refusal to recognise the BSE problem, Britain's scientists have largely escaped his censure. For over a decade, it has been a matter of record within the academic community that much of the research on which the government based its pronouncements on the safety of British beef was either wilfully suppressed or misinterpreted by the government, but almost to a man and woman they acquiesced in the perversion. Those who didn't, such as Richard Lacey, were so few in number they could be picked off with ease by government spin doctors as troublemakers.

This is the latest example of a more general failure among academics to speak out on important issues, identified by Greg Philo and David Miller in a new book Market Killing. Their main targets are social scientists, but they believe the charge sticks more widely. Many academics must have had more than an inkling that something was amiss with the publication of Professor Sir Richard Southwood's report in 1989. This was the report that set the agenda for the government to declare that BSE was an animal, not human, health problem and all but closed the door on scientific research into the human health risks of infected beef.

Sir Richard told one newspaper last week that he was urged to keep his investigation into BSE's impact on the food chain quiet and not to make any recommendations that would involve the government in too much expense. In 1990 he advised the government that further research into "the remote possibility that humans could be infected" was necessary. He admitted: "I did stop eating brain tissue following my research."

And yet academics knew that Southwood's committee contained no experts on scrapie or transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, nor were the available experts in Britain and the US called to give evidence.

As Miller, research manager at the Stirling Media Research Institute, wrote in a paper for Social Science and Medicine, "of those who were called, Hugh Frazer of the Institute for Animal Health is reported to be amazed that he was only asked 'a few simplistic questions' and not for his opinion on other pertinent areas of science". Back in 1990, Miller conducted his own research into food scandals and was amazed at the duplicity of some of the scientists who were actively engaged in government research in BSE: "Even though the government was telling the public that British beef was safe to eat, I came across quite a few academics who told me that, based on the scientific evidence, they had concluded beef was unsafe and had stopped eating it," he says. "More worrying still, one very senior scientist, who made a great show of supporting the government line by stating in public that he was happy to carry on eating beef, had actually stopped eating it on health safety grounds."

Dr Peter Cotgreave, director of the Save British Science Society, claims that the Phillips report highlights the fact that there will have to be changes in the way government deals with scientific advice - and that "scientific experts have not been given the independence to state their views".

But he concedes: "When the government was standing up saying there was no risk from BSE, the scientific community should have been standing up and saying that this was not what the scientific evidence actually pointed to," he says. "The advice was that there might be a risk, but we just didn't know for sure."

Cotgreave says that there are many more strings attached to all kinds of government research grants than in the past. The £775m of new infrastructure funds announced in the government spending review, for example, come with a caveat that academics must attract 25% of the money from industry. "That is going to affect the questions they ask," he says.

A review of physics research in the UK earlier in the year by a group of international experts suggested that UK academics are more willing to just do what the government asks. Similar pressure abroad would start riots in universities.

Former government chief scientific adviser Sir Bob May agreed that scientific experts should be more vocal. "I can see the reasons why people do not get involved. They have given willingly of their time, and then have not been altogether happy with what happened, and are reluctant to give yet more time to make themselves unpopular," he said. "But at the same time I think it is something they should do." But Sir Bob says that he is unaware of evidence that academics or scientists withhold results or that research is getting less fundamental: "If you actually assess the distribution of research council money for fundamental versus applied work, it has moved into the direction of more fundamental work. If you actually count the fraction of papers that are in high-quality, rigorously refereed journals the British share has gone up not down."

Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University, agrees with Miller that academics did abdicate their responsibilities over the BSE crisis and subjects unpopular with ministers. In an email to Miller he wrote: "As you know, in the 1980s and 1990s the number of academics who participated in the food-scandals debate was pitifully few. I have been clearing out my archives for the last week and have got all angry again about how few were prepared to research food poverty. Those who did so were giants."

Academics are ultimately funded by the taxpayer, but are not always the fearless guardians of truth and objectivity they may sometimes claim to be; rather, they are men and women with families and a mortgage who are loath to rock boats for fear of damaging their career prospects. The public interest gets lost.

This is perhaps understandable, if not exactly noble. Miller reports on the reaction he got when he announced he was planning to undertake some unpopular research into the effect of the broadcast ban on the IRA in Northern Ireland. "You could hear the sound of doors shutting," he says.

The other aspect of this silencing of the lambs is the commercialisation of academic research. In the early 1980s many research bodies were publicly funded; now they are virtual plcs. The effect of this is that most research is either driven by commercial gain - hence the huge amount of money and time spent on finding a cure for hair loss - or by a government agenda, for which money is made available. There is very little independent research taking place and almost nothing to rock the status quo. "Most academics have effectively given up their role as a critical voice of public policy," says Greg Philo, director of the Glasgow Media Group. "Increasingly it is being left to journalists to ask the difficult questions. Instead, academics are happy either to take the cash from commercial sponsors or to engage in oceans and oceans of non-empirical, intellectually bankrupt, office-based post-modern research where there is no such thing as truth and anything can mean anything.

"Film studies academics have been pursuing inaccurate and pointless research for years, but because they are all doing it, no one challenges them. What's more they all award themselves top ratings at peer review for the Research Assessment Exercise."

Noam Chomsky, professor of linguistics at Massachussets Institute of Technology, goes along with this. Berating the post-modern trend, he says: "People are being deprived of valuable modes of understanding and insight they badly need, and crucial questions about how the world works and how it might be changed are avoided, even ridiculed."

The point about this postmodern research, of course, is that it is cheap and non-controversial - exactly the sort of thing that cash-strapped universities are looking for to boost their research ratings. "Who is doing the research into the dumbing down of the media," asks Greg Philo, "and the destruction of current affairs programming, the effects of violence in the media and the effects of huge corporations taking over the media?

"There's a similar silence in other areas of public policy. Take the drugs debate. "There are some organisations, such as the Rowntree Foundation, Nuffield and the trade unions sponsoring independent research," he says, "and very good work is coming out of it. For instance the trade union-sponsored research into stress and bullying in the workplace has made an impact. However, such studies are few and far between. I know that many academics are overworked and demoralised but they must be prepared to stand up and be counted in the public forum."

But Cotgreave is pessimistic in the light of further research cuts at the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. "The ministry has got to stop cutting its research budget," he said. "Ministers have said that they are preserving their BSE budget, but this means they are cutting other areas that might be important next year or the year after. If another BSE comes along we would be even worse off than this one."

fields.bodyText: Despite the naming and shaming of nearly 30 senior civil servants and eight former Tory ministers in last week's report by Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers over their refusal to recognise the BSE problem, Britain's scientists have largely escaped his censure. For over a decade, it has been a matter of record within the academic community that much of the research on which the government based its pronouncements on the safety of British beef was either wilfully suppressed or misinterpreted by the government, but almost to a man and woman they acquiesced in the perversion. Those who didn't, such as Richard Lacey, were so few in number they could be picked off with ease by government spin doctors as troublemakers. This is the latest example of a more general failure among academics to speak out on important issues, identified by Greg Philo and David Miller in a new book Market Killing. Their main targets are social scientists, but they believe the charge sticks more widely. Many academics must have had more than an inkling that something was amiss with the publication of Professor Sir Richard Southwood's report in 1989. This was the report that set the agenda for the government to declare that BSE was an animal, not human, health problem and all but closed the door on scientific research into the human health risks of infected beef. Sir Richard told one newspaper last week that he was urged to keep his investigation into BSE's impact on the food chain quiet and not to make any recommendations that would involve the government in too much expense. In 1990 he advised the government that further research into "the remote possibility that humans could be infected" was necessary. He admitted: "I did stop eating brain tissue following my research." And yet academics knew that Southwood's committee contained no experts on scrapie or transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, nor were the available experts in Britain and the US called to give evidence. As Miller, research manager at the Stirling Media Research Institute, wrote in a paper for Social Science and Medicine, "of those who were called, Hugh Frazer of the Institute for Animal Health is reported to be amazed that he was only asked 'a few simplistic questions' and not for his opinion on other pertinent areas of science". Back in 1990, Miller conducted his own research into food scandals and was amazed at the duplicity of some of the scientists who were actively engaged in government research in BSE: "Even though the government was telling the public that British beef was safe to eat, I came across quite a few academics who told me that, based on the scientific evidence, they had concluded beef was unsafe and had stopped eating it," he says. "More worrying still, one very senior scientist, who made a great show of supporting the government line by stating in public that he was happy to carry on eating beef, had actually stopped eating it on health safety grounds." Dr Peter Cotgreave, director of the Save British Science Society, claims that the Phillips report highlights the fact that there will have to be changes in the way government deals with scientific advice - and that "scientific experts have not been given the independence to state their views". But he concedes: "When the government was standing up saying there was no risk from BSE, the scientific community should have been standing up and saying that this was not what the scientific evidence actually pointed to," he says. "The advice was that there might be a risk, but we just didn't know for sure." Cotgreave says that there are many more strings attached to all kinds of government research grants than in the past. The £775m of new infrastructure funds announced in the government spending review, for example, come with a caveat that academics must attract 25% of the money from industry. "That is going to affect the questions they ask," he says. A review of physics research in the UK earlier in the year by a group of international experts suggested that UK academics are more willing to just do what the government asks. Similar pressure abroad would start riots in universities. Former government chief scientific adviser Sir Bob May agreed that scientific experts should be more vocal. "I can see the reasons why people do not get involved. They have given willingly of their time, and then have not been altogether happy with what happened, and are reluctant to give yet more time to make themselves unpopular," he said. "But at the same time I think it is something they should do." But Sir Bob says that he is unaware of evidence that academics or scientists withhold results or that research is getting less fundamental: "If you actually assess the distribution of research council money for fundamental versus applied work, it has moved into the direction of more fundamental work. If you actually count the fraction of papers that are in high-quality, rigorously refereed journals the British share has gone up not down." Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University, agrees with Miller that academics did abdicate their responsibilities over the BSE crisis and subjects unpopular with ministers. In an email to Miller he wrote: "As you know, in the 1980s and 1990s the number of academics who participated in the food-scandals debate was pitifully few. I have been clearing out my archives for the last week and have got all angry again about how few were prepared to research food poverty. Those who did so were giants." Academics are ultimately funded by the taxpayer, but are not always the fearless guardians of truth and objectivity they may sometimes claim to be; rather, they are men and women with families and a mortgage who are loath to rock boats for fear of damaging their career prospects. The public interest gets lost. This is perhaps understandable, if not exactly noble. Miller reports on the reaction he got when he announced he was planning to undertake some unpopular research into the effect of the broadcast ban on the IRA in Northern Ireland. "You could hear the sound of doors shutting," he says. The other aspect of this silencing of the lambs is the commercialisation of academic research. In the early 1980s many research bodies were publicly funded; now they are virtual plcs. The effect of this is that most research is either driven by commercial gain - hence the huge amount of money and time spent on finding a cure for hair loss - or by a government agenda, for which money is made available. "Increasingly it is being left to journalists to ask the difficult questions. webTitle: Why should mature students wait until September?

fields.headline: Why wait until September?
fields.standfirst: Starting studies in the second semester can be the answer for hard-pushed mature students, says  Helen Carter
fields.trailText: Starting studies in the second semester can be the answer for hard-pushed mature students, says Helen Carter
fields.body:
A flexible system which offers students the chance to begin their degree course in either February or September has proved so successful that it has been expanded.

Last year, Bolton Institute in Lancashire introduced a framework covering almost 20 first degrees in the technology faculty across built environment, textiles and engineering. This February it was extended to include degree courses in the faculties of arts, science and education and in the business school.

Around 15% of its 3,000 students have opted to take second semester courses this year. In fact, the institute has just launched a campaign for second semester courses, setting up an information line for students who would prefer to start studying in winter rather than in autumn. The institute is also organising an open day for these potential students in January.

Professor Peter Marsh, dean of the faculties of arts, science and education, says: "We have mature students, both full-time and part-time, who find that the higher education timetable is not necessarily synchronised to their needs.

"There are some people who decide that they don't want to wait until next September before starting a course. We have nurses who take a BA in health studies part-time and it may suit them to start the course in February instead of September."

The pattern of study means there are two semesters per year. The February entrants are one semester behind those students who begin their courses in September. They take their exams at the end of each semester - at the end of June or January.

Professor Marsh says the institute has to ensure that the February entrants do not lose out in terms of pastoral support and the induction process by starting six months later.

"Our aim is that there will be a sufficiently large number of second semester entrants that they will form their own identity.

"It is important that we are aware that they are not just student fodder and we need to look at their cohort needs."

Second semester courses were now being offered in full-time humanities, community studies and social studies, psychology, biology and environmental studies degrees.

Overall, the number of mature and younger students opting for second semester courses has been 50-50.

The University of Central England in Birmingham also offers second semester degree courses. The MA in marketing begins in February.

Steve MacKay, the course director, says: "The MA course attracts people who are typically in middle management positions with fairly hectic schedules who are looking for something which fits into their career aspirations and schedules.

"Most people consider the calendar year rather than the academic year as the more appropriate starting date."

The February version of the course is constructed around a series of three intensive two-day courses, which take place on Fridays and Saturdays. The majority of students are able to negotiate three days off work in return for a commitment to the course for three days from their weekends.

Mr MacKay believes the trend in higher education is moving away from courses which run over several evenings a week to more flexible study. Last year, there were 18 students on his course - more than double the figures in previous years when they offered a more traditional approach.

Josie O'Sullivan, a mature student in her 40s, says the flexibility of the MA course at UCE appealed to her.

"I had previously done my HNC and CIM qualifications at the University of Central England", she says, "but they were two nights a week and after doing this for three-and-a-half years, I was getting fed up.

"Over the years I had got promotion at work so I was working harder and it was not as easy as it was when I was starting off.

"The MA has opened my eyes and I have become more creative. It was the flexibility which appealed to me."

Sara Vernon, 34, who is doing a humanities degree at Bolton Institute, says she began her second semester course in February 1998. "I couldn't have afforded to start in September - I had just finished a course and I needed to find a job," she says.

"I have just been accepted to do a masters at Salford University in heritage starting next October. There are a lot more mature students on my course and I feel as if it has been a stepping stone for me."

webTitle: Why do the parents of bullied children  turn to the law?

fields.headline: Listen, or pay
fields.standfirst: Last week, a schoolboy sued his local authority for allowing him to be bullied.  Esther Addley asks the parents of bullied children why they turn to the law
fields.trailText: Last week, a schoolboy sued his local authority for allowing him to be bullied. Esther Addley asks the parents of bullied children why they turn to the law
fields.body:
The final straw for Liz Carnell came when her 12-year-old son John was attacked in a corridor at school. He had been called "swot" before, his books had been scribbled on, his pencil case and school bag and rugby kit stolen or destroyed. He had been hit on the head a number of times by another pupil, and had even needed hospital treatment for internal bruising after another boy punched him in the kidneys during a chemistry lesson. On that occasion she had called the police, though they took no action.

But after more than a year of torment for John, and what felt like complete indifference from the school, Carnell had had enough. She had visited the school, talked to John's teacher and the headteacher, written, phoned, contacted the governors, written to the local education authority. The school told her: "We don't have this much trouble with other parents," and refused to deal with any specific allegations against the bully. So Carnell took John out of school and kept him at home. She didn't know what else she could do to protect her son.

"We complained in a fairly low-key way to begin with," says Carnell, a journalist from Harrogate in Yorkshire. "I didn't want to make a fuss. But as time went on I got very upset. I used to cry because I didn't know what I had to do to protect John. On one occasion he said to me, 'I wish I was dead.' That's a terrible thing for a parent to have to deal with, to go to work every day knowing that your child is feeling that way." The reaction of the school, she says, was "thoroughly unpleasant". She says the headteacher told her the bullying must be John's fault. In the end they started legal proceedings against North Yorkshire county council. In 1997, five years after the bullying began, the council paid John £6,000 to settle out of court.

Parents and teachers may assume that Carnell's experiences in dealing with her son's bullying are rare, but they would be unwise to be complacent. Last week a 17-year-old boy from Greater Manchester won £1,500 from his local authority because his grammar school was found to be in breach of its duty of care in failing to protect him from being bullied: the first successful legal action over bullying in three decades.

Another teenager, Leah Bradford-Smart, now 19, is pursuing a case against West Sussex county council alleging that her school also failed to protect her from persistent bullying.

Schools are required by law to have anti-bullying policies, but it appears they will increasingly need to consider the risk of litigation if they cannot satisfy parents. Liz Carnell set up a website after John's case was settled. In less than a year Bullying Online has had 42,000 visitors, and Carnell has responded to 3,700 emails since the site launched in April 1999. A lot of her correspondence, she says, is from parents wanting advice on how to sue their local education authority.

Mike McKay knows about the urge to "go in and blow them all up with a cannon". When his son Martin was 12, he got a phone call from his ex-wife saying that Martin had tried to kill himself. McKay had not been aware that the boy, who lived with his mother, was being physically bullied and on one occasion had been beaten up with an iron bar. The reaction of the school, he says, was that Martin must have brought it on himself.

"There was one occasion when the whole thing welled up and I was crying and angry and kicking things because I was really, really mad, but I managed to get that rage out of my system. Because of the way the LEA had misinterpreted my son's behaviour, I didn't want to demonstrate too much emotion in case they thought, well it's hardly surprising, his father is off his trolley as well. That's the effect it can have on people."

Mick Brookes, president of the National Association of Head Teachers and head of a school in Nottinghamshire, agrees McKay's reasoned approach is the best way to deal with the problem. He argues that schools are now much better trained in dealing with bullying. "In the past schools pretended bullying wasn't happening. Now people realise that it tends to happen everywhere, even in the workplace." His view is that no situation of bullying is beyond a solution. "In my 22 years of being a headteacher I have found that where parents can work together with the school this issue can be cracked every time."

Liz Carnell will hope he is right. She would like to see local authorities holding training sessions on bullying every year, and heads required to provide information to their governors on the number of complaints about bullying. Schemes to encourage children to support their peers by reporting any bullying should also be encouraged, she says. It is also vital for parents and teachers to be looking for telltale signs, such as cuts and bruises, missing books or repeated visits to the school nurse to try to get out of class.

"Sometimes it can be difficult for parents to tell what is bullying," she says. "When very young children start school they can be in the rough and tumble of the playground and parents don't know whether that constitutes bullying. I would say even then to pop into the school to have a word with the class teacher and hopefully nip it in the bud. It might save a lot of problems in the long run."

 Some names have been changed.

What parents should do

 At the first sign of bullying, ask to see the teacher and explain the situation in a non-confrontational way. Ask them to keep an eye on the situation.

 Ask to see a copy of the school's bullying policy. Procedures for staff, parents and pupils to follow if bullying occurs should be clear and well publicised throughout the school.

 Keep a diary of what your child tells you is happening.

 If the bullying continues, write to the teacher or head of year, asking them to note your concerns on your child's file, together with a note of the action they have taken.

 Write to the headteacher if you are still concerned, outlining everything and including information from the diary to back up your complaint.

 Take your child to a doctor if they are particularly distressed, as medication or counselling may be appropriate. A letter from your doctor to the school will reinforce your case.

 Each time you visit the school take notes, and write after your meeting confirming what you agreed should happen next.

 If you are still unhappy, contact the chair of governors. You are entitled to see a copy of your child's school record within 15 school days.

 The last resort is to make a formal complaint to the local authority, the local government ombudsman, your MP and ultimately the secretary of state, David Blunkett.

The National Association of Head Teachers: www.naht.org.uk

Bullying Online: www.bullying.co.uk

Parentline Plus: www.parentlineplus.org.uk, helpline 0808 800 2222

A site by George Robinson and Barbara Maines, whose materials are well-regarded: www.luckyduck.co.uk

Kidscape, a child safety charity: www.educate.co.uk/bull2.htm#top

Childline's advice for parents of bullies as well as of bullied children: www.childline.org.ukl

The BBC's anti-bullying site: www.bbc.co.uk/education/bully/

fields.headline: Circle of learning
fields.trailText: St Andrew's School, Eastbourne
fields.body:
We were promised education, education, education. What we've got is results, results, results. Not the same thing at all. That is why Fergal Roche, newly-appointed head of St Andrew's School, a mixed independent establishment for five- to 13-year-olds in Eastbourne, has been looking for a simple visual way of recognising all-round achievement.

"The national curriculum obliges state schools to concentrate almost to the exclusion of all else on literacy and numeracy," says Roche, "while many independent schools, which don't have to follow the national curriculum, are obsessed with sport. Of course these things are essential. But what about aesthetic, spiritual or adventurous achievements? Aren't they part of the picture, too?"

So an "all-round" picture is just what Roche has come up with - literally. A large circle represents the whole child's "landscape". It is divided into four equal quadrants. Thus academic achievement ranks equally with sport. And being in the school play or playing the recorder in a concert is given just as much status as if she or he had stepped adventurously into new experience by, say, sleeping a night away from home for the first time.

"We call it a 'landscape' because sketched symbolically into the four sections are a temple of learning, a forest of beauty, a mountain of sport and a river of adventure," explains Roche, who has had a lot of enthusiastic response from St Andrew's parents.

The globe-like Learning Landscape is discreetly supported at the base by a pair of hands. These are meant to represent the hands of God so that a spiritual, potentially multi-faith dimension is included, but without the point being laboured.

Each St Andrew's child has his or her personal landscape on an A3 sheet each year. "We keep it fairly vague for the youngest children," says Roche, but from year 3, (age seven), they each meet regularly, one-to-one with a tutor. They discuss together what the child has achieved and plot it into the appropriate quadrant on the landscape, which is carefully looked after by the tutor. It might be, say, "swam a length" or "played in a drumming group in assembly" or "went to cub camp for the first time" as well as the more obvious "got full marks in a spelling test".

Roche explains that "adventurous" is different from "sporting". "We want the children to take tiny risks - within very safe parameters - and venture out of their comfort zones," he says. "We want them, for instance, to try new things they're a bit nervous of. It's a significant achievement if you can get a reluctant child to have a go at something like, say, abseiling or talking to someone they might otherwise feel shy with. That's what we mean by 'adventurous'."

So is the Learning Landscape just another prep-school gimmick or is this really a good idea that could be adapted for use in other schools?

Fiona Cox is PSHE co-coordinator at Willow Tree Primary School at Northolt, in London. Cox says: "It's certainly a good idea for teacher and pupil each to know the strengths and weaknesses they are working on, but I think some of these quadrants would be difficult for some to achieve."

She continues: "I'm not sure a school can provide for individual needs such as 'adventure'. We might be a bit stuck in a state school providing enough for every box," suggesting that the idea could be adapted to include other areas of PSHE such as relationships, health and safety, choice and respecting others' differences.

But it will only work if a school's head really wants roundness. A friend, who asked not to be named, resigned her urban primary teaching post last summer. "I was close to despair," she says. "My head was forcing me only to half-educate the children. There was no music and almost no arts or humanities. Sats results were everything." I showed her Roche's Learning Landscape. "Yes, this depicts my view of education exactly," she said, "but it's very far from being the approach in most schools."

Giving a lecture at the RSA last week, "Music and education; towards a non-philistine society", Sir Claus Moser argued that music should be taken for granted in education. But music and the arts get scant attention in most schools. The thrust of his talk was that a person with no knowledge of the arts has a large dimension missing. Roche's Landscape is trying to fill in that dimension.

webTitle: National Bug-Busting Day, when schools  wage war on nits

fields.headline: Nitty gritty
fields.standfirst: Today is National Bug-Busting Day, when schools throughout the country wage war on nits. But they are fighting a losing battle, says  Wendy Moore
fields.trailText: Today is National Bug-Busting Day, when schools throughout the country wage war on nits. But they are fighting a losing battle, says Wendy Moore.
fields.body:
In schools today up and down the country children will be learning about an important battle. It's not the Battle of Hastings or the War of the Roses, and it's certainly not history. Today's lesson concerns the War Against Nits.

Today is officially designated National Bug-Busting Day, when an estimated 5,000 primary schools throughout the UK will be arming their pupils with nit combs and packing them home to wage war against head lice.

The drive - which takes place twice a year on October 31 and January 31 - is the brainchild of the charity Community Hygiene Concern. Now in its 11th year, the organisation targets primary schools, arming them with packs, posters, stickers and even a special "bug busters" song sung to the tune of Ghostbusters in the hope that a concerted front against the tiny insects will see them off for the best part of the winter.

Head lice can infest anyone, young or old, rich or poor - although their preference is for children between four and 11, girls rather than boys and clean hair rather than dirty. They are, in fact, quite slow creatures: they can't jump but rather amble from one person's head to another's. But once rooted, they multiply at an alarming rate. And although they don't inflict serious harm, their bites can be intensely irritating and cause infections. What's more, the tiny creatures - about the size of a sesame seed - are hugely difficult to detect and eliminate.

So dedicating a day to eradicating the beasts sounds perfectly sensible. The only trouble is that the method of attack promoted by school nurses in about half the country - and the focus of today's campaign - fails to work most of the time, latest research says.

A study among 4,000 schoolchildren in North Wales, published in the Lancet in August, found bug-busting - the official term for removing lice by combing wet hair with a special, fine-toothed comb - cured only 38% of pupils, compared to 78% for conventional insecticides. Bug-busting, the researchers concluded, should not be the first line of attack against head lice.

Ian Burgess of the Medical Entomology Centre, Cambridge, agrees that bug-busting can work. But the method, which entails smothering hair with conditioner and painstakingly combing out every last louse for up to 30 minutes, four times over two weeks, is simply unrealistic for many families, he argues.

"In a logical sense there is nothing wrong with the principle of it. The only beef I have is that for a lot of people in the real world it isn't practical."

In field trials, he has met children infested with up to 250 lice. To remove that many insects from maybe six children in a large family could take six hours a week. Miss one louse and the cycle begins again.

Dousing hair with insecticides may be far less pleasant, he admits, but at least it works. The main treatments, which can be bought over the counter in pharmacies, are lotions containing malathion or permethrin. Although head lice have grown resistant to these chemicals in some areas, there is so far no known resistance to malathion with turpenoids, sold as Suleo-M.

Burgess dismisses any safety concerns. The strength and quantity of the chemicals used is so small that the lotions are quite safe when used according to instructions, he says. Although there have been rare complaints of skin irritation or asthma attacks, no serious side-effects have been reported in 70 worldwide trials. Even so, insecticides should be used only when lice are present and not for prevention.

Other options on the market, such as herbal applications, shampoos and electric combs, are largely useless, says Burgess, although there is good evidence that tea tree oil, an essential oil traditionally used against head lice by Australian aborigines, works just as well as insecticides. Here too, however, caution is needed as essential oils can be highly toxic unless used as directed.

None of this convinces Joanna Ibarra, the driving force behind the charity Community Hygiene Concern, which promotes bug-busting. "We know from our own experience and all the people out there in the field that the only thing that is certain to work is bug-busting," she insists.

She dismisses the Lancet study, because researchers failed to use the latest bug-busting comb design. She is optimistic that another study, being carried out by the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, will back bug-busting. In addition, she argues, bug-busting is cheaper (as the £4.95 kit from CHC can be used again and again) than insecticides at nearly £4 a throw.

But she admits the establishment has turned against bug-busting. Once the main front against head lice, support in schools and the National Health Service has now declined so that only half of health authorities promote the method. Even so, CHC still receives funds from the Department of Health and the Lottery, as well as support from many schools.

Among them is Watling Way First School in Milton Keynes, where headteacher Brian Kite will be sounding the battle cry in assembly this morning and sending pupils home with avenging zeal. He for one is still convinced bug-busting works. He declares: "I can say if I do a bug-busting at the end of October my school will be virtually free of aggravation for four to five months."

 CHC runs a bug-busting helpline on 020 8341 7167 and a website at www.nits.net

fields.headline: Have patience
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
The "surgery" turns out to be a spectacular non-event. I am dispatched to the school library, there to await parents who have issues they wish to raise. I pace around. No one comes.

I pick up a book about the Dome. Apparently, in the early days, Jennie Page and her team would consume industrial quantities of chocolate at every meeting.

A whole hour has passed and no one has shown up. I make my way down to the school hall, where the governors are gathering.

I park myself at one end next to one of the parent governors I recognise from the playground. She introduces herself as Samantha. Below the dais, on a few child-sized chairs, are perched four or five parents. This being the first session of the school year, they are entitled to come forward and raise matters directly with the governing body, explains Samantha. No wonder nobody bothered with the surgery.

The chair, Mrs Martin, speaks. "I'd like to welcome you to our first meeting of the year," she says. "And we would very much like to hear whatever matters you would like to raise with the governing body." There is a deafening silence. Eventually, one of the parents takes to her feet. "Well, there is a problem in my child's class," she starts, her voice wobbling. "She's in year 5. We've been back more than a month, but her class has had nothing but supply teachers and no homework has been set. And I think it's a disgrace," continues the parent.

Mrs Martin looks to the head. "Can you enlighten us, Mr Richardson?"

"Er, yes. Unfortunately, the teacher we had appointed only informed us a week before the beginning of term that she was taking up another post. We have readvertised, but as I'm sure you are aware there is a shortage of teachers. So, yes, we have been forced to fall back on supplies.

"But there is no reason why homework should not be being set?" And here he looks over to Mrs Phipps, who chimes in: "No, certainly. We will look into that, Mrs James."

"So can we take it that will be addressed?" Mrs Martin asks. Nods all round.

"Any other questions?" A Turkish father explains that he has to work evenings and cannot help with his sons' homework. But his wife does not read English. Can the school help by providing a homework tutor? There is goodwill, but no definitive answer: an undertaking to "look into it".

Finally it is time for the governing body's business. The foil comes off the plates to reveal a selection of slightly curling sandwiches. No chocolate then.
