webTitle: Controlling naughty children can be a nightmare

fields.headline: Rope trick
fields.standfirst: Last week, headteacher Marjorie Evans was reinstated after a row over discipline at her school. Everyone knows controlling naughty children can be a nightmare - but is tying two together with a rope really a good idea?  Claire Phipps  unpicks a knotty problem
fields.trailText: Last week, headteacher Marjorie Evans was reinstated after a row over discipline at her school. Everyone knows controlling naughty children can be a nightmare - but is tying two together with a rope really a good idea? Claire Phipps unpicks a knotty problem
fields.body:
When is a slap not a slap? When it's administered by a teacher in "exceptional circumstances, where there is an immediate risk of injury", according to Section 550a of the Education Act 1996: then, it becomes "reasonable force". To prevent a pupil from committing an offence, injuring him/herself or others, damaging property or behaving in a manner likely to disrupt good order, "a member of the staff of a school may use ... such force as is reasonable."

The problem - one of many to emerge from the law governing teachers' rights to restrain pupils - comes with that word "reasonable". Is it reasonable to hit a child who is scribbling on a desk? What if the child tips that desk over, or throws a chair? What if that child then throws a chair at a teacher, or another pupil? Most parents, and teachers themselves, would say no, that to react to any of these situations with a slap is unacceptable since the abolition of corporal punishment.

So, slapping is out. But detentions and threats of treats withdrawn often - as any teacher or, indeed, child will admit - fail to control a pupil intent on causing havoc. Is it then reasonable to lock that pupil in a cupboard, throw water in his or her face, tie two young siblings together with a skipping rope? The regulations here are not so much a grey area as a black hole.

The above incidents were all alleged to have taken place at St Mary's primary school in Caldicot, Wales, where headteacher Marjorie Evans is soon to restart her career after 13 months of suspension. Accusations that she had slapped an unruly pupil were cast out at the Court of Appeal last month; no charges will be brought in relation to the other claims.

Evans robustly denies accusations that she has mistreated pupils, but happily concedes that the "skipping rope" incident did happen. The loose tying together of wrists while the two, a brother and sister, were in a group taking part in a sponsored walk was, she insists, done for the protection of both of them - staff were worried that the boy could have run into the road and been hit by a car. It was carried out, says Evans, in a jovial manner: the children themselves were amused, and their mother has expressed her support for the school.

Others involved in the care of children aren't so sure that such measures are as harmless as they might first appear. "It's outrageous," says Carolyn Hamilton of the Children's Legal Centre. "Tying children together definitely crosses the line. Force can only be used in very specific circumstances, ones in which children will pose a danger. Restraint is not appropriate for small children being naughty."

Many teachers are not so certain. When faced with very difficult behaviour, many are unsure about the severity of any sanctions, and are afraid that if they inadvertently overstep the line they could face charges of abuse. And, reading the guidelines issued by the Department for Education and Employment in September 1998 in an attempt to clarify the 1996 Act, is it any wonder?

"There is no legal definition of 'reasonable force'", the guidelines state, "so it is not possible to set out comprehensively when it is reasonable to use force, or the degree of force that may reasonably be used. It will always depend on the circumstances."

So it remains a matter of interpretation. "Three years ago you couldn't do anything at all - it had almost got to the point where you had to stand back if a child was violent," says Roger Alexander, who was headteacher at a "fairly tough" primary school for 13 years. "After various attacks on teachers, it's now agreed that you can use reasonable force to protect yourself, the child, or another child," he explains.

So, was it acceptable to tether two children to each other with a rope? Definitely not, in his opinion. "It just wouldn't work. It's like putting two fireworks side by side. What you need to do is attach - not literally - one child to one teacher and the other to another teacher. It sends a message to the other kids and isolates the ones causing the problems."

Fiona Campbell, a primary school teacher from Sheffield, agrees. "There is no place in education for such a humiliating thing," she insists. "What worries me is that people will think this sort of thing regularly goes on in schools, but it doesn't and shouldn't." She admits that teachers can be pushed to the limits by the more challenging children, but argues that there are other ways to deal with such a situation. "The key thing is safety. If you think that children will be unsafe on a sponsored walk, then you don't take them, even if it means that the whole class doesn't go."

One problem for primary teachers in particular is that there are very few sanctions available to them. Young children cannot be detained after school. Removing the child from a classroom is only a short-term solution. Very quickly, the teacher can find that he or she has run out of disciplinary measures to control a child who simply will not stop misbehaving.

Often, says Alexander, the teacher's situation is complicated by the fact that parents can be blind to their child's faults. Conversely, there are parents who are all too keen for teachers to take a firm hand with their offspring. Parents like Robert Whelan, director of Family and Youth Concern (FYC). "A smack brings a problem to a conclusion," he says. So what do parents like this think of more moderate sanctions, such as the use of a skipping rope as a restraint? "The law should not be brought to bear on a teacher who is doing her job," Whelan says without hesitation. "It is up to parents to decide whether methods of discipline are acceptable. The parents in the skipping rope case supported Marjorie Evans, but she has not been supported by the system. If the parents agree, let that be an end to it. Those who don't can find another school to send their children to."

But shouldn't parents be able to send their children to school in the knowledge that physical force will not be used against them? "I'd go mad if a teacher did that to my daughter," says Tom Carney, who has three children aged between 10 and 21. "There should still be punishment in schools - and I think there's still room for the cane if a kid is really naughty - but there's got to be a line you don't cross."

If a child is not physically harmed, it can be easy to overlook the fact that force has been used. Paula Woodhurst recalls an incident when her son, now 21, told her that his teacher had grabbed his tie and pushed him against a wall. "I told him he probably deserved it, because I knew what a horror he could be," she says. "I should have gone up to the school, but I had sympathy for the teacher."

DfEE guidelines dictate that detailed records should be kept of all incidents where force is used, and that parents should be invited to discuss it. This does not, however, allow the child the same opportunity. Children often have different ideas from adults about what can "reasonably" be done to them. Humiliation, after all, can be as distressing as pain.

"I would have felt worried, and afraid of what she was going to do next," says Jasmine, eight, of the skipping rope solution. "I've never seen it done, and it shouldn't be allowed. It's not funny." Matthew, 12, agrees that "it wouldn't be right," but concedes that "it's a bit funny, but then it isn't really. It probably causes pain. It's probably embarrassing. And it's illegal, isn't it?"

Both children appreciate that pupils can wind their teachers up to the point where tempers are lost and lessons are wasted. "There is a boy in my class who annoys the teacher, and it affects the whole class, stops us from learning," explains Matthew.

The recognition that children be protected from violence has meant there is no longer any place in the classroom for the cane. It has also meant that there is little room for error on the part of teachers. At a briefing for heads, Alexander recalls being warned that few teachers could expect to retire without having been suspended at least once. Official figures indicate that such measures are still rare - the National Union of Teachers registered 120 allegations against teachers last year, of which 60% were proved false. But teachers can feel as if they are under siege: "If a child makes a claim, then you're guilty until proven innocent. The automatic procedures just kick in."

They certainly did for Sarah Foster. She too was falsely accused of assaulting a pupil, at the infant school at which she is head. She was interviewed (and photographed, and finger-printed) by police. Within 24 hours, the Crown Prosecution Service decided there was no case to answer. Nevertheless, she was suspended by the local authority while it carried out its own investigation; she was reinstated two weeks later. The child remains on the site.

"I still feel devastated. There is very little support for teachers. You get complaints from parents whose children have been kicked and thumped by difficult pupils, and you realise that those complaints are justified. You need to remove a child from a situation when he is disruptive, but teachers are wary about stepping in."

On Thursday, the NUT will unveil its new guidelines to teachers. They promise to go beyond the advice offered by the DfEE, which many teachers find impractical. "Teachers need more protection and more clarity," agrees Foster. "At the moment, the code of conduct is just not detailed enough. Everything seems to be working against the teacher."

 Some names have been changed.
fields.bodyText: When is a slap not a slap? When it's administered by a teacher in "exceptional circumstances, where there is an immediate risk of injury", according to Section 550a of the Education Act 1996: then, it becomes "reasonable force". To prevent a pupil from committing an offence, injuring him/herself or others, damaging property or behaving in a manner likely to disrupt good order, "a member of the staff of a school may use ... such force as is reasonable." The problem - one of many to emerge from the law governing teachers' rights to restrain pupils - comes with that word "reasonable". Is it reasonable to hit a child who is scribbling on a desk? What if the child tips that desk over, or throws a chair? What if that child then throws a chair at a teacher, or another pupil? Most parents, and teachers themselves, would say no, that to react to any of these situations with a slap is unacceptable since the abolition of corporal punishment. So, slapping is out. But detentions and threats of treats withdrawn often - as any teacher or, indeed, child will admit - fail to control a pupil intent on causing havoc. Is it then reasonable to lock that pupil in a cupboard, throw water in his or her face, tie two young siblings together with a skipping rope? The regulations here are not so much a grey area as a black hole. The above incidents were all alleged to have taken place at St Mary's primary school in Caldicot, Wales, where headteacher Marjorie Evans is soon to restart her career after 13 months of suspension. Accusations that she had slapped an unruly pupil were cast out at the Court of Appeal last month; no charges will be brought in relation to the other claims. Evans robustly denies accusations that she has mistreated pupils, but happily concedes that the "skipping rope" incident did happen. The loose tying together of wrists while the two, a brother and sister, were in a group taking part in a sponsored walk was, she insists, done for the protection of both of them - staff were worried that the boy could have run into the road and been hit by a car. It was carried out, says Evans, in a jovial manner: the children themselves were amused, and their mother has expressed her support for the school. Others involved in the care of children aren't so sure that such measures are as harmless as they might first appear. "It's outrageous," says Carolyn Hamilton of the Children's Legal Centre. "Tying children together definitely crosses the line. Force can only be used in very specific circumstances, ones in which children will pose a danger. Restraint is not appropriate for small children being naughty." Many teachers are not so certain. When faced with very difficult behaviour, many are unsure about the severity of any sanctions, and are afraid that if they inadvertently overstep the line they could face charges of abuse. And, reading the guidelines issued by the Department for Education and Employment in September 1998 in an attempt to clarify the 1996 Act, is it any wonder? "There is no legal definition of 'reasonable force'", the guidelines state, "so it is not possible to set out comprehensively when it is reasonable to use force, or the degree of force that may reasonably be used. It will always depend on the circumstances." So it remains a matter of interpretation. "Three years ago you couldn't do anything at all - it had almost got to the point where you had to stand back if a child was violent," says Roger Alexander, who was headteacher at a "fairly tough" primary school for 13 years. "After various attacks on teachers, it's now agreed that you can use reasonable force to protect yourself, the child, or another child," he explains. So, was it acceptable to tether two children to each other with a rope? Definitely not, in his opinion. "It just wouldn't work. It's like putting two fireworks side by side. What you need to do is attach - not literally - one child to one teacher and the other to another teacher. It sends a message to the other kids and isolates the ones causing the problems." Fiona Campbell, a primary school teacher from Sheffield, agrees. "There is no place in education for such a humiliating thing," she insists. "What worries me is that people will think this sort of thing regularly goes on in schools, but it doesn't and shouldn't." She admits that teachers can be pushed to the limits by the more challenging children, but argues that there are other ways to deal with such a situation. "The key thing is safety. If you think that children will be unsafe on a sponsored walk, then you don't take them, even if it means that the whole class doesn't go." One problem for primary teachers in particular is that there are very few sanctions available to them. Young children cannot be detained after school. Removing the child from a classroom is only a short-term solution. Very quickly, the teacher can find that he or she has run out of disciplinary measures to control a child who simply will not stop misbehaving. Often, says Alexander, the teacher's situation is complicated by the fact that parents can be blind to their child's faults. Conversely, there are parents who are all too keen for teachers to take a firm hand with their offspring. Parents like Robert Whelan, director of Family and Youth Concern (FYC). "A smack brings a problem to a conclusion," he says. So what do parents like this think of more moderate sanctions, such as the use of a skipping rope as a restraint? "The law should not be brought to bear on a teacher who is doing her job," Whelan says without hesitation. "It is up to parents to decide whether methods of discipline are acceptable. The parents in the skipping rope case supported Marjorie Evans, but she has not been supported by the system. If the parents agree, let that be an end to it. Those who don't can find another school to send their children to." But shouldn't parents be able to send their children to school in the knowledge that physical force will not be used against them? "I'd go mad if a teacher did that to my daughter," says Tom Carney, who has three children aged between 10 and 21. "There should still be punishment in schools - and I think there's still room for the cane if a kid is really naughty - but there's got to be a line you don't cross." If a child is not physically harmed, it can be easy to overlook the fact that force has been used. Paula Woodhurst recalls an incident when her son, now 21, told her that his teacher had grabbed his tie and pushed him against a wall. "I told him he probably deserved it, because I knew what a horror he could be," she says. "I should have gone up to the school, but I had sympathy for the teacher." DfEE guidelines dictate that detailed records should be kept of all incidents where force is used, and that parents should be invited to discuss it. This does not, however, allow the child the same opportunity. Children often have different ideas from adults about what can "reasonably" be done to them. Humiliation, after all, can be as distressing as pain. "I would have felt worried, and afraid of what she was going to do next," says Jasmine, eight, of the skipping rope solution. "I've never seen it done, and it shouldn't be allowed. It's not funny." Matthew, 12, agrees that "it wouldn't be right," but concedes that "it's a bit funny, but then it isn't really. It probably causes pain. It's probably embarrassing. And it's illegal, isn't it?" Both children appreciate that pupils can wind their teachers up to the point where tempers are lost and lessons are wasted. "There is a boy in my class who annoys the teacher, and it affects the whole class, stops us from learning," explains Matthew. The recognition that children be protected from violence has meant there is no longer any place in the classroom for the cane. It has also meant that there is little room for error on the part of teachers. At a briefing for heads, Alexander recalls being warned that few teachers could expect to retire without having been suspended at least once. Official figures indicate that such measures are still rare - the National Union of Teachers registered 120 allegations against teachers last year, of which 60% were proved false. But teachers can feel as if they are under siege: "If a child makes a claim, then you're guilty until proven innocent. The automatic procedures just kick in." They certainly did for Sarah Foster. She too was falsely accused of assaulting a pupil, at the infant school at which she is head. She was interviewed (and photographed, and finger-printed) by police. Within 24 hours, the Crown Prosecution Service decided there was no case to answer. Nevertheless, she was suspended by the local authority while it carried out its own investigation; she was reinstated two weeks later. The child remains on the site. "I still feel devastated. There is very little support for teachers. You get complaints from parents whose children have been kicked and thumped by difficult pupils, and you realise that those complaints are justified. You need to remove a child from a situation when he is disruptive, but teachers are wary about stepping in." On Thursday, the NUT will unveil its new guidelines to teachers. They promise to go beyond the advice offered by the DfEE, which many teachers find impractical. "Teachers need more protection and more clarity," agrees Foster. "At the moment, the code of conduct is just not detailed enough. Everything seems to be working against the teacher."  Some names have been changed.

fields.headline: Scientists investigate possible CJD cluster
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Experts from the CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh are investigating whether two people in the same street might have died from the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Experts from the CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh are investigating whether two people in the same street might have died from the human form of BSE.

Matthew Parker, 19, of Armthorpe, Doncaster, in South Yorkshire, died from new variant CJD three years ago. Tests have begun to determine whether his neighbour, Sarah Roberts, 28, who died last month, fell victim to the same illness.

The cluster of probable vCJD deaths has caused scientists to rethink links between the disease and specific areas. They are already investigating six cases in Leicestershire, four of which have been closely associated with the village of Queniborough.

If an autopsy proved Miss Roberts died from the illness this would be the second cluster of deaths to emerge since the disease was identified. Miss Roberts, an accountant, and Mr Parker lived in the same road and attended the same school.

Mr Parker's father, John Middleton, said: "This does not look like a coincidence. There has to be a connection somewhere."

John Radford of Doncaster health authority confirmed that scientists had travelled to Doncaster to investigate links. "They may have used the same butcher _ but to blame particular food outlets is wrong at this time. We need to understand the disease and understand the food histories of these people as much as we can," he said.

webTitle: Swede looks set to manage England

fields.headline: Swede looks set to manage England
fields.trailText: The Football Association's agonising quest for an England manager came a step closer to resolution last night after it confirmed that Sven-Goran Eriksson, the Lazio coach, was its first choice for the post.
fields.body:
The Football Association's agonising quest for an England manager came a step closer to resolution last night after it confirmed that Sven-Goran Eriksson, the Lazio coach, was its first choice for the post.

After reports from Italy that Eriksson - whose £3m-a-year contract with the Italian club expires at the end of the season - had already signed, the FA was forced to rush out a statement confirming it was in talks with him.

The FA executive director, David Davies, said: "Meetings have taken place over the past 24 hours with Sven-Goran Eriksson and representatives of his club, Lazio.

"The FA have discussed the possibility of him taking charge of the England team both for key games in the short term, and in a full-time capacity in the long term. Those talks will resume in the near future."

Later Mr Davies told Sky News: "We have made good progress and that's why this news has come out from Italy."

The 52-year-old Swede is believed to have agreed a five-year deal worth around £10m. If he is confirmed in the post, he will be the first foreigner to manage England.

The Italian news agency Ansa reported that Eriksson would move from one of European football's best paid jobs to take over the vacant post on July 1 next year. That would leave England to face a 10-month hiatus.

Last night neither Eriksson nor Lazio would comment.

fields.headline: Motorway opens - after 40 years
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Manchester has waited 40 years for its motorway ring road - a 34-mile version of the M25 - which could explain why no one seemed in much of a rush to use it yesterday.
fields.body:
Manchester has waited 40 years for its motorway ring road - a 34-mile version of the M25 - which could explain why no one seemed in much of a rush to use it yesterday.

Delays in slotting in the missing 10-mile link in the south-east corner of the M60 have frustrated drivers for years. But 30 minutes after it was opened you could have safely driven a horse and cart along the northbound inside lane.

The emptiness will not last. South Manchester will soon discover this is the quickest route to Leeds, and Yorkshire will find out that it is a short cut to Manchester airport.

The new stretch, which slithers from four lanes to two and back to four, should have come into use after a ribbon-cutting ceremony presided over by the transport minister, Keith Hill. But he was stranded in Gatwick by storms and floods and Andrew Bennett, Labour MP for Denton and Reddish, had to step into the breach with pupils from primary schools from each end of the £220m length of tarmac.

Before the ceremony, the highway had to be gritted after the first snow of winter and was then baptised with the latest of many deluges that would have frightened Noah.

The M60 used to be known as the M63 and now incorporates a length of the M62. £8m has been spent on new signs ("M60: formerly M63") in an optimistic bid to end confusion.

The first five-mile bit of the M63 opened in October 1960 to carry traffic over the Manchester ship canal via Barton Bridge. Extra lengths were added in 1970. In 1982 it reached Stockport and six years later advanced to a big roundabout at Denton. And stopped dead for 12 years.

The route for the final link was published in 1980 and was discussed at two public inquiries. In 1995 protesters built tree houses and dug tunnels in an attempt to halt the motorway's march through Daisy Nook, a green lung near Failsworth.

It was celebrated by the dialect poet Ben Brierley (1825-96) who wrote: "In the field through which we pass, some 20 cows are browsing. How they stare to see a stranger pass! Lower down a wild colt is careering round the pasture, now stopping suddenly at the gate as if it had intended to leap over it and then changed its mind.

"I hear the sound of a scythe ... there are such strange sweet echoes speaking to each other across the valley that I cannot distinguish whence a sound proceeds."

Cows, colts and scythes were silent yesterday. The only sound was a growing rumble of traffic. Up to 90,000 vehicles a day will now rush unheeding past Daisy Nook.

webTitle: Attempt to make avatars more convincing

fields.headline: Reality bytes
fields.standfirst:
Attempt to make avatars more convincing

Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The company behind virtual newsreader Ananova yesterday said it will work on technology to make virtual people, or avatars, look more human.
fields.body:
The company behind virtual newsreader Ananova yesterday said it will work on technology to make virtual people, or avatars, look more human.

Glasgow-based Digital Animations said animation would remain at the core of the business, but it would also attempt to create a convincing world of virtual secretaries, receptionists and call-centre workers.

It has been working on more realistic animation, lip sync and the use of human voice as well as computer-generated speech.

"We have a vision that virtual characters will become prevalent in the next couple of years," said chief executive Michael Hambly, pictured above with a new avatar, TMmy, created to showcase the advances. TMmy will release a pop song, You Make My Day, be fore Christmas. The company will also produce title sequences for the Christmas releases of two leading computer games companies.

The 10-year-old company was reporting its first profits since it floated in 1996. Pre-tax profits for the six months to September were £1,175,717 but included a one-off gain of some £920,000 in reduced tax liability for employee share options. In the same period last year, the company lost £491,000. The shares rose 7p to 70p.

webTitle: Gore will keep the good times rolling

fields.headline: Gore will keep the good times rolling
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Despite all the complaints about the difficulty of falling in love with either Al Gore or George W Bush, these two very different men have delivered a clean, well-argued campaign that offers a choice between two sharply contrasting visions of the future.
fields.body:
Despite all the complaints about the difficulty of falling in love with either Al Gore or George W Bush, these two very different men have delivered a clean, well-argued campaign that offers a choice between two sharply contrasting visions of the future.

This is the first presidential campaign in recent history centred on an argument over how best to use real resources to address age-old domestic problems while also defining the United States' role in a world evermore dependent on it for farsighted international leadership.

Having listened to their debate, we today firmly endorse Al Gore as the man best equipped for the presidency by virtue of his knowledge of government, his experience at the top levels of federal and diplomatic decision-making, and his devotion to the general welfare.

We offer this endorsement knowing that Mr Bush is not without his strong points and that Mr Gore has his weaknesses.

We commend Mr Bush for running a largely positive, inclusive campaign. He has not played on divisive social themes as his father did in 1988. But on women's rights, guns and law-enforcement issues, he has a harsh agenda, and the centrepiece of his domestic programme is a lavish tax cut for the rich that would negate the next Congress's once-in-a-century opportunity to move the country toward universal health care and stabilisation of social security and Medicare.

Preserving the nation's remarkable prosperity must be considered the thematic spine of this election. Mr Gore promises to maintain fiscal rigour while using the surplus on spending programmes and tax breaks for the working families that profited least from the biggest boom in American history.

Mr Bush's entire economic programme is built on a stunning combination of social inequity and flawed economic theory.

Most citizens know that Mr Gore wins any comparison with Mr Bush on experience and knowledge. Yet many voters seem more comfortable with Mr Bush's personality and are tempted to gamble on him. We do not dismiss this desire for someone who they feel does not talk down to them.

But it is important to remember that the nation's prosperity, its environmental progress and its guarantees of civil rights and reproductive freedom took years to build.

They could be undone in a flash by a pliable and inexperienced president driven by a highly ideological Congress.

webTitle: Bush will restore honour and integrity

fields.headline: Bush will restore honour and integrity
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Does America need continuity for the next four years, or does it need to change the tone and direction of our nation's course?
fields.body:
Does America need continuity for the next four years, or does it need to change the tone and direction of our nation's course?

We believe a fundamental shift is needed. True, the last eight years have brought unrivalled peace and prosperity. Yet this period in our national life also has led to the diminution of respect for the office of the presidency, a greater incivility on Capitol Hill and an exhausted New Democrat agenda.

A clear turning point has arrived. We strongly believe Texas governor George W Bush should become the nation's first president of a new century. We base our decision upon three crucial points.

The potential to redeem Washington's culture - immediately upon becoming Texas's governor in 1995, George Bush reached his hand across the aisle and drew in Democrats to work with him to improve schools, overhaul welfare and develop businesses.

Since 1995, many Republicans and Democrats have maintained a governing coalition that has placed the nation's second most populous state on a centre-right path that emphasises improved schools, fiscal restraint and social tolerance.

No voter should assume that hoisting Austin's model of government upon Washington's weary landscape will be simple. But Governor Bush has the tools to construct a different political architecture.

The ability to restore honour and integrity to the White House - The moment that usually draws the greatest applause in Mr Bush's campaign speeches comes when the Republican nominee talks about bringing dignity and character back to the White House. Even if they enjoy this era's economic expansion, they want honour restored to the White House. So do we. George Bush could do that by providing a clean, clear break from the past.

The opportunity to usher in a progressive-conservative era - Governor Bush started his presidential campaign in June 1999 promoting the promise of "compassionate conservatism". The modern presidency may compete with Wall Street, Silicon Valley, state capitals and even Hollywood to shape American society. But the nation still needs a president who can build bipartisan relationships, restore honour to the White House and promote a responsible agenda.

George W Bush could bring change on each of these fronts. We embrace his call for reform and strongly believe Americans should vote for change over continuity in November.

webTitle: Speaker issues warning on leaks by ministers

fields.headline: Speaker issues warning on leaks by ministers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The Speaker, Michael Martin, flexed his newly acquired muscle as a champion of backbenchers' rights yesterday when he warned ministers he would take a tough stance on media leaks.
fields.body:
The Speaker, Michael Martin, flexed his newly acquired muscle as a champion of backbenchers' rights yesterday when he warned ministers he would take a tough stance on media leaks.

The former shop steward, whom critics had feared would prove ineffectual, seized the opportunity to reveal an uncompromising side a week after being elected to replace Betty Boothroyd.

Responding to allegations that the Ministry of Defence had leaked a story about shipbuilding contracts the day before making an announcement in the Commons, he said: "If ministers were to release information to the press before the house is informed of major policy developments I would regard that as an unacceptable discourtesy. I would expect the minister concerned to apologise to the house."

Ms Boothroyd had made similar pleas about the need for ministers to announce policy first and foremost to MPs, but last week's bitterly fought election left Mr Martin in little doubt that backbenchers were desperate to reassert their collective rights. In his first press conference, he said it was up to backbenchers, not him, to bring ministers to heel.

His tough stance yesterday followed a complaint by the Tory MP for Buckingham, John Bercow, that a statement about shipbuilding contracts was placed on the BBC website last Thursday "precisely one hour and 59 minutes" before it was made to MPs.

Versions of the story, revealing that four roll-on/roll-off ferries would be built on Merseyside, had also appeared in various papers that morning, including the Guardian.

The Speaker conceded that "broadly accurate advance information" had reached the media but said he accepted the assurance of the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, that he was "confident" it had not come from his department.

Nevertheless, he expected ministers to take steps to ensure that any organisations privy to such confidential information should not leak it, and called on Mr Hoon to investigate last week's leak.

Mr Martin also told ministers they should think carefully about announcing policy initiatives as part of debates, instead of making an official announcement to the house. Backbenchers needed time to prepare to question government policies.

But he rejected a call from the opposition defence spokesman, Quentin Davies, for an inquiry into how the information reached the website, stressing repeatedly that in his statement he had already made himself plain.

webTitle: Sunderland deal may win plant new Micra

fields.headline: Sunderland deal may win plant new Micra
fields.trailText: Nissan would have to add at most 300 employees to the 5,000-strong workforce at its Sunderland manufacturing plant to build the new Micra car and nearly double annual output to half a million, industry sources said yesterday.
fields.body:
Nissan would have to add at most 300 employees to the 5,000-strong workforce at its Sunderland manufacturing plant to build the new Micra car and nearly double annual output to half a million, industry sources said yesterday.

The north east plant is in a fierce contest with Renault's factory at Flins, in northern France, to build the new Micra from the end of 2002.

But yesterday its workforce implemented new working arrangements that will enable the Japanese company to add a third shift at little extra cost - if the Sunderland plant wins the new car.

This emerged as Nissan's president, Carlos Ghosn, disclosed a rapid turnaround in the Japanese group's financial fortunes just six months into a three year revival plan that envisages 21,000 job losses and five plant closures.

He said in Tokyo that Nissan had achieved its best results in 10 years, with an operating profit of Y136.6bn (£890m) in the first half - largely through a Y192bn reduction in costs - and was on course for Y220bn in the full year. The Sunderland plant, Europe's most productive, has to show it can reduce its own costs by 30% just to achieve the same cost base as Flins where Renault, owners of 36.5% of Nissan, make Clios and Twingos - and enjoy the benefits of a weak euro while its UK rival suffers from the strong pound.

The north east plant, officials said, is now in position to build the new car without a costly new assembly line. Staff have agreed new patterns of work which will enable Nissan to add a third shift and boost current capacity of 300,000 to 500,000 for the new Micra.

Sources said this would mean taking on only 200 or 300 new staff to build the new car at little extra cost as labour accounts for only 5% of a new car's production costs. Sunderland's present output is just above 300,000 cars a year because of overtime, but the plant's finances would improve immeasurably if output rose to half a million.

"It's in the balance," sources said, pointing out that Sunderland will continue to suffer from the strong pound and weak euro for some time.

webTitle: Paul Foot: The bombing of the Israeli embassy

fields.headline: Sad victims of a useful disease
fields.standfirst:
Failure of disclosure has left two in jail, but it can all be explained.

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Almost as dangerous as BSE is HE, or human error, the disease which constantly comes to the assistance of the police and security services in their hour of need. The latest epidemic of HE can be detected in the astonishing case of R v Botmeh and Alami, which is currently before the court of appeal. Jawad Botmeh and Samar Alami, two young Palestinian activists, were convicted in 1996 of conspiracy "with persons unknown" to bomb the Israeli embassy in 1994 and sent to prison for 20 years.
fields.body:
Almost as dangerous as BSE is HE, or human error, the disease which constantly comes to the assistance of the police and security services in their hour of need. The latest epidemic of HE can be detected in the astonishing case of R v Botmeh and Alami, which is currently before the court of appeal. Jawad Botmeh and Samar Alami, two young Palestinian activists, were convicted in 1996 of conspiracy "with persons unknown" to bomb the Israeli embassy in 1994 and sent to prison for 20 years.

Three years ago, the MI5 agent David Shayler revealed that shortly after the bombing he became aware that there had been a warning of a terrorist attack on the Israeli embassy. Ministers, led by Home Secretary Jack Straw, abused Shayler as a traitor and a fantasist, and ridiculed his assertion that any such warning had been received by the security services. Last week it emerged in court that Shayler was telling the truth. After months of prevarication, the security services finally admitted that there was such a warning and that it had nothing to do with Samar Alami or Jawad Botmeh.

Why hasn't anyone heard about this before? The answer is simple. The security services and the Metropolitan police special branch were struck down with a terrible attack of HE - an attack that rendered them quite incapable of carrying out their most elementary duties in the course of criminal justice.

From what emerged in court last Thursday, I counted six separate cases of HE.

The terrorist organisation warning was "disseminated" by a document within the security service, but "for reasons of human error" it was not placed on the files shown to prosecution counsel in the Jawad/Alami case.

Other documents from the same source were placed before counsel. One of these documents referred to the Israeli embassy, but this was not shown to Mr Justice Garland, the judge in the case, during the disclosure hearing. The reason was oversight, a nasty variant of HE.

A copy of the document about the warning was passed by MI5 to MI6. This was handled by the MI6 desk officer dealing with the terrorist group named in the document. For reasons almost certainly connected with HE, this was not the officer responsible for disclosure of information in the Botmeh/Alami case.

The information was filed by the desk officer but somehow did not emerge in the disclosure hearings in the Botmeh/ Alami case. The reason was obvious: human error.

The document was also passed to the Metropolitan police special branch whose officers were hunting the bombers. It was "placed in a file germane to the main thread of the information received but was not placed on the file connected to the Israeli embassy or one which would have fallen within the crown disclosure." Another bad case of HE, this time in special branch.

There was a cross-reference to the document in a file review for disclosure which would have led to the document if noted, but the unusual physical position of the cross-reference on the file was such that it was overlooked during the disclosure exercise. Another awful case of HE.

From this grim catalogue, there are only two possible conclusions. The first is that both sections of the security services are so hopelessly disorganised that they cannot follow elementary rules of disclosure, and that even in cases involving terrorism and bombing there is not the slightest chance that they will make good use of any information they receive. The second is that in this case MI5, MI6 and special branch conspired not to disclose information which might damage the prosecution of Samar and Jawad.

Either alternative is, to put it mildly, disturbing. What cannot be contemplated is that after such monumental and shocking failure to disclose obviously crucial information, the flawed case against Samar and Jawad should be allowed to continue. They are back in prison. Their appeal is adjourned while their lawyers investigate yet more evidence, revealed in court last Friday and outlined in detail in last Sunday's Observer, that the police knew of another suspect but kept quiet about him.

Surely these two young people should not have to rot any longer in jail. The plain fact is that someone else, with no connection to either prisoner, bombed the Israeli embassy. No European court or hearing under the Human Rights Act could possibly conclude that the trial of Samar and Jawad was fair. Both should be released at once on bail while their innocence is established.

If the director of public prosecutions (David Calvert-Smith QC), who declared that he will not have any role in the current appeal, concludes that the failure of the original prosecution (masterminded by leading prosecution counsel David Calvert-Smith QC) was bungled because of human error, that is entirely a matter for him.

fields.headline: BAA expects go-ahead for Terminal 5
fields.trailText: BAA, Britain's largest airport operator, last night expressed confidence that Heathrow airport's Terminal 5 would be approved in a report due to be published later this year after Britain's longest running public inquiry.
fields.body:
BAA, Britain's largest airport operator, last night expressed confidence that Heathrow airport's Terminal 5 would be approved in a report due to be published later this year after Britain's longest running public inquiry.

Russell Wallis, BAA's finance director, said he did not think that the inspector, Roy Vandermeer, would reject the plan because "it is very difficult to see any viable alternatives".

He said that the implications for the British economy if the government gave "an absolute no" would be considerable.

If Heathrow's expansion was capped, Britain would lose passengers and business to mainland Europe.

Mr Wallis stressed that an investigation by the Civil Aviation Authority into BAA's role as an airports operator was unlikely to lead to a break-up of BAA.

The company operates seven airports - including Heathrow, Gatwick, Stansted, Southampton, Glasgow and Edinburgh - but it was not in the interests of shareholders and BAA would not support it.

BAA's interim results, published yesterday, show that retail sales at its airports are starting to recover from last year's duty free debacle.

It was badly mauled by investors when it was judged to have mishandled last summer's abolition of duty free sales, and issued a profit warning last September wiping 40% off its share price.

But net retail income in the three months to the end of September rose by 14% to £132m, and net income per passenger was some 7% higher at £3.53.

Mike Hodgkinson, BAA's chief executive, said: "These results clearly demonstrate a return to growth after an extremely challenging 15 months post the abolition of intra-EU duty free sales. "

Over the first half of the year, net retail income was up 1% on a six month period in 1999 that included three months of duty free sales. But average spending was down 6%.

Mr Hodgkinson said that there had been a 6.6% increase in traffic during the six monthperiod, and a £200m expansion at Stansted was well under way. Passenger numbers were continuing to grow at 20%.

During the period, 69.5m people travelled through the seven airports.

Mr Wallis pointed out that sales were still running at "one to one-and-a-half per cent below where we would like to be". There was no room for complacency, he said. The travelling public needed to be constantly reminded about the potential of duty free sales for countries outside the EU.

The biggest reduction in sales had been in perfume related products, which had been the biggest single revenue earner before the abolition of duty free.

Group interim profits rose 12% to £327m, and the interim dividend is being boosted by 7% to 6.1p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange yesterday called on OM group to drop its hostile bid after news that the Swedish group's near-£1bn offer had so far been accepted by only 2.73% of shareholders.
fields.body:
LSE calls on OM to scrap bid

The London Stock Exchange yesterday called on OM group to drop its hostile bid after news that the Swedish group's near-£1bn offer had so far been accepted by only 2.73% of shareholders.

"OM's negligible level of acceptances demonstrates that its inadequate offer is of little or no interest to LSE shareholders. It is time OM acknowledged this and withdrew its offer," the London exchange said in a statement.

OM said it had no intention of withdrawing the takeover offer, which closes on November 10.

Balfour Beatty wins PFI deal

Construction and engineering group Balfour Beatty has won a deal from Stoke-on-Trent council to build nine schools in a £153m deal under the private finance initiative.

The deal, thought to be the largest PFI contract of its kind, was won by Transform Schools, a joint venture between Balfour - which is involved in the row over rail track maintenance - and Innisfree.

Homebase bid withdrawn

Venture capital firm Duke Street Capital is said to have pulled out of the bidding for Homebase, the DIY business put up for sale by Sainsbury. Duke Street, which owns Focus Do It All and recently bought rival Wickes, is reported to have disagreed with Sainsbury on the value of the Homebase business. According to Reuters, French retailer Leroy Merlin, which is owned by the Mulliez family, is the only party in talks for Homebase. But sources said the French group is reluctant to pay the £1bn expected by Sainsbury and keen to seek a joint venture with the British group.

Eurafrance to restructure

Eurafrance, the financial holding company for French investment bank Lazard, said yesterday it was studying a number of options for reorganising the group's structure.

Speculation has intensified recent ly that Lazards, made up of a handful of inter-linked holding companies and the renowned merchant bank, is heading for a shake-up.

"The chairman told the board that he had put diverse options about how to simplify the Eurafrance structure under study. As soon as the studies have finished, they will be submitted to the board," Eurafrance said after a board meeting.

Eurafrance chairman Michel David-Weill, who is also chairman of the investment bank Lazard Freres, promised a reorganisation by the end of the year. Eurafrance is due to hold a shareholders meeting on December 18.

Antisoma on buying trail

Antisoma has licensed a new anti-cancer drug from the German Cancer Research Centre in Heidelberg and hopes to acquire rights to another four products within two years.

The new product, Thioplatin, is used in a range of treatments, including lung, ovarian and testicular cancers. It is Antisoma's first venture beyond the field of monoclonal antibodies.

In May the company's leading product Theragyn, for ovarian cancer, was affected by safety fears.

webTitle: Portillo's £8bn tax cut shift angers Labour

fields.headline: Portillo's £8bn tax cut shift angers Labour
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Labour last night accused the Conservatives of planning £8bn worth of "tax cuts on the never-never" in response to Michael Portillo's latest attempt to escape the charge that Tory tax-and-spend policies would create a £16bn black hole in public finances.
fields.body:
Labour last night accused the Conservatives of planning £8bn worth of "tax cuts on the never-never" in response to Michael Portillo's latest attempt to escape the charge that Tory tax-and-spend policies would create a £16bn black hole in public finances.

Senior ministers argued that Mr Portillo's effort to persuade voters that a government not committed to Labour's "stealth taxes" can protect public services and cut taxes at the same time - perhaps by £8bn - could only be done by repeating the ruinous borrowing of the Lawson-Lamont era.

Labour election strategists reacted with fury and frantic alarm after the shadow chancellor modified his earlier commitment to increase public spending at a significantly lower level than the £60bn plus on education, transport and the NHS envisaged in Gordon Brown's three-year programme starting in 2001.

Mr Brown's treasury deputy, Andrew Smith, and Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, mocked Mr Portillo's article in yesterday's Times as "confirming his spending cuts guarantee and adding to it a boom-and-bust guarantee" on the 1980s model.

Conservative MPs protested that ministers are trying to "frighten the sick and vulnerable in order to distract public attention from their own failures". The health secretary, Alan Milburn, will coincidentally announce details of his "concordat" with private hospitals to extend their use by NHS patients.

Mrs Beckett highlighted Mr Portillo's remark on Radio 4's Today programme that a William Hague cabinet would honour Labour's NHS spending pledges while "expecting people who can make a little extra contribution" to do so via voluntary private insurance for non-urgent ailments.

Mr Portillo's article was an attempt to take the sting out of Labour's attacks on Conservative plans outlined in the summer. They committed the opposition to increases in public spending for the next three years in line with the growth rate of the economy - slightly above 2% a year - rather than Mr Brown's promised 3.3% spending increase in 2001-4.

According to Labour, this would result in a £16bn shortfall by the end of the three years and the government has challenged Mr Portillo to specify where the "cuts" would be found over and above the £3-5bn cuts promised in social security and government "waste."

Mr Portillo made a determined effort to break out of Labour's encirclement by saying that a Tory government would stick to Labour's plans in its first year, 2001-2, before reining in spending. Labour officials argued that the Conservatives had pledged to increase spending by just over 2% on average over the three years.

Therefore matching Labour in the first year would mean deeper cuts in the second and third years 2002-4. Simultaneous tax cuts could only be funded by borrowing.

Mr Smith reminded voters of Tory pledges on crime, education and tax breaks for private health insurance. Millbank is costing every shadow cabinet spending pledge. "Portillo's plans are just unbelievably flimsy," a Labour insider said.

The backdrop to the sparring over taxation and spending is the rapidly improving state of the government's finances.

Last March the chancellor was forecasting a £5bn budget surplus by March 2001, but growth in tax revenues and lower spending mean that the prediction now looks far too pessimistic. Even the most cautious City analysts believes that the surplus will be £15bn, with some believing that it could be more than £20bn.

webTitle: Putin throws literary elite with judo book

fields.headline: Putin throws literary elite with judo book
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: In their idle hours, Russia's leaders have always devoted themselves to literature, and Vladimir Putin has demonstrated that he too is eager to bequeath the nation a permanent written legacy - one that will survive when he leaves the fickle world of politics.
fields.body:
In their idle hours, Russia's leaders have always devoted themselves to literature, and Vladimir Putin has demonstrated that he too is eager to bequeath the nation a permanent written legacy - one that will survive when he leaves the fickle world of politics.

While Vladimir Lenin was fond of dashing off works on dialectical materialism, Josef Stalin wrote historical analyses of the Communist party, Leonid Brezhnev tackled the second world war and Mikhail Gorbachev mused on the meaning of perestroika (rebuilding), Mr Putin has chosen a different path.

Eschewing abstract political theory, Russia's president has published a more practical tome: Judo: History, Theory, Practice.

Readers searching for a new understanding of Mr Putin's governmental initiatives will be disappointed. For although Moscow's Kremlin watchers have scoured the text of the book in search of secret combat tactics that may have been used by Mr Putin against political enemies such as the country's regional governors or the media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, they have done so with little success.

Even the section headed Why Does an Opponent Fall? fails to provide any insight into how Mr Putin saw off his two main presidential rivals earlier this year. The answer, like the rest of the text, is disappointingly banal: "A person falls if he loses his balance."

The book ends with a passionate call to arms. "Put on your kimono," the president (a pan-USSR judo finalist) writes. "Fasten your belt. The mysterious world of judo awaits you." It is a call that has already elicited a response. The general secretary of Russia's judo federation, Vladimir Lobintsev, said the organisation had noted a sudden rise in the number of judo enthusiasts since Mr Putin came to power.

webTitle: Nightmare on Wall Street for gasping MPs marooned in lift

fields.headline: Nightmare on Wall Street for gasping MPs marooned in lift
fields.trailText: It is most people's nightmare scenario: being stuck in an airless lift with a bunch of relative strangers. Now think of those people sweating and beginning to tear off their clothes. Finally, imagine they are a band of MPs .
fields.body:
It is most people's nightmare scenario: being stuck in an airless lift with a bunch of relative strangers. Now think of those people sweating and beginning to tear off their clothes. Finally, imagine they are a band of MPs .

Such a drama was played out late last week when members of the Treasury select committee crammed into a lift in a New York building after holding talks with Wall Street leaders.

The parliamentarians, who included Tories Sir Michael Spicer and Michael Fallon and Labour's Giles Radice and Brian Sedgemore, swiftly embarked on "an assignation with fear", after their lift stopped in flight at around the second floor. Last night, Mr Sedgemore, MP for Hackney South and Shoreditch, described being "stuck like rats in a trap" as they were marooned for nearly an hour.

He said: "The temperature was rising fast as we stripped off and there was a shortage of oxygen. We forced a tiny gap in the door to let in air but this was not enough for one of our number who suffered from cystic fibrosis and who was about to turn blue."

The panic button was pressed, but the management of the building apparently insisted the fire brigade could not be called unless the mechanic and his superior - neither of whom could be found - agreed.

"The situation became surreal when a voice said: 'We need your names and telephone numbers together with details of who you are'," said Mr Sedgemore. "Sweat was pouring off us. Yet here they were preparing labels for the body bags. At this moment you could smell the fear in the lift.

"By now it was like being in a Turkish bath. Only Michael Fallon (Sevenoaks) behaved in a wholly British fashion, keeping his jacket on and tie done up. From him came not a drop of fear stained sweat."

Finally the MPs employed political cunning and a mobile phone to dial the emergency number. Mr Sedgemore added: "Had we not had a mobile which worked, who knows what would have happened."

webTitle: Eta blamed for car bomb that kills three

fields.headline: Eta blamed for car bomb that kills three
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: Three people were killed and dozens more injured when a huge car bomb exploded in central Madrid at rush hour yesterday, the bloodiest attack attributed to the Basque separatist group Eta since it broke its ceasefire at the beginning of the year.
fields.body:
Three people were killed and dozens more injured when a huge car bomb exploded in central Madrid at rush hour yesterday, the bloodiest attack attributed to the Basque separatist group Eta since it broke its ceasefire at the beginning of the year.

The bomb, detonated by remote control, exploded when General Jose Francisco Querol, a 69-year-old high court judge, assigned to the military tribunal, was driving past on his way to work. The general, his chauffeur and police bodyguard were killed as his car catapulted into the air and flew over a bus.

The driver of the bus, two passengers and two passers-by, including an 11-year-old girl, were badly injured. Emergency workers treated a further 60 people in a field hospital set up nearby.

The explosion, just after 9am, turned a residential street in the north of the city into a scene of carnage as victims cried for help and ambulances struggled to reach them through dense smoke, burning cars and debris from shattered buildings.

The bombing, which bore all the hallmarks of Eta, brought the number of people killed by the group so far this year to 19.

Querol, a soldier and a judge, belonged to two of the professions most often attacked by the organisation, which has also killed several politicians and journalists.

"Eta chooses its victims among the defenders of the rule of law because it wants to subvert it. For that reason all Spaniards should feel they are victims too and stand firm," said the defence minister, Federico Trillo, a close personal friend of the dead judge.

The attack marks an escalation in Eta violence. In its current campaign it had singled out specific targets but avoided injury to passers-by. Most of its victims have been shot at close range.

This time the bomb, thought by police to contain up to 30kg of dynamite, went off 25 metres from Querol's home when his car had stopped at traffic lights and was bound to be surrounded by people.

It recalled the worst days of Eta's random bombing in the early 1980s and took place near the spot where the group tried to kill the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, with a similar car bomb in 1995.

The Basque regional government, led by the mainstream Basque Nationalist Party (PNV), was quick to condemn the attack. "Eta's talk of democracy is a travesty," its chief spokesman said. "It has no idea of what democracy is and seeks only to blackmail and destroy."

Mr Aznar has accused the PNV of being soft on terrorism after it signed an agreement with Eta in 1998 to work together for an independent state in return for an end to violence. Mr Aznar insists that he will make no political concessions to Eta in return for an end to violence.

He argues that Basques are free to pursue any political aims through institutions set up 25 years ago when Spain became a highly devolved democracy. Eta has killed just over 800 people since it began its violent campaign for an independent state in 1968.

webTitle: Man held in Mexico in backpacker hunt

fields.headline: Man held in Mexico in backpacker hunt
fields.standfirst: Cuban held on rape and assault charges suspected of abducting missing British woman.
fields.trailText: Mexican police have arrested a Cuban man in connection with the disappearance of a British woman who is believed to have been abducted on a backpacking holiday.
fields.byline: Raekha Prasad  and Jo Tuckman in Mexico City
fields.body:
Mexican police have arrested a Cuban man in connection with the disappearance of a British woman who is believed to have been abducted on a backpacking holiday.

Brenda Searle, 27, who was travelling alone and speaks little Spanish, has been missing since September 4 when she failed to meet her boyfriend at Chichén Itzá, the site of a Mayan temple, in the state of Yucatan.

Ms Searle flew to Cancun, the main resort on the Yucatan peninsula, on August 31 from Amsterdam where she was working as an account executive for an internet company. She planned to spend a fortnight in Mexico with Andre van de Vooren, her boyfriend, who was working there as a tourist guide.

From Cancun, Ms Searle travelled by bus and ferry to Isla Mujeres - an island popular with backpackers - and stayed in a budget hotel.

In an email sent to her family from the island, Ms Searle said that she was leaving the next day and had booked a room at a hotel near the Chichén Itzá site. It was the last time her parents heard from her.

The following day Ms Searle's credit and bank cards, which she carried in a money belt, were used to withdraw £270 from an automatic teller machine. On September 8, £800 was charged to her credit card.

After she failed to arrive at Chichén Itzá, Mr Van de Vooren spent a fortnight searching for her.

Mexican police have arrested a Cuban man in the neighbouring state of Campeche on charges relating to assaults and rape on other women last month.

Ariel Arjona, director of Quintana Roo judicial police, said the force had "strong suspicions" that the man has links to Ms Searle's disappearance, but refused to identify him. He has been taken to Chetumal in the state of Quintana Roo by the police.

Police, who are working with the British consul in Cancun, have traced a telephone call Ms Searle made to Mr Van de Vooren's hotel - Hotel Lopez - in a village just outside the ruins on the evening of September 4.

A receptionist said the conversation was difficult due to language barriers. The call was transferred to Mr Van de Vooren's room but he was out and the message was not passed on.

Ms Searle's father, Geoffrey, is English and her mother is Dutch; the family moved to the Netherlands when she was 11. They now live near Arnhem. Ms Searle has a British passport and returned to England in the early 90s to study for a biochemistry degree at Imperial college in London.

Ms Searle's mother, Marjo, who recently returned from a three-week search for her daughter, said she was a very experienced traveller.

"She has travelled to Thailand, Malaysia, Australia, Brazil and South Africa on her own," she said. "We thought this trip was nothing to worry about - just a short break with her boyfriend who'd been living in Mexico and spoke Spanish.

"Looking back, we should have been more worried, but she's so organised and intelligent and has always looked after herself. We don't know which direction to search anymore. We need more facts to be able to continue."

The Searles hired three Mexican private investigators for the first week of the search in the hope of uncovering their daughter's whereabouts, but to no avail.

The family is yet to know if another search by two of Ms Searle's closest friends, who were due to return to Britain from Mexico yesterday, has been fruitful. Charlotte Holgate and Lisa Eastwood, from Sussex, were fellow students of Ms Searle's at Imperial college.

Three Mexican state police departments are investigating the disappearance. They are liaising with Dutch police and Britain's Foreign Office.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said: "It's a difficult time for the family. The investigation continues."

Juliette Quaedvlieg, a friend of Ms Searle's and owner of the company where she works, said: "Brenda is very smart. It's not a case of a naive thing not knowing what she was doing.

"She'd always carry a wallet with false credit cards in case she was robbed and kept the real thing hidden.

"She was brilliant. I don't know anyone more confident and capable."

Concern about the safety of female backpackers travelling alone was raised in August after Kirsty Jones, 23, from Brecon, Wales, was found raped and murdered in her room in a hostel in Chiang Mai, northern Thailand.

The company where Ms Searle worked, ab.fab Interactive Media Group, has created a web page, www.abfab. nl/brenda, appealing for information about her disappearance.

fields.headline: SAS team betrayed by chiefs, court told
fields.trailText: A former member of an SAS squad yesterday accused military commanders of betraying them during an ill-fated mission behind Iraqi lines.
fields.body:
A former member of an SAS squad yesterday accused military commanders of betraying them during an ill-fated mission behind Iraqi lines.

New Zealander Mike Coburn, 36, is fighting attempts by the Ministry of Defence to block publication of his account of the 1991 Gulf war venture in the book Soldier 5.

The New Zealand high court was told that the MoD considered the team expendable.

Coburn, the pen name used by the former soldier, was with the SAS between 1990 and 1997 and was part of the eight man Bravo Two Zero team. Three were killed and four, including Coburn, were captured.

He told Justice Peter Salmon that he blamed the regimental hierarchy for the deaths. "We had been compromised primarily due to the fact that we had been placed in an area right next to a significant number of enemy forces, when there should not have been any," Coburn said. "Being told we were expendable after the fact only served to compound the betrayal of trust."

Last week MoD lawyers said publication of the book should be blocked because military teams could be undermined if details of their operations were made public.

Coburn's lawyers said he signed a confidentiality agreement under duress and that it contravened the Human Rights Act which Britain was obliged to recognise under the European convention on human rights.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Ulster's hopes turn on Blair and Ahern
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Tony Blair held talks with his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, last night as the two governments intensified their efforts to save the Northern Ireland peace process from collapse.
fields.body:
Tony Blair held talks with his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, last night as the two governments intensified their efforts to save the Northern Ireland peace process from collapse.

With republicans and unionists trading bitter recriminations in Belfast, the two prime ministers spoke of their determination to shore up the Good Friday agreement.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, who will hold talks this week with the Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen, attempted to focus minds. Speaking in Omagh, he said: "If we lose it, there will be no replacement, no second chance, no coming back. It is now or never for this agreement and that's why people have really got to devote themselves to making it work."

There were no signs of common ground, however, after David Trimble, first minister and leader of the Ulster Unionists, unveiled plans at the weekend to block Sinn Fein's two ministers from attending meetings of a cross-border ministerial council. fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText:
• The battle to succeed Boris the Jackal Johnson as Spectator editor intensifies. A late run by that pipsqueak historian of the doolally right Andrew Roberts may not lengthen a short list of three, which includes Steven Glover. Some may find it odd that one with Steve's record at the Independent on Sunday would wish to try again, let alone be considered, but I can't see why. After all, Roy Hodgson may well become England coach despite his horrendous failures at Inter Milan and Blackburn.

Steve underlines his claim this week with a typically acute media insight: he has noticed that the News of the World is full of sex, hypocrisy and pictures of near-naked women in "titillating" poses. Turning a couple of pages of the magazine which employs that thunderous moralist turned naughtiest of boys Paul Johnson, meanwhile, we come to a double-page advert (one this paper and others refused to carry) for the Star's website featuring a girl in yellow pants and nothing else.

Some may find it odd that one with Steve's record at the Independent on Sunday would wish to try again, let alone be considered, but I can't see why. Steve underlines his claim this week with a typically acute media insight: he has noticed that the News of the World is full of sex, hypocrisy and pictures of near-naked women in "titillating" poses. Turning a couple of pages of the magazine which employs that thunderous moralist turned naughtiest of boys Paul Johnson, meanwhile, we come to a double-page advert (one this paper and others refused to carry) for the Star's website featuring a girl in yellow pants and nothing else.

 Say what you will, at least the rail companies battle to keep passengers informed. A reader unable to travel to Cheltenham from London yesterday was redirected by a message on the busy national enquiry line to www.nationalrail.co.uk, where he clicked "today's travel info" and found all the information he could have wanted. Admittedly, it was for last Friday, but a bold effort all the same.

 Meanwhile, web failure by MPs is the subject of a study reported by internet news site the Register. Particularly poor is Patricia Hewitt, who "needs to revamp her website after it was branded 'mildly comic' by a parliamentary publication." A quote lifted from her home page reads "the best way to conact (sic) me is to the write to the Leicester office". Ah well, it would be prissy to attack her for overlooking an area so far removed from her government role (as minister for e-commerce).

 Following an item about alopecian Sun editor David Yelland's fixation with the "Metropolitan-Elite", an omission from the slaphead's A-Z is pointed out. Where are the Metro-Elite's very own Posh and Becks, Matthew Freud and Liz Murdoch, the most glittering young plutocrats known to New Labour? Any leading neurologist prepared to discuss whether Slappy's memory may have been damaged when the subway train doors clamped shut on his Syrup should call at once.

 An invitation to the Watford Labour party's Halloween family quiz night arrives late - and at the top dotted alongside the red rose are such traditional symbols such as a pumpkin, a devil face, a silhouetted witch caught inside a crescent moon. . . and the face of O'Mandy Mandelson. Richard Banham at Watford MP Claire Ward's office refuses to comment when asked if this was an attempt to destabilise O'Mandy. Poor show.

 New Carry On Up The Cabinet suggestions include the best proposal since the inspired Charles Hawtrey for Cherie - weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown played by Frankie Howerd. The similar carriage and body shape is important, but the interchangeability of their patter clinches it."Yes, no, oooooh, money supply, missus, oooh don't, stop it, honourable gentlemen opposite, don't titter, nay, nay and thrice nay, endogenous, I said endogenous, love, not erog. . . oh, please yourselves."

 When Lord Lloyd Webber turned 50he quietly hired the Albert Hall, but Michael Winner took an even more bashful approach to his 65th yesterday: there was no advance word about celebrations and he wasn't answering the phone. Most odd. Anyway, Michael, let's have a birthday lunch soon. There's a godfathering vacancy I want to run by you, so if you'd bring along the last cardiology report and any recent ECG results, that would be a great help.

fields.headline: Kosovans pick mainstream moderate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The moderate ethnic Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova claimed victory over his main rivals yesterday in Kosovo's first free elections, opening up hope of a future dialogue with the estranged Serb minority.
fields.body:
The moderate ethnic Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova claimed victory over his main rivals yesterday in Kosovo's first free elections, opening up hope of a future dialogue with the estranged Serb minority.

The preliminary results are likely to be announced later today, but a spokesman for the vote organisers did not dispute Mr Rugova's claim that his Democratic Party of Kosovo (LDK) had won most of the 30 municipalities in the province.

Hashim Thaci, head of the Democratic Party of Kosovo (PDK), said he would respect the outcome.

"We will recognise the final result," he told a news conference, adding that the PDK would assist in the work of the elected town councils. "Objectively, we did not expect such a result."

Mr Rugova, head of the oldest, most mainstream Kosovo Albanian party, said he was dedicated to cooperation across party and ethnic lines in shaping Kosovo's future.

"The LDK cultivates tolerance and cooperation with other political groups," he said. "We will continue protection of minorities, which should be integrated into Kosovo institutions. But it is important to remember that this election had both a local and national context - which is independence for Kosovo."

If the LDK's victory is confirmed, it will mark Mr Rugova's return from the political wilderness after the passive resistance drive he led against the Serb leader Slobodan Milosevic for 10 years was eclipsed by the guerrilla uprising. The rebels broke Belgrade's grip and emerged as folk heroes after the Serbian security forces, under aerial attack by Nato, halted its mass expulsions of ethnic Albanians and left Kosovo. Nato peacekeepers and UN administrators arrived in the middle of last year.

"This was a vote for moderation, so it's welcome," said Louis Sell, director of the Kosovo office of the International Crisis Group.

"Although Rugova has never swerved from independence as his goal, he is more inclined to achieve his objectives peacefully, through negotiation. The Serbs previously made clear they'd prefer Rugova to the ex-guerrillas."

In Belgrade, a senior member of the new Yugoslav president Vojislav Kostunica's reformist cabinet welcomed Mr Rugova's revival.

"We can say it is positive that ethnic Albanian citizens from Kosovo have opted for a more moderate, more democratic, more liberal option and not for an option which is defined by separatism and terrorism," Vladan Batic said.

Kosovo's 75,000-odd Serbs refused to vote in protest at post-war Albanian reprisals. Mr Kostunica's cabinet has supported their protest, and on Sunday it released a statement saying the elections were invalid because the Serb minority had not taken part.

But Mr Kostunica has also said he will seek to cooperate with the UN, whose officials plan to appoint Serbs to municipal councils and allow by-elections later to redress the imbalance. Reuters

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
11 suspended in Austria scandal
Eleven officials of Austria's police intelligence unit have been suspended in connection with a scandal involving reported leaks of confidential police files to political parties, the country's security chief, Erik Buxbaum, said yesterday.
fields.body:
11 suspended in Austria scandal
Eleven officials of Austria's police intelligence unit have been suspended in connection with a scandal involving reported leaks of confidential police files to political parties, the country's security chief, Erik Buxbaum, said yesterday.

Last week the Vienna prosecutor's office was investigating claims that Jörg Haider, the former leader of the far-right Freedom party, and other party members had received information on rivals from police files. [AP, Vienna]

Protests over Zanzibar vote
Police opened fire on protesters in Zanzibar yesterday after opposition leaders and Commonwealth observers demanded the annulment of Sunday's general election.

The poll went smoothly on the Tanzanian mainland, but Zanzibar polling stations closed with about a quarter of the voters still queuing outside. Officials said a new vote would be held in 16 constituencies. [James Astill, Nairobi]

More Kursk bodies found
Divers in the Barents Sea retrieved eight more bodies from the submarine Kursk at the weekend, bringing the total to 12, a spokesman for Russia's Northern Fleet said yesterday. [Reuters, Murmansk]
