webTitle: Comment: Hywel Williams on governmental power

fields.headline: Power obfuscates
fields.standfirst:
Forget the platitudes about 'Whitehall secrecy'. The BSE crisis revealed ancient political truths

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Forget the platitudes about 'Whitehall secrecy'. The BSE crisis revealed ancient political truths argues Hywel Williams.
fields.body:
Who and whom are still the only political words that matter. Who does what to whom? Who has authority? Who are the victims and who the beneficiaries? The questions cut across the ideologies - the conventional credal divisions of left and right. They also lead us to a few universal truths of government.

The victims are a clear enough category in the BSE tragedy - and they are now joined by 14-year-old Zoe Jeffries who died of variant CJD on Saturday. Lord Phillips's cautiously worded report has irritated the commentators and deprived us of a few convenient scapegoats to name and shame before moving on to the next subject. But the response to the report has been as revealing - and even more platitudinous - as the report itself.

The public "right to know" has been invoked and our hoary old explanatory friend, the "Whitehall culture of secrecy", has made a traditional appearance. But in the process a few inconvenient truths go missing.

When government fails it is a combination of the personal and the systemic, the temperamental and the structural. And nowhere more so than here.

Government is naturally gnostic. People become ministers because they want to know secrets. The idea that government is full of secrets dies hard - even in age of instant information and increasing access. Most government is dull. But the insecure Ministerial Ego Erectus needs the fantasy of a private access to the state secret to compensate for its amphibian condition. Behind the rise of that ego lies a slimy trail of conventional crawling and compulsive creeping.

Sometimes a genuine secret does arrive. But instead of gratifying the ego it isolates and disables. Which is what happened in the case of successive agriculture ministers. The dilemma which confronted them from John Macgregor to Nick Brown was a genuine one - and its disabling power owes more to public attitudes than to ministerial turpitude.

Whatever its origins as a disease, BSE and CJD were hardly the result of secrecy. Uniquely among European governments the British variety is subject to a remorseless press scrutiny. The question of a link between the animal food chain and the human disease - if speculative to begin with and then officially denied - was ventilated for years before its confirmation.

Ministers and government scientists had to deal with British public opinion which now claims three rights: the right to know everything, the right to panic and the right to be reassured. When it comes to public health we expect a level of paternalism which reflects the nationalisation of health as a subject of concern. We have also become prone to waves of periodic hysteria from the death of Diana to the march of fuel protesters.

Who here had the genuine authority to warn? Politicians are "good all-rounders" not specialists and the idea of a "political science" is always a fantasy. So, ministers relied on scientists and science in our culture has an unique authority. It is supposed to be objective and universal in its truths - rather than the fallible, human affair it is in reality. Today's exalted truth of the laboratory can become tomorrow's exploded hypothesis.

Scientists are just like any other group of professionals - likely to be swayed by their own hierarchies of loyalty to research grants, companies, departments and colleagues. In the case of BSE ministers relied on one particular group of scientists - those sponsored by the government.

But the problem with the civil service is not that it is forked-tongued but that it speaks with a Pentecostal profusion of tongues. At the bottom of each ministerial submission will be seen a number of possible courses of action - all graded in terms of likely outcomes. The important thing is that the official is covered and can reply retrospectively that each likelihood was assessed. If the course of action chosen was disastrous then at least an alternative was available to the minister.

Fearful of public panic and hearing some Eurosceptic nonsense on Bully Beef Britannia, the line of least resistance was taken. The reality of risk was deemed too hard and adult a message. Hindsight and knowledge has converted that line to the "wrong line to take". It would be easier and simpler if "science spoke" with undiluted authority from the beginning. But it did not and could not.

BSE shows the tensions between one world which is dying away and another which has only half emerged. On the one hand there's the stiff old collegiality, the traditions of ministerial responsibility, the desire to bind everyone in. The self-preservative chums charter dictates that: "It doesn't matter what the line is as long as we're all agreed".

On the outside there's the raw instability of opinion before which all governments retreat to an oligarchic shell. This is especially true of democratic ones subject to the power of a mass franchise which they fear and only pretend to understand.

BSE will recur in other forms as this tension between oligarchy and knowledge becomes more acute in our democracy. After Lord Phillips's irritatingly rational tones we can at least detect the nature of the crisis when its next example arrives.

webTitle: Forgotten author hits big time with his lover's story

fields.headline: Forgotten author hits big time with his lover's story
fields.trailText: Jean-Jacques Schuhl was only 50 francs (about £5) better off yesterday after winning France's top book award, the Prix Goncourt, for a difficult and experimental novel based on the life of his lover.
fields.body:
Jean-Jacques Schuhl was only 50 francs (about £5) better off yesterday after winning France's top book award, the Prix Goncourt, for a difficult and experimental novel based on the life of his lover.

But his back manager will not be worried: Schuhl can expect to sell up to 500,000 copies of his book, Ingrid Caven, such is the prestige of the award.

And the real Ingrid Caven, a German singer and actor, will not do too badly as a result of the book's success, either. She tells this morning's Le Monde that she has received several film offers as a result of its publication earlier this month.

What is more, next month she will release a new album of French and German songs, and, as if to further capitalise on the novel's triumph in Paris, she has a week of concerts at the Folies Bergères starting on November 27.

Schuhl's novel won the prize by only four votes to three, just beating Allah n'est pas Oblige (Allah Doesn't Have To) by Ahmadou Kourama, which was given the consolation prize, the Prix Renaudot.

Schuhl, 59, is hardly a well-known writer in France, not least because Ingrid Caven is his first novel for nearly 25 years.

"It's been a long time since I've written, and it's a dramatic turn of events," he told France-2 television after winning the award. "I didn't expect it."

webTitle: Scot Kenny Richey has been on death row in Ohio for 14 years

fields.headline: 'Just kill me now'
fields.standfirst: Scot Kenny Richey has been on death row in Ohio for 14 years. His lawyer has new evidence that he didn't murder anyone. But will he even be allowed to present it to the US appeal court?  Mick Morton  reports
fields.trailText: Scot Kenny Richey has been on death row in Ohio for 14 years. His lawyer has new evidence that he didn't murder anyone. But will he even be allowed to present it to the US appeal court?
fields.body:
One of Boston's top lawyers is sitting on the edge of his seat in his spacious waterfront offices, talking animatedly about one of his clients. Ken Parsigian specialises in difficult cases and is part of a growing band of Americans concerned about the death-penalty verdict given to Kenny Richey 14 years ago in Ohio. Richey, now 36, was convicted of murdering a two-year-old girl in an arson attack in the small town of Columbus Grove. He is still waiting to be executed.

Appealing against the death penalty is never easy. But Parsigian says: "If I could hit the reset button and do Kenny's trial today, I'd bet my house that he would go free."

Richey, born to a Scottish mother and an American father, grew up in Edinburgh. When his parents divorced in 1982 Richey decided to follow his father back to the US to start a new life. He had been a troubled, angry young man and although things started well - he married and joined the Marines - it was not to last. He left the army and divorce followed.

Richey decided to join his father, then living in a low-rent apartment block on the edge of Columbus Grove. It is classic midwest America, where many of the hardworking citizens fly the stars and stripes outside their houses. They didn't much like the largely welfare-assisted, single-parent and jobless residents of the Old Village Apartments.

To the young women who lived in or hung around the apartments, Richey, the outsider with the Scottish accent, was the nearest thing to exotic in their world. Candy Barchett, then 19, was smitten. For a few weeks in June 1986 she and Richey would meet regularly to gossip and party on the wooden landing between the apartments with their neighbours, Hope Collins, a single mother of a two-year-old girl, Cynthia, and Peggy Villereal.

The afternoon of June 30 started like any other but by two o'clock next morning, Collins's daughter would be dead, killed by a fire at her home. Richey was arrested next day and charged with arson and murder.

The prosecution argued that Richey was in a drunken jealous rage after his girlfriend left to spend the night with Mike Nichols who lived in the apartment below Collins. The fire investigators sifting through the burned-out flat the following day discovered that the smoke detector had been disconnected from its mounting. It was this crucial piece of evidence that was to earn Richey the death penalty. The Scot was said to have had motive and opportunity. He had poured petrol in the flat above and set it alight to kill Barchett and her lover, asleep in the flat below. Most damningly, witnesses said they had heard Richey say he was going to burn the building that night.

Richey has stated that he was never jealous of Barchett and Nichols. Casual sexual encounters were part and parcel of daily life at the apartments. He claims he was planning to return to Scotland for good the following week and had already booked his ticket.

Several witnesses who saw him that night say he watched as Nichols and Barchett kissed in front of him and that he did not seem to mind.

But it is the following sequence of events that Richey's supporters say makes little sense. Prosecutors argue that Richey, heavily intoxicated, laden with two heavy cans of petrol, climbed on to a 5ft-high wall, then jumped on to Collins's balcony and poured the petrol on to her living-room floor to kill his intended victims below. The fact that it was a hot evening and Barchett had left her window open, that the door to the Collins apartment was unlocked, as everyone knew, and that forensic tests could find no trace of petrol on Richey's clothing seems to have mattered little to his case.

But the last straw for his supporters was that a plausible explanation for the disabled smoke detector was provided to Richey's lawyer, William Kluge. Villereal had told him that she had seen Collins take it down that day: "Hope was cooking some pork chops on a pan and the detector went off. She dragged over a chair and pulled it down." But Kluge did not present that evidence.

He was a young, inexperienced attorney appointed by the state to represent Richey. There was a catalogue of disasters. He appointed Gregory Du Bois, a defence expert, to challenge the prosecution's charge of arson. Except that Du Bois was no expert. He was a metallurgist whose only experience of fire forensics was a four-day course from the Ohio State Arson Bureau - the very people claiming the fire had been arson, and whom Du Bois was to investigate independently. Not surprisingly, he agreed with the bureau.

The assistant prosecutor in the case was Randolph Bassinger, a young, ambitious lawyer who at the time of the trial was running a high- profile campaign for election as a county judge. In the days after the fire, feelings were running high in Columbus Grove. Richey, the outsider, was the wrong face in the wrong place. It was Bassinger who called for the death penalty - the first in the county for more than a century.

There is a final, cruel twist in Richey's story. Two of the witnesses that night have retracted statements saying they heard him say that he would burn the building. They claim they were made under pressure from aggressive questioning by the prosecution. Parsigian has also since hired the leading US fire expert to reinvestigate the arson theory. He found that the original fire investigation was scientifically flawed and that the fire was started by a burning sofa, probably due to a cigarette or dropped match. Collins had a history of playing with matches. The fire brigade had been called out on three occasions to fires started by her. Again, this evidence was not heard at the trial.

However, in US jurisprudence it is almost impossible to introduce new evidence challenging original trial findings. Parsigian is not hopeful in this case. He has one appeal left in the state federal court but the standard of proof is extremely tough. Richey's only chance may be clemency from the state governor - who is not known as a liberal in such cases.

Richey himself is philosophical. "There is nothing to do on death row but wait and wait and wait, and hope that the waiting comes to an end sooner or later."

He points through his cell window to an imposing building that was the original Mansfield Prison. "It's the place where they filmed The Shawshank Redemption. But it reminds me of Edinburgh Castle." He pauses. "There's a part of me that says: bring it on, just kill me now."

 Frontline Scotland is on BBC Scotland tonight at 10.35pm.

fields.headline: Drug scheme cuts users' spending
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Offenders referred to a government scheme cut the amount of money they spent on drugs by more than 90% and committed far less crime while they were being treated, research revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Offenders referred to a government scheme cut the amount of money they spent on drugs by more than 90% and committed far less crime while they were being treated, research revealed yesterday.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, said new drug treatment and testing orders (DTTOs) had helped abusers tobreak the vicious cycle which addiction often brought.

But the National Association of Probation Officers warned that the research, based on three pilot sites, was misleading. "For every person accepted on the scheme, another was rejected for being too high risk," a spokesman, Harry Fletcher, said. "The orders are not going to solve the country's drug problems."

Orders were introduced in Croydon, south London, Liverpool and Gloucestershire in October 1998, giving courts an extra option for dealing with drug abusing offenders. Two hundred and ten people were monitored over 18 months. They were put on treatment programmes and their drug use was evaluated with regular urine tests.

According to a report published by the Home Office yesterday, the average amount that offenders spent on drugs fell from £400 to £25 within six weeks. The average number of crimes committed dropped from 137 in the month before arrest to 34 within the first few weeks of the order.

With £60m pledged by the Home Office, orders are being rolled out across the country and should be available everywhere by the end of 2002.

Mr Straw said: "DTTOs help to break the vicious cycle of drug abuse and crime."

Mr Fletcher said probation officers had told him the schemes had not worked as well as the evaluation suggested. "The pilot sites only looked at a small number of people and the offenders were selected quite carefully. We are not against the orders, but we want people to realise DTTOs have their limitations."

fields.headline: Say it loud, say it proud
fields.standfirst: 'Words tend to be inadequate.' Even so, Jenny Holzer's text installations have made her one of America's best-known artists
fields.trailText: 'Words tend to be inadequate.' Even so, Jenny Holzer's text installations have made her one of America's best-known artists
fields.body:
Jenny Holzer has displayed her public art texts all over the world. First in New York, in 1977, and since then in every urban nook and cranny, on billboards and stickers, on monuments and trees. She has provoked and bewildered with statements writ large and anonymously in public spaces: "Protect me from what I want", "Any surplus is immoral".

In Newcastle last week for the first public display of her work in Britain for over a decade, Holzer was apparently distracted from her test projections by a lively crowd of local lads, half-naked on a chilly night and full of life (ie, beer). She found the revellers' feedback "very direct"; she loved the encounter. For this is what Holzer's work is all about, though with the artist usually out of sight. Without any clue as to where these messages are coming from, they intervene, weaving themselves insidiously into the fabric of city life. How people react to these xenon projections - whether they stop, rush by, smile or look outraged - becomes part of the work.

The Baltic centre for contemporary art has devised a series of projects prior to its opening in September next year; for this, Holzer displayed selections from a range of her texts on the facades of three buildings. For two nights the words - including her best-known work, Truisms (1977-9) - had as its dramatic backdrop the Baltic itself, a former flour mill on the edge of the Tyne. This was an atmospheric, cool way of reminding people of Baltic's presence.

More interesting in terms of public interaction were the two other venues. For one night, the words were projected on to the Castle Keep, a steep shock of a building on a busy junction opposite a pub and car park. Here, Holzer had chosen a deep turquoise for the lettering, a luscious contrast to the colour of the building's stone after dark. Like crazy credits for a film you can't imagine, her words rolled up the side of the Keep, disappearing into the night air as they reached the top.

Hypnotic - even with a biting wind and traffic lurching past - the slogans had an oddly calming effect, despite the contradictory viewpoints and voices they articulate. Usually liberal in their outlook, some phrases are harsh, while others have dark echoes of Twin Peaks: "Bodies lie in long grass, some are murdered and some are picnicking." Often mistaken for Holzer's own take on life, the Truisms are in fact starting points for debate. "Illness is a state of mind", "Being happy is more important than anything else", "A lot of professionals are crackpots" - they said to the whole of Newcastle: discuss.

On the night a good-sized crowd gathered, some with cameras trying to chase the words up the facade, others clutching the limited-edition souvenir beer mats bearing Holzer's words. (Next time you see someone in Newcastle in what you take to be a stupor, staring into their glass, remember: they may be reading "Words tend to be inadequate" or "Your actions are pointless if no one notices".) These people knew what to expect, largely, so they were smiling. The uninitiated were in the minority, but they were there: one man had almost walked by, until he stepped through the beam of the projector. With "An elite is inevitable" running across him, he suddenly noticed the crowd, the words, the strangeness of it all. He scarpered.

There were other lovely moments of coincidence too. A woman wanted to get her car out of the car park but could see this meant walking across the beam. "Can I go across?" she said to no one in particular, before making a dignified dash for it. As she pulled out in her car, a train thundered on the tracks behind the Keep. The words read "Automatism is deadly". Later, a fruit and veg van came to a sharp halt beneath the projections, the driver craning his neck to read. He shook his head, drove on, but then stopped again to look some more. "Disgust is the appropriate response to most situations," he had read.

For the Friday night, Holzer's texts ran along the side of the Tuxedo Princess boat, a floating disco. In addition to Truisms, phrases from Arno (1996), a litany of obsessive desire, were shown. "I smell you on my skin", "You are the one, you are the one", "I cry out, I Bite, I bite your lip". We'll never know if these catchy lines made it into chat-up lines on-board on the night.

 For information about future projects at Baltic: www.balticmill.com or 0191-478 1810.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Dracula/Dr Jekyll And Mr Hyde/Young Frankenstein/The Beast With Five Fingers
fields.body:
Dracula

(Tod Browning, 1931)

7.15pm, FilmFour

Launching our Halloween fright night is one of the all-time classics, the vampire story that cemented Universal's position as the most horrible of horror studios. It doesn't nearly match Murnau's awesome Nosferatu for sheer chilliness and there's rather too much chat in London drawing rooms. But Bela Lugosi's sinister way with words and utterly menacing presence (watch him glide up those castle stairs, for example) create a nightmarish vision that set the standard for all subsequent portrayals.

Dr Jekyll And Mr Hyde

(Rouben Mamoulian, 1932)

7pm, 2.30am, TCM

By far the best of the umpteen screen treatments of Stevenson's horror story, cleverly playing up sexual desires in a gloomy London. Fredric March won an Oscar for his man-monster, evoking the hubris of the doctor and the savagery of the beast; and Karl Struss's photography is marvellous.

Young Frankenstein

(Mel Brooks, 1973)

10.40pm, FilmFour

A monster movie in a lighter vein, this is one of Brooks's most successful spoofs. The Brooks/Gene Wilder script runs the gamut of screen humour from witty-to-slapstick ("A riot is an ugly thing - and it's time we had one!"), and there's a top-flight, fall-about cast: Wilder as the grandson of the Baron; Madeline Kahn his fiancee; Marty Feldman as Igor and Gene Hackman hilariously dangerous as the hermit. But none is better than Peter Boyle's bewildered creature.

The Beast With Five Fingers

It doesn't nearly match Murnau's awesome Nosferatu for sheer chilliness and there's rather too much chat in London drawing rooms. But Bela Lugosi's sinister way with words and utterly menacing presence (watch him glide up those castle stairs, for example) create a nightmarish vision that set the standard for all subsequent portrayals. Dr Jekyll And Mr Hyde (Rouben Mamoulian, 1932) 7pm, 2.30am, TCM By far the best of the umpteen screen treatments of Stevenson's horror story, cleverly playing up sexual desires in a gloomy London. fields.headline: One from the heart
fields.standfirst: It's what every film studio boss dreads: the day a director announces his new film is a 'personal project'. Film history is littered with the resultant casualties - and Terry Gilliam looks like he might be the latest victim.  Clark Collis  reports
fields.trailText: It's what every film studio boss dreads: the day a director announces his new film is a 'personal project'. Film history is littered with the resultant casualties - and Terry Gilliam looks like he might be the latest victim.
fields.body:
Asort of Swingers for sci-fi nuts, forthcoming straight-to-video movie Free Enterprise follows the travails of two male Tinseltown insiders as they attempt to engage with the opposite sex while endlessly ruminating on Logan's Run, Star Wars, Star Trek et al. The film's real point of interest, however, is a cameo by Trek starship captain-cum-studmeister William Shatner, playing himself with considerable relish as a hard-drinking has-been desperately trying to find finance for his pet project, a musical version of Julius Caesar.

"I know it's ridiculous," admits Shatner when someone points out that the idea might be a tad on the daft side. "And my playing all the parts? It's absurd. It's the height of hubris. And six hours? Who's gonna sit for that? But... I think I can do it!"

Although Bill's demented Et tu fixation is clearly meant to be funny, it does accurately reflect the fact that many of Hollywood's notables have a pet project that they - and largely they alone - long to make. These are the kind of movies that Jerry Bruckheimer wouldn't touch with someone else's bargepole. Movies that are inspired not by focus groups or demographics but a loftier desire to create something that has more to do with deathless art than popcorn sales. In short, movies that Hollywood studios are extremely reluctant to finance when they could be giving the money to Adam Sandler's accountant instead.

Terry Gilliam, for example, spent years trying to get money for his latest film The Man Who Killed Don Quixote, in which a modern-day advertising executive is whisked back to 17th-century Spain where he is mistaken for Cervantes' hero. It was a quest presumably not helped by the fact that many prospective punters will have trouble even pronouncing its title ("Hey, hon, d'ya wanna go and see The Man Who Killed Don Queezel... Don Kuwaiti... How about Scream 4?") Moreover, even citizens of Nowheresville, Idaho, who don't assume Don Quixote is some distant cousin of Don Corleone, may note with trepidation the similarities between this latest work and Gilliam's box-office turkey The Adventures Of Baron Munchausen, both of which take their cue from characters whose tales need to be taken with a shovelful of salt.

Worse still, having finally secured his $48m budget and a cast that includes Johnny Depp, Vanessa Paradis and Christopher Eccleston, calamity struck last week when Gilliam's Quixote, Jean Rochefort, suffered a double disc hernia, with sources claiming the shoot is unlikely to recommence before January and that the movie is "on hold" awaiting a decision from the completion bond company as to its future.

At least Gilliam actually succeeded in getting the cameras rolling - something that Sergio Leone failed to do on his long mooted Stalingrad movie, despite spending a good many of his declining years trying to set it up. The same goes for Sly Stallone's biopic of Edgar Allen Poe, although in that case movie fans may feel justified in issuing a sigh of relief rather than regret. More remarkable than Leone's failure to get the moolah for Stalingrad, however, was Jerry Lewis's success in doing so for 1972's The Day The Clown Cried, which found the original nutty professor gooning about with concentration camp-dwelling ankle-biters about to be gassed by the Nazis.

"It is the clown who is assigned to try to keep the kids in the camp happy", explained Lewis prior to the film's production. "And it is he who, in the end, is expected to lead them - and himself - to the ovens. I believe that I've grown enough to go ahead with what I feel is a very important film." Sadly for Jerry, contractual wrangles meant the film has never been released.

Even those labours of love which do see the light of a projector tend not to stick around for long, as was recently demonstrated by John Travolta's Battlefield Earth fiasco and Wes Craven's blink-and-you'll-be-glad-you-missed-it Music Of The Heart (note to studio executives: Craven + big knife-wielding homicidal maniac = good. Craven + small string instrument-wielding Meryl Streep = bad). But there are a clutch of films in the file marked "Pet Projects" that should give Gilliam cause for hope, not least Kevin Costner's critically acclaimed and commercially successful Dances With Wolves, which, prior to its release, was considered such an outrageous work of hubris that industry wags dubbed it Kevin's Gate (of course, if Tel wants any chance of a good night's sleep then he should avoid considering the history of Costner's last "pet project", the appropriately apocalyptic Postman). Furthermore, this wouldn't be the first time that Gilliam has overcome all manner of problems to turn an ill-starred labour of love into one of cinema's most highly regarded artistic statements. Then again, at least everyone knows how to pronounce "Brazil".

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Phyllis And Ted's Most Excellent Adventure/Oscar Peterson - Jazz Giant
fields.body:
For decades Ted Ellis contributed to the Guardian's Country Diary from his beloved East Anglia. Once, when the paper arranged a diarists' lunch at a London hotel, he startled everyone by enthusing about the seven rare varieties of grass he'd noted during the short walk from King's Cross. In Phyllis And Ted's Most Excellent Adventure (11.0am, Radio 4) Tony Soper talks to Ted's widow about the 40 years they spent living in an isolated wetland and preaching the gospel of conservation.

Fellow pianist Marian McPartland begins a six-part biography of Oscar Peterson - Jazz Giant (10.0pm, Radio 2). Peterson began piano lessons at school in Montreal because everyone did. When Teddy Wilson's records inspired him to turn professional, his father said he could leave school only if he was aiming for an outstanding career. All went well until Dad brought home Art Tatum's Tiger Rag. Peterson was haunted for weeks when he realised only one man was playing.

fields.headline: BBC's radio news staff return to old base
fields.standfirst:
Journalists welcome move back to central London headquarters.

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Three years after the BBC sacrificed a senior executive and millions of pounds by moving its radio news staff out of Broadcasting House to west London, it is to bring them all back again.
fields.body:
Three years after the BBC sacrificed a senior executive and millions of pounds by moving its radio news staff out of Broadcasting House to west London, it is to bring them all back again.

The corporation confirmed yesterday that its television and radio news operations, and the BBC World Service, will be combined as part of a redevelopment of the BBC's historic central London headquarters to be completed by 2008.

The move spells the end of an era for the World Service, which has broadcast from Bush House in central London for 60 years. It also reverses one of the most reviled decisions of the last director general, John Birt.

Radio journalists were delighted: guests were often reluctant to travel to west London for interviews and were questioned "down the line" instead.

John Humphrys, of Radio 4's Today programme, recently said interviews were less satisfactory as a result: "We like to see the whites of their eyes."

But TV staff were more sceptical: it is likely that the corporation's big election programmes will still need to be broadcast from Studio 1 in Television Centre, the only space big enough to cope.

The redevelopment will be funded not by licence fee cash but by a joint venture with the private sector.

The BBC stressed it would still own Broadcasting House, but would give up the freehold on its White City site as part of a £500m property strategy for its main centres in London.

Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, said: "This will be a new era for Broadcasting House. It has a long history in radio programme-making; now it will also be the hub for all the BBC's news and information services for the UK and the world."

Radio news staff were ousted from Broadcasting House in 1997 after a bitter battle with the corporation's governors. Liz Forgan, then managing director of BBC radio, resigned after failing to dissuade the governors. The switch affected the Today and World at One programmes most intensely, as politicians refused to make the journey out to White City.

Now, as the Guardian revealed this month, architects MacCormac Jamieson Prichard have been handed the brief to create a state-of-the-art digital news centre at Broadcasting House. Ugly 1960s offices between the Grade II* listed building and All Souls Church on Portland Place will be transformed to include a piazza and 50,000sq ft of public space. All the BBC's radio services, scattered throughout London, will be brought together.

The shift of the World Service may upset some BBC traditionalists. Bush House was originally designed as an international trade centre and the BBC's lease on the building, which is owned by the Japanese firm Kato Kagaku, was due to run out in 2005. This has now been extended for three years.

"Bush House is an iconic building for those who live in London, but we should remember that the vast majority of the World Service's 150m listeners have no idea what it looks like," the spokeswoman said. Mark Byford, director of World Service, said the move to Broadcasting House represented a "really exciting opportunity" to work in a "modern, fully digitised broadcast centre".

 The National Union of Journalists has announced that World Service staff are to be balloted on industrial action in a dispute over night shift pay.

webTitle: TV: Who's in town and why

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
London calling... Brace yourself for the first batch of paparazzi bait arriving for the London Film Festival, with young Hollywood moppets Kate (middle name, strangely enough, Garry) Hudson and Patrick Fugit rolling up for Thursday's Opening Night Gala of Cameron Crowe's rock monster fable Almost Famous. Hudson, of course, should be familiar with the media hullaballoo, what with being Goldie Hawn's daughter and all, but it's entirely new ground for the hitherto obscure Fugit - so, should you see a young boy wandering around Leicester Square in a state of tearful confusion, you'll know exactly what's going on. And that's before we even get to Joaquin Phoenix and Geoffrey Rush, facially interesting stars of Marquis de Sade biopic Quills, who pitch up in time for the film's screening on Friday night...

Uma Karuna Blanca... And, even without the LFF, it's a busy, busy week for the snappers, as professionally ethereal Uma Thurman wafts into town for the premiere of Merchant-Ivory period piece The Golden Bowl on Thursday evening. Thurman (middle name, strangely enough, Karuna) should then be attending an aftershow knees-up at a venue not a million miles from the St Martin's Lane Hotel.

Goodbye to all that... Meanwhile, those among you with a yen for loud, inharmonious wailing will no doubt be weeping into your sleeves this week, as turgid prog-grunge icons Smashing Pumpkins roll into London for their final British shows before breaking up. Which means that, yes, after taking their valedictory bows at Wembley on Friday and Saturday, we shall never again be privy to such timeless classics as... um... ah... oh, you know what I mean. And let's not forget veteran naif rocker Jonathan Richman, who'll be popping over to play a one-off show at London's Forum this Saturday, which will almost certainly not be our last chance to hear such timeless classics as Pablo Picasso, and um... ah... oh, never mind.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Dorset
fields.body:
Dorset

The weekend Guardian tells us that our hectarage of apple-orchard has decreased by two-thirds in the past 30 years, so it was good to make a rough count of 205 different species of apple laid out on trestle tables at the Dorchester Apple Day. Each one's card gave its name and provenance: "Mornington Pearmain - arose from cider pomace in the garden of Mr Turley, Uckfield, 1770..."

"Striped Beefing - we found in the garden of W Crowe at Lakenham, Norwich, 1794." Around the hall were set out every kind of apple product - ciders, chutneys, jellies, Dorset apple cake, and of course, principally, and in all their variety of colour, size, shape, texture and flavour, the English apples themselves. And there were free tastings. "Apple Days" are joyous celebrations. And it was not just apples.

"Life in the slow lane" was the legend above a stall advertising escargots. There was "New Forest Nectar" and beside it, with more ginger and bite to it, the companion beverage: "Ginger with attitude". "Dorset Blue Vinny" was but one of the local cheeses whose smiling, proud and expert makers were eager to offer samples. At the International Tree Foundation stand, I was struck by the story of Richard St Barbe Baker, who, in 1922, founded a group in Kenya called "the men of the Trees".

Fifty warriors were sworn to plant and protect trees. The society that grew from that beginning has achieved planting programmes in Palestine, a conservation programme in American Redwood forests, a reclamation scheme in the Sahara, and much more. And all because a wounded ex-soldier with a degree in Divinity cared about trees.

webTitle: Arts: Painting the Century in the National Portrait Gallery

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst: Can a collection of portraits sum up the 20th century?  Adrian Searle  finds fine moments in a flawed concept
fields.trailText: Can a collection of portraits sum up the 20th century? Adrian Searle finds fine moments in a flawed concept.
fields.body:
Painting the Century ambles through the ground floor galleries and corridors of the National Portrait Gallery. A picture a year for the century: 101 works, from 1900 to the millennium. It is a journey through styles and movements, an incomplete and inconclusive story. The exhibition can't quite make up its mind whether it is a show of the century's portraits, or of portraits of the century.

As the exhibition's curator, Robin Gibson, says, this is not an anthology of the century's greatest portraits. Hence, I suppose, no Antonin Artaud, for example, and no Pierre Bonnard; instead, Hans Haake's Maggie Thatcher is here, as well as Michael J Browne's Eric Cantona, for what he's worth. Exhibitions are almost invariably constrained by what is available. There are a few great paintings - Picasso's 1905 Woman in a Chemise, Warhol's Double Elvis, a great lumpen, cyclops-eyed Philip Guston of a man smoking (the 20th century was the century of smoking) - but perhaps it doesn't always take great artists and great subjects to reveal a moment, the spirit of an age, its texture and tone. In fact, mediocrity, or at least minor art, often does just as well - at telling a story, recalling the atmosphere of an epoch.

There are interesting oddball things. George Gershwin's 1934 self-portrait, his hand like a paw, his face self-caricatured against musical staves; Isaac Brodsky's lonely Lenin in Red Square, in working-man's clothes, the crowds milling miles away across the stones; and some works which really have no place in any exhibition at all. Stephen Finer's wretched David Bowie and Iman is one, Charles Wellington Furse's 1903 Gainsborough-esque portrait of his wife Diana, out with the greyhounds on a windy day, another. The only notable thing about this piece of Edwardian dung is that Furse's mum crouched behind her daughter-in-law as the artist painted her, blowing air up Diana's skirts with a bellows to achieve the required windy day effect.

I find I have written "AAARGH" all over the catalogue page featuring Lovis Corinth's 1911 portrait of zoo owner Carl Hagenbeck. The zoo-owner rests a proprietorial hand on a great mustachioed walrus, who, with beady eye and hairy maw, seems intent on Hagenbeck's crotch. What perversity led the curator to ship this picture all the way from Hamburg? Maybe he simply wanted us to be astounded.

The ludicrous aside, there are certain paintings here whose dramatised truths seem to provide the exact feel of their time. German painter George Scholz's self-portrait, standing in front of an advertising column, is the quintessential man in the street, a petit bourgouis in the gloom. I love this painting's quiet, the way Scholz meets us with a quizzical eye on the corner as we pass. Later, in 1940, when Scholz has retreated from public life to a small provincial German town, we meet Felix Nussbaum, who was interned in France in 1940, and later deported and killed at Auschwitz. Nussbaum portrays himself in rags in a camp, on a wretchedly bleak and bone-strewn patch of ground between the huts. I flashback to Scholz, buttoned-up warm against the cold, his collar clean, his tie neat. Perhaps one of the problems of this show is that there are too many possible stories, too many conections to be made.

I also think of works which are not here, but ought to be: Hitler in armour, carrying a banner, by Lanzinger; Adolf Wissel's creepy National Socialist happy family group portrait, and Felix Nussbaum's 1943 self-portrait, holding up his Judenpass. Instead, for 1943, we have Meredith Frampton's remarkable painting of the London Civil Defence Control Room in South Kensington. This is no Dad's Army gag. Three senior civil defence officers are painted in their underground centre of operations: maps on the wall, memos and notes everywhere, a teacup on the table. It is a painting of details - a pint of milk, the red and cream coloured telephones, the dangling flex and sallow artificial light. Frampton really captures the dim electric light. Everything, including the sitters, seems to be made of Bakelite. It is all rendered with a hypnotic acuity which borders on the surreal. Peculiar and full of atmosphere, this unnaturally impeturbable scene could be viewed as stiff-upper-lip propa ganda, but somehow none of this makes this painting a failure as art.

Suddenly, war is over and here's the Belgian poet and mescaline- eating artist Henri Michaux, painted by Dubuffet. We are back in the realms of modern art. It is 1962 now, but the Colony hasn't changed a jot. Only the denizens of the club have changed. They're all dead: Jeffrey and Bruce Bernard, Francis Bacon, the awful barman Ian Board. Photography and film were the media of the past 100 years, and the National Portrait Gallery barely touches the subject. The proliferation of photographic images over the past century - many of which have achieved a more common iconic status than any painting (which is more telling: a movie still of a napalmed girl in Vietnam or Picasso's Guernica?) - has not meant that painting has been downgraded, but that it has become freer to do precisely those things that photography cannot, or could not do, until the advent of the digitalised, infinitely manipulable image.

(And what is Cindy Sherman's self-portrait photograph doing here?) His staring eyes and slack mouth make me think he looks mad. But it is as much the distortions of the close-up, the shallow depth of field accentuated by Close's painting of it, that distorts him.

They are portraits of German society, portraits of guilt, and portraits of our own voyeurism. If not "portraits of the century", they remain the most important suite of paintings to have been made in post-war Europe (post-war Germany being, precisely, Richter's subject).

A summary of the political and cultural events of the century puts the portraits in context, but further individual descriptions on the walls are frequently more irritating than helpful. Franz Gertsch's painting of the transvestite artist Luciano Castelli being made-up by his girlfriend Marina is annotated by a stupid little commentary which doesn't tell us who the painting's subjects are, but does state that the painting "challenges our accepted notions of gender". What drivel. Not even a 10-year-old would be challenged, though they might well like the painting.

This show is a bit of a ragbag. Some of it is laughable, some laudable, some of it irrelevant and some of it really captures a time. In the end, it is just another anthology. But, like the century itself, it had its moments.

A picture a year for the century: 101 works, from 1900 to the millennium. It is a journey through styles and movements, an incomplete and inconclusive story. The exhibition can't quite make up its mind whether it is a show of the century's portraits, or of portraits of the century. As the exhibition's curator, Robin Gibson, says, this is not an anthology of the century's greatest portraits. Hence, I suppose, no Antonin Artaud, for example, and no Pierre Bonnard; instead, Hans Haake's Maggie Thatcher is here, as well as Michael J Browne's Eric Cantona, for what he's worth. fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: The women's pages are looking decidedly buxom today, but we can assure you that there is not the merest hint of underwiring, padding, or ranch-style drawstringing in this part of the Guardian building. It goes without saying that we all flambeed our brassieres long ago ...
fields.body:
The women's pages are looking decidedly buxom today, but we can assure you that there is not the merest hint of underwiring, padding, or ranch-style drawstringing in this part of the Guardian building. It goes without saying that we all flambeed our brassieres long ago ...

Spare a thought, though, for Bodyperks, which has chosen this week, of all weeks, to promote its new Nipple Enhancers. Apparently they're all the rage across the pond. But then, so is Garth Brooks. For the princely sum of £14, Bodyperks will send you a pair of silicone stick-on nipples, direct to your door. No, we can hardly believe it either. Bodyperks founder Lori Barghini and her bosom buddy (oh, I'm so sorry) Julia Cobbs, struck on the invention when they hilariously put bottle tops down their tops for a "joke" one crazy weekend in Vegas. In last Friday's edition of the Sun, Barghini insisted that: "The Nipple Enhancers work like a charm. You pretty much only have to bring the bus fare out with you." Lori, Lori, Lori - it's October. There are tornadoes, rain, gales. Baby, it's cold outside. Save your 14 quid, ladies. Spend it on gin. Sidelines can vouch for the fact that the very same effect can be achieved simply by awaiting the arrival of the number 12 bus with your coat unbuttoned.

Women earn, on average, £338 a week, compared to £453 for the gents. A male colleague tells me that's £115 less per week than our stubblier counterparts. Just as well, really - we'd only blow it on synthetic nipples. Perhaps we should take heed of Lorrie, a 42-year-old lovely from Las Vegas, who splashed out on the Bodyperks "nips" and, to her delight, found that: "The first time I wore them, a handsome man stopped me and declared he was ready to give me his paycheck for the rest of his life!" Poor lad. Little did he know he could purchase his very own pair for less than an hour and a half's work.

webTitle: Auditor backs veto on cash for dome

fields.headline: Auditor backs veto on cash for dome
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Sir John Bourn, parliament's financial watchdog, has backed the senior civil servant who defied the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and eight other millennium commissioners, by refusing to pay out tens of millions of pounds to save the dome from bankruptcy.
fields.body:
Sir John Bourn, parliament's financial watchdog, has backed the senior civil servant who defied the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and eight other millennium commissioners, by refusing to pay out tens of millions of pounds to save the dome from bankruptcy.

Sir John concludes that the arguments put forward by Mike O' Connor, director of the millennium commission, to refuse to pay out the cash " are just the sort of circumstances to justify... seeking an accounting officer direction," according to a memorandum placed in the Commons library.

The conclusion 10 days in advance of the publication of the report by the national audit office into the £1bn Millennium Dome fiasco will put further pressure on Mr Smith and Lord Falconer, the cabinet office minister responsible for the dome, to consider their positions.

The memo reveals that the commission met in a state of panic on May 22, when it was asked to hand out an extra £38.6m to save the dome.

The memo says that the New Millennium Experience Company's letter demanding the cash claimed that it would become insolvent that day, forcing the dome's immediate closure unless it got the cash.

Mr Smith and eight other commissioners forced Mr O'Connor to hand out a total of £76m extra aid to keep the dome solvent in May and September . Mr O'Connor authorised a further £103m from lottery funds this year to keep the dome afloat.

The report, out on Thursday week, will detail how the fiasco unfolded over the last year and who was responsible.

Mr O'Connor's letter reveals that the company had told the commission it would become bankrupt on May 22 with debts totalling £200m. He argued that the commission would not be liable for the debts, but the exchequer "could be landed with the bill".

webTitle: Are bras really bad for your health?

fields.headline: The big squeeze
fields.standfirst: Are bras really bad for your health? Scientists are sceptical about yesterday's report, but ordinary women, scarred by a lifetime of painful encounters, are quite willing to believe it, says  Sally Weale
fields.trailText: Are bras really bad for your health? Scientists are sceptical about yesterday's report, but ordinary women, scarred by a lifetime of painful encounters, are quite willing to believe it, says  Sally Weale.
fields.body:
Yesterday I conducted my own little experiment. I went into the office toilet, removed my bra, then spent the day without it.

For as long as I can remember bras have been a source of discomfort. My earliest bra memories date back to the first year of senior school, when half the girls in class moved with a quiet pride into their trainer bras. Oh, the shame of changing for double PE to reveal a virginal white vest while the rest of them giggled in their little white bras.

Eventually I graduated to my own trainer. It was white, with little pink roses, and made me feel very grown-up. It was utterly redundant, but reasonably comfortable - that is, until twanged repeatedly by one's fascinated male peers.

Next came the teen bra, with its adjustable straps and vicious little hooks which were forever being undone by classmates, male and female. I began to look wistfully at my drawerful of flat white vests. By then, however, I began to need a bra and there was no turning back. That was it - for the rest of my life, just like the rest of the adult female population.

Since then there's been lift and separate, Cross Your Heart, latex, Playtex, lycra and lace; there's been Hello Boys, push up and plunge; the balcony, the Bliss, Affinity, Lovable, and something called Essensis. Strappy, strapless, underwired, wireless, sports bras, day bras - new ones with strings to control your cleavage size and the yoghurty-sounding Bioform with revolutionary plastic inserts instead of underwiring. A £500 million industry aimed at your chest.

Then yesterday I and tens of thousands of other women read a report suggesting that wearing a bra could damage your health. Professor Robert Mansel, of the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff, and Simon Cawthorn, consultant surgeon at Bristol's Frenchay Hospital, carried out a six-month trial to see if wearing a bra influenced breast pain.

They asked 100 pre-menopausal women to go without a bra for three months then return to wearing one for another three months and record the differences. On average, the number of pain-free days went up by 7% when the women stopped wearing bras. Which seems unsurprising to most bra-wearing females. Bras are at best uncomfortable; at worst they can be instruments of torture.

The full findings of the study are to be released in a Channel 4 Dis patches programme called Bras - The Bare Facts, to be broadcast on Thursday, which also investigates claims by medical anthropologist Sydney Singer that breast cancer could be connected with wearing bras. According to Singer's theory, breast cancer is a problem only in cultures where women wear bras. He believes tight bras cause congestion in the lymph nodes, the body's essential defence against the spread of cancer.

Cancer charities yesterday moved swiftly to allay women's fears. Professor Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said: "There is no substantiated evidence to link wearing a bra to breast cancer and I'm very concerned that women will be unnecessarily worried about this suggestion."

McVie went on: "The study carried out in Bristol and Cardiff involved just 100 women and only set out to measure breast pain from wearing a bra. It was never intended to show any link between this pain and breast cancer, and no link between the two has ever been satisfactorily proved."

Likewise one of the authors of the study, Simon Cawthorn, was anxious to stress: "This study does not link breast pain with breast cancer, and does not show any link between wearing a bra and breast cancer." Singer's theory that women in cultures where bras are not worn do not suffer breast cancer is more likely to be because of their diet rather than their underwear, says Cawthorn.

But whether bras are subsequently shown to cause breast cancer or not, what emerged among women I spoke to yesterday in the wake of the report is that many of us do not have very happy relationship with our bras, whether we buy them for a tenner with our groceries in Marks & Spencer, or spend £100 after a two-hour personal fitting in a leading department store. For many of us they are so uncomfortable it would hardly be surprising if they were bad for our health.

This is what one woman had to say: "My whole life I've had one good bra - one bra that was comfortable, that didn't leave enormous scarlet weals on my flesh, that gave me two breasts instead of one; that gave support without stopping me breathing. One good bra!

"It was a sort of blue pebbledash cotton thing from Sock Shop, oddly, and I kept it going for five years. It was disgustingly unattractive, but under clothes my breasts looked like my breasts when I was wearing it. I cried when the much darned strap finally gave in last year and I had to throw it out. Since then I've bought about one bra a week and none of them are comfortable. All of them leave marks."

Or this from another colleague: "I went out dancing once, sporting an all-new underwired number and returned home to find huge parts of my chest gouged out by evil, satanic wiring. I think this might be one of the consequences of wearing such items if one is not overly endowed."

Or this: "I nagged my mother for a little black satin number for my 18th birthday. I tried to ignore the unarguable truth that it gave me a comedy trapezium-shaped bust and no cleavage to speak of. I felt like an utter fraud all night and suffered nasty red strap-marks on my shoulders where I had winched up the bra in an attempt to gain cleavage. It's really not surprising that I should favour vests now, is it?"

Vests are fine for women with flat chests, but for women with big breast, bras are essential for comfort. One colleague described her Triumph "Doreen" as "life-saving". And our breasts are getting bigger all the time. When Tony Dixey, group general manager for Playtex, began working in the bra industry 20 years ago 34B was the average size, now it's 36C.

"To us comfort is the most important thing. British women expect comfort when buying a bra, far more than continental women. Now women will buy bras for occasions. Most women have a wardrobe of bras - a strapless bra, a bra for the day time, a glamour bra for night, a sports bra." If your bra is not comfortable, you're probably wearing the wrong size and should go for a proper fitting - 70 to 80% of us are wearing the wrong bra apparently.

Bras may be bad for your health; they may be good for your figure; they can be a turn-on (black, lacy push-up) or a turn-off (grey, saggy, gone through the wash too many times) but according to Cawthorn they can't keep stop the natural ageing process. Not even if you wear one all night like Marilyn Monroe to keep them perky. "There's no evidence that wearing a bra will prevent your breasts from drooping and sagging," he says.

Which brings me back nicely to my own little experiment. It was much, much more comfortable going without. No red marks on the shoulders; no sore, itchy bit at the back where the label sticks and tickles; no constricted breathing or pinched ribs. Very earthy. Very pleasant. But I stayed very, very still, all day. And when I did move, I clutched something to my chest to hide any unprofessional jiggling. Bras - a necessary evil perhaps.

If your bra is not comfortable, you're probably wearing the wrong size and should go for a proper fitting - 70 to 80% of us are wearing the wrong bra apparently. Bras may be bad for your health; they may be good for your figure; they can be a turn-on (black, lacy push-up) or a turn-off (grey, saggy, gone through the wash too many times) but according to Cawthorn they can't keep stop the natural ageing process. Not even if you wear one all night like Marilyn Monroe to keep them perky. "There's no evidence that wearing a bra will prevent your breasts from drooping and sagging," he says. Which brings me back nicely to my own little experiment. It was much, much more comfortable going without. No red marks on the shoulders; no sore, itchy bit at the back where the label sticks and tickles; no constricted breathing or pinched ribs. Very earthy. Very pleasant. But I stayed very, very still, all day. And when I did move, I clutched something to my chest to hide any unprofessional jiggling. Bras - a necessary evil perhaps.

fields.headline: £1.2m for blunder that cost woman her leg
fields.standfirst:
Victim attacks NHS failure to learn from mistakes.

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A woman whose leg was amputated after she was wrongly diagnosed with cancer won a £1.2m settlement yesterday following a seven-year legal battle.
fields.body:
A woman whose leg was amputated after she was wrongly diagnosed with cancer won a £1.2m settlement yesterday following a seven-year legal battle.

Vicki Gilbert, 27, of Leeds, underwent three gruelling operations to remove her knee and most of her shinbone after she was diagnosed with a malignant bone tumour in 1992. The shinbone was replaced with a titanium implant.

She underwent chemotherapy, but less than a year later doctors at the Royal Orthopaedic hospital in Birmingham told her that the diagnosis was wrong and she did not have cancer.

It emerged that she had a harmless bone cyst and most of her surgery and treatment had not been needed.

The leg implant caused constant stress fractures and pain, so she had to have her leg amputated above the knee in September 1996.

The unnecessary chemotherapy caused permanent damage to her kidneys for which she still takes medication, reduced sensation in her hands and feet and damage to her hearing.

Yesterday Birmingham health authority confirmed it had settled her claim. The authority said in a statement: "The health authority did admit liability some time ago and has not been contesting the case. We are sorry for what has happened and wish her well for the future."

The saga is just the latest in a series of misdiagnosed cancer cases in which patients with benign conditions have been forced to undergo mutilating operations and harmful chemotherapy.

Three weeks ago Jennifer Cormack, who went through more than a dozen operations, including a double mastectomy, after being wrongly diagnosed with breast cancer, won £345,000 compensation at the high court in London.

Ms Gilbert, a college sports lecturer who also works as a disability equality trainer, said she had later learned that a report detailing shortcomings in the pathology service at Birmingham orthopaedic hospital had been leaked to a newspaper seven years before her misdiagnosis.

"I was very angry because they had taken my life away as it was then, all for no reason," she said. "Doctors knew there were inadequacies with the pathology department.

"What has happened to me shouldn't happen in vain and I very much hope the regularity with which these clinical mistakes are occurring is being recognised and that something is done about it."

She said it was "particularly frustrating to see that the NHS are not learning from their mistakes" and producing an effective system to identify errors and staff who consistently make mistakes.

Since her leg was amputated four years ago, Ms Gilbert has worn an artificial limb. But she still has to use crutches or a wheelchair some days.

Her solicitor, Julia Hurstfield of the Manchester law firm Pannone & Partners, said that while £1.2m was a large sum of money, it was to compensate her not only for the pain and suffering relating to the misdiagnosis but also for the ongoing treatment resulting from the chemotherapy, for the provision of an artificial limb for the rest of her life - a conservative estimate is around £300,000 - special adaptations to her home, physiotherapy costs and potential loss of earnings.

Ms Gilbert, who married a surveyor in 1998, lectures in sport at Barnsley and Harrogate colleges. She is also a National Coaching Foundation tutor.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A primary school teacher accused of slapping a pupil across the face returned to work yesterday. Jean Meldrum, 55, of Farndon, Nottinghamshire, had been suspended while the matter was brought to Newark magistrates court where she was cleared of common assault.
fields.body:
Teacher returns after slap case

A primary school teacher accused of slapping a pupil across the face returned to work yesterday. Jean Meldrum, 55, of Farndon, Nottinghamshire, had been suspended while the matter was brought to Newark magistrates court where she was cleared of common assault.

Truce hero, 106, 'is oldest man'

A former Royal Welch Fusilier who was named one of the most culturally influential people of the 20th century because of his role in the 1915 Christmas Day truce which led to a football match between British and German troops in the first world war trenches could be Britain's oldest man. Bertie Felstead who celebrated his 106th birthday in a care home in Gloucester at the weekend could inherit the title after Bill Leigh died last week aged 108.

£6.5m tag for 1963 Ferrari

A 1963 Ferrari 250 GTO 3-litre Berlinetta Competizione has been given a pre-sale estimate of more than $10m (about £6.5m) which would make it the most expensive car sold at auction by Bonhams and Brooks in Gstaad, Switzerland.

28,000 sign firework petition

A petition signed by more than 28,000 people calling for stricter fireworks controls was yesterday presented to MPs by the National Campaign for Firework Safety. Last year 1,056 people were treated for fireworks-related injuries in October and November.

Former Street actress dies

Former Coronation Street actress Elizabeth Bradley, who played the wheelchair-bound Maud Grimes died yesterday aged 78.

fields.headline: No: 1752
fields.standfirst: Tony Cascarino
fields.trailText: Tony Cascarino
fields.body:
Tony Cascarino? Country singer? Had a band called Dawn? No, that's Tony Orlando.

So who is this Cascarino? A footballer.

Italian? No, he played 88 times in the green jersey of Ireland.

Sounds about as Irish as that McAfferty's fun pub on the high street. You might have something there. Even his former national team manager, Jack Charlton, used to refer to him as the ice-cream salesman.

Let's get this settled, where does Tony come from? Born in Kent, Italian father, English mother. Used to be a hairdresser.

So why was he playing for Ireland? Under Charlton, the Irish became cunning in exploiting players' family trees. Tony thought he qualified because his paternal grandfather, Michael O'Malley, was Irish.

Was he? Well yes and no. O'Malley was Irish but wasn't his granddad. The old boy confessed all on his deathbed.

And Tony immediately told the relevant authorities? He didn't know. Although his mother was aware that her son was playing under false pretences she didn't pass on the information until he had retired from the international game.

So Tony was the innocent party? Not exactly. The Irish embassy in London, a bit sharper on the rules than their footballing authorities, refused to issue him with citizenship. He played for the Irish for 12 years on a British passport. "I was a fraud," he says, "a fake Irishman."

And how has the story finally come to light? Unlike the man he thought was his granddad, Tony hasn't waited until the metaphorical final whistle to confess. It's all in his new autobiography, Full Time: the Secret Life of Tony Cascarino.

Ah, he's got a book to sell. Yeah, but it's a lot more interesting than David Beckham's.

Why, whose knickers was he wearing when he played for Ireland? Oh do shut up.

Do say: "Any chance of a signed copy, Tone?"

Don't say: "Loved the way you sang Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Old Oak Tree."

webTitle: Leader: Trimble's survival strengthens No camp

fields.headline: Trimble's wrong turn
fields.standfirst:
He saved himself, but at what cost?

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Those who have equated the survival of the Northern Ireland peace process with the survival of David Trimble breathed yet another sigh of relief on Saturday. The leader of Ulster Unionism survived his 20th nailbiting party meeting, adding that badge of honour to the four leadership challenges he has endured. Asked to back him or sack him, the Ulster Unionist party's ruling council chose to stick with him.
fields.body:
Those who have equated the survival of the Northern Ireland peace process with the survival of David Trimble breathed yet another sigh of relief on Saturday. The leader of Ulster Unionism survived his 20th nailbiting party meeting, adding that badge of honour to the four leadership challenges he has endured. Asked to back him or sack him, the Ulster Unionist party's ruling council chose to stick with him.

But as the immediate relief of that outcome fades, a new feeling takes its place: concern at the price Mr Trimble paid for his survival. For the leader fended off the anti-agreement forces led by Jeffrey Donaldson only by throwing them a juicy bone of rejectionism. Some of the No camp were privately applauding Saturday's result: for though they lost the vote, they took a step toward winning the argument. Mr Trimble has had to move onto their naysaying territory.

That move came in the form of a new way to punish Sinn Fein for the IRA's slow progress on decommissioning. Instead of threatening to pull out of, and so bring down, the province's executive, Saturday's motion attacked another piece of the Good Friday settlement: cross border co-operation with Dublin. Mr Trimble has joint power to nominate which Belfast ministers attend meetings with their Irish counterparts and he promised to use it to keep Sinn Fein out.

It's wholly understandable why Mr Trimble came up with such a manoeuvre. If he had not budged he would have been cast as an apologist for the IRA's failure to disarm and probably removed from his post, thereby torpedoing the agreement. So budging was essential. Giving in to the Donaldsonian demand to set a November disarmament deadline would have been the wrong budge and Mr Trimble was right to reject it: there is nothing less likely to make republicans give up their guns than unionists demanding it. But Mr Trimble's artful move was not the right one either.

It is wrong in principle, for it creates what the agreement did not: two classes of minister. Gerry Adams is surely right to say that Sinn Fein is not in the executive at the pleasure of David Trimble but because it has an electoral mandate. Second, there may be, as the deputy first minister, nationalist Seamus Mallon, argues, a legal question over his colleague's right to veto ministers. Third, what was meant to be a "calibrated", moderate response has triggered a much bigger reaction than perhaps the UUP expected. Now the talk is of the agreement collapsing, just as it would have been if Jeffrey Donaldson's motion had passed. Fourth, the move will be entirely counterproductive. If the IRA was about to re-engage with the decommissioning commission, as it hinted last week, it won't be in a hurry to now, under pressure from unionism.

What can be done? In their conversations yesterday, Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern doubtless discussed an exit from the immediate tangle. They will probably want a fudge which would allow Sinn Fein to attend the next ministerial meeting, due on Friday, and Mr Trimble to save face (perhaps by branding the Friday meeting as a "parallel" session, or some such formulation).

But that, and Mr Mandelson's pleas for calm, will not be enough. Mr Trimble needs to speak over the heads of his own activists and enjoin the support of ordinary unionists who, polls show, still want peace to work. He needs to end this constant sabotage once and for all. For his part, Mr Adams needs to encourage the IRA back into the engagement on arms it was considering last week, not because of Mr Trimble's latest move - but in spite of it.

fields.trailText: Under the headline "Star wars technology to battle breast cancer", page 7, October 20, we said that a "Chromavision" machine for detecting cancer cells was invented by Charles Coombes of Hammersmith Hospital. While Professor Coombes is testing this cellular imaging system, he makes no claim to be the inventor. It was developed by a US firm, Chroma-Vision Medical Systems.
fields.body:
Under the headline "Star wars technology to battle breast cancer", page 7, October 20, we said that a "Chromavision" machine for detecting cancer cells was invented by Charles Coombes of Hammersmith Hospital. While Professor Coombes is testing this cellular imaging system, he makes no claim to be the inventor. It was developed by a US firm, Chroma-Vision Medical Systems.

Writing about job and services cuts by Hackney council, we erred in reporting on page 8, October 24, that the public-service union Unison was predicting up to 10,000 redundancies among council employees. The union's prediction is 1,000 job losses from a Hackney workforce of about 7,500.

A map of next year's proposed Tour de France cycle route - page 36, Sport, October 27 - shifted the north Belgian city of Anvers (normally rendered in English as Antwerp) into the south of the country, and moved the south Belgian towns of Huy and Seraing across the border into France.

Martin Hutchings was not the producer of Headless, a TV programme characterised on page 93, the Guide, October 28, as "surpassing even Channel 5's tidemark of cheap'n'nasty vacuity". The error arose from confusion in programme notes issued by C5. Mr Hutchings was a temporary co-director. The producer of Headless was Matthew Kuipers.

One of our Asia correspondents said in a piece on food, page 63, Weekend, October 28, that Indonesia comprised 17,500 islands. In the editing, 3,900 of these were wiped out, in line with references such as britannica.com, which cite 13,600 islands as Indonesia's lot. Our correspondent says that up to date satellite photos put the figure at 17,508.

Yesterday's paper, page 9, told of a campaign joined by the novelist John Fowles to oppose a housing development which some fear will ruin the outlook from the harbourside stone break- water - the Cobb - at the Dorset town of Lyme Regis. The story said the Cobb was made famous by Fowles's book The French Lieutenant's Woman. True for recent times, but well before Fowles its fame was established in Jane Austen's Persuasion, published in 1817.

webTitle: Bulger father vows to hunt killers

fields.headline: Bulger father vows to hunt killers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The father of murdered toddler James Bulger yesterday vowed to hunt down his son's killers when they are released.
fields.body:
The father of murdered toddler James Bulger yesterday vowed to hunt down his son's killers when they are released.

After spending more than seven years trying to come to terms with the brutal death of his two-year-old son, Ralph Bulger said: "Something's got to be done about it. We can't just stop now, and let these two little animals get released ... I will do all I can to try my best to hunt them down."

Speaking for the first time since the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, announced that the minimum sentence for Robert Thompson and Jon Venables was at an end, meaning they could be eligible for parole within months, Mr Bulger, 34, described his fury at hearing how his son's murderers could be free by next February.

The pair, who were 10 when they abducted James Bulger from The Strand shopping centre in Bootle, on Merseyside, in February 1993, have served their sentences in secure local authority accommodation and are now unlikely to be sent to a young offenders institution or adult prison.

Mr Bulger, who is divorced from James's mother, Denise, said he was "absolutely gutted" with Lord Woolf's decision and that he would appeal against it. "I couldn't believe it," he told GMTV. "I'm going to go through [the appeal] with my solicitor and do as much as we can."

He said the years since James's death had been hard and it was something he would never come to terms with. "The things they did to James ... they even denied an open coffin. We didn't really get to say goodbye to him."

Mr Bulger's warning to his son's killers contrasted with the comments made at the weekend by James's mother, Denise Fergus, who said she wanted to meet her son's killers in an attempt to answer some of the questions that still haunt her.

"I want to look them in the eye and ask them why? I just want to know what they did it for and how they could be so evil as to do it to a baby? Was it just for fun? I want to ask them before they are released ... if they think about James, about the life that has been taken away."

It is unlikely Mr Bulger would be able to carry out his threat to hunt down Thompson and Venables because they would be given new identities when they are released.

In addition, strict rulings made after their trial in 1993 set out terms for a wide-ranging injunction banning the media from revealing any details about their rehabilitation or printing photos of them taken after a certain date.

Last night a spokeswoman for Merseyside police refused to comment on Mr Bulger's remarks. "The welfare of the two teenagers are the responsibility of their carers and it is not really appropriate for us to discuss comments made on television," she said.

After it emerged that Mr Bulger would not qualify for legal aid to fund his appeal, a victims' support group, Mothers Against Murder and Aggression (Mama), announced it was planning a celebrity concert in aid of James's family.

Dee Warner, of Mama, said: "You could say you shouldn't take the law into your own hands but if the law worked for the victims rather than the criminals there wouldn't be these vigilante attacks. I couldn't advocate anyone being murdered but I haven't had a child murdered so I am not in a position to say how I would feel."

Ms Warner appealed for celebrities watching the programme to contact Mama to put their weight behind the concert, which will take place in Liverpool.
