fields.bodyText: The father of murdered toddler James Bulger yesterday vowed to hunt down his son's killers when they are released. After spending more than seven years trying to come to terms with the brutal death of his two-year-old son, Ralph Bulger said: "Something's got to be done about it. We can't just stop now, and let these two little animals get released ... I will do all I can to try my best to hunt them down." Speaking for the first time since the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, announced that the minimum sentence for Robert Thompson and Jon Venables was at an end, meaning they could be eligible for parole within months, Mr Bulger, 34, described his fury at hearing how his son's murderers could be free by next February. The pair, who were 10 when they abducted James Bulger from The Strand shopping centre in Bootle, on Merseyside, in February 1993, have served their sentences in secure local authority accommodation and are now unlikely to be sent to a young offenders institution or adult prison. Mr Bulger, who is divorced from James's mother, Denise, said he was "absolutely gutted" with Lord Woolf's decision and that he would appeal against it. "I couldn't believe it," he told GMTV. "I'm going to go through [the appeal] with my solicitor and do as much as we can." He said the years since James's death had been hard and it was something he would never come to terms with. "The things they did to James ... they even denied an open coffin. We didn't really get to say goodbye to him." Mr Bulger's warning to his son's killers contrasted with the comments made at the weekend by James's mother, Denise Fergus, who said she wanted to meet her son's killers in an attempt to answer some of the questions that still haunt her. "I want to look them in the eye and ask them why? I just want to know what they did it for and how they could be so evil as to do it to a baby? Was it just for fun? I want to ask them before they are released ... if they think about James, about the life that has been taken away." It is unlikely Mr Bulger would be able to carry out his threat to hunt down Thompson and Venables because they would be given new identities when they are released. In addition, strict rulings made after their trial in 1993 set out terms for a wide-ranging injunction banning the media from revealing any details about their rehabilitation or printing photos of them taken after a certain date. Last night a spokeswoman for Merseyside police refused to comment on Mr Bulger's remarks. "The welfare of the two teenagers are the responsibility of their carers and it is not really appropriate for us to discuss comments made on television," she said. After it emerged that Mr Bulger would not qualify for legal aid to fund his appeal, a victims' support group, Mothers Against Murder and Aggression (Mama), announced it was planning a celebrity concert in aid of James's family. Dee Warner, of Mama, said: "You could say you shouldn't take the law into your own hands but if the law worked for the victims rather than the criminals there wouldn't be these vigilante attacks. I couldn't advocate anyone being murdered but I haven't had a child murdered so I am not in a position to say how I would feel." Ms Warner appealed for celebrities watching the programme to contact Mama to put their weight behind the concert, which will take place in Liverpool. "There's a wealth of talent in Liverpool - Jimmy Tarbuck, Lily Savage ... Ricky Tomlinson, we want all those people, that big-hearted city, to come together, give up your time, free of charge."

webTitle: Leader: Kosovo's elections don't mean independence

fields.headline: Kosovo's high hopes
fields.standfirst:
But one election does not make a nation

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The clear victory of Ibrahim Rugova's nationalists in municipal elections is a welcome first step towards democratic self-government in Kosovo. But the widespread assumption, encouraged by Mr Rugova, that the polls mark the beginning of a rapid, inevitable march to full independence should be treated with extreme caution.
fields.body:
The clear victory of Ibrahim Rugova's nationalists in municipal elections is a welcome first step towards democratic self-government in Kosovo. But the widespread assumption, encouraged by Mr Rugova, that the polls mark the beginning of a rapid, inevitable march to full independence should be treated with extreme caution. The results, if confirmed, amount to a repudiation of the strong-arm tactics of Hashim Thaci and the former Kosovo Liberation Army leadership. Outside observers judged the voting to be free and fair. The elections give Mr Rugova, twice elected unofficial president during the Milosevic era, a springboard for an expected provincial assembly vote next spring.

Yet despite the Kosovo Albanians' evident delight in this exercise in "normal politics", the fact remains that the province's rump Serb population (perhaps 75,000 people out of 200,000 prior to last year's Nato intervention) boycotted the vote and Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica, perhaps unwisely, says the results are invalid.

Mr Kostunica, who has indicated a willingness to talk, nevertheless insists on UN security council resolution 1244 that guarantees Yugoslavia's "sovereignty and territorial integrity". In other words, he wants Kosovo (and Serb refugees) back. The suggestion at the weekend that the US may reverse itself and support Kosovan independence is thus, at this particular juncture in Serbia's own delicate democratic transition, distinctly disobliging.

It may be an attempt to jolt the other Nato allies into focusing on Kosovo's final status. Or it may relate to Washington politics. George W Bush has pledged to run down the US military presence in the Balkans should he become president. With Milosevic gone (but not Serb nationalism), the US may be tempted to declare the Balkan problem solved and back out fast.

This would be as unrealistic and premature as Mr Rugova's call for immediate recognition of an independent state. Geo-strategic considerations aside, aid-dependent Kosovo, with only about 2m people, 50% unemployment, backward agriculture, poor infrastructure, high crime, and deep ethnic divisions is neither economically viable nor politically stable enough at present to make it on its own. Independence may be a reasonable aspiration. But it will take time. It is not a panacea or even a certainty. And those in the west who dangerously raise Kosovan expectations act irresponsibly.

webTitle: Letters: Opinions on the rail crisis

fields.headline: What Nathalie could teach Gerald
fields.trailText: I hope that First Great Western give Nathalie, the train manager on last Wednesday's 13.30 from Paddington to Penzance, a large bonus. During the eight or so hours the journey took, she never lost her good humour even when the buffet ran out of food and she was summoned with the desperate tannoy message, "Nathalie can you get here quick, we've got a crisis."
fields.body:
I hope that First Great Western give Nathalie, the train manager on last Wednesday's 13.30 from Paddington to Penzance, a large bonus. During the eight or so hours the journey took, she never lost her good humour even when the buffet ran out of food and she was summoned with the desperate tannoy message, "Nathalie can you get here quick, we've got a crisis."

On my (even longer) return journey, Melvin in the buffet told me that although they took a delivery of sandwiches on board at Plymouth they weren't licensed to sell them until the train reached Exeter "and who knows when that will be". Isn't this a nonsense?
Tony Patterson
Melton, Suffolk
Tony@uk-beeches.demon. co.uk

Ronnie Corbett running Railtrack (Letters, October 30)? Sooty and Sweep more like.
Phil Thomas
Braddan, Isle of Man

I have just heard Gerald Corbett say "it is right that we should blitz the railway". Yet another case of too many beefburgers?
Neil Browning
Surbiton
browningnr@aol.com

In view of the current problems (meteorological and human) besetting the rail network, and the difficulty in getting through to the inquiry service, surely the time is ripe to rename it the Notional Rail Enquiry Service?
Steve Wharton
Bath
steve.wharton@goldserve.net

fields.headline: Postmortem is the key
fields.trailText: Concern has been raised by the diagnosis of a 74-year-old man with variant CJD that there may be a hidden number of such cases previously diagnosed as Alzheimer's disease or other forms of dementia (New case highlights BSE fears, October 28). The question is potentially answerable by the use of dementia registers.
fields.body:
Concern has been raised by the diagnosis of a 74-year-old man with variant CJD that there may be a hidden number of such cases previously diagnosed as Alzheimer's disease or other forms of dementia (New case highlights BSE fears, October 28). The question is potentially answerable by the use of dementia registers.

For many years all cases of dementia identified in Camberwell were systematically followed up to death and a postmortem was carried out whenever possible. Unfortunately, due to the shortsighted view of funding bodies, the register is not as complete as it might have been. However, over a period of some 10 years only one case of CJD was identified at postmortem. This was a younger man with familial CJD, not the new variant.

A definitive answer cannot be given at this stage, but it appears that fears of a large number of cases of "hidden variant CJD" among patients thought to have other forms of dementia may be exaggerated. It emphasises inter alia the need to fully fund such registers and to carry out a postmortem with detailed examination of the brain in every case if possible.
Raymond Levy
Emeritus professor Institute of Psychiatry
RLevylond@aol.com

You correctly state in a tiny column (CJD facts, October 27) that the cause of CJD is "not conclusively proven". However, the remainder of your coverage assumes as incontrovertible fact that BSE is the cause of vCJD. There have been 80 CJD deaths since 1995 - an infinitesimally small number as a proportion of all annual deaths in the UK. Have the numbers of deaths due to CJD increased, decreased or remained relatively stable over the period before and after the discovery of BSE? If there has been an increase, is it statistically significant?

Surely we need to question society's propensity to panic about BSE/CJD? We urgently need a serious consideration of the dangers of society's current mistrust of scientific explanation in favour of emotionalism and wild speculation.
Dr Mark Wanstall
Leeds
mwanstall@hotmail.com

Radio 4's Farming Today programme has said the recent mystery disease in farmed salmon in Scotland might be a brain disease and that salmon had been recycled in the feed given to farmed salmon. When will we have a law prohibiting any cannibalistic practice? Surely after BSE, and vCJD we do not need a vCJD(S).
Alan Mathison
Harrow
alan.mathison@ntlworld.com

fields.headline: Unholy row over atheism
fields.trailText: Congratulations to Joan Smith for her defence of atheism against the woolly minded mutterings of the Archbishop of Canterbury (So the British have become atheists. Thank God for that, October 30).
fields.body:
Congratulations to Joan Smith for her defence of atheism against the woolly minded mutterings of the Archbishop of Canterbury (So the British have become atheists. Thank God for that, October 30).

The collapse of religious belief does not mean the collapse of morality. Nor does rejection of the fantasy of an after-life necessarily presage a new age of self-interest and materialism. On the contrary, it is a necessary first step to moral responsibility. Human beings make their own fate, and have no outside power to appeal to when things go wrong. In a life bounded by the certainty of death we learn to value achievements and ties that will outlast us, whether at work, in our relationships with families and friends, or in our wider social activities. This is an incentive to altruism, not selfishness.

The decline in religious belief in developed liberal societies is inevitable, necessary and thoroughly healthy.
Ian Willmore
London
ianw@foe.co.uk

I'm usually all for anti-clerical rants, but Joan Smith gives non-believers a bad name. Having correctly targeted the "archbishop's conflation of godlessness and immorality", she scores an own goal by conflating anti-clericism and atheism and resorting to that rhetorical chestnut of setting up a single example of religious belief (after-life) and treating all possible convictions as equivalent.

I would like to point out to Ms Smith that one does not deconstruct fallacies: one exposes them. One deconstructs (false) binary oppositions, of which there are several in her analysis. She opposes Christians to atheists, which is offensive to Muslims, Jews Hindus, Buddhists and agnostics alike.
Jason Annadani
London
jason_annadani@yahoo.com

Joan Smith is spot on. For years my life was ruined by Catholic guilt and rendered utterly bleak by religion. Frequent visits to the confessional only increased my anxiety and depression, until one day a priest told me: "You'll go to hell, you will."

What a relief that was. Finally the whole pointlessness of religion was brought home to me and I went to my doctor who prescribed a Prozac lookalike. The result? More peace than I had known for years and the ability to be far more altruistic than I ever was as a Christian. Doctors are far more effective than priests - I've found out first hand.
Mike Clutten
Leicester

Anyone can, as Joan Smith has done, create their own fantasy about "god" and rightly say He, She or It, does not exist. I doubt Robert Runcie conceives of a god as limited as hers.
The Rev Tony Bell
Chesterfield
tonybell@glapwell.f9.co.uk

It was not only some of the world's most inspiring thinkers who were atheists in pre-Darwinian society. Recently I came across this obituary of my great-great-great grandfather, a china potter, in the Worcester Berrows Journal of May 25 1843: "Deceased was a Socialist, and when on his death-bed expressed a hope that he should not die a Christian, as he could not then be happy."
Martin White
Ironbridge, Telford
martin@white-entwistle.freeserve.co.uk

Goodness me! If Joan Smith got out a bit more she'd find that some of the clergy abandoned religious fairy stories years ago - but still have plenty of relevant things to say about the human condition.
The Rev Ian Williams
Lichfield, Staffs
ian@christchurchlichfield. co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Stuart Hall on race report

fields.headline: That's not what we said
fields.trailText: You say (Leader, October 11) that the report of the Commission into the Future of Multi-ethnic Britain argues that Britain is a racially coded word and should therefore be dropped. We propose nothing of the kind.
fields.body:
You say (Leader, October 11) that the report of the Commission into the Future of Multi-ethnic Britain argues that Britain is a racially coded word and should therefore be dropped. We propose nothing of the kind. Indeed, we say that the tendency for increasing numbers to recognise themselves as Black-British or British-Asian is a positive sign of their assertion of "the claim to belong".

What we did say was that, historically, "Britishness ... has systematic, largely unspoken, racial connotations" - which is manifestly true. When people celebrate "Britain's finest hour", the non-white faces of Asian or Caribbean volunteer servicemen in the second world war do not automatically slip into their minds. Since the many peoples who have occupied these islands have been white, it is hardly surprising that this should be so.

What we do argue is that, if in the future ethnic minority people are to feel not only citizens with equal rights but part of the national story, then the meaning of the term "Britishness" will have to become more inclusive. Gary Younge (October 11) and Hugo Young (October 12) accept - indeed, expand on - this argument.

Why then did your leader wittingly or unwittingly perpetrate the damaging impression that the report had called for "Britain" to be abandoned - and provide the means by which the report's enemies could (and did) let themselves off the hook?
Stuart Hall
Commission member

fields.headline: All trick
fields.trailText: Julie Wheelwright paints a cosy picture of Halloween with well-behaved children, supervised by parents collecting goodies or playing jolly japes on their neighbours (G2, October 25).
fields.body:
Julie Wheelwright paints a cosy picture of Halloween with well-behaved children, supervised by parents collecting goodies or playing jolly japes on their neighbours (G2, October 25).

Out here in the real world the picture is rather different. Why should pensioners feel pressurised to spend money on sweets for children who are probably better off? Why do Thames Valley police have to warn shopkeepers not to sell large quantities of eggs to youngsters after people were pelted with them?

For me the final straw came two days after my husband's funeral, when I was cleaning a potentially lethal layer of tomato ketchup from the doorstep. This for the crime of not opening the door, as I wished to grieve in peace.
Name and address supplied

fields.headline: Roman facelift: Tombstone of Longinus the cavalryman restored
fields.trailText: The face of one of the first Romans in Britain, Longinus the cavalryman, has been restored after the missing fragments of the 1st century tombstone were located more than 70 years after the main part was found near Colchester, Essex.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The face of one of the first Romans in Britain, Longinus the cavalryman, has been restored after the missing fragments of the 1st century tombstone were located more than 70 years after the main part was found near Colchester, Essex.

The tombstone, showing a soldier on horseback terrorising an Iron Age Briton, is of outstanding interest to archaeologists. It is not only the oldest Roman gravestone in Britain, but the stone came from Lincolnshire, probably by sea, proving that a sophisticated administration was in place within a few years of the invasion.

It is a mute witness to the violence of the Boudiccan revolt, when followers of the rebel queen swept down from East Anglia in AD61, torching Roman settlements at Colchester, Verulamiam and London. Archaeologists believe that the tall stone, along with that of a man Longinus must have known, Facilis the centurion, was smashed by Boudicca's forces as a symbol of the hated Romans.

Longinus died in AD49, so soon after the invasion in 43 that Philip Wise, curator of archaeology at Colchester Castle Museum, believes he must have come to Britain with Claudius's invasion force, and possibly marched into Colchester in the emperor's procession - complete with elephants - which cowed the natives.

Longinus Sdapeze came from Sardica, now Sofia, Bulgaria. He died aged 40, after 15 years' service, probably of fever, since there was no local fighting in AD49. His tombstone would have been paid for by the burial fund that soldiers paid into.

In 1928 garages were built on the site of a Roman cemetery. As the stone was being broken up and carted away, a splendidly carved Roman letter was spotted. The site's significance was quickly realised, and it has been extensively studied.

In 1996 the museum was able to look for more when the site was cleared again for housing. Many more pieces, including the face, were found.

The only thing missing is Longinus himself. Mr Wise said: "The cremated bones of Facilis were found beneath his stone, so my own feeling is that Longinus is there somewhere."

fields.headline: Home appliances 'impair fertility'
fields.trailText: Radiation from electrical appliances and power lines might make women infertile, Italian researchers suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
Radiation from electrical appliances and power lines might make women infertile, Italian researchers suggested yesterday.

They found that mouse ovarian follicles exposed to extremely low frequency (ELF) electromagnetic fields in the lab failed to develop properly.

They fear similar harm might be caused to women by everyday radiation from refrigerators, washing machines, kettles, vacuum cleaners and other household appliances, as well as computer terminals and power lines.

Britain's supervisory body on radiation, the national radiological protection board, said there was no cause for alarm. The finding was out of step with other studies on mice, said the board, and the radiation used was anything up to 1,000 times more powerful than that found in the home. But it said it would look carefully at the report.

ELF fields are generated by operating an appliance and also when it is on standby.

Ovarian follicles go through stages of development to reach maturity. A crucial step is the creation of the central cavity, called the antrum. The scientists, from the universities of L'Aquilia and La Sapienza in Rome, found that ELF fields prevented a large proportion of cultured mouse ovarian follicles developing to this stage.

Pre-antral cells were exposed to ELF radiation at fre quencies of 33 hertz or 50 hertz.

On day five, only about a third of the 33 hertz follicles and half of those subjected to the 50 hertz frequency developed antral cavities, compared with 80% of cells kept away from electromagnetic fields.

Writing in the journal Human Reproduction, the scientists said: "Our results raise concerns that ELF exposure might impair female reproductive potential by reducing the capacity of follicles to reach the developmental stage that is an essential prerequisite for successful reproduction."

Sandra Cecconi of L'Aquilia, who led the group, said: "At this stage we have no idea whether the same effect would be found [in women], but it would seem prudent to investigate. But human infertility is very complex, and many factors can combine to reduce fertility, and in every woman these factors are likely to be different."

A spokesman for the British radiation board said after seeing the paper: "The exposures here really are quite high, 100 or even 1,000 times what you would get standing next to a dishwasher or other appliance.

"Other work in this area has shown no effect on reproduction in mice, but we will look at it very carefully and refer it to our advisory group."

webTitle: The best motel reception scene: Memento

fields.headline: The best motel reception scene: Memento
fields.trailText: Staying at the Discount Motel, short-term memory loss victim Leonard Shelby (Guy Pearce) approaches receptionist Bert (Mark Boone Jr).
fields.body:
Staying at the Discount Motel, short-term memory loss victim Leonard Shelby (Guy Pearce) approaches receptionist Bert (Mark Boone Jr).

"Hi," he mumbles through a half-inch of Plexiglas. "Uh, Mr Shelby - 304."

Bert glances up.

"What can I do for you, Leonard?"

"I don't know. I think I may have asked you to hold my calls."

"You don't know?"

"Well, I think I may have. I'm not too good on the phone."

"Right, you said you liked to look people in the eye when you talked to them."

"Yeah."

Bert narrows his eyes.

"You don't remember saying that?"

"Well, that's the thing. I have this condition."

"Condition?"

"It's my memory."

"Amnesia?"

"No, no, it's different from that. It's short-term. I know who I am, I know all about myself. It's just... since my injury, I can't make new memories. Everything fades. If we talk for too long, I'll forget how we started. Next time I see you I'm not going to remember this conversation. I don't even know if I've met you before. So, if I seem strange or something, then..."

Leonard hesitates before finishing his sentence.

"Have I told you this before?"

Bert gives a small shrug.

"Yeah. I don't mean to mess with you, Leonard. It's just so weird. You don't remember me at all?"

"No."

"We've talked a bunch a times."

Leonard half-smiles.

"I'm sure we have."

See also: LA Confidential, The Terminator, Psycho (1960)

Don't see also: Psycho (1998)

Pointless trivia: Several of Guy Pearce's songs were used on the soundtrack to the 1991 film The Hunting, in which he also starred.

fields.headline: Out-of-hours calls to doctor to be put on single number
fields.standfirst: Health ministers want to establish a single national telephone number to summon out-of-hours help from a GP.
fields.trailText: Health ministers want to establish a single national telephone number to summon out-of-hours help from a GP, instead of local services of variable speed and quality.
fields.body:
Health ministers want to establish a single national telephone number to summon out-of-hours help from a GP, instead of local services of variable speed and quality.

The national service would aim to provide an almost instant assessment of a patient's needs, leading to advice over the phone for minor ailments, an out-of-hours visit by the patient's GP or locum for more serious conditions, or a rapid response from an ambulance to accidents or emergencies.

The first step will be taken today by John Denham, the health minister, when he accepts a report from a team led by David Carson and Ian Trimble, GPs from east London and Nottingham.

It calls for an amalgamation of services offered by the telephone advice line NHS Direct, local GPs and other services such as accident and emergency. The report suggests different areas could experiment with different models of integration, depending on local strengths.

In some areas GPs might want to continue to provide most out-of-hours care for their patients, while in others there might be greater use of locum services. But in each case the patient would call a single hotline and be directed to the appropriate service.

Mr Denham is expected to accept a recommendation for national targets, including 90% of calls answered in 30 seconds and all patients getting the care they needed within a maximum of six hours. Patients should also always be told how their call was being looked after and when they could expect to be seen.

The report follows concern among ministers about large variations in speed and quality of out-of-hours services. A health department source said: "Some parts of the country have good, consistently fast and popular ways of doing this; in others there are networks of answering machines which are slow and frustrating for patients."

The health service ombuds man, Michael Buckley, warned in June of "totally unacceptable" performance by the biggest of the private companies providing a deputising service for GPs outside working hours.

Defects in the service offered by Healthcall for 7,500 GPs included insufficient training for call-handling staff and inadequate procedures for prioritising calls. The company promised to address these weaknesses.

Mr Denham is expected to tell the National Association for Primary Care conference in Harrogate, North Yorkshire, that the government will sponsor local experiments in integration over the next year. Financial support would be available if needed. The scheme would not amount to a takeover by NHS Direct. There would be no threat to successful schemes such as the GP cooperative offering out-of-hours care in west London.

The health department ex pects support from GPs who are willing to attend patients at night in cases of real need, but dislike making pointless visits. Ministers think this could be achieved by better trained assessment of callers' requirements.

fields.headline: England go for Eriksson
fields.standfirst:
 Swede set to sign FA's five-year deal worth £10m
 Will be first foreigner to take charge of national side
 Will take full-time role after leaving Lazio in June
Davies hails 'very good news'
David Lacey comment
Sven-Goran Eriksson profile
fields.trailText: Lazio coach Sven-Goran Eriksson is set to sign a five-year deal worth £10m to become England's first foreign manager when his contract with the Serie A champions ends next June.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has agreed to become the new England coach and will take up his appointment on July 1 next year, according to detailed Italian reports yesterday.

However, for various reasons the Football Association preferred to play down the breakthrough after the news leaked and would go no further than confirm that talks had taken place. The FA hopes to make announcement later this week.

"Our representatives have been to Rome and clearly they have made progress and that is why that report has come out," said the FA's executive director David Davies.

However, the clear indications in Italy were that this was a done deal and that the 52-year-old Swede will become the first foreign manager of the national side.

The immensely respected Lazio coach is reported to have agreed a five-year deal worth around £10m before bonuses. It is even understood he will have extensive input into the three World Cup qualifiers, against Finland, Albania and Greece, that England play before he comes on board full time.

The fact that Eriksson is not English will upset the traditionalists but the main thing is that the FA appears to have achieved what it said it would and secured the talents of one of the best coaches in the world to turn round the flagging reputation of the England side.

FA officials, led by the chief executive Adam Crozier, were in Rome yesterday with the specific intention of appointing Eriksson following Kevin Keegan's shock resignation after the World Cup qualifying defeat by Germany at Wembley on October 7.

Crozier said when Keegan resigned that the FA would go all out to get the best man for the job and appoint someone long term. And when the chief executive let slip over a week ago that the FA had drawn up a three-man shortlist, the No1 choice was the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger. But he insisted on seeing out the remaining two years on his Highbury contract and the FA was unwilling to wait that long.

Eriksson, who took Lazio to their first Serie A title in 26 years last season, was second on the list but had the advantage that his contract with his club expires next June.

Although Lazio tried to entice him into signing an extension with a large increase on his £1.25m salary, the challenge of managing a national side appears to have proved too tempting for a man who has won almost every honour in club football.

Everyone from Roy Hodgson to Terry Venables to Martin O'Neill has been linked with the job. And the FA suffered a setback when Newcastle refused to allow their manager Bobby Robson to act as a stand-in coach until the summer, and subsequently turned to the Leicester manager Peter Taylor and Manchester United's No2 Steve McClaren to take charge for England's friendly against Italy in Turin on November 15.

When Eriksson was asked about the England job last week he played down his interest. "I am honoured to be linked with the England situation," he said, "but I am at a very big club with very big ambitions. When you are there you don't want to leave it."

But Eriksson wants to see out his Lazio contract in an attempt to win the main club honour that has eluded him, the Champions League.

It is understood that Eriksson will bring his long-term No2 Tord Grip with him to England, where the pair will also work with the team of part-time England coaches which the FA plans to put in place.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Davies hails 'very good news'
fields.standfirst:
England go for Eriksson
David Lacey comment
Sven-Goran Eriksson profile
fields.trailText: The FA's executive director David Davies beats around the bush as speculation reaches fever pitch.
fields.body:
The Football Association's executive director David Davies welcomed the likely conclusion of their search for a new coach as a deal with Lazio's Sven-Goran Eriksson became imminent.

"We are very pleased with the progress we have made," he said. "This is a very important decision for supporters and for anyone who cares about English football.

"His proven track record speaks for itself. I don't think anyone disputes that - football people will tell you that. He's won a championship in his home country of Sweden and he's won a championship in Portugal and in Italy. He is well known throughout world football. But let's not jump the gun here. Progress has been made, as we hoped it would be this week, and the talks will continue.

"We have discussed with him the possibility of taking charge of the England team both for key games in the short term and in a full-time capacity in the long term. Those talks will resume in the very near future."

But Davies, mindful of the fans' anxiety over England's foreign future, stressed the role that will be played by Englishmen should Eriksson's appointment be confirmed.

"I understand his contract runs until the end of this season," he said, "and meanwhile we are continuing to build a team of young English coaches, all with real potential.

"We are building that team to work with the senior England coach and our aim in this difficult process is to get the best available team of coaches to give the England players the greatest chance of success."

The FA chairman Geoff Thompson welcomed the promised appointment, despite the fact that England would have a foreign manager for the first time.

"We said from the outset that we wanted to get the best possible coach for the England team," said Thompson. "There are not many English people available at the present time, so we have to spread the net a little bit.

"Clearly, the appointment of Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren for the game against Italy is the first step of the process of ensuring there are Englishmen coming through the coaching system.

"But we have to address the issue as it stands. It is not signed and sealed yet and I'm sure I will be the first to know when it is. But I am fully confident in Adam Crozier and the team he has got around him. I am sure they will get the best person available." It now looks as if they might already have got him.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: England await the new professor
fields.standfirst:
England go for Eriksson
Davies hails 'very good news'
Sven-Goran Eriksson profile
fields.trailText: So the FA has grasped the nettle and gone foreign. No matter what people say, Eriksson's just what England need - provided he doesn't change his mind again.
fields.body:
The expected choice of Sven-Goran Eriksson to coach England from next July should be a matter for relief with trepidation and mild rejoicing. Relief that the wilder speculation concerning Kevin Keegan's successor has proved untrue, a natural fear of the unknown and pleasure that the national side may, from next summer, be picked by a man whose football credentials are impeccable.

When the name of Johan Cruyff entered the equation it was time to start worrying. As it is, the Football Association has gone for the studious Swedish coach of Lazio who has a string of championships in three countries to his credit and is widely respected throughout the game. If tactical acumen, common sense and an ability to command the respect of the world's leading players count for anything, the FA may be on to a winner.

Yet in going for a foreign coach to run the national squad it is still taking an enormous gamble, not so much with the future success of the England team but with the reaction of the country as a whole to the idea of having a foreigner in charge. Obviously foreign, professorial types are the flavour of the moment. The FA could not get Arsène Wenger, so it is going for the next best thing.

The notion might seem old-fashioned but some fans may feel that, while it is one thing to have French coaches running Arsenal and Liverpool, where there are large complements of overseas players, it will be quite another to have the England team picked and organised by a Swede.

In the 21st century this should not matter. After all, an Englishman, George Raynor, took Sweden to a World Cup final 42 years ago, so maybe they owed us one.

Eriksson, moreover, would appear ideally suited to combine his experience in Europe with the affection for English football shared by most northern European coaches. He would doubtless take office praising the high quality of the players available to him as well as the exciting string of up-and-coming youngsters queuing for a chance in the national side.

The reality is that Eriksson would take over the squad much as a new head teacher arrives at a problem school. He would need to sort out those with genuine talent from the ones who have learning difficulties. Above all he would need to organise whatever is left of England by then into a team capable of achieving the basics of good passing and movement.

Reaching the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea is far from impossible, despite England's poor start, but the idea of winning it is an idle dream. The FA believes that it is more realistic to concentrate on building a side for Euro 2004, in Portugal, and the 2006 World Cup in Germany.

Just what kind of legacy Eriksson would inherit depends on the FA's ability to achieve a reasonable strength of continuity in the team over the coming eight months. Eriksson would take up his post full-time on July 1 next year, by which time England will have played another three World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March and Greece in June.

Unless, therefore, the FA manages to obtain his services part-time for these games Eriksson will start in the midst of a wake or an awakening. So much depends on Peter Taylor, the present caretaker, getting a sufficiently strong performance from England in their friendly against Italy in Turin a fortnight tomorrow to give the team a platform from which to resume operations early next year.

Taylor has already indicated his intention of giving some of the younger players a taste of full international football and will draw on his recent three years with the England Under-21 team to bring this about. If he can successfully blood the likes of West Ham's Joe Cole, he would have done the next man no small favour.

Eriksson, meanwhile, has been reported as saying that, if he took the England job, he would like David Platt as his assistant. There would be a certain logic in this. Platt, England captain under Graham Taylor, was coached by Eriksson at Sampdoria where a strong relationship developed between the two.

For the FA it will be more important to establish the time scale of Eriksson's mission to restore England to a position of respect not enjoyed by the national side since they went into the 1970 World Cup as holders and co-favourites with Brazil.

The fact that the FA has found it necessary to look abroad for a coach is a measure of the extent to which the structure of the English game has declined. By going for a foreigner England have as good as admitted that they are a second-class football power. It is hard to imagine Italy, Germany, France, Brazil or Argentina doing likewise, although Holland did reach the final of the 1978 World Cup under an Austrian, Ernst Happel.

Much has to happen before Eriksson becomes England coach. He was on the point of becoming manager of Blackburn Rovers before deciding that he would be better off in Italy. Now, clearly, he would be financially better off in England. Just how better off England might be will be much discussed over the coming months.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

Eriksson would take up his post full-time on July 1 next year, by which time England will have played another three World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March and Greece in June. Unless, therefore, the FA manages to obtain his services part-time for these games Eriksson will start in the midst of a wake or an awakening. So much depends on Peter Taylor, the present caretaker, getting a sufficiently strong performance from England in their friendly against Italy in Turin a fortnight tomorrow to give the team a platform from which to resume operations early next year. Taylor has already indicated his intention of giving some of the younger players a taste of full international football and will draw on his recent three years with the England Under-21 team to bring this about. webTitle: The rise and rise of the 'Iceman' with a wanderlust

fields.headline: The rise and rise of the 'Iceman' with a wanderlust
fields.standfirst:
England go for Eriksson
Davies hails 'very good news'
David Lacey comment
fields.trailText: Kevin Buckley profiles Sven-Goran Eriksson.
fields.body:
It is only partly due to Sven-Goran Eriksson's Swedish origins that he is known in Italy as the "Iceman". It is more because when compared to others who inhabit the precarious world of the Serie A touchline, he is the personification of calm authority and carries things off with an air of elegance.

Italy's new coach Giovanni Trapattoni is famous for torrential outbursts at press conferences and Parma's Alberto Malesani often celebrates goals by running around on the edge of the pitch, arms outstretched imitating an aeroplane, wearing his trusty old grey crombie overcoat.

In contrast Eriksson's behaviour is impeccable. He is endlessly patient and diplomatic even when facing the rapacious Italian media. A thinking coach rather than a changing-room rabble-rouser, he possesses an intelligent, calculating football mind. In a 24-year career in Sweden, Portugal and two spells in Italy he has won, including cups, a total of 16 trophies, seven of them in Italy.

After a nondescript playing career as a semi-professional in his native country, at the age of only 28 he took over at the Swedish Third Division club Deghefors in 1976, guiding them into the top division with consecutive promotions.

This prompted a move in 1979 to Gothenburg, where in four seasons he won the Swedish championship once. His first spell abroad followed, winning the Portuguese championship in successive seasons at Benfica.

Then came the first call from Serie A and he took Roma to seventh place.

Although they finished as runners-up in 1986, he was sacked the following season. Two seasons at Fiorentina saw the viola finish seventh and eighth, before he returned to Portugal in 1989.

Three more successful seasons with Benfica brought one championship and two second places, before he returned to Italy to manage Sampdoria. In five seasons at the Genoese club their best position was third in Serie A in 1994.

He arrived at Lazio in 1997. After an inauspicious start the success-starved Rome club came within a whisker of the championship in 1999, throwing away a seven-point lead to be overtaken by Milan in a nail-biting run-in. However, Eriksson convincingly silenced his critics last season when finally he guided his biancoceleste to their first title in 27 years.

Eriksson's professorial image is reflected in his notoriously thorough tactical preparation for every match but is belied by his role as a strict task-master in training.

One criticism levelled at him, even during last season's successful campaign, is his hesitancy to substitute under-performing players during a match. Yet his tactical nous means his half-time team talks often lead to much improved second-half performances. He commands the ultimate respect from the superstars in his charge, who rarely publicly question his work.

Eriksson has a son and daughter, both university students, by his Swedish wife, from whom he separated while at Sampdoria. Although he left his wife for a younger Italian woman, he maintains close relations with his original family, who still live in Italy. His current contract with Lazio runs until June 2001.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Cricket club found woman 'unacceptable' in senior job

fields.headline: Cricket club found woman 'unacceptable' in senior job
fields.trailText: A woman cricket executive was turned down for a job at Lancashire Cricket Club because her gender was seen as unacceptable to traditionalists, an employment tribunal was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman cricket executive was turned down for a job at Lancashire Cricket Club because her gender was seen as unacceptable to traditionalists, an employment tribunal was told yesterday.

Maria Grant, 45, a former executive director of the Women's Cricket Association, is claiming sexual discrimination by the Lancashire board after she failed to make the shortlist for assistant secretary and development coordinator at the club.

The tribunal in Manchester was told one reason given by the board was "a lack of knowledge of men's cricket", despite her having played, managed and coached cricket for more than 15 years. She responded: "There is no significant difference in how men and women play cricket, nor in the way it is administered. In requiring such knowledge I was bound to be treated less favourably by the selection committee than the eight candidates who were shortlisted, because they were all men."

The tribunal heard that Ms Grant had been a force behind developing women's cricket in the north-west, sitting as regional officer of the north west sports council. She applied for the £24,000 Lancashire job in July 1999, thinking she was perhaps overqualified having run a national organisation, but feeling it was a step to her goal of being the first female chief executive of a county club.

Astonished not to be on the shortlist, she wrote to the board secretary, David Edmundson. He replied that the grounds were, among others, a lack of budget and coaching experience and "a perception that [she] would not be personally fully acceptable to the leagues [local teams associated with the county club]".

Ms Grant told the tribunal the first could not fairly be applied to her; she had the same or a better coaching qualification as some shortlisted, but that criterion had not been mentioned in the job application; and the view she would not be acceptable was a "coded expression" of the reaction the selection committee felt her appointment would provoke among conservative thinkers who run the leagues and clubs.

"I can only infer that this perceived non-acceptability is on the ground of sex _ changing attitudes takes a long time, and there remains a large and powerful group who maintain 'traditional conservative values' and who still regard cricket as a 'man's game' despite the fact that women have been playing since at least 1745."

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Forget the youth policy - let's get a pension plan

fields.headline: Forget the youth policy - let's get a pension plan
fields.trailText: If last weekend's match reports are anything to go by, future England success will depend on nurturing a squad of seniors.
fields.body:
Those searching for anecdotal evidence that the population of England is getting older would have done well to read yesterday's Premiership match reports. A glance through them was enough to unnerve anybody uncertain of how we will cope with the ever-increasing demands being placed on the NHS, the national pension fund and manufacturers of slacks with elasticated waistbands.

Manchester United's hero at Old Trafford was 34-year-old Teddy Sheringham. At Upton Park, meanwhile, Newcastle's 67-year-old manager Bobby Robson praised the performance of 34-year-old Robert Lee saying, "He played like Beckenbauer" (who is getting on himself). For the home side Stuart Pearce (38) was outstanding. "I love having him around the place," said the Hammers boss, Harry Redknapp. Who can blame him? After all, it's always nice when at least one person in the dressing room gets your reference to Bob Stokoe's trilby.

Before the Merseyside derby Everton's Walter Smith made his contribution by saying that 33-year-old Paul Gascoigne should be playing for England and at Villa Park John Gregory did boostering duties on behalf of Paul Merson, aged 32. There is surely enough here to suggest that, far from being orange, the future is a distinguished grey.

The notion that the demographics of the Premiership mirror that of society is borne out statistically. For example, in the 1990 FA Cup final the average age of the Manchester United and Crystal Palace starting line-ups was around 25 years and 11 months. A decade later when Aston Villa took on Chelsea there was a preponderance of thirtysomethings on the pitch and the average age had risen to roughly 28 years and four months. If this trend carries on at the same rate, by the end of the century most of the players trotting out at Wembley in May will be well into their fifties.

Yet, while the rest of the country is getting to grips with the changes - increasing the provision of nursing facilities, stockpiling Crimplene and churning out more and more hours of nostalgia TV - football has characteristically ignored the evidence and carried on in its time-honoured whippersnapper-worshipping fashion.

Witness the predictable outpourings that greeted Kevin Keegan's resignation. Once again we heard how it was critically important to get the youth structure right and introduce young players into the side earlier. Yet as a strategy for the future this is frankly about as likely to improve things as taking to the streets demanding the return of hand-knitted goalkeeping jerseys. Investing in youth football is a piece of absurd short-termism because, to put it bluntly, in 50 years' time there will not be enough young people left in the country to make up a team, never mind a squad.

Instead of wasting its days on reactive endeavours such as constructing imitations of the Australian and French academies, the FA should go proactive and put all its effort into finding some way to harness the power of the grey wave. Money must be funnelled away from youth football and into the veterans' game for it is surely from here that the national team of the future will be drawn.

Our approach to coaching, too, must be radically altered. Praising Sheringham's display on Saturday, the Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle came over all Jim Morrison observing, "A set of curtains opens in your mind when you are older and you begin to read the game better." This mystical change, rather than speed and stamina, is what we should build our system around. A player of 66 plainly cannot sprint on to a through-ball like a man of 22 but, if he is able to peep through those velvet drapes of perception and see where the ball is going to be in five, 10 or even 15 minutes' time, you can bet he'll be in position to receive it, even if he has to use his free bus pass to get there.

The FA should also be lobbying Fifa for rule changes that will influence the game in favour of our new style of play. Allowing defenders to use golf carts to carry them up to the opposition penalty area for set plays, for instance, or moving kick-off times to more pensioner-friendly hours such as 6.30 in the morning.

Whatever steps Lancaster Gate decides to take, it is obvious we must stop living in the juvenile-fixated past and come to terms with our rapidly balding population. England is entering the Age of the Third Age. Youth is yesterday's thing. The only way for English football to go forward is to look backwards.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Robson missing the storm signals
fields.standfirst: Crazy Gang can push Boro's manager to the edge tonight
fields.trailText: Discontent with Bryan Robson's tenure is growing on Teeside as the big-spending Middlesbrough manager tries to negotiate the potential banana skin of a third round tie against Wimbledon.
fields.body:
Bryan Robson's mood may be defiant, his work ethic unflappable, but the soundbites are starting to become vaguely ridiculous.

"We want to compete with the best in Europe," he said yesterday, referring to the club's new internet site which is launched this afternoon. "This shows the foundations at this club are growing all the time." In reality, the only thing growing on Teesside is discontent.

Goal difference spares Boro a place in the relegation zone and, with games against Arsenal and Manchester United looming large, Robson travels to tonight's Worthington Cup tie at Wimbledon with his tenure as manager hanging from an increasingly slender thread. They may only be First Division kickers these days, but the Crazy Gang could be about to shatter another high-profile Premiership reputation.

"Morale's not great after three successive defeats, but the lads know they can turn it round," said Robson. "We need a change in fortune. I'm not looking too far ahead, but if we beat Wimbledon and then get a good win against Arsenal, the smile will be back on people's faces."

Such optimism offers scant comfort. Boro's latest setback - Saturday's 2-1 defeat at Ipswich - deepened the gloom; the visitors were outclassed and their leading scorer of the last two seasons, the disillusioned Hamilton Ricard, was substituted after 32 minutes. After the game, rumours abounded that Robson had sought out his eternally sympathetic chairman and close friend Steve Gibson to tender his resignation.

"It's absolute rubbish that I offered to hand in my resignation," he insisted. "It has never crossed my mind. And Hamilton does not want to quit - I've cleared the air with him now. The media is full of panic, but I'm not.

"I have nine first-teamers out injured - you cannot lose five top international players if you want to compete in this league. I'm fairly confident that as soon as some of my players return, we will get back on track.

"I've had some fantastic responses in the mail this morning; hundreds of letters of support. Of course there are some disgruntled supporters, but the fans' opinions have turned dramatically round in the last few days. That makes me even more determined to put things right."

But as the manager wades through his paper encouragement, disillusion is making itself felt at the Riverside. Attendances are down by almost 4,000 on last season and there were banks of empty seats at the recent derby with Newcastle.

"Most Boro fans are quite disenchanted at the moment," said Robert Nichols, the editor of the Boro fanzine Fly Me To The Moon. "It was quite telling, going to Ipswich; they're newly promoted, their PA was announcing sell-out crowds, everyone was buoyant and there was a real party atmosphere. Just like it was at Boro a few years ago.

"Somebody at the club has to realise something has got to be done. The fans were chanting 'There's only one Steve Gibson' on Saturday - I suppose people were appealing for the chairman to see sense. We've had relegations in the past, we know the signs. We need some big changes - if not the manager, then the managerial attitude and direction."

The current philosophy saw Boro enter the Premiership but has seen more money than sense thrown at recent problems. Robson has spent £78m on new personnel since taking the reins in 1994. He may have recouped over £44m but, with players' wages of up to £60,000-a-week, a return of two promotions and a highest top-flight finish of ninth place in 1999 hardly represents value for money. The side are crying out for the kind of spirit typified by the manager during his playing days.

"We could understand all the glamourous signings when we were looking to raise the profile, but we've seen so many people come here for the money," says Nichols. "There's no patience any more."

Inevitably, the policy of buying big for instant success has nullified the impact of the club's youth academy. If Robson had a fully fit squad from which to choose, the England under-21 striker Andy Campbell would have a £63,000-a-week Croatian, an out-of-form Colombian, a £4m Cameroonian and £5.5m worth of Brian Deane and Noel Whelan ahead of him in the pecking order.

"After six years under Robson, it's difficult to name one home-grown player to have come through and established himself in the first team," said Nichols. "The academy's up and running, but where's the motivation for a youngster?"

Given that Boro reached two cup finals the last time they were relegated, in 1997, the suggestion that their top scorer Alen Boksic may have been rested at Ipswich with tonight's tie in mind will hardly have Teesiders sleeping easier.

"It's not a must-win game, but the Worthington Cup is always the best route into Europe," added Robson. "If you offered me a slightly worse finishing position in the league than last year and the Worthington Cup, I'd take it.

"My own resolve is still strong. We've had bad league runs before, although they're usually after Christmas. We're just having our poor spell earlier this year - I hope."

Robson at Boro

1994 Signs three-year contract as Middlesbrough player-manager in May.

1995 Wins First Division title in first season. Signs the Brazilian midfielder Juninho for £4.75m.

1996 In April signs three-year contract extension. Buys Emerson and Ravanelli for £11m.

1997 Boro have three points deducted for no-show at Blackburn. Beaten by Leicester in Coca-Cola Cup final replay. Relegated from Premiership. Lose FA Cup final to Chelsea.

1998 Signs Paul Gascoigne for £3.75m. Beaten by Chelsea in Coca-Cola Cup final. Promoted back to Premiership. In October Boro rise to third. Signs a five-year contract extension.

1999 Finish ninth in the Premiership despite slump in the new year. Lose to Tranmere and Wrexham in the cups.

2000 End season in 12th. Six players bought in the summer but slip to 17th in league without home win since March.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Accused Collymore will cite racist abuse

fields.headline: Accused Collymore will cite racist abuse
fields.trailText: Bradford's Stan Collymore plans to cite racist abuse if he is charged with inciting crowd trouble against Leeds at Valley Parade on Sunday.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore will cite racist abuse from Leeds United supporters in his defence if the Bradford City striker is charged with inciting crowd trouble during Sunday's west Yorkshire derby at Valley Parade.

Collymore could be facing his second Football Association misconduct charge of the season after the referee Stephen Lodge yesterday confirmed he had filed an official complaint about the striker's behaviour in his match report.

Several Leeds fans spilled over the perimeter fence when Collymore goaded them after scoring the opening goal in a 1-1 draw.

Lodge will accuse Collymore of inciting the visiting supporters with his "over-zealous celebrations" but senior figures at Valley Parade responded yesterday by claiming the 29-year-old was reacting to racial taunts and had not broken any rules.

Although Lodge took no action at the time, the Barnsley official said yesterday: "I will be reporting the incident in my account to the FA.

"We are advised to do that in cases of over-zealous goal celebrations and this one did cause a few fans to spill on to the pitch."

Collymore escaped immediate action because he stayed within the playing area and guidelines for referees stipulate yellow cards only when players leave the pitch.

He still has an FA charge pending after being accused of stamping on Everton's Paul Gascoigne during his last Premiership match for Leicester City.

fields.headline: Here comes Johnny reggae
fields.standfirst:
John Holt/ RPCO
Hammersmith Apollo, London
***
fields.trailText:
John Holt/ RPCO
Hammersmith Apollo, London
***
fields.body:
When John Holt was at his early-70s peak and based in London, his albums were invariably sweetened with orchestral arrangements. So teaming one of reggae's golden voices with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra was not such an incongruous notion. More than a quarter of a century later, traditional reggae has long been usurped by its truculent step-children, ragga and rap. Yet there is always hope for music of life-enhancing optimism and at the Hammersmith Apollo even the standing areas were full.

As soon as Holt emerges, crooning Lobo's I'd Love You to Want Me in his delicious tenor, with the 20-piece orchestra behind him at full-pelt and Lloyd Parkes's We The People Band providing rhythmic foil, you wonder what that muffled, rumbling sound is. It is the well-behaved, seated crowd, hands aloft, swaying from left to right and back again, and singing along with unbridled gusto.

Tiny, bushy-bearded John Holt - 53, dressed in formal eveningwear, greying dreadlocks down to his buttocks - grins like a fool. As well he might. "Everyone feeling irie?" he asks. Indeed, everyone is and matrons scream as if it were 1974 and Holt was having his only hit with Kris Kristofferson's Help Me Make it Through the Night. When he performs the song, it might as well be. Holt prowls the stage with his microphone, pointing, smiling and letting the crowd sing the choruses.

The orchestra seem to have a ball, adding a sheen of lushness to Holt's already rich tones, while Parkes's team, who had already played their own set and backed Freddie McGregor, carried on insouciantly, never missing a beat.

For the final half hour, Holt kept clear of the orchestra, reducing them to a spectating role. This worked fine when reclaiming Holt's own The Tide is High from the anaemic hands of Blondie and Wear you to the Ball, as covered by UB40, but the endless re-checking of whether we remained "irie" and a succession of a cappella fragments hardly helped correct the impression of a man who had lost concentration, run out of ideas and squandered precious orchestral resources.

fields.headline: RSNO/ Lazarev
fields.standfirst:
Glasgow Royal Concert Hall
****
fields.trailText:
Glasgow Royal Concert Hall
****
fields.body:
If there were works that caused Shostakovich embarrassment in his mature years, his Second and Third symphonies must rank fairly high among them. He tried to talk both his son Maxim and Rostropovich out of conducting or recording them, and while they chose to ignore his pleas, thankfully, plenty of conductors have heeded them.

The two symphonies remain Shostakovich's changeling works - gigantic political gaffes in an otherwise impressive symphonic legacy, largely ignored in both the concert hall and the recording studio.

So why, then, was the opening concert - comprising the first three symphonies - in the Royal Scottish National Orchestra's Shostakovich series rewarded with such an enthusiastic response? This is, in fact, easier to understand than the embarrassment they caused their composer.

The agitprop texts which conclude both the Second and Third symphonies raise hardly more than a smile today, although, ironically, Shostakovich himself apparently found them hilarious. The subtitles To October and The First of May belie the enormous complexity and innovation of both works - they are not merely rabble-rousing pieces.

These apparently political symphonies essentially perform the same delicate balancing-act as many of Shostakovich's most popular works: striving for creative freedom within political constraints. Hearing them now is exhilarating, particularly when, as with the RSNO, they are played with a sense of danger and excitement. Their theatrical impact is undeniable: they go out with a bang, not, as the Fourth symphony does, with a whimper.

Lazarev and the RNSO were on less vigorous form in the First symphony, which was decidedly patchy; there was some first-rate solo playing - particularly from the principal oboe and cello - but also a number of rough edges.

The Second and Third symphonies proved better suited to the mood of the evening. Lazarev's dynamism and sense of theatre prevailed to magnificent effect. The fine RSNO chorus coped well with the unfamiliar Russian texts

Over-exposure to a handful of works has slanted our view of Shostakovich. It may be that more frequent performances of works he didn't want us to hear might serve him better than he could have imagined. A chance to hear Shostakovich as experimental modernist once in a while makes a refreshing change. It also reminds us that for sheer imaginative vitality he is hard to beat.

fields.headline: Indian percussion king's African fantasy
fields.standfirst:
Trilok Gurtu
Union Chapel, London
****
fields.trailText:
Trilok Gurtu
Union Chapel, London
****
fields.body:
The Indian percussionist Trilok Gurtu always gives his shows a governing idea which puts his mix of hard-swinging jazz drumming, dizzying tabla rhythms, electronic effects and jabbering Indo-scat in a context beyond virtuosic. Last time, the theme was Indian temple-dance forms, this time it is African-Asian crossover. On Sunday night, Gurtu's band featured three Indians and two Africans, with the London-based stars Najma Aktar and Nitin Sawhney in guest slots.

Though the references were different, the single-set gig was a triumph for the same reasons Gurtu's shows usually are - the immense variety of textures and polyrhythms he can generate on his own, but more fundamentally for the group sound he inspires, which can make just about any instrumentation sound like a big percussion section. But there was a crucial extra ingredient - the powerful singing and hypnotic presence of Sabine Kabongo, the Zairean singer.

Kabongo's gliding high-register lines, reverberating low notes and Gurtu-echoing chatters and exclamatory sounds combined with the Cameroon bass-player Hilaire Penda's dancing counter-melodies kept the African element of the programme not just strong, but seamlessly blended with the more melodically oblique and rhythmically ambiguous Asian core. The guest appearances were glitzy and diverting, but inevitably rather perfunctory set against the focused power of the African Fantasy programme.

The delicacy and clarity of Najma's remarkable voice was arresting in the quiet opener to a ballad composed jointly by Gurtu and his classical singer mother, Shoba, but the song ran out of steam. Sawhney came on to play a luxurious and unexpected Spanish feature for acoustic guitar, then developed an expressive exchange of vocalised percussion sounds in duet with Gurtu.

But it was the group pieces, ranging from richly coloured tapestries of temple music (using Gurtu's unique palette of bells, gongs, distantly mysterious booms, running-water effects and tiptoeing footfalls), to Weather Report-like orchestral funk and staccato Asian-fusion themes reminiscent of the leader's projects with John McLaughlin, that brought the crowd to its feet for encores.

Gurtu's easy cohabitation with the music of his roots as well as American jazz gives his accompaniments an exhilaratingly bumpy energy, the meticulous precision of Indian percussion patterns at high speeds constantly nudged and disrupted by explosive cymbal sounds and whiplash offbeats. There was hardly a duff melody in nearly two hours of music, with Kabongo's voice investing already capriciously inventive material with sinewy twists and dives.

World music without a cliche in earshot.

fields.headline: Hindle Wakes
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
If cinema - as Michael Powell claimed - was the folk art of the 20th century, then the unearthed Hindle Wakes marks the point when the present recedes irretrievably into the past. Shot in 1927 from a 1912 stage play by Stanley Houghton, this tale of class intrigue at a Lancashire mill town plays like a remnant from a bygone age, a spectral reel of history excavated from the National Film and Television archive. The haunting live accompaniment from the Sheffield-based soundtrack band In the Nursery only adds to the air of strangeness.

Controversial in its day, the plot offers standard melodrama with a proto-feminist twist. During the town's annual Wakes Week holiday (a time when "the bond slaves of cotton know the ecstasy of freedom"), the working-class Fanny (Estelle Brody) darts off on an illicit vacation with the mill-owner's playboy son (John Stuart). Cue burlesque eye-rolling from her scandalised mother and a rash of intertitles. The wedding is all arranged. The trouble is that Fanny (a liberated woman before her time) won't play ball.

From our 21st-century perspective, however, the narrative is one of the least compelling aspects of Hindle Wakes. What resonates is the extraneous detail. The director, Maurice Elvey, shot the film on location in Lancashire and Blackpool, and his style is fluid and airy, free from the shackles that accompanied early talkies. On one occasion he props his camera precariously at the front of a plunging big-dipper. On another he trails John Stuart down the helter-skelter, eyeing the back of his Brylcreemed head.

This style of documentary reportage reaches its giddy peak with an extended shot from high above Blackpool's Tower Ballroom. Below, a sea of bodies surges back and forth in a tidal dance-step - hundreds, maybe thousands, of them. As the camera pins these ghostly revellers in its gaze, In the Nursery's chiming synthesiser score matches their rhythmic ebb and flow. Halfway through the scene, a mirrorball to the right of the screen is set in motion and grey lozenges of light drift across the cinema's darkened walls. For a moment, it is as though the apparitions have waltzed right out of the frame, as if they were visitors called up during a seance.

Screens at Chapter, Cardiff (029-2030 4400), on Sunday, then tours to Bristol, Manchester, Sheffield and Nottingham.

fields.headline: Endellion read between Berg's lines
fields.standfirst:
Endellion Quartet
Britten Festival, Snape Maltings
****
fields.trailText:
Endellion Quartet
Britten Festival, Snape Maltings
****
fields.body:
The Britten Festival has become a neat autumn appendix to the annual Aldeburgh festival in June. Each year it focuses upon a different aspect of the achievement of the festival's only begetter, the theme this year being Britten and serialism. Its centrepiece was a staging of The Turn of the Screw by the students of the Britten-Pears School; other recitals were designed to point up Britten's relationship with some of the composers who explored the boundaries of tonality and new techniques of organisation in the first half of the 20th century.

The most important of those figures in his development was Alban Berg, whose music he got to know through his teacher, Frank Bridge. The influence is unmistakable in the astonishingly assured Quartettino, composed when Britten was just 17, which began the Endellion Quartet's recital on Saturday. It is arguably the most forward-looking of all his early works and the Endellion made the most of its sinewy lyricism.

However, Berg's own music provided the most intriguing element of the programme. One of the most surprising musicological discoveries of recent times was made in 1977, when the American scholar George Perle came upon a score of Berg's string-quartet masterpiece, the Lyric Suite. It contained the composer's own detailed annotations of the work's secret programme.

Each of the six movements had been given a specific connotation, meshing the composer's own world with that of Hanna Fuchs-Robettin, a woman with whom he had been having a long, though apparently platonic, affair.

To even the most innocent listener, the explicit quotations from Wagner's Tristan and Zemlinsky's Lyric Symphony in the quartet might suggest something significantly personal lurking behind the notes. Yet there is no doubt that for public consumption Berg intended that the work should stand on its own. The tightly organised structure and explosively passionate invention are wonderfully satisfying in their own right. We don't need to know precisely the personal significance of every phrase.

But when a text, Baudelaire's De Profundis, was discovered in another copy of the score, carefully written into the last movement of the work, that was a different matter. Berg apparently envisaged this extraordinary, anguished finale, a largo desolato, as a setting of the poem, embedded in the fabric of the strings.

Since Perle's revelation, performances of the Lyric Suite with its vocal finale have been surprisingly rare. The Endellion's, with the soprano Gweneth-Ann Jeffers, was only the second in Britain, and the first for more than a decade. The sudden appearance of the voice in the last movement does alter the trajectory of the work in a remarkable way.

After the rigours of the previous movements, their technical challenges, confidently met here by the Endellion, the soprano takes the work on to a different plane and opens up new vistas. The sound itself is remarkable, with the voice nearly always doubled by an instrument, usually the viola, as if the texture had mysteriously thickened. It may not be the way one always wants to hear the Lyric Suite, but it does offer a whole new perspective on one of the greatest of all 20th-century quartets, and on Berg's intentions as composer.

webTitle: What's the best way to get a new job?

fields.headline: What's the best way to get a new job?
fields.trailText: Should I leave the one I'm in - or stick it out and search while I work.
fields.body:
The problem

I have a very busy, sometimes stressful job that I often don't like. This is probably due to the fact that I don't like anyone I work with and I feel underpaid and used. I also feel uneasy there - the environment and ethos are not "me".

My friend and I have decided for a change and are moving to Leeds. She has found herself a job already, but cannot live there until I have found one, but I just can't find the time or energy to throw myself into finding a new job.

I keep wondering, should I just hand in my notice so I can search properly or continue in the busy job taking double the amount of time, trying to snatch sneaky days off for interviews, with the whole process taking painfully long. Am I being rash and stupid if I hand my notice in first without having a job to go to?

The solution

I think you know what you should do, but need some reassurance that you are doing the right thing. You don't like your job, don't like your colleagues, you're underpaid, starting to make mistakes at work, don't like the work environment and spend four hours every day commuting. No wonder you are stressed, tired and lack the energy to job-hunt!

You are in an impossible situation and you know it - you want to and need to get out, but the demands of your job mean that you can't. As you yourself say, if you packed the job in you could search properly and be less stressed and tired. Is "this rash and stupid"? Under the circumstances, it sounds rather sensible to me. Packing your job in would allow you the space and time to sit back and re-evaluate your career and want you want, as well as allow you to apply for jobs and go to interviews without the whole process taking a 'painfully long time'.

The only things holding you back are financial considerations and concern about how this will look to future employers. On the second point, it is possible that some employers will wonder why you packed the job in, or favour someone who is currently employed. But this can easily be explained by a short statement in your covering letter about your need to relocate to be with your partner. One or two employers might still be wary, but most will simply accept it.

As for the finance, maybe you could get a part-time job somewhere to tide you over. Or see this time off as an investment into your health, career and future. Put like that, even if it takes a few months to get yourself sorted, it would seem a wise investment.

fields.bodyText: The problem I have a very busy, sometimes stressful job that I often don't like. This is probably due to the fact that I don't like anyone I work with and I feel underpaid and used. I also feel uneasy there - the environment and ethos are not "me". My friend and I have decided for a change and are moving to Leeds. She has found herself a job already, but cannot live there until I have found one, but I just can't find the time or energy to throw myself into finding a new job. I keep wondering, should I just hand in my notice so I can search properly or continue in the busy job taking double the amount of time, trying to snatch sneaky days off for interviews, with the whole process taking painfully long. Am I being rash and stupid if I hand my notice in first without having a job to go to? The solution I think you know what you should do, but need some reassurance that you are doing the right thing. You don't like your job, don't like your colleagues, you're underpaid, starting to make mistakes at work, don't like the work environment and spend four hours every day commuting. No wonder you are stressed, tired and lack the energy to job-hunt! You are in an impossible situation and you know it - you want to and need to get out, but the demands of your job mean that you can't. As you yourself say, if you packed the job in you could search properly and be less stressed and tired. Is "this rash and stupid"? Under the circumstances, it sounds rather sensible to me. Packing your job in would allow you the space and time to sit back and re-evaluate your career and want you want, as well as allow you to apply for jobs and go to interviews without the whole process taking a 'painfully long time'. The only things holding you back are financial considerations and concern about how this will look to future employers. On the second point, it is possible that some employers will wonder why you packed the job in, or favour someone who is currently employed. But this can easily be explained by a short statement in your covering letter about your need to relocate to be with your partner. One or two employers might still be wary, but most will simply accept it. As for the finance, maybe you could get a part-time job somewhere to tide you over. fields.headline: Banks agree to end laundering
fields.standfirst:
Eleven sign up to global guidelines

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Eleven of the largest international banks yesterday committed themselves to a set of global guidelines to eliminate money laundering, effectively drawing up a new barrier against financial crime.
fields.body:
Eleven of the largest international banks yesterday committed themselves to a set of global guidelines to eliminate money laundering, effectively drawing up a new barrier against financial crime.

The agreement involves the private banking arms of Barclays, HSBC, ABN Amro, Banco Santander, Chase Manhattan, Citibank, Crédit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, JP Morgan, Société Générale and UBS. Other banks are being urged to join the guidelines, named the Wolfsberg Principles, which were drawn up with the help of Transparency International and an OECD expert.

"This should be seen as a clear recognition by the private commercial banks of their responsibility in the fight against serious international crime," said Hans-Peter Bauer, chief risk officer of UBS.

Some banks have introduced similar internal rules in recent years, but the new guidelines adopt the highest European standards and apply them globally, including in offshore centres. However, there is no provision for sanctions or checks on enforcement.

The voluntary code establishes clear procedures for staff to identify customers and beneficial owners for the private banking arms of the banks, wherever they are doing business. It also advocates monitoring and the banks are pledging to either reject a suspicious client or report them to the authorities.

In effect the principles would act as a barrier against taking money from corrupt government officials or organised crime by depriving them of anonymity or the ability to hide behind proxy account holders and foundations.

"Heightened security will be brought to bear where relationships emanate from countries whose money laundering regimes are not advanced or where there are recognised high risks relating to crime and corruption," said Chris Duncan, wealth management risk director at Barclays.

Lawyers acting for the Nigerian government say Barclays, and several other British-based banks, held accounts linked to the late Nigerian dictator, Sani Abacha. Mr Duncan said he had not received any information so far although internal checks were conducted.

"Barclays has not been approached to date by the serious fraud office or the financial services authority," he said.

Several of the banks admitted that they would lose some business and new, potentially embarrassing, money laundering cases might come to light as a result.

Mark Pieth, head of the OECD's anti-bribery group, said the initiative filled a hole left by government regulators. "We've had great difficulties getting regulators to coordinate. They've never really touched the issues of know your customer or due diligence, and harmonised," he said.

The banks reacted cautiously to the suggestion of enforced regulation. "These principles reflect decent and adequate standards; we neither expect nor wish to see the standards being raised higher," said Reinout van Lennep, head of ABN Amro private banking.
